doore anon labour ſpedily gon prieſt curſed chanons bidding vpon fire anon ſet thing blew fire buſied full faſt chanon croſlet caſt pouder whereof made either chalke earth glaſſe ſomewhat el worth flie blind prieſt bad hie theſe cole couchen aboue croſſelet token thee loue qd chanon thine owne honds two shall werke thing ſhall grant mercy qd ye prieſt full glad couched cole chanon bad buſie fiendly wretch falſe chanon ye foule fende fetch boſome take bechen cole full ſubtily made hole therein put ſiluer limaile vnce ſtopped without faile hole waxe keep limaile underſtandeth falſe gin made made thing ſhall tell hereafter brought er came begile thought ſo went twin till nere vndon could blin dulleth ſpeke falſhede faine would wreke wiſt ſo variaunt bideth taketh hede ſirs god loue toke cole ſpake aboue honde bare prively while prieſt couched beſily cole together told er chanon ſaied friend ye doen amis couched ought ſone ſhall amend qd let meddle therewith pitty st gile ye right hot ſee well ye ſwete haue cloth wipe away wete prieſt wiped hace chanon took cole ſhrew face laied abouen vpon midward croſlet blew well afterward till cole began faſt bren yeue u drink qd chanon ſwithe ſhall well undertake sit let v mery make chanons bechen cole brent limaile hole croſlet anon fell adown ſo muſt need reaſoun sen ſo euen aboue couched wiſt prieſt nothing ala demed cole iliche good ſlight nothing underſtood alkamiſter ſaw time reiſeth ſir prieſt qd ſtondeth wote well ingot none goth walketh forth bring chalke ſtone woll make ſame ſhappe ingot may happe bring eke bolle pan full water ye ſhall ſee beſines ſhall hap preue yet ye ſhall haue misbeleue ne wrong conceit abſence woll preſence go come chamber doore ſhortly ſain opened ſhet went forth weie forth hem caried keie comen ayen withouten delay ſhould tary long day toke chalke ſhope wiſe yngot ſhall deuiſe ſay tooke ſleue teine ſiluer iuell mote cheue iuſt vnce weight taketh heed curſed ſleight ſhop yngot length brede teine withouten drede ſlily prieſt eſpide ſleue gan hide fire tooke vp matere yngnot put mery chere water veſſel caſt liſt bad prieſt faſt loke wt put thine hond grope thou ſhalt finde ſiluer hope diuel hell ſhould el shauing ſiluer ſiluer parde put hond tooke vp teine ſiluer fine glad euery vaine prieſt ſaw ſo god bleſſing mother alſo hallowes haue ye ſir chanon saied prieſt maliſon ye vouchſafe teachen noble craft ſubtilte woll euer may qd chanon yet woll make aſſaie ſecond time ye mow take hede expert nede another day aſſay mine abſence diſcipline craftie ſcience let take another ounce qd tho quicke ſiluer withouten word mo doen therewith haue doen er ſiluer prieſt beſieth doen chanon curſed man commanded faſt blewe fire come effect deſire chanon right meane ready prieſt eft begile countenance hond bare hollow ſticke take kepe beware thende ounce ſiluer limaile put cole ſtopped waxe wele keepen limaile euery dele while prieſt buſineſſe chanon ſticke gan dreſſe anon pouder caſt erſt deuill skin torne pray god falſhede euer falſe word dede ſticke aboue croſſelet ordained falſe iet ſtirreth cole till relent gan waxe fire euery man foole wote well mote nede hole yede croſſelet haſtily fell prieſt ſuppoſed nothing well buſied faſt wonder fain suppoſing nought trouth ſoth ſain ſo glad cannot expreſſe maner mirth gladneſſe chanon profered eft ſone body good ye qd chanon anon tho pore craftie thou ſhalt find warne thee yet behinde coper within ſaied ye ſir qd prieſt trow el go buie ſome ſwithe good ſir go forth thy way hithe went way coper came chanon hond name coper wayed ounce ſimple tonge pronounce miniſter wit doubleneſſe chanon root curſedneſſe ſemde frendly hem yt knew nought fendly werke thought werieth tell falſeneſſe natheles yet woll expreſſe intent men may beware thereby none cauſe truely put ounce coper croſſelet fire ſwithe hath ſet caſt pouder made ye prieſt blow working ſtoupe low erſt na yape right liſt prieſt made ape afterward ingot caſt pan put laſt water put hond ſleue ye hond heard tell ſiluer teine ſlily tooke curſed heine vnwitting prieſt falſe craft pannes botome hath laft water rombleth fro wonder priuily tooke vp alſo coper teine knowing prieſt hid hent breſt ſpake thus ſaid game stoupeth adown god ye blame helpeth whilere put hond loketh prieſt tooke vp ſiluer teine anon ſaid chanon let u gon theſe three teines han wrouȝt ſome goldſmith wete ought faith nold hood ſiluer fine good ſwithe well proued ſhall vnto goldſmith theſe teines three went put aſſaie fire hammer might man ſaie nay ought ſotted prieſt gladder neuer birde gladder ayenſt day ne nightingale ayenſt ceaſon may neuer none liſt better ſing ne lady luſtier carolling ſpeake loue womanhede ne knight armes doen hardy dede ſtonden grace lady dere prieſt craft lere chanon thus ſpake ſaid loue god u deid may deſerue vnto ſhall receit coſt telleth lady qd chanon dere warne well ſaue frere england man make force qd ſir god ſake ſhall pay tell pray wi qd full deare ſay sir one worde ye liſt haue ye ſhall pay fourtie pound ſo god ſaue nere friendſhip ye er ye ſhoulden pay iwis prieſt ſum fortie pound anon noble fet told hem euerichon chanon ilke receit worching fraud deceit sir prieſt ſaid keep haue loo craft would kept cloos loue keepeth ſecre men know ſubtilte god men would haue ſo great enuie becauſe philoſophie ſhould dead none way god forbid qd prieſt ye ſay yet leuer ſpend good haue el waxe wood ye ſhould fallen ſuch miſchefe good haue ye right good prefe qd ye chanon farewell graunt mercie went way ye prieſt neuer ſeie yt day prieſt ſhould maken aſſay ſuch time would receit farewell nold lo thus beyaped beguiled thus maketh introduction bring folke deſtruction conſidereth ſirs eſtate betwixt men gold debate ferforth vnneths none multiplying blindeth ſo many one good faith trow greateſt cauſe ſuch ſcarſite theſe philoſophers ſpeaken ſo miſtily craft yt men cannot come thereby wit men haue adaies may wel chattre iangle ye iaies tearmes ſet luſt paine purpoſe ſhull neuer attaine man may lightly learne haue ought multiplie bring good nought lo ſuch lucre luſty game man mirth woll turne grame emptien alſo great heauy purſes maken folke purchaſe curſes hem han alſo good ylent fie ſhame yt han brent ala cannot flie fire hete ye vſen rede ye lete leaſt ye leſen bet neuer late neuer thriue long date though yt ye prolle aye ye ſhall neuer find ye ben bold bayard blind blondereth forth perill caſteth none bold renne ayenſt ſtone goe beſide way faren ye multiplien ſay eyen cannot ſeene aright looketh yt mind lacke ſight though ye looke neuer ſo broad ſtare ye ſhall win mite chaffare waſt yt ye may repe renne withdraw fire leaſt faſt brenne medleth art meane ye done thrift gone full cleane right ſwithe woll tellen yt ye philoſophers ſain matere lo thus ſaith arnolde new toun roſarie maketh mentioun ſaith right thus withouten lie may man mercurie mortifie brother knowledging lo firſt ſaid thing philoſophers father hermes ſaith dragon doutles ne dieth ſlaine brother ſaine dragon mercury none vnderſtood yt brimſtone brother sol luna ydraw therefore ſaid take heed ſaw let man buſie art ſeech entention ſpeech philoſophers vnderſtond doe leaud man ſcience cunning qd ſecre ſecres parde alſo diſciple plato time ſaid maiſter booke senior woll beare witneſſe demaund ſoothfaſtneſſe tell name priuy ſtone plato anſwerd vnto anone take ſtone titanos men name qd magnetia ye ſame said plato ye ſir thus ignotum per ignotius magnetia good ſir pray water made ſay element foure qd plato tell roche good ſir qd tho water nay nay qd plato certaine nill philoſophers yſworne eachone ſhould diſcouer vnto none ne booke write manere vnto chriſt ſo lefe dere woll diſcouered liketh deitie man enſpire eke defend liketh lo end conclude thus ſens yt god heuen ne philoſophers nemen man ſhall come unto ſtone rede beſt let gone ſo maketh god aduerſary werch thing contrary vnto certes neuer ſhall thriue though yt multiply tearme liue point ended tale god ſend euery true man bote bale ¶the doctor phyſicks prologue yeoman tale ended falſe chanon ſo bad hoſt gan ſay truly certaine prieſt beguiled ſooth ſaine wened philoſopher till right gold left cofer ſoothly prieſt yape curſed chanon put hood ape paſſe ouer sir doctor phyſicke yet pray tell v tale ſome honeſt matere ſhall done ye woll said doctor tale began anone good men qd herkeneth euerichone ¶the doctor phyſicks tale virginius ſlayeth onely daughter rather ſhe ſhall defiled letcherous judge appius telleth v titus liuius knight cleaped virginius fulfilled honour worthineſſe ſtrong friend great richeſſe daughter wife neuer mo life faire maid excellent beautee abouen euery wight man may ſee nature hath ſoueraigne dilligence formed ſo great excellence though ſhe would ſay lo nature thus forme paint creature liſt counterfete pigmalion though alway forge bete graue paint dare well ſaine apelles xeuxſis ſhould werch vaine graue paint forge bete preſumed counterfete fourmer principall hath made vicar generall fourme paint earthly creature right liſt thing cure vnder moone yt may wane waxe werke nothing woll axe lord fully accord made worſhip lord mine creature colour figure thus ſeemeth nature would ſay maid age xii yere tway nature hath ſuch delite right ſhe paint lilly white rody roſe right ſuch painture painted hath noble creature ere ſhe borne vpon lims free al bright ſuch colour ſhould bee phebus died treſſes grete like ſtreames burned hete excellent beaute thouſand fold vertuous ſhe ne lacketh condition praiſe diſcretion well body ghoſt chaſt ſhe ſhe floured virginite humility abſtinence attemperaunce patience meaſure eke bering aray diſcreet ſhe anſwering alway tho ſhe wiſe pallas dare ſaine facond eke full womanly plaine counterfeited termes ſhe ſeeme wiſe degree ſpake word leſſe sowning vertue gentleneſſe shamefaſt ſhe maiden ſhamefaſtneſſe conſtant hert euer buſineſſe driue ſluggardie bacchus mouth maiſtrie wine youth done venus encrece men fire woll caſten oyle grece owne vertue vnconſtrained hath full oft ſicke yfained ſhe would flie companie likely treaten follie feaſts reuels daunces occaſions daliaunces thing maken child bee ſoone ripe bold men may ſee full perillons hath yore ſoon may ſhe learne lore boldneſſe ſhe wife ye maiſtreſſes old life lord doughters han gouernaunce ne taketh word diſpleaſaunce think ye ſet gouernings lord doughters onely two thing either han kept honeſty either ye han fall freelty knowen well ynough old daunce conne forſake fully miſchaunce euermore therefore chriſts ſake keepeth well tho ye vndertake theefe veneſon hath forlaft likerouſneſſe theeues craft keepe forreſt beſt man keepeth hem well ye woll ye looketh well vice ye aſſent leaſt ye damned euill entent ſo doth traytour certaine taketh keepe ſhall ſaine treaſon ſoueraigne peſtilence wight betrayeth innocence ye father eke ye mother alſo though ye han child one mo charge ſufferaunce while gouernaunce beth ware yt enſample liuing either negligence chaſtiſing ne periſh dare well ſay done ye ſhall full ſore abay vnder ſheepheard ſoft negligent wolfe hath many ſheep lambe rent sufficeth one enſample mote turne ayen matere maid tell tale expreſſe kept ſelue ſhe needed maiſtreſſe liuing maiden might rede booke euery good worke dede longeth maid vertuous ſo prudent ſo bounteous ſprong euery ſide beauty bounty wide thorow ye lond preiſed echone loued vertue ſaue enuy alone ſorry men wele glad ſorrow vnhele doctour maketh deſcriptioun maid went day toun toward temple mother dere young maiden manere iuſtice toun gouernour regioun ſo befell iuſtice eyen caſt vpon maid auiſing full faſt ſhe came foreby iudge ſtood anon heart chaunged mood caught beauty maid himſelfe full priuely ſaid maid ſhall mine man anon fiend heart ran taught ſuddainly wt ſleight maid purpoſe win might certes force ne meed thought able ſpeed ſhe ſtrong friend eke ſhe confirmed ſuch ſoueraigne beaute well wiſt might neuer win make body ſin great deliberatioun ſent client toun knew full ſubtill full bold iudge client tale hath told ſecret wiſe made enſure ſhould tell vnto creature ſhould leſe hede aſſented curſed rede glad iudge made good chere yaue gift precious dere ſhapen conſpiracie fro point point letcherie performed ſhould full ſubtilly ye ſhullen heare openly home goth client yt hight claudius falſe iudge hight appius name fable knowen hiſtoriall thing notable ſentence ſooth dout falſe iudge ſay goth faſt haſten delight may ſo befell ſoone day falſe iudge telleth u ſtorie wont ſat conſiſtorie yaue doomes vpon ſundry caas falſe client came forth full great paas ſaid lord doth right vpon pitous bill plaine vpon virginius woll ſay thus woll proue find good witneſſe ſooth bill woll expreſſe iudge anſwerd abſence may yeue definite ſentence let doe call woll gladly thou ſhalt haue right wrong virginius came wete ye iudges right anon rad curſed bill ſentence ye ſhall heare lord appius ſo deare sheweth poore ſeruaunt claudius knight called virginius ayenſt law ayenſt equite holdeth expreſſe ayenſt ſeruant yt thral right mine hous ſtolen night while ſhe full yong woll preue witneſſe lord ſo ye greue doughter ſo ſay wherefore lord iuſtice pray yeeld thrall lo ſentence bill virginius gan upon client behold haſtily ere tale told would haue defended ſhuld knight witneſſe many trew wight falſe ſaid aduerſarie curſed iudge would lenger tary word virginius yaue iudgment ſaid thus deme anon client ſeruaunt haue thou ſhalt lenger thine houſe ſaue go bring forth put ward client ſhal haue thrall thus award worthy knight virginius aſſent iudge appius muſt force deare doughter yeuen vnto iudge letchery liuen goth home ſet hall let anon deare doughter call face dead aſhen cold vpon humble face gan behold father pity ſticking hert would purpoſe conuert doughter qd virginia thy name ben two way either death ſhame thou muſt ſuffer ala yt borne neuer thou deſeruedeſt whereforne dien ſword knife oh dere doughter comfort life haue foſtred vp ſuch pleſance thou neuer remembrance doughter yt art laſt wo life laſt ioy alſo iemmme chaſtitie patience take thou thy death ſentence loue hate thou muſt dead pitous hond mote ſmite thine head ala euer appius thee ſey thus hath falſely iudged thee dey told caſe ye han heard needeth tell mercy dere father qd maid word armes laid necke ſhe wont teares braſt eyen two ſaid good father ſhall die grace remedie certes deare doughter mine qd yeue leaue father mine qd ſhe death complaine little ſpace parde iepte yaue doughter grace complaine ere ſlough ala god wot nothing treſpas ſhe ran father firſt ſee welcome great ſolemnitee word ſhe fell aſwoune anone ſwouning gone riſeth vp father ſaid bleſſed god ſhall die maid yeue death ere haue ſhame doth child wil god name word ſhe praieth full oft ſwerd ſhould ſmite ſoft word aſwoune doune ſhe fell father ſorrowfull heart fell head ſmote top hent iudge yaue preſent ſat doome conſiſtorie iudge ſaw ſaith ſtorie bad take hong alſo faſt right anone people thraſt ſaue knight routh pity knowen iudges iniquity people anon ſuſpect thing manner client challenging aſſent appius wiſt well letcherous unto appius gone keſten priſon right anone whereas ſlew himſelfe claudius ſeruant vnto appius demed honged vpon tree virginius great pitee prayed exiled el certes beguiled remnaunt honged leſſe conſented curſedneſſe may men ſee ſin hath merite beware man wot god wol ſmite degree ne manner wiſe worme conſcience woll ariſe wicked life though ſo priuie man wote god whether leaud man lered ſoone may affered therefore rede counſaile take forſake ſinne ſinne forſake ¶the word hoſt hoſt gan ſweare wood harrow qd nailes blood falſe theefe curſed iuſtice ſhamefull death heart may deuiſe come iuſtice aduocas algate ſilly maiden ſlaine ala ala deare abought ſhe beautee wherefore ſay men may ſee yefts fortune nature cauſe death many creature beauty death dare well ſaine ala ſo pitouſly ſhe ſlaine hereof woll proceed men haue full oft harme prow truly truly mine owne maiſter dere ernefull tale natheleſſe paſſe ouer force pray god ſaue thy gentle corce thy vrinals thy iordanes thine ypocras eke thy galianes euery boxe full letuarie god bleſſe hem lady ſaint marie mote thee thou art proper man ylike prelate ſaint runian saue cannot ſpeake well terme well wot thou doſt mine hert yerne haue almoſt ycaught cardiacle corpus domini haue triacle el draught moiſt cornie ale heare anon another merry tale heart loſt pity maid thou belamy thou iohn pardoner ſaid tell v ſome merry tale iape right anon ſhall done qd ſaint runion firſt qd ale ſtake woll drinke bite cake right anone theſe gentles gan crie nay let tell v ribaudrie tell v ſome morall thing yt mow lere wit woll gladly graunt qd ywis ye cup ile think ſome honeſt thing while drink ¶the pardoner prologue lordings qd chirch preche paine mee haue hauteine ſpeche ring round doth bell rote tell teme alway one euer radix omnium malorum eſt cupiditas firſt prono • nce fro whence come bils ſhew ſome liege lord ſeale patent ſhew firſt body warrent man ſo bold prieſt ne clerke diſturbe chriſts holy werke tell forth tale buls pope cardinales patriarkes biſhops ſhew latine ſpeake word ſauer predication ſtere men deuotion ſhew forth long chriſtall ſtones ycrammed full clout bone relickes wene echone haue laton ſhoder bone holy iewes ſhepe good men ſay take word kepe bone waſhen well cow calfe ſheepe oxe ſwell worme hath eaten hem ſtong take water well waſh tong hole anon furthermore pockes ſcabs euery ſore shall ſhepe hole well drinketh draught take keepe yt tell good man beaſts oweth woll euery day ere cocke croweth faſting drinke well draught thilke holy iew elder taught beaſts ſtore ſhall multiplie ſirs alſo healeth jealouſie though man fall jealous rage let make water potage never ſhall wife miſtriſt though ſooth defaut wiſt ſhe taken prieſts two three mittaine eke ye may ſee hand woll put mittaine ſhall multiplying graine hath ſowen wheat otes offer good pen grotes men woman thing warne wight church hath done ſinne horrible dare ſhame ſhriuen woman ſhe yong old hath made husbond cokewold folke ſhull haue power ne grace offer relickes place ſo findeth ſuch blame commeth offer god name aſſoyle authoritie bull graunted vnto gaude haue every yere hundred marke ſithen pardonere ſtond like clerke pulpet leud people doune yſet preach ſo ye haue lered tell hundred yapes paine ſtretch forth necke eaſt weſt vpon people becke doth dove ſitting upon berne honds tongue gone ſo yerue joy ſee buſineſſe avarice ſuch curſedneſſe preaching maken hem free yeuen pen namely vnto mine entent winne nothing correction ſinne recke neuer ben buried though ſoule gone black buried certes many predication commeth oft time evill entention pleaſaunce folke flaterie auaunced hipocriſie ſome vaineglory ſome hate dare wayes debate woll ſting hem tongue ſmert preaching ſo ſhall aſtert ben defamed falſely hath treſpaſſed bretherne though tell proper name men ſhall well know ſame ſignes circumſtaunces thus quite folke yt doth v diſpleaſaunces thus put venum hew holineſſe ſeemen holy trew ſhortly mine entent woll deuiſe preach nothing couetiſe therefore teme yet ever radix omnium malorum eſt cupiditas thus preach ayenſt y• ſame vice uſe avarice though ſelf guilty ſinne yet maken folke twinne auarice ſore hem repent principal entent preach nothing couetiſe matere ought ynough ſuffiſe tell hem enſamples many one old ſtories done long time agone leaud people aye louen tale old thing well report hold trowen ye while may prech win gold ſiluer tech woll liue pouert wilfully nay nay thought neuer truly woll preach beg ſundry londs woll doe labour mine honds ne make basket liue thereby becauſe woll beg idelly woll none apoſtles counterfete woll haue money mault cheeſe whete yeuen pooreſt page pooreſt widdow village though child ſhould ſterue famine nay woll drinke licour wine haue jolly wench every toun hearkeneth lordings concluſioun liking ſhould tell tale haue drunken draught corny ale god hope ſhall tell thing ſhall reaſon liking though ſelfe full vicious man morall tale yet tell wont preach win hold peace tale woll begin ¶the pardoner tale company riotours conſpire kill death killeth one another flanders whilom companie yong folke haunted follie haſard riot ſtewes tauernes whereas harp lute geternes dauncen plaien dice night day eaten alſo ouer might may done deuill ſacrifice within devil temple curſed wiſe ſuperfluitie abhominable othes ſo great ſo damnable griſly heare hem ſweare bleſſed lord body teare hem thought ye iews rent ynough hem others ſinne lough right anon comen tombleſteres fetis ſmale yong foiteres singer harpes baud waferers verely deuils officer kindle blow fire letcherie annexed vnto glotonie holy writ take witneſſe letchery wine dronkenneſſe lo dronken loth vnkindly lay daughter two vnwittingly dronke niſt wrought therefore ſore repenten ought herodes ſo woll ſtories ſeche may ye learne enſample teche wine replete feaſt right owne table yaue heſt ſleen iohan baptiſt full guiltleſſe seneke ſaith eke good word doubtleſſe ſaith difference find betwixt man mind man dronkelew woodneſſe fallen ſhrew perſeuereth lenger doth dronkenneſſe glotenie full curſedneſſe cauſe firſt confuſion originall damnation til chriſt bouȝt v blood lo dere ſhortly ſain bought firſt curſed villanie corrupt world throgh glotenie adam fornfather wife alſo fro paradice labour wo driven vice drede while adam faſted rede paradiſe hee eat fruit defended tree anon caſt wo paine glotenie thee well ought v plaine oh wiſt man many malady followeth exceſſe glotenies would meaſurable diete ſitting table ala ſhort throat tender mouth maketh eaſt weſt north south earth aire water men ſwinke getten glutton deinte meat drinke matter paul wel canſt thou treat meat vnto wombe wombe eke vnto meat shall god deſtroien paule ſaith ala foule thing faith ſay word fouler dede men ſo drinketh white rede throte maketh priue thilke curſed ſuperfluite apoſtle ſaieth weeping full pitouſly walken many told haue ſay weeping pitous voice enemy chriſts croice end death womb god belly wombe ſtinking cod fulfilled dong corruptioun either end thee foule ſoun great coſt labour find theſe cooke lord ſtamp ſtrein grind turne ſubſtance accident fulfill thy likerous talent hard bone knocken mary caſt away may go gullet ſoft ſote ſpicerie leaf barke rote shall ſauce ymade delite maken hem newer appetite certes haunteth ſuch delices dead while liveth vice lecherous thing wine dronkennes full ſtriving wretchednes oh dronken man disfigured thy face soure thy breath foul art thou enbrace thy dronken noſe ſouneth y• ſoun tho thou ſaideſt aie sampſon sampſoun yet god wot sampſon dronk never wine thou falleſt ſticked ſwine thy tongue loſt thine honeſt cure drunkenneſſe ſepulture man wit diſcretion drinke hath domination counſaile keepe drede kepe fro white fro rede namely fro white wine lepe ſell fiſhſtreet chepe wine spaine creepeth ſubtilly ſo wine growing faſt riſeth ſuch fumoſitee man hath dronk draught three weneth home chepe spaine right toune lepe nought rochell ne burdeaux toun woll ſay sampſoun sampſoun herkeneth lordings word pray ſoveraigne act dare ſay victory old teſtament god yt omnipotent doen abſtinence prayere looketh bible ye mow lere looketh attila great conquerour died ſleepe ſhame diſhonour bleeding aye noſe drunkenneſſe captaine ſhould liue ſoberneſſe auiſe right well commaunded unto lamuel samuell lamuel ſay redeth bible find expreſly wine yeuing hem haue juſtice may well ſuffice ſpoke glotonie woll defend haſardrie haſard mother leſings deceit curſed forſwearings blaſpheme chriſt manſlauȝter waſt alſo cattel time mo repreue contrary honour holden common haſardour ever higher eſtate holden deſolate prince ſhall uſe haſardrie gouernaunce pollicie common opinion hold leſſe reputation stillebon hold wiſe embaſſadour ſent corinth full great honour fro calidone maken hem alliaunce came happed chaunce greateſt lond playing haſard hem yfond ſoone might ſtale home ayen countre ſaied woll leſe name nill take ſo great defame allie none haſardours sendeth wiſer embaſſadours trouth leuer die ſhould haſardours alie ye ſo glorious honour shall alie haſardours ne treatie wiſe philoſopher thus ſaied looke eke king demetrius king parthes ye booke ſaieth v sent paire dice gold ſcorne vſed haſardrie biforne held glory renoun value reputatioun lord might find manner play honeſt ynough driue day away wol ſpeake othes falſe great word two bookes entreat great ſwearing thing abhominable falſe ſwearing yet reprouable high god forbad ſwearing witneſſe mathew ſpeciall ſwearing ſaieth holy ieremie thou ſhalt ſweare ſooth thine othes lie ſweare dome eke rightwyſnes idle ſwearing curſedneſſe behold ſee firſt table high god heſtes ben honourable ſecond heſt take name idleneſſe amis lo rather forbiddeth ſuch ſwearing homicide curſed thing ſay thus order ſtondeth knoweth yt heſts vnderſtondeth ſecond heſt god furthermore woll thee tell plat vengeaunce ſhall part fro hous othes outrageous god precious heart nailes bloud chriſt hailes seuen chaunce thine fiue three god armes thou falſly play dagger ſhall thine heart ygo fruit commeth thilke bone two ſwearing ire falſeneſſe homicide loue chriſt v dide leaueth othes great ſmale ſhall tell meruellous tale theſe roitours three tell long erſt prime rong bell ſet hem tauerne drinke ſat heard bell clinke corſe carried graue one hem gan call knaue goe bette qd aske redily corſe paſſeth forth looke thou report name wele sir qd needeth neuer dele told ere ye came two hour parde old fellow ſuddainly ſlaine night drunke ſat bench vpright came priuy theefe men clepen death countrey people ſ • aeth ſpeare ſmote heart wo went way withouten word mo hath thouſand ſlaine peſtilence maiſter ere ye come preſence thinketh neceſſarie beware ſuch aduerſarie bethe redy meten euermore thus taught dame ſay ſaint mary ſaied tauernere child ſayeth ſooth hath yere hen ouer mile ſlaine great village man woman child page trowe habitation auiſed great wiſdome ere man diſhonour ye god armes qd riotour ſuch perill meet ſhall ſeeche ſtile eke ſtreet make auow god digne bone herkeneth fellowes three one let ech v hold vp hond ech v become others brother woll ſlea falſe traitour death ſhall ſlaine ſo many ſlaeth god dignity ere night togider han theſe three trouths plight liue die ech though owne brother vp ſtert dronken rage forth gone toward village tauerner hath ſpoken many griſ • othe ha • ſwore chriſtes bleſſed body rent death ſhall dead may hent han gone fully mile right would haue troden ouer ſtile old poore man hem met old man full meekely hem gret ſaied lordings god ye ſee proudeſt theſe riotours three anſwerd ayen churle hard grace art thou forwrapped ſaue thy face liueſt thou ſo long ſo great age old man gan looken viſage ſaied thus cannot find man though walked iude neither city ne village would chaunge youth mine age therefore mote haue mine age ſtill long time ſhall god ne death ala • ill haue life thus walke like reſtleſſe caitife ye ground mother gate knocke ſtaffe erliche late ſay ſtill leue mother let lo vaniſh fleſh blood skin ala ſhall bone reſt mother would chaunge cheſt chamber long time hath ye heren clout wrap yet ſhe woll doen y• grace full pale welked face ſirs ne courteſie ſpeaken vnto old man villanie treſpace word either dede holy writ may ſelfe well rede ayenſt old man hore vpon hede ye ſhould ariſe therefore rede ne doeth old man harme ye would man age ye may ſo long abide god whether ye go ride mote go thider go nay old churle god thou ſhalt ſo saied theſe haſardours anon thou parteſt ſo lightly ſaint iohn thou ſpakeſt riȝt thilke traitor death country friend ſlaeth trouth thou art eſpie tell el thou ſhalt die god holy sacrament ſoothly thou art aſſent ſlea v yong folke thou falſe thefe ſirs ſo lefe find death tourne vp crooked way groue left fay vnder tree woll abide ne boſt nill nothing hide se ye yonder oke right ye ſhall find god ſaue bought ayen mankind amend thus ſaied old man eueriche theſe riotours ran til came ye tree found floreines gold fine • oined round well nigh ſeuen buſhels hem thought lenger death ſought ech hem ſo glad ſight floreins ſo faire bright doune ſit precious hord yongeſt hem ſpake firſt word brother qd take keepe ſay wit great though bord play treaſure hath fortune v yeuen mirth iollity life liuen lightly come ſo woll ſpend heie god precious hart wend day yt ſhould ſo faire grace might gold caried fro place home houſe el vnto well wote yt gold high felicite truly day may men would ſay wer theeues ſtrong owne treaſure doen v hong treaſure muſt yearied night wiſely ſlily might wherefore rede draw cut among v let u ſee cut woll fall hath ſhorteſt cut hart blith shall renne toune full ſwith bring v bread drinke full priuely two u ſhall keepe full ſubtilly treaſure well woll tarie night woll treaſure carie one aſſent v liſt beſt one hem brought graſſe feſt bad hem draw look wold fall fell yongeſt hem forth toward toune went anone alſo ſoone gone one hem ſpake vnto thou woſt well thou art ſworne brother thy profite woll tell thee right anone thou woſt well fellow gone gold yt full great plentee ſhall departed among v three natheleſſe ſhape ſo departed among v two doen friendly turne thee anſwerd yt might woll well gold two ſhould doe might ſo shall counſaile ſaid firſt ſhrew ſhall tell thee word woll doen bring well graunt qd dout trouth woll thee bewrain qd thou woſt well twain twain v ſhall ſtronger one looke ſet anone ariſe thogh thou wouldeſt play ſhall riuen ſides tway while yt thou ſtrugleſt game thy dagger looke thou ye ſame ſhall good departed owne dere friend betwixt thee may luſts fulfill play vice right owne thus accorded ben theſe ſhrews tway ſlea third ye heard ſay yongeſt yt went ye toune full often hart rolled doune beauty theſe floreines faire bright lord qd ſo might haue treaſure ſelfe alone ni man liueth vnder trone god ſhould liue ſo merry laſt fiend enemy put thought ſhuld poiſon bey might ſlaen felows twey fiend fond ſuch liuing leue ſorrow bring vtterly entent ſlaen hem neuer repent forth goth lenger would tary toune vnto potecary praied would ſell poyſon might rat quell eke polkat hawe ſaied capon yſlaw ſaid would wreken yt might vermine deſtroied hem night poticarie anſwerd thou ſhalt haue thing wiſly god ſoule ſaue world ni creature eateth drinketh confecture mountenaunce corne ne ſhall life anone forlete ye ſterue ſhall leſſe thou woldeſt gone apace mile poiſon ſo hard ſo violent turſed man hath hond hent poiſon boxe ſwithe ran next ſtreet unto man borrowed large bottle three two poiſon poured third kept cleane drinke night ſhope ſwinke carying gold place riotour ſorry grace hath fild great bottle three fellowes ayen repaired hee needeth thereof ſermon right caſt death right ſo han ſlain yt anone doen ſpake yt one let u ſit drinke make v mery afterward wolne body bury happed hem per caas one took bottle ye poiſon dronke yaue fellow drinke alſo anon ſteruen two certes ſuppoſe auicenne wrote neuer chanon ne fenne wonder ſorrows empoyſoning theſe wretch two ending thus ended theſe homicide two eke falſe empoyſoner alſo curſed ſinne full curſedneſſe traitour homicide wickedneſſe glotenie luxurie haſardie thou blaſphemour chriſt villanie othes great vſage pride ala mankind may betide thy creatour yt thee wrought precious blood thee bought thou art ſo falſe ſo vnkind ala good men god foryeue treſpas ware fro ſinne auarice mine holy pardon may wariſh ye offer noble ſtarlings el ſiluer ſpoones brooch ring boweth head vnder holy bull commeth vp ye wiues offreth wol name enter roll anone bliſſe heauen ſhull ye gone aſſoile mine high powere ye offren cleane clere ye borne lo ſirs thus preach ieſu chriſt ſoules leach graunt pardon receiue beſt woll deceiue ſirs one word foryate tale haue relickes pardon male faire man man englond yeuen pope hond woll deuotion offren haue mine abſolution commeth forth anon kneeleth adoun ye may haue part pardoun el taketh pardon ye wend new freſh euery tounes end ye offren alway new new noble pen good trew great honour euerich ye may haue ſufficient pardonere aſſoile countrey ye ride auentures may betide perauenture may fall one two doune hors breke neck atwo look ſuertie fellowſhip yfall may aſſoile laſſe ſoule ſhall fro thy body paſſe rede hoſt ſhall firſt beginne moſt enuelopt ſinne commeth forth ſir hoſt offer firſt anone thou ſhalt kiſſe relikes euerichone ye grote vnbokell anon thy purſe nay nay qd haue chriſts curſe let qd ſhall ſo theiche thou wouldeſt make kiſſe thine old brech ſweare relike ſaint though thy foundement depaint croſſe ſaint helain fond would thine coilons mine hond inſteed relikes ſanctuarie let cut hem woll help thee hem carie ſhull ſhrined hog tord pardoner anſwered word wroth would word ſay qd hoſt woll lenger play thee ne none angrie man right anon worthy knight began ſaw people lough right ynough sir pardoner merry glad chere ye ſir hoſt ſo dere pray ye kiſſe pardonere pardoner pray thee draw thee nere let u lough play anon kiſſed ride forth way ¶the shipmans prologue friendes ſaid hoſt ſo dere liketh iohn ye pardonere hath vnbokeled well male hath u told right thriftie tale touching men miſgouernaunce pray god yeue full good chaunce ye han heard theſe riotours three gentle mariner heartely pray thee tell u good tale right anon ſhall doen god ſaint iohn said mariner well euer right anon tale thus began ¶the shipmans tale marchant deniſe cozened wife monke called dan john argument taken bochas novel marchant whilome dwelled ſaint deniſe rich men held wife excellent beaute compinable reuelous ſhe wiſe thing yt cauſeth diſpence worth chere reuerence men hem doen feaſts daunces ſalutations countenaunces paſſeth doeth ſhaddow wall wo pay mote ſely husbond algate mote pay mote v clothe eke array owne worſhip richely array dauncen jolily may perauenture el luſt ſuch ſpece endure thinketh waſt yloſt mote another pay coſt lend v gold perillous noble marchant held noble hous day great repaire largeſſe wife faire wonder herkeneth tale among guells great imale monke faire man bold trow thirtie winter old euer one drawing place yong monke ſo faire face acquainted ſo well good man sithens firſt knowledge began houſe familiar poſſible friend much good man eke monke began two yborne one village monke claimed couſinage againe ſaied nay glad thereof foule day heart great pleaſaunce thus ben knit eterne alliaunce eke hem gan enſure brotherhed while life may dure free dan iohn namely diſpence hous full diligence doe pleaſaunce eke great coſtage foryate yeue leaſt page houſe degree yaue lord ſithen meinee yt came ſome maner honeſt thing glad comming foule faine ſunne vp riſeth hereof ſuffiſeth ſo befell marchaunt day shope make ready array toward toune bruges fare buy portion ware hath ſent paris anon meſſenger praied hath dan ihon ſhould come denis plain wife day twain bruges went wiſe noble monke deuiſe hath abbot liſt licence becauſe man high prudence eke officer ride ſeene graunges berne wide vnto ſaint denis commeth anon ſo welcome lord dan iohn dere couſin full courteſie brought jubbe malueſie eke another full fine vernage volatily aye vſage thus let hem eat drinke play marchant monke day tway third day marchaunt vp riſeth need ſadly aviſeth vp counting houſe goth reckon himſelfe well may thilke yere ſtood diſpended good encreaſed none bookes bagges many one laieth afore counter bord full rich treaſure hord full faſt counter dore ſhet eke nolde man ſhould let account meane time thus ſate till paſſed prime dan iohn riſen morrow alſo garden walked fro hath thing ſaied full courteſ • good wife come walking priuely garden walked ſoft ſalueth ſhe hath doen full oft maiden child came companie luſt ſhe may gouerne gie yet vnder yerd maid dere couſin mine dan iohn ſhe ſaid aileth ſo rathe riſe nece qd ought ynough ſuffiſe fiue houres ſleepen night old palled wight theſe old wedded men yt lie dare forme ſitteth weary hare al forſtraught hound great ſmale deere nece looke ye ſo pale trowen certes good man hath laboured ſith night began need reſten haſtely word lough full merely owne thought woxe fall red faire wife gan ſhake hed ſaied thus ye god wote qd ſhe nay couſin mine ſtonds ſo god yave ſoule life ye realme fraunce wife leſſe luſt hath ſory play may ſingen ala welaway borne wight qd ſhe dare tell ſtont wherefore think world wend el ſelfe ſoone make end full drede eke care monk began vpon wife ſtare ſaied ala nay nece god forbede ye ſorrow drede fordoe ſelfe telleth greefe perauenture may miſcheefe counſaile helpe therefore telleth annoy ſhall ſecre porthoſe make oth neuer life lefe ne loth ne ſhall counſaile bewray ſame ayen qd ſhe ſay god porthoſe ſweare though men would peeces teare ne ſhall neuer goe hell bewray word thing ye tell couſenage ne alliaunce verely loue affiaunce thus ſworne hereupon kiſt ilke hem told hem liſt couſin qd ſhe ſpace none namely place would tell legend life ſuffred haue ſith wife mine husbond though coſin nay qd monke god martin ni couſin vnto leafe hongeth ye tree clepe ſo ſaint denis fraunce haue cauſe acquaintaunce haue loued ſpecially abouen woman ſikerly ſweare profeſſion telleth greefe leaſt come adoun haſteth goth way anon dere loue qd ſhe dan iohn full lefe counſaile hide mote may lenger abide husbond worſt man euer ſith world began ſithen wife ſit tellen wight priuite neither bed ne none place god ſhild ſhould tell grace wife ne ſhould ſay husbond honour vnderſtond saue vnto thus much tell ſhall helpe god nought worth degree value flie yet greueth moſt nigardie well ye wot woman naturally deſiren thing ſixe well woulden husbonds ſhould hardy wiſe rich thereto free buxome wife freſh bed ilke lord v bled honour ſelfe array ſunday next comming mote need pay hundred frankes el lorne yet leuer vnborne done ſlaunder villanie mine husbond eke might eſpie nere loſt therefore prey lene ſumme el mote dey dan iohn ſay lene hundred frank parde woll faile thanks ye liſt doe pray certain day woll pay wt pleaſaunce ſeruice may done right ye liſt deuiſe god take vengeaunce foule euer genilion fraunce gentle monk anſwerd manere truly mine owne lady dere haue qd ſo great touth ſwere plight trouth husbond flanders fare woll deliuer care woll bring hundred frankes caught ye flankes embraced hard kiſſed oft goth way qd ſtill ſoft let u dine ſoone euer ye may kalender prime ye day goth beth true ſhall el god forbid good ſir ſaid ſhe forth ſhe goth iolly pie bad cooke yt ſhould hem hie men might dine yt anone vp husbond wife gone knocked counter dore boldely qui eſt la qd peter qd ſhe long woll ye faſt long time woll ye recken caſt ſums bookes thing diuell haue part ſuch reckoning ye haue ynough qd ſhe god ſond come doun day let bag ſtond ne ye aſhamed dan iohn shall faſting long day gon let v go heare maſſe go dine wife qd man little canſt thou diuine curious buſineſſe haue u chapman ſo god ſaue lord called ſaint iue scarſly among twenty twelue ſhall thriue continually laſting vnto age may well make chere good viſage driue forth world may keepe ſtate priuite till dead el play pilgrimage gone way therefore haue great neceſſite vpon queint world aduiſe euermore mote ſtand drede hap fortune chapmanhede flanders woll gone morrow day come ayene ſone euer may dere wife thee beſeke euery wight buxom meke keepe good curiouſe honeſtly gouerne well houſe thou haſt ynough euery maner wiſe thrifty huſwife may ſuffice thee lacketh none array ne vitaile ſiluer thy purſe thou maieſt faile yt word counter dore ſhette goth lenger would lette haſtily maſſe iſaide ſpedily table ilaide dinner faſt hem ſpedde richly chapman monke fedde dinner dan iohn ſoberly chapman tooke apert priuily ſaid thus couſin ſtondeth ſo well ſee bruges ye woll go god ſaint auſten ſpede gide pray couſin wiſely ride gouerne well alſo diete temperatly namely hete betwixt u two nedeth ſtrange fare farewell couſin god ſhilde fro care thing day night lie power might ye woll command wiſe ſhall done right ye woll deuiſe thing ye go may wold faine pray lene hundred frankes weke twey certaine beaſts yt mote need bey ſtore therewith place god helpe ſo would ſhall faile ſurely day thouſand frankes mile way let thing ſecret pray yet night theſe beaſts mote bey fare wele mine owne couſin dere grant mercie coſt chere noble marchant gentilly anon anſwerd ſaid couſin dan ihon likerly ſmall requeſt gold leſt onely gold chaffare liſt god ſhild ye ſpare one thing ye know well inough chapman money plough may haue creaunce haue name goodleſſe ſhame pay ayen lieth eſe might faine would pleſe hundreth frankes fet forth anon priuily tooke hem dan iohn wight world wiſt lone sauing marchant dan iohn alone drinke ſpeak rome pley till dan iohn rideth abbey morow came forth rid marchant flanders ward prentes brought hem auant til came bruges wel merely goeth marchant well beſily nedes buieth creaunſeth neither playeth dice ne daunceth marchant ſhortly tell led life let dwell ſonday next yt marchant gon ſaint denis comen dan iohn croune berde freſh new iſhaue houſe na ſo litle knaue ne wight el full faine yt lord dan iohn comen againe ſhortly point gon faire wife accordeth dan iohn theſe c frankes ſhould night haue armes bolt upright accord parformed dede mirth night beſie life lede til day yt dan iohn yede way manie farewell good day none hem ne wight toun dan iohn ſuſpectioun forth rideth home abbey liſte ſey marchant ended faire ſaint denis gan repaire wife maketh feeſt chere telleth chaffare ſo dere need muſt make cheueſaunce bonden reconyſaunce pay twentie thouſand ſhildes anon marchant paris gon borrow certaine friend certaine frankes ſome lad comen toun cherite great affectioun vnto dan iohn firſt goth pley nought borrow money wete ſee welfare tellen chaffare friend mette infere dan iohn maketh feaſt mercy chere tolde ayen full ſpecially bought full well graciouſly thonked god hole marchandiſe saue muſt manner wiſe maken cheueſaunce beſt ſhould ioy reſt dan iohn anſwered certes right fane ye heale commen home againe rich bliſſe twenty thouſand ſhildes ſhuld ye miſſe ye ſo kindly day lent gold may thonke god ſaint iame natheles •• k unto dame wife home ſame gold againe vpon bench ſhe wote wel certaine certaine token tell leave may longer dwell abbot woll toun anon company mote gon grete well dame mine neece ſwete farewell deare couſin till mete marchant full ware wiſe creaunced hath eke paide paris certaine lombardes redy honds ſum gold gate hem bond home goth mery popingay well knew ſtood ſuch aray need muſt win viage thouſand frankes coſtage wife full ready mete yate ſhe wont old uſage algate night mirth ſette rich clerely dette day marchant gan enbrace wife new kiſſed face goeth made wonder tough qd ſhe god ye ynough wantonly ayen ſhe plaide till laſt marchant thus ſaid god qd little worthe wife although lothe wote ye god geſſe ye haue made maner ſtrangeneſſe betwixt couſin dan iohn ye ſhould warned gon hundred frankes paide redy token held evill apaide ſpake cheueſaunce ſeemed ſo countenaunce natheles god heavenly king thought aske nothing pray thee wife ne ſo tell alway er fro thee go dettour hath mine abſence ypaide thee leſt thy negligence might aske thing hath paide wife aferde ne affraide boldly ſhe ſaid anon mary defie falſe monke dan iohn keepe token neuer dele tooke certaine gold wote wele euill dome monkes ſnoute god wote wend without doute yeue becauſe doen therwith mine honour prow coſinage eke belle chere hath full often time ſith ſee ſtonte ſuch disioynte woll anſwere ſhortly pointe ye haue mo ſlacke dettours woll pay well redely fro day day ſo faile wife ſcore taile ſhall pay ſoone ever may truth mine aray waſte beſtowed every dele beſtowed ſo wele honour god ſake ſay wrothe let u laugh play ye ſhall joly bodie wedde god nill pay bedde foryeue mine owne ſpouſe dere turneth hitherward make better chere marchant ſaw ther remedy chide foly sith thing may amended wife ſaid foryeue thee thy life ſo large keep bet good yeue thee charge thus endeth tale god u ſend taling inough unto life ende ¶here followeth wordes hoſte well ſaid corpus domini qd hoſte long mote thou ſaile ye coſte thou gentle maiſter gentle marinere god giue ye monk thouſand laſt quad yere ha fellowes beware ſuch iape monke put marchants hode ape wife eke ſaint auſtin draweth monkes inne paſſe let u ſeeke aboute ſhall tell firſt route another tale word ſaid curteouſly maid lady prioreſſe leaue wiſt ſhuld greue wolden deme ye tellen ſhold tale next ſo ye wold wol ye vouchſafe lady dere gladly qd ſhe ſaid manere ¶the prioreſſes prologue domine dominus noſter quam admirable eſt nomen tuum univerſa terra lord lord thy name merueilous wide world iſprad qd ſhe onely thy laud precious parformed men dignite mouth child thy bounte parfourmed breeſt ſucking sometime ſhewen thine heriyng wherefore laude beſt may thee white lilly floure thee bare maide alway tell ſtorie wol labour nought may encreſe honour ſhe ſelfe honour rote bountie next ſonne ſoules bote mother maiden maiden mother fre buſhe vnbrent brenn moyſes ſight rauiſhedeſt downe fro deite thin humblenes ye goſt thee alight whoſe vertue thine hert pight conceiued father ſapience helpe tell thy reuerence lady thy bountie thy magnificence thy vertue thy great humilite may tongue expreſſe ſcience ſometime lady er men pray thee thou goeſt thy benignite getteſt v ye light thy prayere giden v vnto thy ſonne ſo dere conning weake blisfull queen declare thy high worthineſſe ne may weight ſuſtene childe twelue moneth old leſſe vnnethes word expreſſe right ſo fare therfore pray gideth ſong ſhall ſay ¶the prioreſſes tale miracle chriſtians child murthered jewes aſie great citie amonges chriſten folke certain iewrie suſtened lorde countrie foule vſury lucre villany hatefull chriſt company ſtrete men might ride wend free open euery end little ſchole chriſten folke ſtood farther end ther child hepe comen chriſten blood learned ſchole yere yere manere doctrine men vſen ſay ſingen rede ſmale child done childhede amonges theſe child widow ſon litle clergion vii yeres age day day ſchole eke alſo ſey image chriſtes mother vſage taught kneele adown ſay aue maria goth way thus hath widow little child itauȝt bleſſed lady chriſtes mother dere worſhip aye foryate naught ſely childe would day ſone lere aye remember matere saint nicholas ſtondeth euer preſence ſo yong chriſt reuerence litle childe litle booke lerning ſate ſchole primere alma redemptoris mater herd ſing child lered antiph • nere durſt drewe aye nere nere harkened wordes note till firſt verſe couth al rote nouȝt wiſt latin ſay ſo yong tender age day felow han pray expound ſong language tellen ſong vſage praid conſtre declare full often time vpon knee bare felow elder anſwerd thus ſong haue herd ſay made bleſſed lady fre f • lewe eke prey help ſuccour dey expoune mater lerne ſong ſmall grammer ſong imade reuerence chriſtes mother ſaid innocent ce •• e woll done diligence conne er chriſtenme • ſe went though primer ſhall ſhent ſhould beten thriſe houre woll conne ladie honoure felow taught homeward priuely fro day day till couth rote ſung well boldely fro 〈◊〉 word according note twiſe day paſſed throte 〈…〉 homeward went chriſtes mother ſet entent haue ſaid throughout iewrie little child came fro ful merely would ſing crie alina redemptoris mater euer mo ſweetnes hath hert perſed ſo chriſtes mother pray cannot ſtint ſinging way firſt foe serpent sathanas hath iewes hert waſpes neſt vp ſwale ſaid chrake people ala thing honeſt ſuch boy ſhall walke le • te diſpite ſing ſuch ſentence againſt lawes reuerence thenceforth iewes han conſpired innocent world chaſe homicide 〈◊〉 han hired aley priuie place child gan foreby pa • e curſed iew hent held faſt cut throte pit caſt ſay wardrope threw iewes purged intraile curſed folke heraudes new may euil entent auaile murder woll certes woll faile namely ther ye honor god ſhall ſpred blood crieth curſed deed martyr founded virginitie maiſt thou ſing folowing euer white lambe celeſtiall qd ſhe great euangeliſt ſaint iohn pathmos wrote ſaieth yt gon lambe ſing ſong new neuer fleſhly woman ne knew poore widow awaiteth al night little childe came nought ſoone day light face pale drede buſy thought hath ſchole el ſought till finally ſhe gan ſo farre aſpie laſt ſene iewrie mother pitie breaſt encloſed goth ſhe halfe minde euery place ſhe hath ſuppoſed likelihood child finde euer chriſtes mother good kinde cried laſt thus ſhe wrought among curſed iewes ſhe ſought freneth ſhe praieth pitouſly euery iew dwelleth thilke place tellen child went ſay nay ieſu grace yaue thought within little ſpace place ſonne ſhe cryde caſt pit beſide great god performeſt thy laude mo • th innocencie loe thy might iemme chaſtitie emerande eke martirdome rubie bright throte icorne lay vpright alma redemptoris gan ſing loude place gan ring chriſten folk yt ſtreet went comen wonder thing haſteley prouoſt ſent came anon without tarying herieth chriſt heauen king eke mother honour mankind iews let binde child pitous lamentation vp taken ſinging ſong alway honour great proceſſion carien next abbey mother ſowning bere lay vnneath might people new rachell bringen fro bere turment ſhamefull deth like one prouoſt doth theſe iews ſterue murder wiſte anone nolde ſuch curſedneſſe obſerue euill ſhall haue euil wol deſerue therefore wild horſe hem draw afterward hong hem law vpon bere aye lieth innocent beforn cheef aulter while maſſe laſt abbot couen hem ſpedde burie al faſt holy water caſt yet ſpake yt child ſprint holy water ſang alma redemptoris mater abbot yt holy man monkes el ought yong childe couer began ſaid dere child hailſe thee vertue holy trinitie tell thy cauſe ſing sithens thy throte cut ſeeming throte cut vnto necke bone said child way kind ſhould haue deyd ye long time agone ieſus chriſt ye bookes find woll glory laſt minde worſhip mother dere yet may ſing alma loude clere wel mercie chriſts mother ſwete loued alway conning life ſhould forlete ſhe came bad ſing antem verily dying ye han herde ſong thought ſhe laid graine vpon tong wherefore ſing ſing mote certaine honour blisfull maiden free till fro tongue taken graine thus ſhe ſaid little child woll fetch thee yt graine fro thy tong itake agaſte woll thee forſake holy monke abbot mene tong caught toke away yt graine yaue vp ghoſt full ſoftly abbot wonder ſeyne ſalt teres trikled reyne groffe fell flat ground ſtill lay ibound couent lay eke vpon pauement weeping herying chriſtes mother dere riſen forth ben went tooke away martir fro bere tonthe marble ſtones clere encloſen litle body ſwete god leue v mete yong hew lincolne ſlaine alſo curſed iewes notable little ago pray v ſinfull folke vnſtable mercie god merciable u great mercy multiply reuerence mother mary ¶here followeth wordes hoſte chaucer ſaid miracle euery man ſober wonder ſee till hoſte yapen began erſte looked vpon ſaid thus man art thou qd thou lookeſt thou wouldeſt finde hare euer vpon ground ſee thee ſtare approch neere looke vp merely ware ſirs let man haue place waſte ſhapen well popet armes enbrace woman ſmall faire face ſemeth eluiſh countenance vnto wight doth daliance say ſomewhat ſithens folke han ſaid tell v tale mirth anon hoſte qd ne euil apaide tale certes none rime lerned yore agone ye good qd ſhullen deinte thing thinketh thy chere ¶here followeth rime sir thopas northern tale outlandiſh knight purpoſely uttered chaucer differing rime ſtile tale though himſelf author onely reporter reſt liſteneth lordinges good entent woll tell verament mirth ſolas knight faire gent battaile turnament name ſir thopas iborne ferre countre flaunders beyonde ſee popering place father man full fre lord countre god grace sir thopas doughty ſwaine white face paine maine lippes reed roſe rudde like ſcarlet graine tell good certaine ſeemely noſe haire berde like ſafroun girdle raught adowne ſhoone cordewane bruges hoſen broun robe chekelatoun coſt many iane couth hunt wilde dere ride hauking riuere grey goſhauke honde thereto good archere wraſtling none pere ram ſhould ſtonde full many maide bright boure mourne paramoure whan hem bet ſleepe chaſte lechoure ſweet bramble floure beareth red hipe ſo befell vpon day forſoth tell may sir thopas would ride wroth vpon ſtede gray honde launce gay long ſword ſide pricketh faire foreſt therein many wild beeſt ye bucke hare pricked north eaſte tellen almeſte betide ſory care ſpringen herbes great ſmall licores setual many clowe gelofer nutmiges put ale whether new ſtale lie cofer bird ſingen nay sperhauke popingaie ioy throſtell eke made laie wood doue vpon ſpraie ſung full loude clere sir thopas fill loue longing heard throſtill ſing pricketh wood faire ſtede pricking ſweete men might wring ſides blood sir thopas eke ſo wearie pricking ſoft graas fiers corage downe laied place maken ſtede ſome ſolace gaue good forage oh ſaint mary benedicite aileth loue blinde ſo ſore dreamed night parde elfe queene ſhall lemman ſleep vnder gore elfe queene woll loue • wi world woman make towne woman forſake elfe quene take dale eke doune ſaddle • e clombe anone pricked ouer ſtile ſtone elfe queene ſpie till ſo long ridden gone found priuie wone countrey fairie wherein ſought north south oft ſpied mouth many forreſt wilde countre na none farre rid gone neither wife ne childe till came great giaunt name called ſir oliphaunt perillous man deede ſwore child termagaunt pricke haunt anon ſlea thy ſteede queene fairie harpe pipe ſimphonie within place boure childe ſaied al ſo mote thee morow woll meten thee whan haue mine armoure yet hope par faie thou ſhalt launce gaie abien thy mawe thy hawberke ſhall perce may fully prime day thou ſhalt ſlawe sir thopas droue abacke full faſt gyaunt ſtones caſt fell ſtaffe ſling faire eſcaped ſir thopace god grace faire bearing yet liſtneth lordings tale merier nightingale woll ye roune ſir thopas ſides ſmale pricking ouer doune dale comen ayen toune merry men commanded maken game gle needes muſt fight giant head thre paramour iolite one ſhone full bright doe come ſaid miniſtrales ieſtors tellen v tale anon mine arming romaunces royal pope cardinal eke loue longing fet firſt ſwete wine mede eke mazeline royal ſpicerie ginger bread full fine licores eke comine suger trie next white lere cloth lake fine clere breche eke ſhert next ſ • ert haketon ouer habergion percing hert ouer fine hauber • e iwrought iews werke full ſtrong plate ouer cote armoure white lilie floure would debate ſhield gold ſo red therein bore head carbocle ſide ſwore ale bread gyant ſhould dead betide ſo betide iambeux cure buly ſword ſheth iuorie helmet laton bright ſaddle ruel bone bridle sunne ſhone moone light ſpeare fine sypres biddeth warre nothing peace head full ſharpe iground ſteede dapple gray hee goeth aumble way full ſoftly round londe lo lord mine fit ye woll tellen woll fond hold mouth charite knight alſo ladie fre herkeneth ſpell battaile cheualrie lady love drerie anon woll tell men ſpeken romaunces pris hornechild ipotis beuis ſir gie ſir libeaux blandamoure ſir thopas beareth floure riall cheualrie good ſteede beſtrode forth upon way glode ſparke bronde vpon creſt bare tour therein ſtricked lilie flour god ſhilde cors fro ſhonde knight auntrous nolde ſlepen none houſe liggen hood bright helme wanger fed deſtrer hearbes fine good himſelfe dronke water well knight ſir perſiuell worthy wede ¶the word hoſte god dignite q hoſte thou makeſt wearie thy leudenes alſo willy god ſoule bleſſe mine eares aken thy draftie ſpeach ſuch riche deuill beteach may wel clepe rime dogrel qd ſo qd wolt thou let tale man sin beſt time god qd plainly worde thy draftie timing worth torde thou doeſt nought el ſpendeſt time sir one word thou ſhalt lenger rime let ſee whether thou canſt tell ought geſt tell proſe ſomewhat leſt ther may ſome mirth doctrine gladly qd god ſwete pine woll tell little thing proſe ought like ſuppoſe elſe ye certes dangerous morall tale vertuous tolde ſometime ſundry wiſe ſundry folke ſhall deviſe thus ye wote every evangeliſt telleth u paine ieſu chriſt ne ſaith thing fellow doth natheleſſe ſentence ſoth accorden ſentence telling difference ſome hem ſaien ſome leſſe whan pitous paſſion expreſſe meane marke matthew luke iohn doubtleſſe ſentence one therefore lordings beſeech thinke vary ſpeech thus although tell ſomewhat proverbes ye han heard comprehended little treatiſe enforcen effect matere though ſame word ſay ye han heard yet pray blameth ſentence shull ye finde mochell difference fro ſentence treatiſe lite little tale write therefore hearkeneth ſhall ſay let tell tale pray ¶chaucers tale melibeus prudence diſcreet wife melibeus perſuadeth husband patience receive enemy mercy grace tale full morality wherein high low may learn govern affection ayong man called melibeus mighty rich begate upon wife called prudence doughter called sophie vpon day befell diſport went field play wife eke doughter left within houſe doores faſt iſhet foure old foe han aſpied ſetten ladder walles houſe windowes beene entred bet wife wounded doughter five mortall woundes five ſundry place ſay foot honds eares noſe mouth leften dede wenten way melibeus returned houſe ſee miſchiefe hee like mad man renting clothes gan weep crie prudence wife farre foorth ſhee durſt beſought weping ſtint thy gan weep cry ever lenger noble wife prudence remembred upon ſentence ovid booke cleped remedy loue whereas ſaith hee foole diſtourbeth mother weepe death childe till ſhe wept fill certain time ſhall man doen diligence amiable wordes recomfort pray weeping ſtint reaſon noble wife prudence ſuffered husbond weepe cry certaine ſpace ſhe ſaw time ſhee ſaied wiſe ala lord qd ſhe make ye ſelfe like foole forſoth apperteineth unto wiſe man maken ſuch ſorowe doughter grace god ſhall wariſh eſcape ſo ſhe right dead yee ne ought death ſelf deſtroy senek ſaith wiſe man ſhall take great diſcomfort death child certes ſhould ſuffer patience wel abideth ye death proper perſon melibeus anſwered anon ſaid man qd ſhould weping ſtint hath ſo great cauſe weep ieſus himſelfe lorde wept death lazarus friend prudence anſwered certes well wote temperat weeping nothing defended ſorowfull among folke ſorow rather graunted weepe apoſtle paule unto romanes writteth men ſhould rejoyce maketh joye weepe ſuch folke weepen though temperate weeping granted certes outragious weeping defended meaſure weeping ſhould conſidered lore teacheth u senek yt thy friend dead qd let thine iyen moiſt teers ne much drie although teeres comen thine eyen let hem fall thou haſt forgon thy friend doe diligence get another friend wiſedom weepe thy friend thou haſt lorne therein bote therefore ye govern ſapience put away ſorow heart remembreth ieſus sirake ſaieth man yt joyous glad hart conſerueth floriſhing age ſothly ſorowfull heart maketh bone drie hee ſaith eke thus ſorow heart ſlayeth full many man salomon ſayeth right mouth ſheepes fleiſe annoieth clothes ſmall wormes tree right ſo anoieth ſorow hart man wherefore u ought well death child loſſe temporal good patience remember upon patient iob hee loſt child temporall ſubſtaunce body endured receiued full many grieuous tribulation yet ſaied hee thus lord ſent lord hath bereft right ſo lord would right ſo done ibleſſed name lord theſe foreſaid thing melibeus unto wife prudence anſwered thy word qd ben true thereto profitable truely mine heart troubled ſorrow ſo grievouſly let call qd prudence true friend al thy linage wiſe telleth hem caſe hearkeneth ſay counſailing gouerne ſentence salomon ſaith werke thy thing counſaile thou ſhalt never rue counſaile wife prudence melibeus let cauſe great congregation people surgiens phiſitions old folke yong ſome old enemy reconciled ſemblance loue grace therwithal came ſome neighbour reverence dread loue happe ofte comen alſo ful many ſubtil flatterer wiſe advocate learned lawe theſe folkes togeders aſſembled melibeus ſorrowfull wiſe ſhewed hem caſe manner ſpeech ſeemed hart bare cruell ire ready doen vengeaunce upon foe ſuddainly deſired warre ſhould begin natheles yet asked counſaile upon matter surgien licence aſſent ſuch wiſe roſe unto melibeus ſaied ye ſhall heare sir qd u surgiens appertaineth doe every wight beſt beene withholden patient wee dooen damage wherefore happeth many time ofte two men everch wounded one surgien healeth hem wherfore vnto arte pertinent noriſh warre ne party ſupport certes ye wariſhing doughter ſo perilouſly ſhe wounded ſhall doe ſo tentife buſineſſe fro day night grace god ſhe ſhall whole ſound ſoone poſſible almoſt right ſame wiſe phiſitions anſwered ſaue yt ſaiden word right malady beene contrary cured right ſo ſhall man wariſhe warre peace neigbours full enuie fained friend yt ſeemed reconciled flatterer maden ſemblaunce weeping enpaired agrutched much matter prayſing greatly melibe might power rich friend diſpiſing power aduerſaries ſaid vtterly hee anon ſhould wreken foe begin warre vp roſe aduocate wiſe leaue counſaile wiſe ſaied neede wee beene aſſembled place full heauie thing great matter becauſe ye wrong wickedneſſe yt hath bee doen eke reaſon great damage time comming poſſible fallen ſame eke reaſon ye great rich power party reaſons full great peril erren matter wherefore melibeus ſentence counſaile abouen thing right anon thou doe thy diligence keeping thy proper perſon ſuch wiſe yt thou ne want non eſpie ne watch thy body ſaue yt counſaile yt thine houſe thou ſet ſufficient garriſon ſo may well thy body thy houſe defend certes mouen warre doen ſuddainly vengeaunce may deeme ſo little time profitable wherefore aske leiſer ſpace haue deliberation cauſe deme common prouerbe ſaith thus yt ſone deemeth ſone ſhall repent eke men ſaine thilke iudge wiſe yt ſone vnderſtondeth matter iudgeth leiſer tarriyng noifull algate reproued yeuing iudgement ne vengeance taking ſufficient reaſonable yt ſhewed lord ieſu chriſt enſample woman taken auoutrie brought preſens knowen wt ſhuld doen perſon wiſt wel himſelf wt would anſwere yet ne would anſwere ſuddainly would haue deliberation ground wrote twiſe cauſe asken deliberation ſhall grace god counſaile thing ſhall profitable vp ſtert yong folke one moſt part companie haue ſcorned old wiſe man begun make noiſe ſaid right ſo while iron hot men ſhould ſmite right ſo men ſhould wreken wrong freſh new loud voyce cried warre warre vp roſe one old wiſe hand made countenance ſhould holden hem ſtill yeuen audience lordings qd full many man crieth warre warre wote full lite warre amounteth warre beginning hath ſo great entring ſo large every wight may enter liketh lightly find warre certes end thereof ſhall fall lightly know warre begun ful many child vnborne mother ſhal ſterue yong becauſe thilke warre el liue ſorrow dien wretchedneſſe therefore warre bee begon men muſt haue great counſaile good deliberation whan olde man wende enforten tale reaſon wel nie one begon riſe breaken tale bidden full oft wordes abredge certes hee preacheth hem liſt heare wordes ſermon hem annoieth ieſus sirake ſayeth yt weeping muſick noious thing much ſay much auaileth ſpeake beforne folk ſpeech anoieth ſingen hem weepe wiſe man ſaw wanted audience ſhamefaſt ſet adown ayen salomon ſaith thou mayeſt audience enforce thee ſpeake ſee well qd wiſe man common proverbe ſuch good counſail wanteth moſt need yet melibeus counſaile many folke yt privily eare counſailed certain thing counſailed contrary general audience melibeus heard greateſt part counſaile accorded ſhould make war anon conſented counſailing fully affirmed ſentence dame prudence ſhe ſaw husbonde ſhope awreke enemy begin warre ſhee full humble wiſe ſhee ſaw time ſayed theſe word lorde qd ſhe beſeech heartily dare ne halfe faſt guerdon yeue audience peter alphons ſaieth whoſo doeth thee good harme haſte thee quite wiſe thy friend woll abide thine enemie ſhall ye lenger liue dread prouerbe ſaieth haſteth well wiſely abide wicked haſt profite melibe anſwered wife prudence purpoſe qd werke thy counſaile many cauſes reaſons certes euery wight would hold mee foole ſay thy counſailing would change thing ordeined affirmed ſo many wiſe secondly ſay woman beene wicked none good hem thouſand men ſaith salomon found one good man certes al woman found neuer none alſo certes gouerned mee thy counſaile ſhould ſeeme yeue thee ouer mee ye maiſtrie god forbid ſo ieſus sirake ſaieth wife haue maiſtrie ſhee contrarious husbond salomon ſaieth neuer thy life thy wife ne thy childe ne thy friend ne yeue power ouer thy ſelfe better thy child aske thee thing hem needeth thy ſelfe hand thy child alſo woll werche thy counſail certes counſail muſt ſomtime ſecrete till time muſt bee knowen ne may bee ſhould counſailed thee dame prudence full debonairly great patience heard husbonde liked ſay asked ſhe licence ſpeake ſaied wiſe lord qd ſhe firſt reaſon may lightly anſwerd ſay follie chaunge counſaile thing changed el thing ſeemeth otherwiſe ſeemed afore moreouer ſay though yee haue ſworne behight performe empriſe juſt cauſe ye doe men ſhould ſay therefore ye lyer forſworn booke ſaieth wiſe man maketh leſing hee turneth corage better albeit empriſe bee eſtabliſhed ordeined great multitude folke yet dare accompliſh thilke ordinance liketh trouth thing profit rather founden folke wiſe full reaſon great multitude folke every man crieth clattereth liketh ſoothly ſuch multitude honeſt ye ſecond reaſon whereas ye ſay woman ben wicked ſave grace certes ye deſpiſe woman wiſe deſpiſeth ſaith booke al diſpleaſeth senecke ſaith ſo woll haue sapience ſhall man diſpraiſe ſhall gladly teach ſcience without preſumption pride ſuch thing nought ne hee ſhall beene aſhamed learne hem enquire leſſe folke himſelfe yt ther hath ben many good woman may lightly prooued certes ſir lord ieſu chriſt nold neuer han diſcended borne woman woman wicked yt great bounte woman lord ieſu chriſt riſen death life appeared rather woman apoſtles tho salomon ſayed found neuer woman good followeth therefore woman wicked though hee ne found good woman certes many another man hath founde many woman full good true el perauenture ye entent salomon ſoueraign bounte found woman ſay yt wight hath parfite bounte ſaue god alone himſelfe recordeth euangelie ni creature ſo good yt ne wanteth ſomwhat ye perfection god maker third reaſon ye ſay yt ye gouerne counſaile ſhould ſeeme ye yeue maiſtrie lordſhip perſon sir ſaue grace ſo ſo man ſhould bee counſailed onely hem han lordſhip maiſtrie perſon men nolde bee counſailed ſo oft ſothly thilke man asketh counſaile purpoſe yet hath free whither hee woll doe counſaile non fourth reaſon yee ſaine ianglerie woman hide thing wot ſo ſaieth yt woman cannot hide ſhe wote sir theſe wordes vnderſtonde woman iangelers wicked woman men ſaine three thing driuen man houſe ſay ſmoke dropping raine wicked wiues ſuch woman salomon ſaieth man better dwell deſerte woman riottous ſir leaue ye haue full oft aſſaied great ſilence great patience eke well hide heale thing men oughten ſecretly hiden ſothly fift reaſon whereas ſay yt wicked counſaile woman vanquiſh men god wote thilke reaſon ſtant ſtede vnderſtondeth ye asken counſaile doe wickednes ye woll werken wickednes wife reſtraineth thilke wicked purpoſe ouercome reaſon good counſail certes wife ought rather bee praiſed blamed thus ſhould vnderſtonde phyloſopher yt ſaieth wicked counſaile woman vanquiſh husbondes ye blame al woman reaſons ſhall ſhewe many enſamples many woman haue full good yet counſaile wholeſome profitable eke ſome men han ſaied ye counſaile woman either deere little worth albeit ſo yt full many woman bee bad counſaile vile nought worth yet han men found full many good woman full diſcrete wiſe counſailing lo iacob counſaile mother rebecke wan beniſon father lordſhip brother iudith thorow good counſaile deliuered citie bethule ſhe dwelt honde holofern beſieged wold haue deſtroyed abigaile deliuered naball husbond fro dauid king yt would haue ſlaine appeaſed ire king wit good counſaile heſter counſaile enhaunced greatly ye people god reigne aſſuerus king ſame bountie good counſailing many good woman may men reade tell furthermore whan lord hath created adam former father hee ſaied wiſe good man alone make wee helper himſelfe ſemblable may yee ſee woman good counſaile good profitable lorde god heauen ne would neither han wrought hem ne called hem helper man rather confuſion man ſayed clerke one two verſes better gold iaſper better iaſper wiſdom better wiſdome woman better good woman good man better good man nothing ſir many reaſons may yee ſeene many woman good eke counſaile good profitable therefore ſir yee woll truſt counſaile ſhall reſtore doughter hole ſound eke woll doe ſo much yt ye ſhall haue honour caſe melibe heard word wife prudence ſaied thus ſee well ye word salomon ſooth ſaith word yt bee ſpoken diſcretly ordinaunce honicombes yeuen ſweetneſſe ſoule holſomneſſe ye body wife becauſe thy ſweet word eke haue proued aſſaied thy great sapience thy great trouth woll gouerne thy counſaile thing ſir qd dame prudence ſithens ye vouchſafe gouerned counſaile woll enforme yee ſhall govern ſelf chuſing counſailours ye ſhall firſt werke mekely beſeeching high god yt would counſailour ſhapeth ſuch entent hee yeue counſaile comforte taught thobie ſonne time thou ſhalt bleſſe god praie dreſſe thy way loke eke thy counſailes evermore saint iames ſaieth man neede ſapience aske god afterwarde ſhullen ye take counſaile ſelfe examine well owne thought ſuch thing thinken beene beſt profit ſhall yee drive fro heart thing bee contrarious good counſaile ſay ire covetiſe haſtineſſe firſt yt asketh counſaile himſelfe certes muſt withouten ire wrath himſelfe many cauſes firſt hath great ire wrath himſelfe weneth alway may doe thing may ſecondly irous wrothfull may well deeme hee may well deeme may well counſell third hee irous wroth ſaieth seneke may ſpeake blamefull thing thilke vicious wordes hee ſtirreth folke anger ire eke ſir yee muſt drive covetiſe heart ye apoſtle ſaith covetiſe roote harmes truſteth right well covetous man ne deem ne thinke fulfill end covetiſe certes ne may never accompliſhed evermore haboundance hath richeſſes hee deſireth ſir ye muſt alſo drive heart haſtineſſe certes ye may deme beſt ſuddain thought falleth heart ye muſt adviſe full oft yee heard common proverb yt ſone deemeth ſone repenteth sir ye ne alway like diſpoſition certes ſome thing ſeemeth ſomtime good doe another time ſeemeth contrarie ye han taken counſaile ſelfe han deemed good deliberation ſuch thing ſeemeth beſt rede yee keepe ſecret bewray yee counſaile perſon ſo yee wene ſikerly bewraying condition ſhall bee profitable ieſus sirake ſaith neither thy foe ne thy friend diſcover thy ſecret ne thy folly woll yeue audience looking ſupportation preſence ſcorn abſence another clerke ſayth ſcarſly ſhall finde perſon may keepe counſaile ſecretly booke ſaieth thou keepeſt counſaile thine heart thou keepeſt thy priſon thou bewrayeſt thy counſaile wight hee holdeth thee ſnare therefore better hide counſaile heart pray yee bewrayed counſaile woll keepe cloſe ſtill seneca ſaieth ſo thou maieſt thine owne counſaile hide howe dareſt thou pray wight thy counſaile ſecret keepe natheleſſe thou wene ſikerly thy bewraying thy counſaile perſon woll make thy condition ſtonde ye better plight ſhalt thou tell thy counſaile wiſe firſt thou ſhalt make ſemblant whether thee lever peace warre ne ſhewe thy ne thine entent truſt well commonly theſe counſailours beene flatrerers namely counſailours great lordes enforce hem alway rather ſpeak pleaſant word enclining lordes luſt word ben trew profitable therfore men ſay ye rich man hath ſeld good counſaile hee himſelfe thou ſhalt conſider thy friendes thine enemy touching thy friendes thou ſhalt conſider hem moſt faithfull moſt wiſe eldeſt moſt approved counſailing hem ſhalt thou aske thy counſaile caſe requireth ſay firſt yee ſhall call counſaile friend true saloman ſaith right ye heart man deliteth ſavour ſote right ſo counſaile true friend yeueth ſweteneſſe ſoule hee ſaieth alſo may nothing likened ye true friend certes gold ne ſilver bee ſo much worth good true friend alſo ſaith true friend ſtrong defence ſo findeth hath great treaſure ſhall ye alſo conſider true friend diſcreet wiſe booke ſaith aske alway thy counſaile bin wiſe ſame reaſon ſhall ye call counſaile friend yt beene age ſuch ſeeme beene expert many thinges approoved counſailing booke ſaieth olde men sapience long time prudence tullius ſaieth great thing beene aye accompliſhed ſtrength ne deliverneſſe body counſaile aucthoritie perſons science three thing ne beene feeble age certes enforce encreaſe day day ſhall ye keep generall rule firſt ſhall yee call counſaile fewe friend yt eſpecial salomon ſaieth many friend thou among thouſand chuſe thee one bee thy counſailour bee ſo thou firſt ne tell thy counſaile fewe thou mayeſt afterwarde tell mo folke bee neede looke alway thy counſaylours thoſe condition ſayd yt ſay true wiſe old experience werke alway every need one counſailer alone ſometimes behooueth bee counſailed many salomon ſayth saluation thing many counſaylers haue told folke yee ſhall counſailed woll tell couſaile yee ought eſchew firſt yee ſhall eſchew counſailing fooles salomon ſayth take counſaile foole hee woll counſaile owne luſt affection booke ſayth propertie foole troweth lightly harme euery man lightly troweth bountie himſelfe thou ſhalt eſchew counſailing flaterers enforcen hem rather praiſe perſon flatterie tell ſoothfaſtneſſe thing wherefore tullius ſayeth among peſtilence friendſhip greateſt flatterie therefore need yt thou eſchew dread flatterer people booke ſaith thou ſhalt rather flee fro ſweete wordes flattering praiſing fro eagre word thy friend ſaith ſooths salomon ſaith word flatterer ſnare catch innocence ſayth alſo yt ſpeaketh friend wordes flatterie pleaſaunce ſetteth net beforne foot catch therefore tullius ſayth encline thine eares flatterer ne take counſaile flatterer caton ſayeth auiſe thee well eſchew wordes ſweetneſſe pleaſaunce eke thou ſhalt eſchew counſailing thine old enemy reconciled booke ſayth wight retourneth ſafely grace old enemie iſope ſayth ne truſt hem thou haſt ſometime war enmity ne tell hem thy counſaile seneck telleth ye cauſe may ſayth great fire hath long time endured dwelleth ſome vapour heat therefore ſaith salomon thine old foe truſt thou neuer likerly though thine enemie reconciled make ſigne humilitie loute thee head truſt neuer certes maketh thilke faigned humility profite humility loue thy perſon becauſe deemeth haue victory ouer thy perſon ſuch fained countenaunce victorie might haue ſtrife warre petrus alphons ſayeth make fellowſhip thine old enemy thou hem bounty wollen pervert wickedneſs eke thou muſt eſchew counſailing hem yt thy ſervaunts bearen thee great reverence peraventure ſayne dread love therfore ſaith philoſopher wiſe wight perfitly true dredeth tullius ſayth might ſo great emperour long may endure haue loue people dread ye ſhall eſchew alſo counſailing folke dronklewe ne counſaile hide salomon ſayth ni priuity reigneth drunkenneſſe ye ſhall haue alſo ſuſpect ye counſailing ſuch folke counſaile one thing priuily counſaile contrarie openly caſſidorie ſayeth manner ſleight hinder enemy ſheweth done thing openly werketh priuily ye contrary thou ſhalt haue alſo ſuſpect counſailing wicked folke alway full fraud dauid ſayth blisfull man yt hath followed counſailing ſhrews thou ſhalt alſo eſchew counſailing yong folke counſailing ripe salomon ſaith ſir ſithens haue ſhewed ſuch folke ye ſhall counſailed follow woll teach ye ſhall examine counſaile ye doctrine tullius examining counſailers ye ſhal conſider many thing firſt thou ſhalt conſider thilke thing thou purpoſeſt vpon thing thou wolt haue counſaile trueth ſaid conſerued ſay tell truly thy tale yt ſayeth falſe may well counſailed caſe lieth thou ſhalt conſider thing accorden yt thou purpoſeſt doe thy counſailours reaſon accord thereto eke thy might may attaine therto part better part counſailours accorden thereto ſhalt thou conſider thing ſhall follow counſailing hate peace warre grace profite damage many thing thing ſhalt thou chuſe beſt weiue thing ſhalt thou conſider root engendred matter thy counſaile fruit may conceive engender thou ſhalt eke conſider cauſes whence ſprong thou haſt examined thy counſaile haue ſaid partie better profitable haſt approoued many wiſe folke old thou ſhalt conſider thou maieſt performe make good end certes reaſon woll man ſhall begin thing might performe ought ne wight ſhould take vpon ſo heauie charge yt might bere ye proverbe ſayth much embraceth diſtraineth little caton ſaith aſſay ſuch thing thou haſt power done leaſt charge oppreſſe thee ſore thee behooueth weiue thing yt thou haſt begunne ſo yt thou dout whether thou maieſt performe thing none chuſe rather ſuffer begin peter alphons ſaieth thou haſt might thing thou muſt repent better holde thy tongue ſtill ſpeake maieſt thou vnderſtond ſtronger reaſons thou haſt power perfourme werke thou ſhalt repent thee better thou ſuffer begin well ſaine defenden euery wight aſſay thing doubt whether may performe none ye haue examined counſaile haue ſaid know well yee may performe empriſe conferme ſadly till bee end reaſon time ſhewe wherfore ye may chaunge counſaile withouten reproofe soothly man may change purpoſe counſaile cauſe ceaſeth newe caſe betideth ye law ſaith vpon thing newly betideth behooueth newe counſaile seneke ſaieth thy counſaile come eares thine enemy chaunge thy counſaile thou maieſt alſo chaunge thy counſaile ſo thou find error cauſe harme dammage may betide alſo thy counſaile diſhoneſt el come diſhoneſt cauſe chaunge thy counſaile ye law ſaith beheſts diſhoneſt ne value eke ſo bee vnpoſſible may gladly perfourmed kept take general rule euery counſaile enformed ſo ſtrongly yt may chaunged condition may betide ſay ilke counſail wicked melibeus heard doctrine wife dame prudence aunſwerd wiſe dame qd yet vnto time ye han well taught gouernaile ſhall gouern ye chuſing withholding counſaile would faine ye would condiſcend eſpecial yt ye ſeemeth counſailours wee haue choſe preſent need lord qd ſhe beſeech humbleſſe yee woll wilfully replie ayenſt reaſons ne diſtemper hert though ſpeake thing diſpleaſe god wote mine entent ſpeake beſt honour profit eke ſoothly hope benignity woll take patience truſteth well yt counſaile caſe neſhould ſpeak properly called counſailing motion mouing folly counſaile ye haue erred many ſundry wiſe firſt yee haue erred aſſembling counſailours firſt yee ſhould haue cleped fewe folke counſaile yee might haue ſhewed mo bee neede ye haue cleped counſail great multitude people full chargeous full noyous heare alſo ye haue erred yee ſhould haue onely cleped counſaile trew friend olde wiſe ye haue cleped ſtraunge folke yong folk falſe flatterer enemy reconciled folk yt done reuerence withouten loue eke yee haue erred yee haue brought counſaile ire couetiſe haſtineſſe ye three thing contrary euery good counſaile honeſt profitable three thing yee haue deſtroyed neither ſelf ne counſailours ye ought ye haue erred alſo yee haue ſhewed counſailours talent affection make warre anon vengeance haue eſpied word thing ye beene enclined therefore han rather counſailed talent profite ye han erred eke ſeemeth ſufficeth haue counſailed theſe counſailours onely little auiſement whereas ſo high ſo great need neceſſarie mo counſailours deliberation performe empriſe ye han erred alſo ye haue examined counſaile ye foreſaid matter ne due manner y• caſe requireth ye haue erred alſo ye made diuiſion betweene true friend fained counſailours ne ye haue knowne trewe counſailours friend old wiſe ye haue caſt word hochpot enclined heart part greater number fooles wiſe men therefore ye counſaylings beene congregation multitude folke men take regard number
