ſapience perſons ye ſeene well yt ſuch counſaylings fooles han maiſtrie melibeus anſwerd ſaid ayen graunt well haue erred thou haſt told beforne yt ni blame chaungeth counſaile certaine caſe certaine juſt cauſe redie chaunge counſailours right thou wouldeſt deuiſe prouerbe ſayth done ſinne manniſh certes perſevere long ſinne werke diuell ſentence anſwereth anone dame prudence ſaid examineth qd ſhe well counſaile let v ſee hem hath ſpoke moſt reaſonably taught beſt counſaile much examination neceſſarie let v begin surgiens phyſicians firſt ſpake matter ſay phyſicians surgiens haue ſaied counſayle diſcreetly hem ought ſpeech ſaid full wiſely office hem appertaineth done euery wight honour profite wight annoy craft done great diligence vnto cure hem haue gouernaunce ſir right answerd wiſely diſcreetly right ſo read yt beene highly ſouerainly guerdoned noble ſpeech eke ſhull done ententife buſineſſe ye curation doughter beit ſo friend therfore ſhullen ye ſuffer ſerue nought ye ought therafter guerdon hem pay hem largeſſe touching y• propoſition phyſicians entreteden caſe ſaine malady contrarie wariſhed another contrary would faine know ye vnderſtond thilke text ſentence certes qd melibeus vnderſtond wiſe right han doe contrary ſo ſhould done hem another right han venged hem vpon done wrong right ſo woll venge vpon hem done hem wrong haue cured one contrary another lo lo qd dame prudence lightly euery man enclined deſire owne pleaſaunce certes qd ſhe ye wordes phyſicians ne ſhould vnderſtond yt wiſe certes wickedneſſe contrary wickedneſſe ne vengeaunce contrarie vengeaunce ne wrong wrong euery hem encreaſeth engendreth certes word phyſicians ſhould vnderſtond wiſe good wickedneſſe ben two contrary peace warre vengeaunce ſuffraunce diſcord accord many thing certes wickedneſſe ſhall wariſhed goodneſſe diſcord accord warre peace ſo forth thing therto accordeth ſaint paule apoſtle many place ſayth ne yeeld harme harme ne wicked ſpeech wicked ſpeech doe well hem done thee harme bleſſe hem ſaith thee harme many place admoniſheth peace accord woll ſpeke ye counſaile iyeue vnto men lawe wiſe folke old folke ſayden one accord ye heard beforne ouer thing ye ſhall done buſineſſe diligence keepe perſon warnſtore houſe ſaid alſo caſe ye ought werchen full wiſely great deliberation ſir firſt point toucheth keeping perſon ye ſhall vnderſtond hath warre ſhall euer deuoutly meekly praien beforne thing ieſu chriſt mercie woll haue protection ſoueraigne helper need certes world ni wight may counſailed ikept ſufficiently without keeping lord ieſu chriſt ſentence accordeth prophet dauid yt ſayth god ne kept citty idle waketh hee keepeth ſir ſhould hee commit keeping perſon true friend approued iknow ſhould ye aske helpe perſon keep caton ſaith thou haue need helpe aske thy friend ni none ſo good hhyſician thy true friend ſhall yee keep fro ſtraunge folke fro liers alway ſuſpect companie peter alphons ſaieth ne take company way ſtraunge man ſo bee thou haſt known lenger time ſo fall thy companie peradventure withouten thine aſſent good enquire ſubtelly thou canſt converſation life beforne faine thy way ſaying thou wouldeſt go thider thou wolt goe beare ſpeare hold thee right ſide beare ſwerd hold thee left ſide ſhall ye keepe wiſely manner ſuch people ſaied hem counſaile eſchew ſhall yee keepe ſuch manner preſumption bodily ſtrength ye deſpiſe ne account might adverſary ſo lite ye let keeping perſon preſumption every wiſe man dredeth enemie salomon ſayth foole yt hath drede certes thorow hardneſſe heart ye hardineſſe himſelfe hath great preſumption ſhall euill betide ſhall ye euermore encounter waite embuſhments eſpiaile seneke ſayeth wiſe man yt dredeth harmes eſcheweth harmes ne falleth peril perill eſcheweth ſo thou ſeeme yt thou ſecret place yet ſhalt thou alway done diligence keeping thy perſon ſay ne negligent keepe thine owne perſon onely thy greateſt enemy alſo thy leaſt enemy seneke ſayth man yt well aduiſed dreadeth leaſt enemie ouid ſayth ye little weſell woll ſlee ye great bull wild hart prouerbe ſayth little thorn woll greeue king full ſore little hound woll hold ye wild bore nathaleſſe ſay thou ſhalt ſo coward thou doubt dred book ſayth ſomemen haue great luſt deceiue yet dread bee deceiued keepe thee fro ye companie ſcorners booke ſayth ſcorners ne make company flie word venome ſecond point whereas wiſe counſaylours counſayled warneſtore houſe great dilligence would faine know yee vnderſtond thilke wordes ſentence melibeus anſwered ſaid certes vnderſtond wiſe ſhall warneſtore mine houſe toures ſuch haue caſtles maner edifice armure archery betweene thing may perſon houſe ſo keepe defend mine enemy ſhullen dread mine houſe approch ſentence anſwered anon prudence warniſhing qd ſhe high toures high edifice great coſtages great travaile yt ben accompliſhed yet bin worth ſtraw defended true friend ben old wiſe underſtondeth well greateſt ſtrongeſt garniſon rich men may well keepen perſon good beloved ſubjects neighbour thus ſayth tullius manner garriſon yt man may vanquiſh ne diſcomfite lord beloved citizen people nowe ſir third point whereas olde wiſe counſaylours ſaied yt ye ought ſuddainly ne haſtily proceed need yee ought purueyen apparaile caſe great dilligence deliberation verely trow ſaied right truly right ſooth tullius ſayth every deed thou begin apparaile thee great diligence ſay vengeaunce taking war battaile warneſtoring thou begin rede thou apparaile thee thereto great deliberation tullius ſayth long apparailing tofore battaile maketh ſhort victorie caſſidorus ſayth garriſon ſtronger long time aviſed let u ſpeake counſayle accorded neighbour ſuch done reverence withouten love old enemy reconciled flatterer counſailed certain thing prively openly counſailed contrarie young folke alſo counſailed venge make warre anon certes ſir ſaied ye greatly erred clepe ſuch manner folke counſaile counſailours ben ynough reproued reaſons aforeſaid natheleſſe let u deſcend ſpecial ye ſhull firſt proceed doctrine tullius certes trouth matter counſaile needeth diligently enquire wel wiſt han done treſpas villanie many treſpaſſours manner done wrong villany ſhull ye examine ſecond condition tullius addeth matter tullius putteth thing clepeth conſenting ſay ben many conſenten thy counſaile thy wilfulneſſe done haſtie vengeaunce let u conſider alſo many conſented adverſaries firſt point well knowen folke conſented haſtie wilfulneſſe truly tho counſaile maken ſuddaine warre ne friend let ſee beene ye holden ſo greatly friend perſon albeit ſo ye mighty rich certes ye alone truly yee ne child doughter ne ye brother ne couſin germaines ne none nigh kinrede wherefore enemy ſhould ſtint plead ne deſtroy perſon ye know alſo rich mote diſpended diverſe party every wight hath part wollen take little regard venge death thine enemy ben three many brother child couſins nigh kinrede though ſo thou haddeſt ſlaine hem two three yet dwelleth ynowe avenge death ſlea thy perſon though ſo kinrede ſtedfaſt ſiker kinne adverſaries yet nevertheleſſe kinrede kinrede ben little ſibbe kinne enemy ben nigh ſibbe hem certes condition better let u conſider alſo counſayling hem counſayled take ſuddaine vengeaunce whether accord reaſon non certes yee know well nay right reaſon may man take vengeaunce wight judge hath jurisdiction graunted take vengeaunce haſtely attemperately law requireth yet moreover thilke word tullius clepeth conſenting thou ſhalt conſent thy might thy power may conſent ſuffice thy wilfulneſſe thy counſaylours certes thou mayeſt well ſay nay ſikerly ſpeake properly may nothing ſuch thing may done rightfully certes rightfully ye may take vengeaunce proper authority may ye ſee power ne conſenteth ne accordeth wilfulneſſe nowe let u examine third point tullius clepeth conſequence thou ſhalt underſtond yt vengeaunce thou purpoſeſt take conſequent thereof followeth another vengeaunce perill warre dammages withouten number wee ware time touching fourth point tullius clepeth engendring thou ſhalt conſider wrong done thee engendred hate thine enemy vengeaunce taking upon hem yt would engender another vengeaunce muckell ſorrow waſting richeſſe ſayed ere ſir touching fift point tully cleapeth cauſes laſt point thou ſhalt underſtond wrong thou haſt received hath certain cauſes clerkes callen oryen effycien cauſa longinqua cauſa propinqua ſay ferre cauſe nigh cauſe ferre cauſe almighty god cauſe thing neere cauſe three enemy cauſe accidentall hate cauſe material ben ye five wound thy doughter cauſe formall ye maner werking brought ladder clambe thy windowes cauſe finall ſlea thy doughter letted much ſpeak ferre cauſe end ſhould come finally ſhall betide caſe ne deme conjecting ſuppoſing ſhall ſuppoſe ſhall come wicked end becauſe booke decree ſayth seld great paine ben cauſes brought good end ben badly begun ſir men would aske god ſuffred men villany truly cannot well anſwer ſoothfaſtneſſe ye apoſtle ſayeth ſciences judgement lord god almightie full deep may man comprehend ne ſearch hem natheleſſe certain preſumptions coniectings hold beleeve god full juſtice righteouſnes hath ſuffred betide iuſt cauſe reaſonable thy name melibe ſay man drinketh honey thou haſt dronke ſo much honey ſweet temporall richeſſe delices honour world thou art dronke haſt forgotten ieſu chriſt thy creatour thou ne haſt doen ſuch honour reverence thee ought ne thou ne haſt taken keepe ye word ovid ſayth vnder ye honey good thy bodie hid ye venome yt ſlaeth thy ſoule salomon ſayth ſo yt thou haſt found honey eat ſame honey ſufficeth ſo bee thou eat ſame honey meaſure thou ſhalt ſpewe alſo needy poore peraventure almightie god ieſu chriſt hath thee diſpight hath tourned away fro thee face eares miſericorde mercie alſo hath ſuffred give licence thou thus ſhouldeſt bee puniſhed chaſtiſed ye manner thou haſt treſpaſſed offended thou haſt done ſinne againſt lord chriſt certes three enemy mankind ſay fleſh fiend world thou haſt ſuffered hem entre thine heart wilfully windowes thy body haſt defended thy ſelfe ſufficiently ayenſt aſſaults temptation ſo wounded thy ſoule five place ſay deadly ſinnes ben entred thy hart thy five wit ſame manner lorde chriſt hath would ſuffered thy three enemy entered thy hous yt windowes wounded thy doughter foreſaied manner truly qd melibe ſee well yee enforce much word overcome ſuch manner ſhall venge mee mine enemy ſhewing ye peril evil yt might fall vengeaunce ſo would conſider vengeance peril evil might ſue vengeaunce taking man would never take vengeaunce harme vengeaunce taken ye wicked men diſcevered fro good men yt doe wickedneſſe reſtrain wicked purpoſe ſee puniſhing chaſtiſing treſpaſſours yet ſay mo • e right ſingular perſon ſinneth taking vengeaunce another man right ſo ſinneth ye judge doe vengeaunce hem deſerved senecke ſayeth thus maiſter ſayth good preveth ſhrews caſſiodore ſaith man dredeth outrage wot knoweth yt diſpleaſeth ye iudges soveraignes another ſayth iudge yt dreadeth doe right maketh men ſhrewes add ſaint poule apoſtle ſayeth epiſtle writeth unto romanes iudge bear ſpeare withoutcauſe beare puniſh ſhrewes misdoers defend good men ye woll take vengeaunce enemy ye ſhull retourne recourſe iudge hath jurisdiction upon hem ſhall puniſh hem law asketh requireth ha ſaied melibe vengeaunce liketh nothing bethink take heed fortune hath nouriſhed mee fro childhood hath holpe paſſe many ſtronge paas would aſſay trowing god helpe ſhe ſhall helpe mee ſhame avenge truly ſaied prudence yee woll werke counſaile yee ſhall aſſay fortune way ne yee ſhall lean unto word senecke thing fooliſhly doen done hope fortune ſhall never come good end ye ſame senek ſayth clere ſhining fortune britle ſooner broke ſhe truſteth ſhe ſtedfaſt ne ſtable thou troweſt moſt ſure ſtedfaſt helpe ſhe woll faile deceive thee whereas ye ſay fortune hath nouriſhed fro childhood ſay ſo much ye ſhall leſſe truſt wit seneke ſaith man yt nouriſhed fortune ſhe maketh great foole ſith ye deſire aske vengeaunce vengeaunce done law judge ne liketh vengeaunce doen hope fortune perillous uncertaine yee none remedie haue recourſe vnto ſoveraine iudge vengeth villanies wrong ſhall venge himſelf witneſſeth whereas ſaith leave vengeaunce ſhall melibeus anſwerd ne venge ye villanie yt men haue doen ſummon warne hem haue doen villanie doe another villany written thou take vengeaunce old villany thou ſummoneſt thine aduerſaries thee new villanie alſo ſufferaunce men would doe ſo much villanie might neither beare ne ſuſtain ſo ſhould put holden ouer low men ſain mikell ſuffring ſhal many thing fall vnto thee thou ſhalt mow ſuffer certes qd prudence graunt yt ouermuch ſuffraunce good yet ne followeth thereof euery perſon men doe villanie ſhould take vengeance appertaineth longeth onely iudges ſhould venge ye villanies iniuries therefore thoſe two authority yee haue ſaied beene onely vnderſtond iudges ſuffer ouermuch wrong villanies bee doen withouten puniſhment ſummon man onely doe newe wrong commaund alſo wiſe man ſayth ye iudge correcteth ſinner commaundeth biddeth doe ſinne iudges ſoueraines might lond ſo much ſuffer ſhrews miſdoers ſhould ſuch ſuffraunce proceſſe time ſuch power might ſhould put iudges soueraignes place laſt make hem leſe lordſhips let v ſuppoſe ye haue leue venge ſay yee might power venge ye woll make compariſon vnto might aduerſaries yee ſhould find many thinges haue ſhewed er yt condition better therefore ſay good ye ſuffer patient furthermore ye know well common ſaw woodneſſe manne ſtriue ſtronger mightie man hee himſelfe ſtriue man euen ſtrength ſay ſtrong man hee perill ſtriue weaker man folly therfore ſhould man flie ſtriuing mikell might salomon ſayeth great worſhip man keepe fro noiſe ſtrife ſo befall hap yt man greater might ſtrength thou art doe thee greeuaunce ſtudie buſie yt rather ſtill ſame greeuaunce venge thee seneke ſayth putteth great perill ſtriueth greater man himſelfe caton ſayth man higher eſtate degre mightie thou thee annoy greuaunce ſuffer yt hath greeued thee may another time releeue thee helpe thee yet ſet caſe ye haue licence venge ſay full many thing yt ſhall reſtrain vengeance taking make encline ſuffer haue patience wrong haue doen firſt formoſt ye woll conſider fault owne perſon fault god hath ſuffered haue tribulation haue ſaied poet ſayeth ought patiently take ye tribulation come v wee thinke conſider wee haue deſerued haue ſaint gregorie ſayth manne conſidereth well number default ſinnes paine tribulatious ſuffereth ſeeme leſſe vnto much thinketh ſinnes heauie greeuous ſo much ſeemeth paine lighter eaſier vnto alſo yee owne encline bow heart take patience lord ieſu chriſt ſayeth ſaint peter epiſtles ieſu chriſt ſaith hath ſuffred v yeuen enſample euery man follow ſue neuer ſinne ne neuer came villainous word mouth men curſed curſed hem men bete manaced hem alſo great patience saint paradice haue tribulation haue ſuffered without deſert guilt ought much ſtirre patience furthermore ye ſhull enforce haue patience conſidering tribulation world little endure ſoone paſſen gone joy yt man ſeeketh haue patience tribulation perdurable apoſtle ſays epiſtle joy god ſayeth perdurable ſay euerlaſting alſo troweth beleeueth ſtedfaſtly well noriſhed well taught cannot haue patience woll receiue patience salomon ſayth ye doctrine wit man knowne patience another place ſayeth hee patient gouerneth great prudence y• ſame salomon ſaith angrie wrothfull man maketh noiſes patient man attempreth ſtilleth hem ſaith alſo worth patient right ſtrong yt may haue ye lordſhip heart praiſe force ſtrength taketh great city therefore ſaieth ſaint iames epiſtle patience great vertue perfection certes qd melibee graunt dame prudence yt patience great vertue perfection euery man may haue ye perfection yee ſeeke ne ye number right perfit men mine heart may never peace unto time bee avenged albeit ſo yt great perill mine enemy doe mee villanie taking vengeaunce upon yet tooke heed ye perill fulfilled wicked courage therefore thinketh men ought repreve though put little perill avenge though great exceſſe yt ſay venge one outrage another ah qd dame prudence ye ſay liketh caſe ye world man ſhould outrage ne exceſſe venge caſſiodore ſaith evill doth yt vengeth outrage doth y• outrage therefore ye ſhall venge order right ſay law exceſſe ne outrage alſo woll venge ye outrage aduerſaries maner right commandeth ye ſinne therefore ſayth senek man ſhall never venge ſhreudneſſe ſhreudneſſe ye ſay right asketh defend violence violence fighting fighting certes ye ſay ſooth defence doen without intervall without tarrying delay defend venge behooveth man put ſuch attemperaunce defence men cauſe ne matter repreve defendeth outrage exceſſe el againe reaſon parde yee know well yt yee make defence defend venge ſo ſheweth ye doe deed attemperately therefore thinketh patiente good salomon ſaieth patient ſhall great harme certes ſaied melibe graunt yt man impatient wrothe toucheth appertaineth unto though harme wonder ye law ſaith hee culpable entermetleth medleth ſuch thing appertaineth unto salomon ſaith entremetleth noiſe ſtrife another manne like taketh ſtraunge hound ye eares right hee taketh ſtraunge hound eeres otherwhile bitten hond right ſo ſame wiſe reaſon harme impatience medleth noiſe another man whereas appertaineth unto ye know well deed ſay greefe diſeaſe toucheth right nigh therefore though bee wroth impatient mervaile ſaving grace cannot ſee might greatly harme though took vengeaunce richer mightie mine enemy bee well know ye money great poſſeſſions beene thing world governed salomon ſayth theſe thing obey money prudence heard husbond avaunt richeſſe money diſpraiſing power adverſaries ſhee ſpake ſaied wiſe certes deare ſir graunt yee bee rich mightie ye richeſſe good hem well gotten hem well uſe right body manne may live without ſoule may live without temporall goodes richeſſe may manne get great friend therefore ſayeth pamphillus nerthes doughter ſayeth rich ſhe may cheſe thouſand menne ſhee woll take husbond thouſand one woll forſake ne refuſe pamphillus ſaith alſo thou right happie ſay thou rich thou ſhalt find great number fellowes friendes thy fortune chaunge farewell friendſhip fellowſhip thou ſhalt alone withouten companie companie poore folke yet ſayeth pamphillus moreover bond thrall linage ſhall made worthy noble richeſſes right ſo richeſſes come many goodneſſes right ſo povertie come many harmes evil great povertie conſtraineth manne doe many evil therefore calleth caſſiodor povertie mother ruine ſay mother overthrowing falling therefore ſayth peter alfonce one ye greateſt adverſities world free man kinde birth conſtrained povertie eate ye almoſe enemie ſame ſayeth innocente one bookes ſayth ſorrowfull miſhap condition poore begger aske meat hee dieth hunger aske dieth ſhame algates neceſſity conſtraineth aske therefore ſayeth salomon better die ſuch povertie ſame saloman ſayth better die bitter death live ſuch wiſe theſe reaſons ſaid unto many reaſons could ſay graunt richeſſes good hem hem well getten hem well uſen tho richeſſes therfore woll ſhew ye ſhall behave gathering rich manner ſhe ſhullen uſe hem firſt yee ſhall get hem withouten great deſire good leiſure ſokingly haſtily manne deſiring get richeſſe habandoneth firſt theft evil therefore ſayeth salomon yt haſteth buſily wexe rich ſhall none innocent ſayeth alſo richeſſe yt haſtily commeth manne ſoone lightly goeth paſſeth man richeſſe commeth little little wexeth alway multiplieth ſir ye ſhall get richeſſe wit trauaile vnto profite without wrong harme perſon law ſayeth maketh manne himſelfe rich hee doe harme another wight ſay nature defendeth forbiddeth right manne maketh himſelfe rich vnto ye harme another perſon tullius ſayth ſorow ne dread death ne nothing may fall vnto man ſo much ayenſt nature man encreaſe owne profite harme another manne though great mightie menne get richeſſes lightly thou yet ſhalt thou bee idle ne ſlowe doe thy profite thou ſhalt wiſe flie idleneſſe salomon ſayth idleneſſe teacheth man doe many evil ſame salomon ſayeth trauaileth buſieth tilthe lond ſhall eat bread idle caſteth buſineſſe ne occupation ſhall fall pouertie die hunger idle ſlow neuer find couenable time doe profite verifier ſayeth ye idle manne excuſeth winter becauſe ye great cold sommer becauſe ye heat theſe cauſes ſayth caton waketh encline ouer much ſleepe ouer much reſt nouriſheth cauſeth many vice therefore ſayeth ſaint hierome ſome good deed yt diuel enemie ne find vnoccupied deuill ne taketh lightly vnto werking ſuch hee findeth occupied good werkes thus getting richeſſes ye muſt flie idleneſſe afterward yee ſhull vſe richeſſes yee haue got wit trauaile ſuch manner men hold ſcarce ne ſparing ne foole large yt ſay ouer large ſpender right men blame auaricious man becauſe ſcarcitie chincherie ſame wiſe blame ſpendeth ouer largely therfore ſaith caton vſe ſayth richeſſes thou haſt gotten ſuch manner men may haue matter ne cauſe call thee nother wretch ne chinche great ſhame man haue poore heart rich purſe hee ſayth alſo good thou haſt gote vſe meaſure ſay ſpend meaſurably fooliſhly waſt diſpend good haue haue proper owne ſhape hem take good another manne ſay ye ſhall flie auarice vſing richeſſe ſuch manner men ſay richeſſes buried yee haue hem might welding wiſe man repreueth auaricious man ſayth thus theſe verſes two whereto burieth manne good great avarice knoweth well need muſt die death end every man preſent life cauſe encheſon joineth knitteth ſo faſt unto good yt al wit mow diſcever ne depart fro good knoweth well ought know dead ſhall nothing bear world therefore ſaith ſaint auguſtine avaricious manne likened unto hell ſwalloweth deſire hath ſwallow devour well yee would eſchew called avaricious man chinche well ſhould yee keepe governe ſuch wiſe menne call foole large therefore ſaith tullius good thine houſe ne ſhould hid ne kept ſo cloſe might opened pity debonairte ſay yeue hem part great need ne thy good ſhould ſo open every mannes good afterward getting richeſſes uſing hem ye ſhall alway three thing heart ſay lord god conſcience good name firſt ye ſhall god heart richeſſe yee ſhould doe thing may manner diſpleaſe god creatour maker ye word salomon better little good love god much good treaſure leſe love lord god prophet ſaith better good manne little good treaſure holden ſhrewe great richeſſe yet ſay furthermore yee ſhould alway doe buſineſſe get richeſſe ſo yee get hem good conſcience ye apoſtle ſayeth ni thing world wee ſhould ſo great joy conſcience beareth u good witneſſe wiſe man ſaith ſubſtaunce man full good ſinne mannes conſcience afterward getting richeſſes uſing hem yee muſt great bnſineſſe great dilligence good name bee alway kept conſerved salomon ſaith better availeth man good name many richeſſes therefore ſayeth another place great diligence ſaith salomon keeping thy friend thy good name ſhall lenger abide thee treaſure never ſo precious certes ſhould called great gentleman god good conſcience thing left ne dooth dilligence buſineſſe keepe good name caſſiodor ſayth ſigne gentle heart manne loveth deſireth good name therefore ſayeth ſaint auguſtine ben two thing right neceſſarie alſo needfull good conſcience good loſe ſay good conſcience thine owne perſon inward good loſe thy neighbour outward hee truſteth ſo much good conſcience hee deſpiſeth ſetteth nought good name loſe recketh though keepe good name ni cruell churle sir haue ſhewed ye ſhuld doe getting richeſſes yee ſhould vſe hem ſee well truſt ye haue richeſſes ye woll moue warre battaile counſaile ye begin warre truſt richeſſes ne ſuffice warres maintaine therefore ſayeth philoſopher man yt deſireth would algates haue warre ſhall neuer haue ſuffiſaunce richer yt greater diſpences muſt make woll haue worſhip victorie salomon ſaith greater rich yt man hath diſpendours hath therfore ſir albeit ſo yt richeſſes ye may haue much folke yet behooueth ne good begin warre whereas ye may manner haue peace vnto worſhip profit victorie battailes yt world lieth great number multitude people ne ye vertue man lieth hond lord god almightie therfore iudas machabeus god knight hee ſhould fight againſt aduerſarie greater number greater multitude folk ſtronget people machabe yet recomforted little companie ſaied right wiſe alſo lightly ſaied may lord god almightie yeue victorie fewe folke many folke victorie battaile commeth ye great number people commeth lorde god heeuen deare ſir much manne certaine worthie god yeue victorie salomon ſayeth therefore euery man ſhould greatly dreade warres begin becauſe yt battels fall many peril happeth ſoone great man ſlaine little man written ye ſecond booke king deed battailes ben adventurous nothing certaine lightly one hurt ſpeare another great perill warre therefore ſhould man flie eſchew warre much man may goodly salomon ſayeth hee loueth perill ſhall fall perill dame prudence ſpoken manner melibe anſwerd ſaid ſee well dame prudence fair word reaſons ye haue ſhewed mee ye warre liketh nothing haue yet heard counſaile ſhall doe need certes ſaid ſhee counſaile ye accorde aduerſaries yee haue peace hem ſaint iames ſayth epiſtle concorde peace ſmall rich wexe great debate diſcorde rich decay yee know well one greateſt moſte ſoueraigne thing world vnity peace therefore ſayeth lord ieſu chriſt apoſtles wiſe well happy beene loue purchaſe peace called child god ah ſaied melibe ſee well ye loue mine honour ne worſhip ye know well mine aduerſaries haue begun debate brige outrage yee ſee well yt ne require ne pray peace ne aſke reconciled woll ye yt goe meeke obey hem crie hem mercie forſoth yt worſhip right men ſay ouer great humblenes engendreth diſpraiſing ſo fareth great humilitie meekeneſſe began dame prudence make ſemblaunt wrathe ſayed certes ſir ſaue grace loue honour profite doe mine owne euer haue doe ye ne none neuer ſee ye contrary yet ſaied yee ſhould haue purchaſed peace reconciliation ne much miſtake mee ne ſaied amiſſe ye wiſe man ſayeth diſcention beginneth another man reconciling beginneth thy ſelfe ye prophet ſaith flie ſhreudneſſe doe goodneſſe ſeeke peace follow much thee yet ſay yee ſhould rather purſue aduerſaries peace ſhould know well ye ben ſo hard hearted ye woll doe nothing salomon ſayth hath ouer hard heart laſt ſhall miſhap misbetide melibe heard dame prudence make ſemblaunt wrath hee ſaied wiſe dame pray yee diſpleaſed thing ſay yee know well angry wroth wonder wroth wote well doe ne ſay therefore ye prophet ſayth troubled eyen haue cleare ſight ſay counſaile liketh ready doe right ye woll deſire ye repreue folly holden loue praiſe salomon ſaith yt repreueth yt doth follie ſhall find greater grace deceiueth ſweete word ſaied dame prudence make ſemblaunt wrath ne anger great profit salomon ſaith wroth repreueth chideth foole follie ſhewing ſemblaunt wrath hee ſupporteth praiſeth misdoing laugheth folly ſame salomon ſaith afterward ſorrowfull viſage man yt ſay ſorie heauie countenance man foole correcteth amendeth himſelfe ſaid melibe ſhall conne aunſwere vnto ſo many faire reaſons ye put ſhew ſay ſhortly counſaile ready performe fulfill dame prudence diſcouered vnto ſaid counſaile ſaid ſhee aboue thing yt ye make peace betweene god bee reconciled vnto grace haue ſaied god hath ſuffred haue tribulation diſeaſe ſinnes yee ſay god woll ſend aduerſaries vnto make hem fall foot ready doe commaundement salomon ſayeth condition man pleaſaunt liking god chaungeth heart man aduerſaries conſtraineth hem beſeech peace grace pray let ſpeake aduerſaries priuely ſhall know will▪ aſſent know entent may counſaile ſurely dame ſaid melibeus doth liking put wholly diſpoſition ordinaunce dame prudence ſhe ſaw good husbond delibered tooke aduiſe ſelfe thinking ſhee might bring need vnto good concluſion good end ſhee ſaw time ſhee ſent theſe aduerſaries come vnto priuie place ſhewed wiſely vnto hem great good come peace great harmes peril warre ſaid hem goodly manner hem ought haue great repentaunce iniurie wrong done melibeus lord vnto doughter heard goodly word dame prudence ſo ſurpriſed rauiſhed ſo great joy hir yt wonder tell ah lady ſaid yee haue ſhewed vnto v bleſſing ſweetneſſe ye ſaying dauid prophet reconſiling worthy haue mannere ought require great contrition humility ye goodneſſe haue preſented vnto v ſee wel yt ſcience cunning salomon full true ſaith ſweet word multiply encreaſe friend maketh ſhrewes debonaire meeke certes ſaid wee put deed matter cauſe wholly good ready obey ye commaundement lord melibeus therefore deere benigne lady wee pray beſeech meekely may like vnto great goodneſſe fulfill indeed goodly wordes wee conſider know wee haue offended greeued lord melibeus meaſure ſo ferforth wee power make amends therefore wee oblige bind v friend commaundement peraduenture hath ſuch heauineſſe ſuch wrath v ward becauſe offence woll enjoyne v ſuch paine wee mowe beare ne ſuſtaine therefore noble ladie wee beſeech womanly pitty take ſuch aduiſement neede wee ne friend diſherited ne deſtroied folly certes ſaid prudence hard thing right perilious man put vtterly arbitration iudgement might power enemie salomon ſayth leueth yeueth credence yt ſhal ſay ne yeueth neuer ye power ne gouernaunce thy good thy ſonne thy wife thy friend ne thy brother ne yeue thou neuer might ne maſtry ouer thy body thou liueſt ſith defendeth man ſhould yeue brother ne friend might body ſtronger reaſon defendeth forbiddeth man yeue himſelf enemy natheleſſe counſaile yee miſtruſt lord wot well know verely debonaire meeke large courteous nothing deſirous ne couetous good ne rich nothing world deſireth ſaue onely worſhip honour furthermore know right ſure yt ſhall nothing doe need without counſaile ſhall ſo werke caſe yt grace lord god ye ſhall reconciled vnto v ſaid one voice worſhipfull lady put v good al fully diſpoſition ready come day liketh vnto nobleſſe limit v aſſigne v make obligation bond ſtrong liketh vnto goodneſſe mow fulfill ye lord melibe dame prudence herd ye anſwer theſe men ſhe bad hem goe ayen priuely ſhe returned lord melibe told ſhe found aduerſaries full repentaunt knowledging full lowly ſinnes treſpas ready ſuffer paine requiring praying mercy pitie ſaid melibe well worthy haue pardon foryeueneſſe ſinne excuſeth ſinne knowledgeth repenteth asking indulgence seneke ſaith remiſſion foryeueneſſe ye confeſſion confeſſionis neighbour innocence therfore aſſent confirme haue peace good nought without ye aſſent friend prudence right glad ioyfull ſaid certes ſir ye haue well goodly anſwerd right ye counſell aſſent help friend yee haue bee ſteered venge make war right ſo without counſaile ſhall ye accord ne haue peace aduerſaries law ſaith nothing ſo good way kind thing vnbound yt ibound dame prudence without delay tarying ſent anone meſſenger kinſfolke olde friendes true wiſe told hem order ye preſence melibe matter aboue expreſſed declared praiſed hem would ſay aduiſe counſaile beſt doe need melibeus friend taken aduiſe deliberation foreſaid matter examined great buſineſſe dilligence yaue full counſaile haue peace reſt melibe ſhould receiue good hert aduerſaries foryeuenes mercy dame prudence herd ye aſſent lord melibe counſaile friend accord entention ſhe wondrouſly glad hart ſaied old prouerbe ſaied ſhe goodneſſe thou maiſt day doe abide ne delay till next day therefore counſayle yee ſend meſſengers ſuch diſcreet wiſe vnto aduerſaries telling hem behalfe yt woll treate peace accord ſhape hem without delay tarrying come vnto v thing perfourmed indeed theſe treſpaſſours repenting folke folly ſay aduerſaries melibeus heard theſe meſſengers ſaied vnto hem right gladde joyfull anſwered full meekely benignely yeelding grace thankes lord melibeus companie ſhope hem without delay goe meſſengers obeyed ye commaundement lord melibeus right anone tooke way court melibe tooke hem ſome true friendes make faith hem borowes comen preſence melibe ſaid hem theſe word ſtondeth thus ſaid melibe ſooth cauſeleſſe without skill reaſon ye haue done great iniuries wrong wife prudence doughter alſo ye haue entred houſe violence haue done ſuch outrage men know well ye haue deſerued death therefore woll know • e whether ye wol put ye puniſhing ye chaſtiſing vengeaunce outrage wife ye woll wiſeſt hem three anſwerd hem ſaid sir ſaid know wel unworthy come court ſo great lorde ſo worthy ye haue ſo greatly miſtaken v haue offended agilted ſuch wiſe againe high lordſhip truely haue deſerued death yet great goodneſſe debonairte worlde witneſſeth perſon wee ſubmit v excellence benignite gracious lordſhip ready obey commandements beſeeching yt mercifull pite ye woll conſider great repentaunce lowe ſubmiſion graunt v forgiueneſſe outragious treſpaſſe offence well know liberall grace mercie ſtretcheth goodnes doen outragious gilt treſpaſſes wickedneſſe bee curſedly damnably haue agilted againſt hie lordſhip melibe tooke hem vp fro ye ground full benignly receiued obligation bondes others vpon pledge borowes aſſigned hem certain day returne vnto court receiue accept ſentence judgement melibeus would command done hem cauſes aforeſayd thing ordained euery man returned houſe dame prudence ſaw time ſhe fained asked lorde belibe vengeance hee thought good aduerſaries melibe anſwerd ſaid certes ſaid hee think purpoſe mee fully diſherite hem euer haue put exile euer certes ſaid dame prudence cruell ſentence much ayenſt reaſon ye rich inough haue neede men rich ye might lightly wiſe get couetous name vicious thing ought eſchewed euery good man ſaying apoſtle couetiſe root harmes therfore better leſe ſo much good owne take good maner better leſe good worſhip winne good villanie ſhame euery man ought diligence buſineſſe get good name yet ſhall hee onely buſie keeping good name ſhall alſo enforce alway doe ſome thing may renew good name written ye olde good loſe man good name ſoone gone paſt renued touching yt yee ſay yee woll exile aduerſaries thinketh much ayenſt reaſon meaſure conſidering power haue yaue vpon ſelfe written worthy loſe priuiledge miſuſeth might power giuen ſet caſe ye might enjoyne hem paine right law trowe ye may ſay yee might put execution peraduenture like turne warre therefore yee woll men doe obeiſaunce ye muſt demeane cuteouſly yt ſay ye muſt yeue moſt eaſie ſentences iudgement written yt moſt courteouſly commandeth men muſt obey therefore pray neceſſitie need ye caſt ye ouercome heart senek ſaith hee yt ouercommeth heart ouercommeth twiſe tullie ſaith nothing ſo commendable great lord debonaire meek appeaſeth lightly pray ye woll forbeare vengeaunce ſuch manner yt good name may kept conſerued men may haue cauſe matter praiſe pite mercy yt ye haue cauſe repent thing done seneke ſaieth ouercommeth euill maner yt repenteth victory wherefore pray let mercy hert effect entent god almightie haue mercy vpon laſt iudgment ſaint iames ſaith epiſtle iudgement without mercy ſhall doe yt hath mercy another wight melibe heard great skilles reaſons dame prudence wiſe information teaching heart gan encline ye wife conſidering true entent confirmed anon aſſented fully worke counſaile thanked god proceedeth goodneſſe vertue ſent wife ſo great diſcretion day came aduerſaries ſhould appeare preſence hee ſpake hem goodly ſaid wiſe ſo pride high preſumption follie negligence vnconning yee haue misborne treſpaſſed vnto mee yet mikell ſee behold great humilitie ye ſory repentant giltes conſtraineth mee doe grace mercy wherefore receiue grace foryeue holy offence iniuries wronges yee haue doen ayenſt mee mine theffect ende god endles mercie woll time dying foryeue v giltes haue treſpaſſed wretched world doubtleſſe ſory repentant ſinnes giltes haue treſpaſſed ſight lorde god hee ſo free ſo merciable woll foryeue v giltes bring v bliſſe neuer ſhall haue end amen ¶the monkes prologue ended tale melibee prudence benignite hoſt ſaide faithfull man precious corp madrian leuer barell ale goodlefe wife heard tale ſhe nothing ſuch patience melibeus wife prudence god bone bete knaues bringeth great clubbed ſtaues cryeth ſlee dog euerichone break backe bone neighbour mine woll church wife incline bee ſo hardie treſpace ſhe cometh home ſhe rampeth face cryeth falſe coward wreke thy wife corpus domini woll haue thy knife thou ſhalt haue diſtaffe go ſpin fro day till night ſhe woll thus begin ala ſhe ſaith euer ſhe ſhape wed milkeſop coward ape woll ouerleide euery wight thou dareſt ſtond thy wiues right life woll fight doore anone mote dight el loſt like wilde lion foole hardy wote well ſhe woll doe ſlee ſome day neighbour go way perillous knife honde dare withſtonde ſhe bigge armes faith ſhall finde misdoth ſaith let v paſſe away mattere lord ſaid ſir monk mery chere ye ſhall tell v tale truely lo rocheſter ſtondeth faſt ride forth mine lord breke game troth know name wheder ſhall call lord dan iohn dan thomas dan robert dan albon houſe ye father kin vow god thou haſt full faire chin gentle paſture thou goſt thou art like pinaunt ghoſt vpon faith thou art ſome officere worthy sexten ſome celerere father ſoule dome thou art maiſter thou art home poore cloiſterer ne poore nouice gouernour ware wiſe therewithall brawne bone well faring perſon none pray god yeue confuſion firſt thee brought religion thou woldeſt trede foule aright hadſt thou great leaue thou haſt might performe thy luſt ingendrure thou haddeſt begotten many creature ala weareſt thou ſo wide cope god yeue ſorow pope onely thou euery mightie man though ſhore high vpon pan haue wife world lorn religion hath take vp corn treding borell men ben ſhrimps feble tree ther commeth wretched imp maketh heires ſo ſlender feeble yt may well engender make wiues woll aſſay religious folke may pay venus payment better mow god wote luſſheburghs payen ye wroth lord though play full oft game ſooth haue heard ſay worthy monke took al patience ſaid woll diligence ferre ſouneth honeſtie tell tale ye two three ye liſt herken hitherward woll ſaine life ſaint edward el tragidies firſt woll tell haue hundred cell tragedie tell certaine ſtory old bookes v maken memorie hem ſtood great proſperitie fallen hie degree miſerie ended wretchedly ben verſified commonly ſix foot men call exemetron proſe eke ben endighted many mitre many ſundry wiſe lo ought inough ſuffice herkeneth liſt firſt beſeech matere though order tell theſe thing pope emperours king age men written finde tell hem ſome ſome behinde commeth remembrance haue excuſed mine ignorance ¶the monkes tale tragical diſcourſe ſuch haue fallen high eſtate extream miſery bewaile manner tragedie harme hem yt ſtode high degree fell ſo na remedie bring hem aduerſitie certaine fortune liſt flie ther may man ye courſe witholde let man truſt blinde proſperitie beth ware enſample yong olde lucifer lucifer though angell man begin though fortune may nat angell dere high degree yet fell ſinne hell yet inne lucifer brighteſt angel art thou sathanas thou maiſt twin miſerie thou art fall adam lo adam field damaſcene god owne finger iwrought begotten man ſperm vncleane welt paradiſe ſauing tree neuer worldly man ſo high degree adam till miſgouernance driuen high proſperitie labour hell miſchance sampſon lo sampſon annunciat angell long natiuitie god almightie conſecrat ſtode noble might ſee neuer ſuch another ſpeake ſtrength thereto hardineſſe wiues told ſecree ſlough wretchedneſſe sampſon noble mighty champion withouten weapon ſaue hand twey ſlough rent lion toward wedding walking wey falſe wife coulde ſo pleaſe pray till ſhe counſaile knewe ſhe vntrew vnto foe counſaile gan bewray forſoke tooke another new hundred fox tooke sampſon yre tailes hee together bond ſet fox tailes fire euery taile hath put brond brent corne lond oliues vine eke thouſand men eke ſlough hond weapen aſſe cheke ſlaine ſo thriſted yt well lorne gan prey god wold paine haue ſome pite ſend drinke el mote dey aſſe cheke ſo drey wang toth ſprang anon well drunke inough ſhortly ſey thus halp god iudicum tell force gaſa night maugre philiſtins cite gate town hath vp plight backe icaried hem hath high hill men might hem ſe noble mightie sampſon lefe dere thou told woman thy ſecre world ne thy pere sampſon neither ſider drank ne wine ne head came raſour none ne ſhere precept meſſenger diuine ſtrength haires fully twenty winter yere yere iſrael gouernance ſoon ſhall weep many tere woman ſhall bring miſchance vnto lemman dalida told haires ſtrength lay falſely foe ſhe ſold ſleeping barme vpon day made clip ſhere haires away made fomen craft eſpien found ſuch aray bound faſt put eyen er haires clipped iſhaue ther na bond men might bind priſon caue whereas made ye querne grinde noble sampſon ſtrongeſt mankind whildom iudge glory rich nowe mayeſt thou weepen thine eyen blind sith thou art wele fall wretchedneſſe end caitife ſhall ſey fomen made feaſt vpon day made foole hem play temple great aray laſt made foule afray two pillers ſhoke made hem fall fell temple lay ſlough himſelfe eke fomen ſay prince euerichone eke three thouſand body ther ſlain falling great temple ſtone sampſon woll ſain beth ware example old plain men tell counſaile wiues ſuch thing would haue ſecret fain touch limmes liues hercules hercules ſoueraigne conquerour singen werkes laud high renown time ſtrength bare ye flower ſlough raft skinne lion centaur laid boſte adowne harpia ſlew cruell bird fell golden apple raft fro dragon drew cerberus hound hell ſlew cruell tirant buſirus made horſe fret fleſh bone ſlough ſerpent venemous achelous two horne brake one ſlew cacus caue ſtone ſlough gyant antacus ſtrong ſlough griſely bore anon bare head vpon ſpeare long neuet wight ſith world began ſlough ſo many monſters throughout wide world name ran ſtrength wt bounte euery realme went ſee ſo ſtrong yt man might let world end trophe ſtede bound braſſe pillour ſet lemman noble champion hight deianire freſh maie theſe clerkes maken mention hath ſent ſhert freſh gaie ala ſhert ala well awaie envenomed ſubtilly withall er weared halfe day made fleſh fro bone fall natheleſſe ſome clerkes excuſen one hight neſſus maked may woll accuſen body ſhert al naked till fleſh venim ſlaked ſaw non remedie hote cole hath himſelfe iraked venim dained die thus ſterfe worthy mighty hercules lo may truſt fortune throw foloweth world pres beware oft laid full lowe full wiſe himſelfe know beware fortune liſt gloſe waiteth ſhe man downe throwe ſuch way would leaſt ſuppoſe nabuchodonoſor mightie trone precious treſore glorious ſcepter royall maieſtie hath king nabuchodonoſore tonge vnneth may diſcriued twiſe wan hieruſalem cite veſſell temple lad babilon ſoueraigne ſee glorie delight hieruſalem gelde anon fayreſt child blood royall make hem thrall among daniel one wiſeſt euerichone dremes king expouned whereas caldee clerkes none wiſt fine dreme ſounded proude king let make ſtatu gold sixty cubites long ſeuen brede image young old commanded lout haue drede forneis ful flame rede ſhould deed would obey neuer would aſſent dede daniel ne yong felowes twey king king ſo proud elate weend god ſitteth maieſtie ne might nat berefe eſtate ſodainly loſt dignitie like beaſt ſeemed ete hey oxe lay therout raine wilde beaſts walked till certaine time come like egles fethers heeres neiles alſo like bird clawes god releeued certaine yeeres yaue wit many tere thonked god life fere doe amiſſe treſpace ere layed bere knew god ful might grace balthaſer ſonne high balthaſare held ye reign faders day fader could beware proude heart array eke ydolaſter aie high eſtate aſſured pride fortune caſt downe lay ſuddainly reigne gan deuide feaſt made vnto lord vpon time made hem blith officer gan call goth bring forth veſſels qd father proſperitie temple hieruſalem beraft god thonkes yelden honour elder v laft wife lord concubine aie drunken while appetite laſt theſe noble veſſels foundrie wine wall king eyen caſt •• ſaw hond armeleſſe wrote faſt feare quoke ſighed ſore hond balthaſer made ſore agaſt wrote mane techel phares al londe magicien ther non could expoune letter ment daniel expouned anon ſaid king god thy father ſent glory honour reign treſour rent proud nothing god drad therfore great wrath god vpon ſent beraft reigne caſt man company aſſes habitation eate haie beaſt wete drie till knew wit reaſon god heauen hath domination ouer euery reigne euery creature god compaſſion reſtored reigne figure eke thou yt art ſonne art proud alſo knoweſt theſe thing priuely art rebell god fo thou dranke eke veſſels boldly thy wife eke thy wench ſinfully dronke ſame veſſels ſundry winis heried falſe god curſedly therefore thee ſhapen great pine hond ſent fro god yt wal wrote mane techel phares truſt thy reigne doen thou woteſt diuided thy realme ſhall medes perciens giuen qd ſame night king ſlaw darius occupied dignitie though thereto neither right ne law lordings enſample mowe ye take lordſhip ſikerneſſe fortune woll man forſake beareth away reigne richeſſe friend leſſe man hath friend throgh fortune miſhap woll make hem enemy geſſe prouerbe full ſoth full commune zenobia zenobia palmerie queene writeth perciens nobleſſe worthy armes ſo kene wight paſſed hardineſſe ne linage ne gentilneſſe king blood perce ſhe diſcended ſay ſhe moſt faireneſſe ſhape ſhee might amended childhood find ſhe fled office woman wood ſhe went many wilde harte blood ſhe ſhed arrowes broad ſhe hem ſent ſo ſwift ſhe hem hent ſhe elder ſhe would kill lion libards beeres rent armes weld hem durſt wild beaſts dennes ſeeke renne mountaines night ſleepe vnder buſh ſhe could eke wraſtell force might yong man neuer ſo wight might nothing armes ſtond kept maidenhead euery wight man dained ſhe bound laſt friendes hath maried odenat prince countrie ſo ſhe hem long taried ye ſhall vnderſtond ſuch fantaſies like ſhe natheles knit fere liued joy felicite ech hem lefe dere saue one thing ſhee nolde neuer aſſent way ſhould lie one plaine entent haue childe world multiply alſo ſo ſone ſhe might eſpie ſhe child deed would ſhe ſuffer fantaſie eftſones one dreed ſhe child caſt ſhould play game till fully fourtie dayes paſt would ſhe one ſuffer ſame odenat wild tame gate thus ſhe ſaied wiues letcherie ſhame caſe men hem plaied two ſonnes odenat ſhe ſhe kept vertue lettrure vnto tale againe turne ſay ſo worſhipfull creature wiſe therewith large meaſure penible warre curteis eke ne labour might war endure non though world men wold ſeek rich aray ne might told well veſſell clothing clad pierrie gold eke ſhe left none hunting haue ſundry tongue full knowing ſhe leiſure entend learne bookes liking ſhe vertue life might diſpend ſhortly ſtorie treat doughtie husbond ſhe conquered many reignes great orient many faire cite appertainaunt vnto maieſtie rome ſtrength held mfull faſt ne neuer might foeman doe fle odinates dayes laſt battailes ſo liſt hem rede againe sapor king mo proces fill dede ſhe conquered title therto miſchiefe wo ſhe beſieged itake let maiſter petrarke go writeth ynough vndertake odenat dead ſhe mightily realmes held owne honde ayenſt foe ſhe fought ſo truely ther na prince ne king ye lond full glad grace fond ſhe ne ſhould vpon londe warrey made aliaunce bond peace let hem ride pley emperour rome claudius ne beforne romain galien ne durſt neuer ſo coragious ne non armen ne non egipcien ne surrien ne none arabien within field durſt fight leſt yt ſhe would hem hondes ſleen maine put hem flight king habite wenten ſonnes two lawfull heires realmes hermanno titamallo name perciens hem call aie fortune hath honie gall mightie queene may endure fortune reigne made fall wretchedneſſe miſauenture aurelian gouernance rome came honds twey ſhope vpon queene vengeance legion tooke way toward zenobia ſhortly ſay made flie laſt hent fettered eke child tway wan land home rome went emongeſt thing wan chair gold wrought pierre great romaine aurelian hath lad men ſhould ſee beforne triumph walked ſhe golden chaines necke honging crowned ſhe degre full pierre charged clothing ala fortune ſhe whilom dredefull king emperours gaureth people ala ſhe helmed ſtark ſtoures wan force townes ſtrong toures shall head weare autremite ſhe bare ſepter full floures shall beare diſtafe coſt quite nero although nero vicious fende lieth full low adown yet telleth v suetonius world ſubiectioun eaſt weſt septentrioun ruby saphires perles white clothes broudred vp gemmes greatly gan delite delicate pompous aray proude neuer emperour like cloth weared day time nold neuer ſee nettes golde threde great plente fiſh tiber liſt play luſts law degre fortune friend would obay rome brent dilicacie senatours ſlue vpon day heare wiues would weepe crie ſlow brother ſiſter lay mother made pitous aray wombe let ſlit behold conceiued ſo welaway ſo little mother told teares eyen ſight came ſaied faire woman ſhe great wonder coud might domiſman dead beaute wine bring commaunded dranke anon none wo made might joined vnto cruelte ala deepe venume wade youth maiſter emperour teach lettrure courteſie moralite flour time bookes lie while maiſter maiſtrie made ſo cunning ſo ſouple long time tyrannie vice durſt encouple senek maiſter deuiſe becauſe nero ſuch drede vice would chaſtiſe diſcreetly word dede sir would ſay emperour mote nede vertuous hate tyrannie made bathe blede armes till muſt die nero eke cuſtomaunce youth ayenſt maiſter riſe afterward thought great grevaunce becauſe often would chaſtiſe therefore made die wiſe choſe bathe die manere rather another turmentiſe thus hath nero ſlaine maiſter dere fell ſo fortune liſt longer high pride nero cheriſhe tho ſtrong yet ſhe ſtronger thought thus god nice ſet man fulfilled vice high degree emperour call god ſeat woll trice leaſt weneth ſooneſt ſhall fall people roſe upon night defaut aſpied dores anon hath dight alone wend allied knocked faſt aye cried faſter ſhet dores tho wiſt well himſelfe beguiled went way lenger durſt call people cried rombled ear heard ſaied falſe tyrant neroun feare full neere wit braied god right pitouſly praied ſuccour might betide drede thought deid ran garden hide garden found chorles twey sitting fire great red chorles two gan prey ſlea gird hed body ded deſpite done defame himſelfe ſlough could better red fortune lough game holofernes neuer capitaine vnder king reignes mo put ſubjectioun ne ſtronger field thing time ne greater renoun ne pompous high preſumptioun holoferne fortune aye kiſt ſo licourouſ • lad doun till dead ere wiſt onely yt world awe leſing richeſſe liberte made euery man renie lawe nabuchodonoſor lord ſaied none god ſhould honoured ayenſt heſt dare wight treſpace saue bethulia ſtrong cite eliachem prieſt place take keepe death holoferue amid hoſt dronke lay night within tent large berue yet pompe might iudith woman lay vpright sleeping head ſmote fro tent full priuely ſhe ſtole euery wight head vnto toun ſhe went antiochus needeth king antiochus tell high roiall maieſte great pride worke venemus ſoch another man na neuer redeth machabe redeth proud wordes ſeid fill proſperite hill wretchedly deid fortune enchaunſed ſo pride verily wend might attain vnto ſterres vpon euerie ſide balaunce wey mountain floudes ſea reſtrain god people moſt hate hem would ſlea torment pain wening god ne might pride abate nichanore timothe iews venquiſhed mightily vnto iewes ſoch hate greithe chare full haſ • ely ſwore ſaied full diſpitouſly vnto hieruſalem would eftſone wrecke yre full cruelly purpoſe let full ſone god manace ſo ſore ſmote inuiſible wound aie incurable guttes carfe ſo bote paine importable certainly wreche reaſonable many man guttes paine purpoſe curſed damnable ſmert nolde reſtrain bade anon aparaile hoſt ſodainly ware god daunted pride boſt ſo ſore fell chare limmes ſkinne tare might go ne ride chaire men bare forbruiſed backe ſide wreche god ſmote ſo cruelly bodie wicked wormes crept therewithall ſtanke ſo horribly none meine kept whether woke el ſlept ne might ſtinke endure miſchief wayled wept knew god lord euerie creature hoſt himſelfe alſo full lothſome ſtinke caraine man might beare ne fro ſtinke horrible paine ſterfe full wretchedly mountaine thus hath robber homicide many man made wepe plaine soch guerdon belongeth pride alexander ſtorie alexander ſo commune every wight hath diſcretioun hath heard ſomwhat fortune wide world concluſioun wan ſtrength renoun glad peace unto ſend pride man boſt layed adown ſo came vnto world end compariſon might yet never maked betwixt another conquerour al world dread hath quaked knighthood freedome floure fortune made heir high honour saue wine woman nothing might aſſuage high intent armes labour full loving courage price wer though told darius hundred thouſand mo prince earles knight bold conquered brought wo ſay ferre man may ride go world wt ſhuld deviſe though wrote told evermo knighthood might ſuffice twelve yere raigned rede machabe phillips ſonne macedone firſt king grece countre worthy gentle alexander ala ever ſhould thee fall ſoch caſe empoiſoned thy folke thou thy ſice fortune hath turned ace yet thee ne wept ſhe never tere ſhall yeve men teres complaine death gentleneſſe fraunchiſe world welded demaine yet thought might ſuffice full courage high empriſe ala ſhall helpe endite falſe fortune poyſon deſpiſe woe wite iulius ceſar wiſedome manhood high labour humble bed royal majeſte vp roſe iulius conquerour occident lond ſee wan ſtrength honde elſe trete unto rome made tributarie ſith rome emperour till fortune wexe adverſarie mighty ceſar theſſaly ayenſt pompey father thine law orient chivalry ferre day beginneth daw knighthood haſt take iſlaw saue folke pompeius fled thou put orient aw thanke fortune ſo well thee yſped little woll bewaile pompey noble governour rome fled battaile ſay one men falſe traitour head ſmote win favour iulius head brought ala pompey orient conquerour fortune vnto ſuch fine thee wrought rome againe repaireth iulius triumph lauriate full hie time brutus caſſius ever high eſtate envie full prively made conſpiracie ayenſt iulius ſubtil wiſe caſt place ſhould die bodkin ſhall deuiſe iulius unto capitoll went vpon day wont gone capitoll anon hent fals brutus ſone ſticked bodkin anone many wound thus let lie never grutched ſtroke one elſe two ſtorie lie manly iulius hart ſo well loved ſtately honeſte tho deadly wound ſo ſore ſmart mantle hip yet caſt man ſhould ſee privite lay dying traunce wiſt verily die ſhould honeſtie yet remembraunce lucan thee ſtorie recommend sueton valerie alſo ſtorie writen word end theſe great conquerours two fortune firſt friend ſith fo man truſt upon favour long await euermo witneſſe conquerours ſtrong creſus rich creſus whilom king lide creſus cirus ſore drad yet caught amid pride brenne men fire lad ſuch rain fro firmament ſhad queint fire made ſcape beware yet grace till fortune gallows made gape eſcaped could ſtint begin new aray wend well fortune ſent hap eſcaped rain foe might ſlain eke ſweven upon night met ſo proud eke ſo fain vengeaunce heart ſet vpon tree thought iupiter wisſhe back ſide phebus eke faire towell brought dry therwith wexe pride doughter ſtood beſide yt knew hie ſentence habound bad tell ſignified ſhe dreame right thus expound tree qd ſhe yt gallows meane iupiter betokeneth ſnow rain phebus towell ſo cleane betokeneth sun beames ſooth ſain thou ſhalt honged father certain raine ſhall thee waſh ſun ſhall thee drie thus warned full plat full plain doughter called phanie honged creſus proud king roiall throne might auaile tragedie none ne manner thing ſinging crie ne bewaile fortune day woll aſſaile unware ſtroke ye reignes yt proud men truſteth wol ſhe faile couer bright face cloud peter spaine noble worthy petro glory spain fortune held ſo high majeſtie well ought men thy pitous death complain thy lond thy brother made thee flee ſiege ſubteltee thou betraied lad unto tent owne hond ſlue thee succeeding thy reigne thy rent field ſnow thegle black therin caught ye limrod coloured ye glede brewed curſedneſſe ſinne wicked neſte werker dede charles ne oliver yt tooke aye hede trouth honour armorike genillion oliver corrupt mede brought worthy king ſuch brike petro king cipre worthy petro king cipre alſo alexandrie wan high maiſtrie full many heathen wroughteſt thou wo thine liege enuie thing thy chiualrie thy bed han ſlain thee morow thus fortune whele governe gie joy bringen men ſorow barnabo vicount millaine great barnabo vicounte god delite ſcourge lumbardie ſhould thine infortune account sen eſtate thou clomben ſo high thy brother ſonne yt thy double alie thy nevew ſonne lawe within priſon made thee die ne yt thou ſlawe hugeline piſe erle hugeline piſe ye langoure may tongue tell pite little piſe ſtont toure toure priſon put bene little child three eldeſt ſcarſely five yere age ala fortune great cruelte bird put ſuch cage damned die priſon roger biſhop piſe made falſe ſuggeſtion ye people gan upon riſe put priſon ſuch wiſe ye heard meat drinke ſmall unneth may ſuffice therewithall full poore bad day befell houre whan yt meat wont brought geilour ſhette doores toure heard well ſpake right nought heart anon fill thought hunger would doe dien ala qd ala wrought therewithall teares fill fro eyen yong ſonne thre yere age vnto ſaid father doe ye wepe geilour bring potage morſell bread ye kepe ſo hungrie may ſleepe would god might ſleepe ever ſhould hunger wombe crepe ni nothing bread yt lever thus day day childe began cry till father arme adowne lay ſaid farewell father mote die kiſt father deide ſame day wofull father ſey wo armes two gan bite ſaid ala fortune well away thy falſe whele wo may wite child wend hunger armes gnewe wo ſaied father doe ſo ala rather eat fleſh upon u two fleſh yaue u take fleſh u fro eate inough right thus ſeid within day two laid hem lap adoun deid thus ended mighty earle piſe himſelfe diſpeired eke hunger ſtarfe tragedie ought inough ſuffice high eſtate fortune away carfe ſo woll heare longer wiſe readeth great poete itaile hight dante deuiſe fro point point word woll faile ¶here ſtinteth knight monke tale followeth prologue nonnes prieſt ho qd ye knight good ſir ye ſaid right ynough iwis mokell little heavineſſe right ynough much folke geſſe ſay great diſeaſe men wealth eaſe heare ſuddaine fall ala contrary joy ſolas man hath poore eſtate climbeth wexeth fortunate abideth proſperite thing gladſome thinketh ſuch thing good tell ye qd hoſt saint poules bell ye ſay right ſoth monke clappeth loud ſpake fortune covered cloud wote alſo tragedie right heard perde remedie bewailen ne complaine done al paine ye ſaid heare heavineſſe sir monke ſo god bleſſe tale anoyeth companie talking worth butterflie therein diſport ne game therefore ſir monk dan pier name pray heartily tell u ſomewhat el ſikerly nere clinking bel bridle honge every ſide heaven king u dide ſhould ere han fall ſlepe although flough never ſo depe tale tolde vaine certainely theſe clerkes ſaine man may none audience nought helpeth tell ſentence well wote ſubſtaunce thing ſhall well reported sir ſay ſomwhat hunting pray ne qd monke luſt play let another tell told ſpake hoſt rude ſpeech bold ſaied unto nonnes prieſt anon com nere prieſt com hither thou ſir iohn tell u ſuch thing may herts glad blithe though thou ride upon jade though thy horſe foule lene woll ſerve thee recke bene looke thy heart mery evermo yes ſir qd yes hoſt ſo mote go mery iwis woll blamed right anon tale hath attained thus ſaid unto u everichon ſweet prieſt goodly man ſir iohn ¶the nonnes prieſt tale cock hen moral whereof embrace true friend beware flatterer poore widdowe ſomdele iſtept age whilom dwelling poor cotage beſide grove ſtonding dale widowe tell tale sen day ſhe laſt wife patience led full ſimple life little cattell rent husbandry ſuch god ſent found ſelf eke doughters two three large ſowes ſhe mo three kine eke ſheep hight mall well ſooty boure eke hall ſhe ete many ſlender mele poinant ſauce ne knew ſhe never adele ne deinty morſell paſſed throte diet accordaunt cote repletion ne made never ſicke temperate diet phyſicke exerciſe heart ſuffiſaunce gout let nothing daunce ne apoplexie ſhent hed wine dranke ſhe white ne red bord moſt ſerved white black milk broun breed ſhe found lack seinde bacon ſometime eye twey ſhe manner dey yerd ſhe encloſed ſtickes drie diched without ſhe cock hight chaunteclere land crowing na pere voice merrier ye merry orgon maſſe day church gon well ſikerer crowing loge clocke abbey orloge nature knew ech aſſentioun equinoctiall toun degree xv aſcended crew might amended combe redder fine corall battelled caſtle wall bill blacke jet ſhone like aſ • leg tone nailes whiter lilly flour like burned gold colour gentle cocke governaunce seven hen done pleaſaunce ſuſters paramour wonder like colour faireſt hewed throte called faire damoſell pertelote fethered hundred time day ſhe pleaſeth ever ſhe may curteis ſhe diſcreet debonaire compenable bare ſelf ſo faire sen time ſhe ſevennight old truliche ſhe hath hert hold chaunteclere looking every lith loveth ſo yt wel therwith ſuch joy heare ſing bright ſunne gan ſpring ſweet accord lefe ferre lond time underſtond beaſts bird coulden ſpeake ſing ſo fell dawning chaunteclere among wife sat perch hall next ſat faire pertelote chanteclere gan grone throte man yt dreme drenched ſore yt pertelot thus herd rore agaſt ſaid heart dere aileth grone manere ye ſleper fie ſhame answered thus god madame pray ye take griefe god mette ſuch miſchiefe right yt yet mine hert ſore afright god qd ſweven hede right keepe body foule priſoun mette romed within yerde wher ſaw beeſt like hound would made areeſt vpon body would deed colour betwixt yellow reed tipped taile eeres black unlike ye remnant heeres ſnout ſmall glowing eyen twey yet looke almoſt feare dey cauſeth groning doubtles away qd ſhe fie ſhame heartleſſe ala qd ſhe god ye loſt heart love cannot love cowarde faith certes ſo woman ſaith deſire might husbonds hardy wiſe free diſcrete ne niggard ne foole ne agaſt every toole ne none avauntour god durſt ye ſay ſhame unto love ſweven might make aferde ye man heart berde ala con ye aferd ſwevenis nothing bnt vanitie god wotte ſweven swevens ben engendred replecions oft fume complecions humour ben habundant wight certes dreme wch ye met night commeth great ſuperfluitie red color parde cauſen folke dred dreames arrowes fire red lemes red beaſts wollen hem bite conteke waſps great lite right humour melancholie cauſeth many man ſleepe cry feare great bulles beres blake el black devills woll hem take humour could tell alſo werke man ſlepe much wo woll paſſe lightly lo caton yt ſo wiſe man said thus force dreames ſir qd ſhe flie fro bemes god love taketh ſome laxative vp pexill ſoule life counſell beſt woll lie collor melancholie ye purge ye ſhull tarie though town none apotecarie ſhall ſelfe two herbes techen ſhall heale prow yerde tho hearbs ſhall finde propertie kinde purge bineth eke forgetteth god owne love ye right colericke complection ware ſunne aſcention ne finde ye repleate humour hote dare wel lay grote ye ſhall fever terciane el ague may bane day two ye ſhall digeſtives wormes ye take • axatives laurel centorie femetere el elder berry grow catapuce gaitres bereis yvie growing yard merry plucke hem grow eat hem merry husbond father kin dredeth dreme ſay madame qd gramercy lore natheleſſe touching dan caton wiſedome hath ſo great renoun though dreames drede god men may old bookes rede many man authoritie ever caton ſo mote thee revers ſaith ſentence well found experience dreames ſignifications well joy tribulation folke endure life preſent nedeth make non argument prefe ſheweth indeed one greateſt authours yt men rede saith thus yt whilome two fellowes went pilgrimage full good intent happed ſo came town ſuch congregatioun people eke ſtrait herbigage ne found much cottage might ylodged wherefore mote neceſſite night depart company hem goeth hoſtelry tooke lodging would fall one hem lodged ſtall farre yerd ox plough man lodged well ynough aventure fortune u governeth commune ſo befell long day man met bed lay fellow gan upon call ſaid ala ox ſtall night ſhall murdered lie helpe dere brother die haſt come ſaid man ſleep fear abraid waked ſleeye turned tooke keepe thought dreame vanite thus twiſe ſleepe dreamed third time yet felaw came thought ſaid ſlaw behold bloudy wound deepe wide ariſe earely morrow tide weſt gate toun qd hee cart full dung ſhalt thou ſee body hid full prively doe thou cart arreſten boldely gold cauſed death ſooth ſaine told every point ſlaine full pitous face pale hew truſt wel dreme found right trew morrow ſoone day fellowes inne tooke way came ox ſtall fellow began call hoſteler anſwerd anone ſaid ſir fellow igone ſoone day went toun man gan fall ſuſpectioun remembring dreames mette forth goeth lenger would lette vnto weſt gate toune fond dung cart dung lond araied ſame wiſe ye haue heard dead man deuiſe hardy heart gan crie vengeaunce iuſtice fellonie fellow murdred ſame night cart lieth gaping vpright crie miniſters qd ſhoulden keepe rule cite harow ala lieth fellow ſlaine ſhould tale ſaine people ſtart caſt ye cart ground middle dung found dead man murdred new blisfull god art ſo good trew lo thou bewrayeſt murder alway murder woll ſee day day murder ſo waltſome abhominable god ſo juſt reaſonable ne woll ſuffer hylled bee though abide yeare two three murder woll concluſioun right anon miniſters toun haue hent carter ſore pined eke hoſteler ſo ſore engined knew wickedneſſe anone honged vp necke bone may ye ſee dremes ben drede certes ſame lefe rede right next chapter gabbe ſo haue joy blis two men would haue paſſed ouer ſee certaine cauſes ferre countree wind ne contrarie made hem city tarie ſtood full merry vpon hauen ſide day ayenſt euen tide wind gan chaunge blew hem leſt iolly glad wenten reſt caſt hem full early ſaile herken one man fell great meruaile one hem ſleeping lay mette wonder dreme day thought man ſtood bed ſide commaunded ſhould abide ſaid thus thou morrow wend thou ſhal dreint tale end woke told fellow wt met praied voyage let day prayed abide fellow lay bed ſide gan laugh ſcorned full faſt dreme qd may ſo hart agaſt woll let doe thing ſet ſtraw thy dreaming ſweuens vanity yapes men meten day oules ape eke many maſe therewithall dremen thing neuer ne ſhall ſith ſee thou wolt abide thus ſlouthen wilfully thy tide god wot rueth haue good day thus tooke leue went way ere halfe courſe yſailed ne miſchaunce ailed caſuelly ſhips bottome rent ſhip men vnder water went ſight ſhips beſide hem ſailed ſame tide therefore faire pertelot ſo dere ſuch enſamples old maiſt thou lere man ſhould recheleſſe dremes ſay thee doubtleſſe many dreme full ſore drede lo life ſaint kenelme rede kenelphus ſonne noble king mercenryke kenelm mette thing little ere murdred deie murder viſion ſeie norice expouned euery dele ſweuen bad keepe wele fro treaſon ſeuen yere old therefore little tale thereof told dreame ſo holy hert god rather ſhert ye haue herd legend haue dame pertelot ſay truly macrobius writeth auiſion affrick worthy scipion affirmeth dremes ſayeth warning thing ſeen furthermore pray looketh well old teſtament daniel held dreames vanitee reade eke ioſeph ſhall ye ſee whether dremes ben ſometime ſay warning thing ſhall fall looke egipt king yt hight pharao baker butteler alſo wheder felt none effect dremes ſo woll ſeeke act ſundry remes may rede dreames many wonder thing lo creſus lide king mette ſat vpon tree ſignified ſhould honged bee lo andromacha hector wife day hector ſhould leſe life dreamed ſame night beforne life hector ſhould lorne day went vnto battaile warned might auaile went fight neuertheleſſe ſlaine anone achilles tale long tell eke nigh day may dwell shortely ſay concluſion ſhall haue auiſion aduerſity ſay furthermore ne tell laratiues ſtore ben venomous wot wele hem defie loue hem neuer adele let v ſpeke mirth ſtint madame perrelot ſo haue blis one thing god hath ſent large grace ſee beautie face ye ben ſo ſcarlet red eyen maketh dread dien ſo ſiker principio mulier eſt hominis confuſio madame ſentence latine woman man joy blis fele night ſoft ſide albeit may ride perch made ſo narrow ala ſo full joy ſolas defie ſweuen dreme yt word flew doun fro beme day eke hennes chucke gan hem call found corne lay yerd royall aferd feddred pertelot twenty time trode eke oft ere prime looketh grim lioun toe romed vp doun deigned ſet foot ground chucked corne yfound ran wiues royall prince hall leaue chaunteclere poſture woll tell aduenture y• month world began yt hight march god firſt made man complete paſſed alſo sith march began thirtie dayes two befell chaunteclere pride ſeven wiues walking beſide caſt vp eyen bright ſunne ſigne taurus irunne twenty degree one ſomewhat knew kind none lore yt prime crew blisfull ſteuen ſunne ſaid clombe vp heuen forty degree one ſomewhat iwis madame pertelot world blis herken theſe blisfull bird ſing ſee freſh floures gan ſpring full mine heart reueli ſollas ſuddainely fell ſorrowfull caas euer latter end joy wo god wote worldly joy ſoone ago rethore coud faire endite chronicle might ſafely write ſoueraine notabilite euery wiſe man herken ſtory ſo true vndertake booke launcelot du lake woman holden full great reuerence woll turne ayen ſentence col foxe full ſleight iniquitee groue wonned yeares three high imagination aforne caſt ſame night hedge braſt yerd chaunteclere faire wont eke wiues repaire bed wortes ſtill lay till paſſed vndren day waiting time chaunteclere fall gladly done theſe homicide await lie murder men falſe murder rucking thy den new scariot new gauilion falſe diſſimuler greeke sinon broughteſt troy vtterly ſorrow chaunteclere accurſed morrow thou thy yerd flew bemes thou full well warned thy dremes ilke day perillous thee yt god afore wote muſt need bee opinion certaine clerkis witneſſe clerk ſchole great altercation matter great diſputation hath hundred thouſand men ne cannot boult bren holy doctour ſaint auſtin boece biſhop bradwardin whether god worthy foreweting straineth needly doe thing needly clepe ſimple neceſſite free choice graunted ſame thing nought though god forewot wrought weting ſtreineth neuer dele neceſſitie condicionele woll haue done ſuch matere tale cocke ye ſhall took counſaile wife ſorrow walke yerd vpon morrow met dreme told woman counſailes often full cold woman counſaile brought v firſt wo made adam fro paradice go full merry well eaſe might diſpleaſe counſaile woman would blame paſſe ouer ſaid game redeth author trete ſuch mattere ſay woman ye mow theſe ben cockes word mine woman harme deuine faire ſond bath merely lieth pertelot ſuſters ayenſt ſunne chaunteclere ſo free sung merrier mermaid ſee phiſiologus ſayeth vtterly ſingen well merely ſo befell caſt eie among wortes butterflie ware foxe lay full low nothing liſt crow cried cocke cocke vp ſtert one affraid hert naturally beaſts deſireth flee fro contrarie may ſee tho neuer erſt ſeene eie chaunteclere gan eſpie would haue fled foxe anone said gentle ſir ala woll ye done ye afraid friend certes worſe fiend would harme villanie come counſaile eſpie truly cauſe comming heren ye ſing ſoothly ye haue merry ſteuen angel hath heuen therewith ye haue muſicke feeling boece ſing lord father god ſoule bleſſe eke mother gentleneſſe haue houſe ben great eaſe certes ſir full faine would pleaſe men ſpeaken ſinging woll ſey mote broken well mine eyen twey save ne herd neuer man ſo ſing father morning certes heart ſong make voice ſtrong would ſo paine y• eyen muſt winke ſo loud muſt crien ſtonden tiptoe therewithall ſtretchen forth neck long ſmall eke ſuch diſcretion man region ſong wisdome might paſſe haue well red dan burnel aſſe among verſes cocke prieſts ſonne yaue knocke vpon leg yong nice made leſe benefice certain compariſon betwixt wisdome diſcretion father ſubtilty ſingeth ſir ſaint charity let ſee ye father counterfete chaunteclere wing gan bete man could treaſon eſpie rauiſhed flatterie ala ye lord many falſe flatterour court many falſe leſingour pleaſeth well faith ſoothfaſtneſſe vnto ſaith readeth eccleſiaſt flatterie beware ye lord trecherie chaunteclere ſtood high vpon toos stretching necke held eyen cloos gan crowen loud none dan ruſſell foxe ſtart vp one gorget hent chaunteclere backe toward wood bere yet man ſued deſtinie maiſt eſchued ala chaunteclere flew fro beames ala wife rought dreames friday fell miſchaunce venus art goddeſſe pleaſaunce sithens yt thy ſeruant chaunteclere thy ſeruice powere delite y• world multiplie woldſt thou ſuffer thy day die gaulfride deere maiſter ſoueraigne y• worthy king richard ſlaine ſhot complainedeſt death ſo ſore ne thy ſcience thy lore friday chide ye friday ſhortly ſlaine wold ſhew y• coud plaine chauntecleres drede paine certes ſuch crie ne lamentation na neuer lady made whan ilion pirrus bright ſwerd hent king priam beard ſlough ſaieth eneidos made hen cloos loſt chaunteclere y• ſight ſouerainly dame pertelot ſhright well louder hasdruballes wife husbond loſt life romanes brent cartage ſo full torment rage willfully fire ſhe ſtert brent ſelfe ſtedfaſt hert wofull hennes right ſo cried ye nero brent cite rome cryed ſenatours wiues husbonds ſhould leſe liues withouten gilt nero hath hem ſlaine woll turne tale againe ſely widow doughters two heard hennes crien make ſuch wo dore ſtert anon ſaw foxe toward wood gon bare vpon backe cocke away cryed harow well away ha foxe hem ran eke ſtaues many another man ran coll dogge talbot eke garlond malkin diſtaffe hond ran cow calfe eke hogges ſo ſore aferd dogges ſhouting men woman eke ran yt thought herts ſhuld breke yellen loud fendes hell duckes cried men would hem quell geeſe feare flew ouer tree hiues came ſwarme bee hidous noiſe benedicite certes iacke straw ne meine ne made neuer ſhoutes halfe ſo ſhrill would flemming kill day made vpon foxe braſſe blew trompes boxe horne bone blew pouped therewith ſhriked ſhouted ſemed though heauen ſhould fall good men pray herken lo fortune tourneth ſodainly hope pride enemy cocke lay vpon fox backe drede vnto foxe ſpake ſaied good ſir ye yet ſhould ſay wiſe god helpe tourneth ayen ye proud churles peſtilence upon fall come unto wood ſide maugre hed cocke ſhall abide woll eat faith anon foxe anſwerd faith ſhall ſpake word ſodainly cock brake mouth deliuerly high upon tree flew anon foxe ſaw gon ala qd chaunteclere ala haue qd done treſpaſſe much made aferd whan hent brought yerd ſir wicked entent come downe ſhall tell wt ment ſhall ſay ſothe god helpe ſo nay qd ſhrew v two firſt ſhrew ſelfe blood bone thou begile • ter one thou ſhalt thy flatterie doe ſing winking eye winketh ſhould ſee wilfully god let neuer thee nay qd y• fox god yeue miſchance ſo diſcrete gouernance iangleth whan ſhold haue pee lo ſoch recheles negligent truſt flatterie ye hold tale lie foxe cocke hen taketh moralite good men ſaint poule ſayeth written doctrine written iwis taketh frute let chaffe ſtill good god thy ſaieth lord ſo make v good men bring v high bliſſe amen ¶the manciples prologue sir nonnes prieſt hoſt ſaied anone bleſſed thy brech euerie ſtone merrie tale chaunteclere troth thou ſeculere thou wouldeſt tredfoule aright thou haue corage thou haſt might thee nede hen wene ye ſeuen time ſeuentene se braunes hath gentle prieſt great necke ſuch large breeſt loketh like sparhauke eyen needeth colour dien braſill ne gram portingale ſir yet faire fall tale full merrie chere saied another man ye ſhall wote ye ſtondeth little towne called bob vp downe vnder blee canterbury way gan hoſt yape play ſaied ſirs dunne y• mire man praier ne hire woll awake fellow behind theefe might full lightly rob bind see nappeth ſee cockes bone woll fall hors atones cook london miſchaunce doe comfort knoweth penaunce ſhall tell tale fey although worth bottle hey awake thou cook qd god yeue thee ſorow eileth thee ſleepe morow haſt thou fleen al night art thou dronk haſt thou al night ſome quean iſwonk thou maieſt hold vp thy hed cooke y• full pale nothing red saied ſir hoſte ſo god ſoule ybleſſe fallen great heuineſſe leuer ſlepe beſt gallon wine chepe well qd y• mancipie may doe eaſe thee ſir cooke wight diſpleaſe ride companie hoſte courteſie woll excuſe thee thy tale good faith thy viſage full pale thine eyen daſe ſoothly thinketh well wot thy breath full ſoure ſtinketh ſheweth wel thou art wel diſpoſed certaine that▪ ſhalt gloſed see galpeth lo dronken wight though would v ſwallow anon right hold cloſe thy mouth thy father kin deuill hell ſet foot therein thy curſed breath infect v fie ſtinking ſwine fie foule mote thee befall taketh heed ſirs luſtie man ſweet ſir woll ye iuſt van thereto thinketh ye well ſhape trow ye haue dronken wine ape men play ſtraw ſpeech y• cooke waxed wraw manciple gan nod faſt lacke ſpeech doun hors caſt lay till men vp tooke faire cheueſaunce cooke ala ne hold ladill ere ayen ſadill great ſhouing fro lift vp much care wo vnweldy ſely palled goſt manciple ſpake hoſt becauſe drinke hath domination vpon man ſaluation trow leudly woll tell tale wine old moiſtie ale hath dronk ſpeketh ſo noſe ſniueleth faſt eke hath poſe alſo hath done ynough keepe caple ſlough fall caple eftſone ſhall haue ynough doen lifting vp againe dronken corce tell thy tale make force yet manciple faith thou art nice thus openly repreue vice another day woll perauenture recleime thee bring thee lure meane ſpeake ſmale thing pinch thy rekenings honeſt came prefe qd y• manciple y• great miſchefe might bring ſnare yet leuer pay mare rideth ſhould ſtriue woll wrath ſo mote thriue ſpake ſaied bourd wote ye haue gourd draught wine ye ripe grape right anon ye ſhall ſee good yape cooke ſhall drinke thereof may vp paine life woll ſay nay certainly tellen veſſell cooke dranke faſt ala needeth dranke ynough beforne pouped horne manciple tooke gourd drinke cooke full fain thonked ſuch wiſe coud gan hoſt laugh wonder loud ſaied ſee well neceſſary yt gon good drinke v cary turne rancour diſeaſe accord loue many word peaſe bacchus ybleſſed thy holy name ſo canſt turne earneſt game worſhip thonke thy deite matter ye get tell thy tale thou manciple thee pray well ſir qd herkeneth ſay ¶the manciples tale phoebus keepeth white crow ſpeak jay crow accuſeth wife jelous played falſe abſence hereupon arrow ſlayeth wife repenting raſhneſs taketh revenge crow phebus dwelled earth adoun old book v make mentioun moſt luſtie batcheler world eke ye beſt archer ſlough pheton ſerpent lay sleeping ayenſt sunne vpon day many another noble worthy dede bow wrought men mow rede play could euery minſtralcie ſing melodie heren clere voice ſoun certes king thebe amphioun ſong walled cite could neuer ſing halfe ſo well thereto ſeemeliſt man ſith world began needeth feture diſcriue world na none ſo faire aliue therewith fulfilled gentleneſſe honour perfite worthineſſe phebus yt floure bachelerie well freedome chiualrie diſport ſigne eke victorie pheton ſo telleth v ſtorie wont beare hond bow phebus hous crow within cage yfoſtred many day taught ſpeech men teach iay white crow white swan counterfete ſpeech euery man could ſhould tell tale world nightingale ne could hundred thouſand dele sing ſo wonderly merry wele phebus hous wife loued life night day euer dilligence pleaſe doe reuerence saue onely ſooth ſhall ſain ielous wold haue kept fain loth yaped bee ſo euery wight ſuch degree nought auaileth nought good wife yt clene werke thought kept none await certaine truly labour vaine keepe ſhrew woll hold nicete ſpill labour keepe wiues thus writeth old clerkes liues purpoſe firſt began worthy phebus doth pleaſe wening ſuch pleſaunce manhood gouernaunce man ſhould put grace god wote may man embrace diſtraine thing nature hath naturally ſet creature take bird put cage doe thine entent thy corage foſter tenderly meat drinke dainty thou canſt bethinke keepe alſo cleanely thou may although cage gold neuer ſo gay yet bird twentie thouſand fold leuer forreſt wide cold goe eaten wormes ſuch wretchedneſſe euer bird doe buſineſſe eſcape cage may libertie bird deſireth aye let take cat foſter milke tender fleſh
