nat heard tell aventure certes anne ye rede woll faine iwedded effect ſhould ſeine lieth live deine ſuſter anne ſhe yt coud good said thought ſomdele withſtood hereof ſo long ſermoning long make rehearſing finally may withſtonde love woll love wight woll wonde dawning vp riſt ſee amorous quene chargeth meine nettes dreſſe ſperes brode kene hunting woll luſtie freſh quene pricketh new jolly wo horſe luſtie folke igo vnto court houndes ben ibrought vp courſer ſwift thought yong knight heven woman eke huge rout vpon thicke palfray paper white ſaddle redde enbrouded delite gold barres vp enboſſed high sate dido gold perrey wrigh ſhe faire bright morrow healeth ſicke folkes night ſorrow vpon courſer ſtartling fire men might tourne little wire eneas like phebus deviſe freſh arrayed wiſe fomie bridle bitte gold governeth right himſelfe hath would forth noble queene lady ride hunting troian ſide herd harte founden anon hey gobet pricke thou let gon let gon nill lion comen beare imiȝt one meten ſpear thus ſaine yong folke vp kill wild harte hem emong romblen gan y• heven thunder rored griſly ſteven doune come ye rain haile ſleet ſo faſt heaven fire made ſo ſore agaſt noble queene alſo meine ech hem glad away flie ſhortly fro y• tempeſt ſave fled ſelfe little cave went eneas alſo hem went mo authour maketh mention began deepe affection betwixt hem two ye firſt morrow gladneſſe ginning ſorrow hath eneas ikneled ſo told hurt wo ſworne ſo deepe true wele wo chaunge new falſe lover ſo well plaine ſilly dido rewed paine toke husbond became wife evermore hem laſt life tempeſt ſtent mirth came home went wicked fame vp roſe y• anon eneas hath queene igon cave demed hem liſt y• king yarbas hight wiſt loved ever life woed wife ſorrow hath maked ſuch chere routh pitie love alday happeth ſo one ſhall laughen anothers wo laugheth eneas joy richeſſe ever troy ſilly woman full innocence full pitie truth continence maked men truſten ſo ye ſuch routh vpon fained wo ſuch old enſamples beforne see ye nat ben forſworne ſee ye one y• ne hath laft lefe ben vnkind done ſome miſchefe pilled boſted dede ye may well ſeene ye may rede take hede great gentilman troian ſo well pleaſe faineth ſo true obeiſing gentill ſo privie ſo well done obeyſaunce feaſts daunce ſhe goeth temple home faſten till hath lady ſein bearen deviſes ſake nat ſongs would make iuſten done armes many thing send letter token brooch ring herkneth ſhal lady ſerve perill ſterve hunger miſchefe ſee deſolate fled fro countree folke tempeſt driven hath body eke realme yeven hond ſhe might land cartage queen lived joy inough wt would ye eneas hath thus deepe iſwore wearie craft within throw hote earneſt overblow prively doeth ſhips dight ſhapeth ſteale away night dido hath ſuſpection thought well al amis bed lieth night ſiketh asketh anon miſliketh dere hart love moſt certes qd night father ghoſt hath ſlepe ſo ſore tourmented eke mercury meſſage hath preſented needes conqueſt itaile deſtinie ſoone ſaile thinketh broſten mine hart therwith falſe teares ſtart taketh within armes two earneſt qd ſhe woll ye ſo ye nat ſworne wife take ala woman woll ye make gentlewoman queen ye woll fro wife thus foule fleen borne ala ſhall tellen ſhort noble queen dido ſeeketh hallowes doth sacrifiſe kneeleth crieth routh deviſe coniureth profereth thrall ſervaunt beſt degre falleth foot ſowneth diſcheuile bright gilt heere ſayth mercy let ride theſe lordes wonnen beſide woll deſtroyen ſake ye woll wife take ye ſworne woll yeve leve ſlaen ſwerd ſone eve yet ſhall dien wife child yeve child life mercy lord pitie thought thing vaileth right nought traitour forthe gan ſaile toward large countrey itaile thus hath laft dido wo pine wedded ladie hight lavine cloth laft eke ſword ſtanding fro dido ſtale ſleeping right bed head ſo gan hie ſtale away nauie cloth ſillie dido gan awake hath kiſt full oft ſake ſaid ſweet cloth iupiter leſt take ſoule vnbind vnreſt fulfilled fortune courſe thus ala withouten ſocourſe twentie time iſwouned hath ſhe ſhe vnto ſuſter anne complained may write great routh endite bad norice ſuſtren gone fetchen fire thing anone ſayd ſhe would ſacrifie ſhe might time well aſpie vpon fire sacrifice ſhe ſtart ſword ſhe rofe hart mine authour ſaith yet ſhe ſeide ſhe hurt beforne ſhe deide wrote letter anon thus began right ſo qd ſhe white swan ayenſt death beginneth ſing right ſo make complaining trow getten againe well wote vaine sen god ben contrarious ſin name loſt qd ſhe may well leſe word letter albeit ſhall never better thilke wind blew ſhip away ſame wind hath blow away fay ſo woll letter mind rede ovide ſhall find ¶the legend hipſiphile medea thou root falſe lover duke iaſon thou ſleer devourer confuſion gentlewoman gentle creature thou madeſt thy reclaiming thy lure lady thy ſcathliche apparaunce thy word farſed pleaſaunce thy fained trouth thy manere thine obeiſaunce humble chere thine counterfeited paine wo fallen one thou falſed two oft ſwore thou thou wouldeſt die love thou ne felteſt maladie save foule delite thou calleſt love live thy name ſhall ſhove engliſh thy deceit ſhall know thee iaſon thine honor blow certes routh wo love falſe lover werketh ſo ſhall well better love chere hath bought love full dere armes many bloodie boxe ever tender capon eateth ye foxe though fals hath foule betraied ſhall good man therefore paied although capon skill right falſe foxe woll part night iaſon enſample well iſeene hipſiphile medea queene theſſalie ovide telleth v knight hight peleus brother hight eſon age might vnnethes gon yave peleus governing al reign made lord king eſon iaſon getten time land na nat ſuch famous knight gentilleſſe freedome ſtrength luſtineſſe father death bare ſo na none liſt ben fo honour companie peleus hath great envie imagining iaſon might enhaunſed ſo put ſuch degre love lordes regioun reigne may put adoun wit night compaſſed iaſon might beſt deſtroyed withouten ſlaunder compaſment laſt tooke aviſement ſend ſome ferre countre iaſon may deſtroyed wit made iaſon great chere looke affection drede leaſt lord eſpide fell fame ronneth wide ſuch tiding ſuch loo iſle called colcos beyond troy eaſtward ſee ram men might ſee flees gold ſhone ſo bright ſuch another ſight kept alway dragoun many marvailes vp doun two buls maked bra ſpitten fire much thing eke tale nathelees ſo would winnen thilke flees muſt winnen might buls dragon fight king otes lord ile peleus bethought vpon nephew iaſon would exhort ſailen lond diſport ſayd nephew might bee ſuch worſhip might fall thee thou famous treaſure might win bring region within great pleaſaunce honour hold quite thy labour thy coſtes woll ſelfe make choſe wt folke thou wolt thee take let ſee darſte thou taken voyage iaſon yong luſtie corage vndertooke done like empriſe anon argus ſhips gan deviſe iaſon went ſtrong hercules many another ches ſo asketh gon let rede argonauticon woll tell tale long ynough philoctetes anon ſaile vp drough wind good gan hie countrey called theſſalie long ſayled ſalt ſee till iſle lemnon arrived hee nat rehearſed guido yet ſaieth ovide epiſtles ſo iſle lady quene faire yong hipſiphile ſhene whylom thoas doughter y• king hipſiphile gone playing roming clevis ſee vnder banke anone eſped ſhe lay ſhip iaſon gan arrive goodneſſe adoune ſhe ſendeth blive weten ſtraunge wight tempeſt thider iblow anight done ſuccour vſaunce en every wight done pleaſaunc • bountie courteſie meſſenger adoune gan hie found iaſon hercules alſo cogge lond igo hem refreſhen take aire morning attempre faire way meſſenger hem mette full cunningly theſe lordes two grette meſſage asking hem anon y• broken ought wo begon need lodeſmen vitaile ſuccour ſhould nothing faile vtterly queenes iaſon anſwerde meekely ſtill lady qd thanke hartely goodneſſe v needeth truly nothing weary come play ſee till wind better way lady rometh cliffe play meine endlong ſtrond findeth iaſon ſtond ſpeaking thing told hercules iaſon gan behold queen faire grete anone right lady mete ſhe tooke heed knew manere array wordes chere gentill men great degree caſtle leadeth ſhe theſe ſtrange folk doth hem great honour asketh hem travaile labour ſuffred ſalt ſee within day two three knew folke ſhips iaſon full renomee hercules great loo ſoughten aventures colcos hem honour hem dealed ever longer ben worthy folke withouten lee namely moſt ſhe ſpake hercules hart bare ſhould sadde wiſe true word aviſee withouten affection love imagination hercules hath iaſon praiſed sunne hath vp raiſed halfe ſo true man na love vnder cope heaven wiſe hardie ſecret riche theſe iii point na none liche freedome paſſed luſtie head tho liven ben dead thereto ſo great gentill man theſſalie likely king na lacke agaſt love ſpeake ſhamefaſt lever himſelfe murder die men ſhould lover eſpie would god iyeve blood fleſh ſo might live bone y• aught wife eſtate ſuch luſtie life ſhoulden lede luſtie knight compaſſed night betwixt iaſon hercules theſe two ſhreud lee come houſe vpon innocent bedote queene entent iaſon coy maid looketh pitouſly naught ſayd freely yave counſailers yefts great officer would god leaſer time proceſſe wrong rime houſe falſe lover right himſelfe doth right ſo faining every ſubtill dede ye get ye woll rede thoriginall telleth caas ſooth iaſon wedded vnto queene tooke ſubſtaunce ſo liſt vnto purveyaunce vpon begate child two drough faile ſaw never mo letter ſent ſhe certaine long writen ſaine reproveth great vntrouth praieth ſome routh child two ſhe ſayd like thing iwis iaſon ſave couth nat beguile prayd god long ſhe hart ireft fro muſt • nden vntrue alſo ſhe muſt child ſpill tho ſuffreth true iaſon ſhe life ever kept chaſt wife ne never ſhe joy hart died love ſorrowes ſmart colcos come duke iaſon love devourer dragon matire appeteth forme alway forme forme paſſen may well bottomles right ſo iaſon pee deſiren appetite done gentlewoman delite luſt felicite iaſon romed forth citie whylome cleped iaſonicos maſter toune colcos hath itold cauſe comming vnto otes countrey king praying muſt done aſſay get fleece gold may king aſſenteth boone doth honour doone ferforth doughter heire medea ſo wiſe faire fairer ſaw never man eie made done iaſon companie meat ſitte hall iaſon ſeemely man withall like lord great renoun looke royall lioun godly ſpeech famil lere coud love craft art plenere withouten booke everiche obſervaunce fortune ought foule miſchaunce woxe enamoured vpon man iaſon qd ſhe ought ſee thing ye ben ye ſelfe ye put much dout ſo woll aventure atcheve may nat wele aſterten leve withouten death helpe natheleſſe qd ſhe forthren ſo ye ſhall nat die turnen ſound home theſſalie right lady qd iaſon tho ye death wo regard done honour wot well might ne labour may nat deſerve life day god thanke ne ne may man lowely beſeech ben helpe withouten ſpeech certes death ſhall ſpare tho gan medea declare perill caſe fro point point batayle deſioint mote ſtonde creature save ſhe ne might life aſſure ſhortly right point go ben accorded fully betwixt hem two iaſon ſhall wedde true knight terme yſet come ſoone night vnto chambre make othe vpon goddes lefe lothe ne ſhulde never falſen night ne day ben husband whyle live may ſhe deth ſaved vpon night mete yfere doth othe gothe bedde morow vpward ſpedde ſhe hath taught ſhall nat faile flees winne ſtinten bataile ſaved life honour gate name conquerour right ye ſleight enchantment hath iaſon fleſe home went medea treaſours fell great wonne vnwiſt father ſhe gonne theſſalie duke iaſon lefe afterward hath broght miſcheife traytour go left yong child two falſely hath betraied ala ever love chefe traytour wedded yet thirde wife anon doughter king creon meede loving guerdon medea received duke iaſon right trouth kindneſſe loved better ſelfe geſſe left father heritage iaſon vaſſalage dayes na never none yfound ſalſe lover going ground therfore letter thus ſhe ſaid firſt ſhe falſeneſſe vpbraid liked yellow haire ſee bound mine honeſtie liked youth thy faireneſſe thy tong infinite graciouſneſſe haddeſt thou thy conqueſt dead ybe ful mikel vntrouth diede thee well ovide letter verſe endite long write ¶the legende lucrece rome mote ſaine thexiling king rome horrible doings laſt king tarquinius ſaith ovid titus liuivs cauſe tell nat ſtorie prayſen drawen memorie wife lucreſſe wifehood ſtedfaſtneſſe nat painems commend cleped legend great auſtyn hath compaſſioun lucrece ſtarfe rome toun wiſe woll ſhortly treat thing touch great ardea beſieged romanes yt full ſterne ſtout full long lay ſiege little wroughten yt halfe idle hem thoughten play tarquinius yong gan yape light tong ſaid idle life man wife let v ſpeke wife beſt praiſe every man owne leſt ſpeech let v eaſe hert knight hight collatin vp ſtert ſayd thus nay ſir nede trowen word dede wife qd trow holden good ever know go rome night ſhull ſee tarquinius anſwerde liketh mee rome comen faſt hem dight colatins houſe downe light tarquinius eke colatine husbond knew efters well fine full prively houſe gone gate porter none chamber dore abide noble wife ſate bed ſide diſcheueled mallice ſhe ne thought ſoft wooll ſayth liuie ſhe wrought kepe ſlouth idleneſſe bad ſervaunts done buſineſſe asketh hem tidings heren ye ſayth men ſiege ſhall god would wals fallen adoun mine husbond long toun drede doth ſore ſmert right ſword ſtingeth mine hert thinke place god ſave lord pray grace therwithall ſo tenderly ſhe gan weepe werke ſhe tooke keepe meekely ſhe let eyen fall thilke ſemblant ſate well withall eke teares full heavineſſe embeſeſſed wifely chaſtneſſe countenaunce hert digne acordeden deed ſigne word husbond collatin ſhe ware came ſtertling ſaid drede thee nat ſhe anone vp roſe bliſfull chere kiſſed wife wonne tarquinius proud king ſonne conceived hath beautie chere yellow haire bountie manere hew word y• ſhe hath complained craft beautie nat fained caught lady ſuch deſire hert brent fire woodly wit forgotten well thought ſhe ſhould nat gotten aye diſpaire coveiteth thought faire blind luſt coveiring morrow bird began ſing vnto ſiege commeth full prively himſelfe walketh ſoberly image recording alway new thus lay hair thus freſh hew thus ſate thus ſpan chere thus fair ſhe manere conceit heart hath new itake ſee tempeſt ſhake ſtorme ago yet woll water quappe day two right ſo though forme abſent pleaſaunce forme preſent natheleſſe nat pleaſaunce delite vnrightfull talent diſpite maugre ſhe ſhall lemman hap helpeth hardy man alway qd end make ſhall ſo girt ſword gan go forthright till rome come alone way hath nome vnto houſe colatin full right doun y• ſunne day hath loſt light come vnto privie halke night full theefely gan ſtalke every wight reſt brought ne wight treaſon ſuch thought whether window gin ſwerd ydraw ſhortly commeth ſhe lay noble wife lucreſſe ſhe woke bedde ſhe felt preſſe beaſt qd ſhe wayeth thus king ſonne tarquinius qd thou crie noiſe make thou creature awake thilke god formed man live ſwerd thine hert ſhall rive therwithall vnto throte ſtert ſet ſwerd ſharpe hert word ſhe ſpake ſhe hath might therto ſhall ſhe ſaine wit ago right wolfe findeth lamb alone ſhall ſhe complaine make mone ſhall ſhe fight hardy knight well wote men woman hath might ſhall ſhe crie ſhall ſhe aſtert hath ye throte ſwerd hert asketh grace ſaid ſhe wolt thou nat qd cruell man wiſely iupiter ſoule ſave ſhall thy ſtable ſlea thy knave lay thy bed loud crie thee find ſuch avoutrie thus thou ſhalt dead alſo leſe thy name thou ſhalt nat cheſe roman wife loveden ſo name thilke time dreden ſo ſhame wt fere ſlander drede death loſt one wit breath ſwough ſhe lay woxe ſo dead men mighten ſmite arme head feleth nothing neither foule ne faire tarquinius art king heire ſhouldeſt linage right done lord knight haſt thou done diſpite chivalrie haſt thou done thy lady villanie ala thee villanous dede purpoſe ſtory rede gon miſchaunce fall lady ſent friendes father mother husbond ifere diſcheveled haire clere habite ſuch woman vſed tho vnto burying friend go ſate hall ſorowfull ſight friend asken aylen might dead ſhe ſate aye weeping word ſhame ne may ſhe forth bring ne vpon hem ſhe durſt nat behold laſt tarquiny ſhe hem told rufull caſe thing horrible wo tell impoſſible ſhe friend make one folkes herts ben ſtones might maked hem vpon rew hert ſo wifely ſo trew ſaid gilt ne blame husbond ſhould nat ye foule name would ſhe nat ſuffren way anſwerde vnto fay foryave right gilt lay nat might ſaiden enſamples many one naught thus ſhe ſaid anone may qd ſhe forgiving nat forgift nothing prively ſhe cought forth knife therwithall ſhe raft ſelfe life ſhe fell adowne ſhe caſt looke clothes yet heed ſhe tooke falling yet ſhe care leaſt foot ſuch thing lay bare well ſhe loved cleanneſſe eke trouth towne rome routh brutus hath chaſt blood ſwore tarquin ſhould ybaniſhed therfore kinne let people call openly tale told hem openly let carry bere y• town men may ſee horrible deed oppreſſioun ne never king rome toun sen thilke day ſhe holden ſaint ever day yhallowed dere law thus endeth lucreſſe noble wife titus beareth witneſſe tell ſhe love ſo trew ne ſhe chaunged new ſtable hert ſadde kind theſe woman men may day find caſt hert dwelleth well wote chriſt himſelfe telleth iſrael wide lond ſo great faith lond ne fond woman lie men looke ye ſuch tyrannie doen day aſſay hem ſo liſt trueſt full brothell triſt ¶the legend ariadne athens jvdge infernall minos crete king commeth thy lot thou commeſt ring nat thy ſake written ſtorie clepe ayen vnto memorie theſeus great vntrouth love god heaven ben wroth wrath take thy ſinne red ſhame thy life beginne minos y• mighty king crete hundred city ſtrong grete ſchoole hath ſent ſonne androgeus athens happed thus ſlaine learning phyloſophie right citie nat envie great minos ſpeke ſonnes death come wreke alcathoe beſieged hard long natheleſſe walles ſo ſtrong niſus king cite chivalrous little dredeth minos hoaſt tooke cure till day befell aventure niſus doughter ſtood vpon wall ſiege ſaw manner happed ſcarmiſhing caſt hert vpon minos king beautie chevalrie ſore ſhe wende die ſhortly proceſſe pace made minos winnen thilke place citie ſaven liſt el ſpill wickedly quit kindneſſe let drench ſorrow diſtreſſe nere god pite tale long athene wan king minos alſo alcathoe townes mo effect minos hath ſo driven hem athene mote yeven fro yere yere owne child dere ſlaine ye ſhall minos hath monſter wicked beſt ſo cruell without areeſt y• man brought preſence would eat helpeth defence every third yeare withouten dout caſten lotte came rich poore muſt ſonne take childe muſt preſent make minos ſave ſpill let beaſt devour hath minos done right diſpite wreke ſonne ſet delite make hem athene thrall fro yere yere liven ſhall home ſaileth toun wicked cuſtome ſo long yron till athene king egeus mote ſenden owne ſonne theſeus sen lotte fallen vpon ben devoured grace non forth ladde wofull yong knight vnto ye country king minos full might priſon fettred faſt till time ſhould yfreten well maiſt thou wepe wofull theſeus art king ſonne damned thus thinketh thou art depe yhold ſaved thee fro care cold woman helpe thee well oughteſt thou ſervaunt bee ben true lover yere yere come ayen matere toure theſeus throw bottome derk wonder low joyning wall foreine longing vnto doughtren tweine minos chamber grete dwelten maiſter ſtrete towne joy ſollas nat happed percaas theſeus complained night king doughter ariadne hight eke ſuſter phedra herden complaint ſtood wall looked vpon bright moone hem liſt nat go bed ſo ſoone wo compaſſion king ſonne ſuch priſon ben devoured thought hem great pite ariadne ſpake ſuſter free ſaid phedra lefe ſuſter dere wofull lord ſonne may ye nat pitouſly complaineth kin eke poore eſtate guiltleſſe certes routh ye woll aſſent trouth ſhall ben holpen ſo phedra anſwerde iwis wo ever man helpe beſt rede done gailer prively come ſpeke v haſtely done wofull man come may monſter overcome quit none boot let v well taſt hart root ſo weapon life dare kepe ſave fighten fiend defend priſon ſhall diſcend ye wote well beaſt place derke hath roume eke ſpace welde axe ſwerde ſtaffe knife thinketh ſhould ſave life man ſhall ſo ſhall make balles eke alſo towe gapeth faſt beeſtes throte ſhall hem caſt ſleke honger encomber teeth right anon theſeus ſeeth beeſt acheked ſhall leepe ſleen comen heepe apen ſhal gailer tide full prively within priſon hide houſe crencled fro hath ſo queint way go ſhapen maſe wrought thereto remedy thought clewe twine hath gon ſame way may returne anon folowing alway threde hath come beeſt overcome may flien away ſtede eke gailer may lede avaunce home countre sen ſo great lord ſonne rede ye dare take ſhold lenger ſermon make gailer cometh theſeus theſe thing ben accorded thus downe ſate theſeus vpon knee right lady life qd ſorowfull man ydamned deth fro while laſteth breth wol nat twinne aventure ſervice thus woll endure wretch vnknow woll ſerve forevermore till mine hert ſterve forſake woll home mine heritage ſaid ben court page ye vouchſafe place ye graunt ſoche grace may nat meate drinke ſuſtinaunce yet woll ſwinke right liſt minos ne wight sen ſaw never eyen ſight ne man el ſhall eſpie ſlily ſo well ſhal gie ſo wel diſfigure ſo low world ſhall man know life preſence done excellence father ſhall ſende worthy man gaylere ſo guerdon ſhall well one greateſt men countre durſt ſaine lady bright king ſonne eke knight wold god might ye countrey thre beare companie ſhuld ye ſene thereof lie profer lowe manere ben page ſerven right ſerve lowly place pray mar yeve ſoch grace ſhames death mote fall death poverte frends ſprite night mote go death walke fro mote traitour name ſprit mote go ſhame clayme ever degree ye vouchſafe yeve mee ſaid ſhames death dey mercy lady naught el ſey ſemely knight theſeus ſee yonge twenty yere three ſo yſene countenance wold wept routh penance ariadne manere anſwerde profre chere king ſonne eke knight qd ſhe go ben ſervaunt ſo lowe degree god ſhilde ſhame woman lene never ſoch caſe befall ſende grace ſleight hert alſo defend knightly ſleen foe lene hereafter may find ſuſter ſo kind ne repent nat yeve life yet better wife sith ye ben gentill borne realme nat faſt ſuffred gentilleſſe ſterve let page ſerve profite vnto kinrede y• man woll nat dred ſuſter ſith ſo ſhe mote gone go el ſuffre death wel ye vnto ſonne trewly done wedded home coming finall end thing ye ſwere vpon may ſworne ye lady mine qd el torne mote minotaure morow haveth mine hert blood borow ye woll knife ſpeare would letten thereon ſweare erſte wot ye would leve mar chiefe beleve might liven nat faile morow taken bataile nolde never fro place flie till ye ſhould profe ſe ſoth ſhall ſay loved full many day though ye ne wiſt nat countre aldermoſt deſired ſee earthly living creature vpon truth ſweare aſſure ſeven yere ſervaunt alſo ye dere hert athene ducheſſe lady ſmileth ſtedfaſtneſſe hartely wordes chere luſter ſaid manere ſothly ſuſter mine qd ſhe ducheſſes ye ſikerde regals athene hereafter likely queenes ſaved fro death king ſonne ever gentill woman wonne ſave gentil man enforth might honeſt cauſe namely right thinketh wight ought v blame ne bearen v therefore yvel name ſhortly mater make theſeus hath leave ytake every point performed dede ye covenaunt herde rede wepen clewe thing yt ſaid gailer houſe ylaid minotaure hath dwelling right faſt dore entring theſeus lad vnto dethe forth vnto minotaure gethe teaching adriane overcame beeſt bane cometh clewe againe ful prively beeſt hath ſlaine gailer gotten hath barge wife treaſure gan charge toke wife eke ſuſter free gailer hem al three ſtole away lond night countre enupie dight frende knowing feeſten daunſen ſing armes hath adriane beeſt hath kept fro bane get noble barge anone countrey folke ful great wone taketh leave homeward ſaileth hee yle amidde wilde ſee dwelt creature none save wild beeſtes full many one made ſhippe londe ſette yle halfe day lett e ſaid londe muſt reſt mariner done right leſt tell ſhortly caas ariadne wife ſlepe ſuſter fayrer ſhe taketh honde forth goeth ſhip traitour ſtale away ariadne ſlepe lay countrey warde ſailed blive twenty divel way winde drive found father drenched ſee liſte ſpeke parde theſe falſe lover poiſon bane wol turne againe adriane ſlepe werineſſe ytake ful ſorowfully hert may awake ala thee mine herte hath pite right dawning awaketh ſhe gropeth bed fond right nought ala qd ſhe ever wrought betrayed heere rent ſtronde barefote faſt ſhe went cried theſeus mine hert ſwete ye may nat mete might thus beeſtes ben yſlaine halow rockes anſwerde againe man ſhe ſaw yet ſhone moone hie vpon rocke ſhe went ſoone ſawe barge ſayling ſee cold woxe hert right thus ſaid ſhe meker ye find beeſtes wilde hath nat ſinne thus begilde cried turne againe routhe ſinne thy barge hath nat meine kerchefe pole ſticked ſhe aſcaunce ſhould well yſe remembre ſhe behind turne againe ſtronde find naught way gone downe ſhe fel ſwowne ſtone vp ſhe riſte kiſſed care ſteppes feete hath fare bed right thus ſhe ſpeketh tho thou bed qd ſhe haſt received two thou ſhalt anſwere two one greater parte away gone ala wher ſhal wretched wight become though ſo bote none come home countrey dare nat drede ſelfe caſe nat rede ſhould tell complaining ſo long heavy thing epiſtle naſo telleth ſhortly end tell ſhall goddes holpen pite ſigne taurus men may ſee ſtones crowne ſhine clere ſpeake matere thus falſe lover begile trew love divel quite wile ¶the legende philomene thou yever ye formes yt haſt wrought fayre world bare thy thought eternally er thou thy werke began madeſt thou vnto ſlaunder man thy end make ſoch thing ſuffredeſt thou tereus bore love ſo falſe ſo forſwore fro world vp firſt heven corrumpeth yt folke name neven ſo griſly dede foule ſtorie rede mine iyen wexen foule ſore alſo yet laſteth venime ſo longe ago enfecteth wolde behold ſtorie tereus told trace lord kin marte cruel god ſtante blody darte wedded bliſfull chere king pandionis faire doughter dere hight progne floure countre though iuno liſt feaſt ne himeneus god wedding feaſt ready ben iwis fury three mortall bronde oule night balkes wonde prophete wo miſchaunce revell full ſong full daunce laſt fourtenight little laſſe ſhortly ſtorie paſſe weary tell five yere wife togither dwell till day ſhe gan ſo ſore long ſeene ſuſter ſhe ſaw long deſire ſhe niſt ſay husbond gan ſhe pray god love ſhe mote one gone ſuſter ſeene come ayen anone el ſhe mote wend praied would ſend day day prayere al himbleſſe wifehood word chere tereus let make ſhips yare grece himſelfe forth ifare vnto father law gan pray vouchſafe moneth tway philomene wife ſuſter might progne wife one ſight ſhe ſhall come anon ſelfe come gon herts life kepe old pandion king gan wepe tenderneſſe hert leve doughter gon yeve leve world loved nothing ſo laſt leave hath ſhe go philomene ſalt teares eke gan father grace beſeke ſeene ſuſter longeth ſo enbraceth armes two alſo yong faire ſhe tereus ſaw beaute array none liche yet beautie ſhe ſo riche caſt fierie hert vpon ſo woll ſo go wile kneled ſo praied till laſt pandion thus ſaied ſonne qd art ſo dere thee betake yong doughter dere beareth key mine herts life grete well doughter thy wife yeve leave ſometime pley ſhe may ſeen one deie ſothly hath made riche feaſt folke moſt eke leaſt came yave yefts great conveieth maſter ſtreat athene ſea brought tourneth home malice ne thought ore pulleth forth veſſell faſt trace arriveth laſt vp foreſt led cave prively ſped darke cave leſt liſt nought bad reſt herte agroſe ſaied thus ſuſter brother tereus therewithall ſhe wept tenderly quoke feare pale pitiouſly right y• lambe y• wolfe bitten y• culver egle ſmitten claves forth eſcaped yet aferde waped leſt hent eftſones ſo ſate ſehe vtterly may none force hath traitour done deede hath reft maidenhede maugre head ſtrength might lo deede men aright crieth ſuſter full loude ſteven father dere helpe god heven helpeth yet falſe thefe hath done lady yet miſchefe feare leſt ſhe ſhould ſhame crie done openly villanie ſweard tong kerfe caſtell made full prively priſon evermore kept vſage ſtore ſhe ne might never aſtarte ſely philomene wo thine hart huge thy ſorowes wonder ſmart god wreke thee ſende thee thy bone time make end ſone tereus wife icome armes hath wife inome pitiouſly wept ſhoke hedde ſwore found ſuſter dedde ſelie progne hath ſoch wo nigh ſorowfull hert brake two thus teares let progne dwell ſuſter forth woll tell wofull lady ilearned youth ſhe worken enbrauden couth weaven ſtole rade vore woman hath woved yore ſothly ſaine ſhe hath fill meate drinke clothing couthe eke rede well inough endite penne ſhe could write letter ſhe weave fro yere ago woven ſtames large ſhe brought fro athens barge cave ſhe brought thing tereus wrought wave wel wrote ſtorie ſhe ſerved ſuſters love man ring ſhe yave anon praied ſignes gon vnto queene bearen clothe ſigne ſwore many othe ſhould yeve ſhe getten might man anon vnto quene dight toke maner told y• progne hath thing behold worde ſhe ſpake ſorow eke rage fained gon pilgrimage baccus remple little ſtound dombe ſuſter ſitting hath ſhe found weeping caſtell ſelfe alone ala wo conſtraint mone progne vpon dombe ſuſter maketh armes everich hem taketh thus let hem ſorow dwell remnaunt charge tell ſome thus ſhe ſerved never agilt ne deſerved vnto cruell man ſhe wiſt ye may beware men liſt woll ſhame doen tereus leſe name ne ſerve murtherer knave full little ſhull ye trewe wol ſain al brother ſo may another ¶the legende phillis prove wel aucthorite wicked fruicte commeth wicked tree may ye find liketh end ſpeake tell falſe demophon love falſer heard never non father theſeus god grace fro ſoch one kepe v thus theſe woman praied effect tourne matere deſtroied troie citee demopon came ſayling ſee toward athene paleis large came many ſhip many barge full folke full many one wounded ſore ſicke wo begone ſiege long ilaine behind came winde eke raine ſhofe ſo ſore ſaile might ſtonde lever world londe hunteth tempeſt fro darke could go wave bruſten ſtere ſhip rent ſo lowe ſuch manere carpenter could amende ſee night torche brende wood poſſeth vp doun till neptune hath compaſſioun thetis chorus triton maden vp londe fall wherof phillis lady queene lycurgus doughter fairer vnto ſeene floure bright sonne vnneth demophon londe iwonne weake eke werie folke forpined werineſſe alſo enfamined death almoſt idriven wiſe folke counſaile yeven ſeken helpe ſuccour queene loken grace might bene maken lande ſome cheveſaunce kepen fro wo fro miſchaunce ſicke almoſt death vnneth might ſpeake draw breath lieth rhodopeia reſt may walk thought beſt vnto countrey ſeeken ſuccour men knew wele honour athene duke lord theſeus father hath ibe time great renoun man ſo great regioun like father face ſtature falſe love came nature doth foxe renarde fox ſonne kind could old father wonne without lore drake ſwimme caught caried brimme honorable queen phillis doth chere liketh well ſporte manere agroted beforne write hem love forſworne eke haſte legende performe god grace ſende therfore paſſe ſhortly wiſe ye well heard theſeus giſe betraiyng faire adriane pite kept fro bane ſhort wordes right ſo demophon ſame way ſame pathe hath gon falſe father theſeus vnto phillis hath ſworne thus wedden trouth plight piked good might hole ſound reſt doth phillis ſo leſt well could liſt ſo tellen fro ſayd countrey mote ſaile would wedding apparaile fill honour alſo openly tooke leave tho ſwore would ſojourne month would retourne londe let make ordinaunce lorde tooke obeiſaunce well humbly ſhippes dight home goeth next way might vnto phillis yet came nought hath ſhe ſo harde ſore ibought ala ſtorie doth v record owne death corde ſhe ſaw y• demophon traied firſt wrote ſhe faſt praied would come deliver pain rehearſe ſhall worde twain liſte vouchſafe ſwinke diſpenden penne full ynke falſe love right ſire devill ſet ſoules fire letter phillis woll write worde twain although lite thine hoſteſſe qd ſhe demophon thy phillis ſo wo begon rhodopeie vpon mote complain terme ſet betwixt v twain ye ne holden forward ye ſayd ancre ye layd hight v ye would comen doubt moone one went time fower y• moone hath hid face sen thilke day ye went fro place fower time light world yet ſhall ſothly ſain yet hath ſtreme scython brought athens ſhip yet came nought ye terme reken would true lover doe ſhould plain god wot day al letter writen ne may order charge letter right long therto large rime layd thought ſhe hath wel ſayd ſayd ſailes cometh ne worde ni • ey certain wot ye come qd ſhe love ſo fre goddes ye ſwore vengeaunce fall therfore ye ſuffiſaunt beare pain moche truſted well may ſain vpon linage faire tong teares falſly wrong coud ye wepe ſo craft qd ſhe may ſoche teares fained certes ye would memory ought little glory ſelie maide thus betrayed god qd ſhe pray oft prayed greateſt price moſt honour ever ſhall befall thine old aunceters painted bee men may worthineſſe ſee pray god thou painted alſo folke may reden forth go lo flattery betraied hath done villany true love thought dede ſothly point yet may rede ye like father begiled ariadne iwis ſuch arte ſuch ſubtelte thou thy ſelves haſt begiled poinct although feire thou foloweſt certain art heire ſens thus ſinfully ye begile body mote ye ſene within right athene fleeting withouten sepulture buriyng though ye harder ſtone letter forth ſent anone knew brotell fals diſpaire fordid ſelfe ala ſorow hath ſhe ſhe beſet ſo beware ye woman ſubtill fo sen yet day men may enſample ſe truſteth love man ¶the legende hypermeſtre grecen whilom brother two one called danao many ſon hath body wonne ſoch falſe lover ofte conne emong ſonnes one aldermoſt loved everychone child borne danao shope name called lino brother called egiſte love falſe ever liſte many daughter gate life gate vpon right wife doughter dere call hypermeſtra yongeſt hem child nativite good thewes borne ſhe liked goddes ſhe borne ſhefe ſhe ſhould corne werdes clepen deſtine hath ſhapen ſhe muſt needes pitous ſad wiſe true ſtele woman accordeth wele though y• venus yave great beaute iupiter compowned ſo ſhe conſcience trouth drede ſhame wifehode kepe name thought felicite reed mar time yere feble malice raft repreſſed hath venus cruell craft venus oppreſſion houſes mar venime hypermeſtre dare handle knife malice though ſhe ſhould leſe life natheleſſe heaven gan tho turne two bad aſpectes hath ſhe saturne made die priſon ſhall make mencion danao cgiſtes alſo though ſo y• brother two thilke tyme na ſpared linage liked hem maken mariage betwixt hypermeſtre lino caſten ſoch day ſhall ſo full accorded vtterly aray wrought tyme faſt thus lino hath father brother doughter wedded ech hem hath torch brennen ye lamp bright sacrifice full ready dight thenſence fire reketh ſoote floure leefe rent vp roote maken garlandes crounes hie full place ſound minſtralcie ſonges amourous mariage thilke tyme plain vſage paleis egiſte hous lord right liſte thus day driven end frendes taken leve home wend night come bride ſhall go bed egiſte chamber faſt ſped prively let doughter call houſe voided hem looketh doughter glad chere ſpake ye ſhall right doughter treſour mine hert sen firſt day y• ſhapen ſhert fatall ſuſter dome nie mine hert never thing ne come thou hypermeſtre doughter dere take hede thy father ſayth thee werke thy wiſer ever mo alderfirſt doughter love thee ſo world ni halfe ſo lefe ne nolde rede thee thy miſchefe good vnder cold mone meane ſhall ſaid right ſone proteſtacion ſaine theſe wiſe thou doe ſhall thee deviſe thou ſhalt ded y• al hath wrought ſhort wordes thou ne ſcapeſt nought paleis thou deed thou conſent werke reed take fearfull concluſioun hypermeſtre caſt iyen doun quoke doth leefe aſhe grene deed wext hew like aſhen ſene ſayd lord father might god wote fulfill confuſion nill qd none excepcion caught knife raſour kene hide qd iſene thine housbond bed go ſlepeth cut throte atwo dreme warned nevewe ſhall bane wherfore woll ſiker thou ſay nay two ſhall biker ſayd ſworn hipermeſtre hath nigh wit forlorn paſſen harmeleſſe place graunted ther none grace withall coſtrell taketh tho ſayd hereof draught two yeve drinke goeth reſt ſhal ſlepe long ever thee leſt narcotikes apies ſo ſtrong go thy way leſt thinke long cometh bride full ſobre chere maiden oft manere chamber brought revel ſong ſhortly leſte tale long lino ſhe beth brought bed every wight doore ſped night waſted fell aſlepe full tenderly beginneth ſhe weepe riſt vp dredfully ſhe quaketh doth braunch zephirus ſhaketh huſht aragone citee colde froſt wexeth ſhee pite herte ſtrained ſo drede death doth ſo moche wo thriſe doune ſhe fill ſoche riſte vp ſtakereth hand faſt looketh ſhe ala ſhall mine hand bloudie maide nature ſemblaunt veſture mine hand ſhapen knife reve man fro life devill knife ſhall throte corve two ſhall blede ala ſhende nedes thing mote ende mote nedes leſe life certes qd ſhe ſens wife hath faith yet bette dedde wifely honeſte traitour living ſhame may earneſt game ſhall awake riſe go way gutter er day wept full tenderly vpon face armes gan embrace ſhe joggeth awaketh ſoft window lepe fro loft ſhe hath warned done bote lino ſwift light foote ran full good paas ſelie woman ſo weake ala helpleſſe ſo er ſhe ferre went cruell father hent ala lino art thou ſo vnkind ne haſt thou remembred thy mind taken led forth thee ſhe ſaw gone away hee ſhe might ſo faſt go ne folowen ſhe ſate doune right tho vntill ſhe caught fettred priſon tale ſayd concluſion ¶here endeth legende good woman ¶a goodly ballade chaucer mother norture beſt beloved freſhe floure good thrift god ſende childe luſte ſo call vnable ſelfe ſo pretende diſcrecion recommende mine herte al every circumſtaunce wholly vnder governaunce moſt deſire ever ſhal thing might herts eaſe amend excuſed power ſmall natheleſſe right ye ought commend good faine would entend ſervice ſuffiſaunce holly vnder governaunce meulx vn hert never ſhall apall aie freſhe new right glad diſpend time ſervice ſo befall beſeching excellence defend ſimpleneſſe ignoraunce offend wiſe ſith mine affiaunce holly vnder governaunce daiſie light ground comfort sunnes doughter ye hight rede weſtreth farwell diſport nature anone right pure drede rude night yt boiſtous wede darkeneſſe ſhadoweth emiſpere cloſen ye life ladie dere dauning day kind reſort phebus father ſtreames rede adorneth morrow conſuming ſort miſtie cloudes woulden overlede true humble herts miſtie hede nere comfort day iyen clere diſcloſe ſprede life ladie dere ie vouldray great god diſpoſeth maketh caſuel providence soch thing man frele wit purpoſeth beſt conſcience grutche humble pacience receive god ſaith without fable faithful hert ever acceptable cautels ſo vſeth gladly gloſeth eſchewe ſoch right high prudence ye ſayd one mine hart oppoſeth writing yapes abſence pleaſed moch better preſence yet ye excuſable faithfull harte ever acceptable quaketh penne ſpirit ſuppoſeth writing ye find woll ſome offence min hert welkneth thus ſone anon riſeth hotte colde eft feruence miſſe cauſed negligence malice therefore beth merciable faithfull harte ever acceptable ¶lenuoye forth complaint forth lacking eloquence forth little letter enditing lame beſought lady sapience thy behalfe accept game thine inabilitie doe thou ſame abide yet ie ſerve ioueſſe forth cloſe thee holy venus name thee ſhall vncloſe hart governereſſe boecius de conſolatione philoſophiae book handled high hard obſcure point viz purveyance god force deſtiny freedom will infallible preſcience almighty contemplation god himſelf summum bonunt carmina qui quondam ſtudio florenti peregi flebilis heu moeſtos coger inire modos ala weeping conſtrained begin verſe ſorrowful matter y• whilom floriſhing ſtudie made delitable ditees lo rending muſes poet enditen thing written drerie teates laſte drede ne might overcome tho muſes ne werren fellowes folowden way ſay exiled youth whilom weelful grene comforten ſorowful wierdes old man elde commen unwarely vpon haſted harmes ſorrow hath commaunded age heeres hore ſhad overtimeliche vpon head ſtacke skinne trembleth mine empted body thilke death menne weleful y• ne commeth yeres ſwet commeth wretch often • leped ala ala deafe eare death cruell turneth away wretch •• aieth cloſe weepying iyen fortune vnfaithfull fauoured light goodes ſorowful houre ſay y• death almoſt dreint mine hedde fortune cloudie hath chaunged deceiueable chere meward mine vnpitous life draweth along vngreable dwelling ye frends whereto auaunted ye wilfull hath fallen ſtode ſtedfaſt degree haec dum mecum tacitus ipſe reputarem querimoniamque lacrimabilem ſtili officio deſignarem aſtitiſſe mihi ſupra verticem viſa eſt mulie • reverendi admodum vultus oculis ardentibus ultra communem c mean ſtil recorded theſe thynges ſelf marked wepely complainte office poinctell ſaugh ſtondyng abouen hight mine hed woman full great reuerence ſemblant iyen brennyng clere ſeyng ouer y• common might men liuely colour ſoch vigour ſtrength y• ne might nempned ſo y• ſhe full ſo great age menne woulden trowen manere ſhe elde ſtature doutous iudgement ſometime ſhe conſtrained ſhronke ſeluen like y• common meaſure men ſometime ſeemed ſhe touched y• heaven ye hight hedde ſhe houe hedde higher ſhe perced ye ſelfe heauen ſo ſight men looking idell clothes maked right delie thredes ſubtell craft per durable mattier clothes ſhee wouen owne honds knew well ſelfe declaring ſhewing beauty clothes darkeneſſe forleten diſpiſed elde dusked darked wonte darke ſmoked image nethereſt hemme border theſe clothes men redde iwouen therein grekiſh ſignifieth life actiue aboue letter y• hieſt bordure grekiſh c y• ſignifieth lyfe contemplatife betwene theſe two letter ſeen degree nobly wrought maner ladder degree men might climben nethereſt letter ye vppereſt natheleſſe handes ſome men hadden kerue cloth violence ſtrength eueriche man hem borne away ſuch peces might getten forſothe foreſaid woman bare ſmall bookes right hand left hand ſhe bare scepter ſhe ſawe theſe poeticall muſes approching bed endityng wordes wepinges ſhe little amoued glowe cruell iyen qd ſhe hath ſuffred approchen ſicke man theſe commen ſtrompets place men callen theatre onely ne aſſwagen ſorrowes remedy would feden noriſh ſwete venime forſoth tho thornes pricking talentes affection nothing fructuous profitable diſtroyen come plentuous fruictes reaſon holden harte men vſage ne deliuer folke fro malady y• muſes withdrawen fro flattery vnconnyng vnprofitable man wont finde commenly among y• people would well ſuffre laſſe greuouſly ſoche vnprofitable man myne entente nothyng endammaged ye withdrowen fro man hath noriſhed ſtudies ſcoles eleaticis achademicis grece goeth rather away yee metmaydens ſwete till laſt ſuffreth man cured healed muſes yt ſay notefull science thus company muſes iblamed caſten wrothly chere douneward yearth ſhewing redneſſe ſhame paſſeden ſorowfully threſhold ſight plounged teares darked ſo ne might know woman ſo imperiall aucthoritie wo • e abaſhed aſtonied caſt ſight doune yearth began ſtill abide ſhe would doen afterward came ſhe nere ſet doune vpon vttereſt corner bed ſhe beholding chere caſt yearth heauy greuous weeping complained theſe wordes ſhall • aine perturbation thought heu quam praecipiti merſa profundo men habet propria luce relicta tendit ad externas ire tenebras terrenis quoties flatibus acta creſcit immenſum noxia cura hic quondam coelo liber aperto c ala thought manne dreinte ouerthrowing depeneſſe dulleth foreleteth proper cleereneſſe mintyng gone forayne darkneſſe oft anoious beſineſſe wexeth without meaſure yt driuen worldly windes manne whilome free whome heauen open knowen wont gone heauenly pathes ſawe lightneſſe redde sunne beheld ye sterres cold moone sterre heauen vſeth wandring recourſes • lit diuers ſpheres man ouercomer comprehended al thing nomber accompting aſtronomie ouer hee wont ſeken cauſes whence ye ſowning windes mouen beſien ſmothe water sea spirite tourneth stable heauen sterre riſeth red eaſt fallen y• weſtren waues attempreth luſtie houres ye firſt sommer ſeaſon highteth apparayleth yearth roſie floures maketh plumtuous autumpne full yeres fleeten heauie grape eke manne wont tell diuers cauſes nature hidde ala lightly empted light thought necke preſſed heauy chaines beareth chere enclined adoune ye great weight conſtrained looken fooliſh yearth sed magi medicinae inquit tempus eſt quam querelae boe tum vero totis intenta luminibus philo tu ne ille e ait qui noſtro quondam lacte nutritus noſtris educatus alimentis virilis animi robur evaſeras c time medicine qd ſhe complaint forſooth ſhee entending mewarde ye lookyng iyen ſaied art nat thou qd ſhe yt whilom nouriſhed milke foſtred meat eſcaped commen y• courage parfite man certes yaue thee ſoche armour thou thy ſelf ne haddeſt firſt caſt hem away ſhoulden haue defended thee ſikerneſſe may ouercomen knoweſt thou art thou ſtil ſhame aſtoniyng leuer ſhame ſeemeth aſtoniyng hath oppreſſed thee ſhe ſawe onely ſtill rather without office tongue dombe ſhe layed hand ſoftely breaſt ſaied perill qd ſhe fallen litarge common ſickneſſe harte deceiued hath little foryeten himſelfe certes ſhall lightly remembren himſelf ſo hath knowen er may doen ſo wipe iyen little darked cloud mortall thing theſe wordes ſaied ſhe lappe garment iplited frounce ſhe dried mine iyen full waues weeping tunc diſcuſſa liquerunt nocte tenebre luminibuſque prior redit vigor ut cum praecipiti glomerantur ſidera choro nimboſiſque polus ſtetit imbribus sol later ac nondum coelo venientibus aſtris c thus night diſcuſſed away darkneſſe forlette iyen repaired againe firſt ſtrength right enſample ye sunne hidde sterres couered cloud ſwift wind hight chorus firmament ſtant derked plungy cloud sterres apperen vpon ye heauen ſo night ſemed ſprad vpon yearth wind hight boreas iſent caue country trace beateth night ſaine chaſeth away diſcouereth y• cloſed day ſhineth phebus iſhaked ſodaine light ſmiteth beam marueyling iyen haud aliter triſtitiae nebulis diſſolutis hauſi coelum ad cognoſcendam medicantis faciem mentem recepi itaque ubi eam deduxi oculos intuitum que defixi reſpicio nutricem meam cujus ab adoleſcentia c right ſo none otherwiſe cloudes ſorrowe diſſolued doen awaie tooke heauen receyued mynd knowen face phiſicien ſo ſette myne iyen vpon faſtened looking beheld nourice philoſophie whoſe houſe conuerſed fro youth ſaied thus thou maiſtreſſe vertues diſcended ſoueraine ſeate art thou commen ſolitarie place myne exile art thou commen thou art made coulpable falſe blame qd ſhe nourice ſhould forſake thee ſhould parten thee commen trauayle charge thou haſte ſuffered enuie name certes lefull ne fitting philoſophie leten without companie way innocent shold redout blame agriſe though befallen new thing troweſt thou philoſophie alderfirſt aſſayled perilles folke wicked maner ſtriuen full grate ſtrife old time age plato ayenſt foolehardineſſe foly eke ſame plato liuyng maiſter socrates deſerued victorie vnrightfull death preſence heritage socrates heritage ſaine doctrine socrates opinion felicite yt cleape welefulneſſ people epicuriens stoiciens many enforced go raviſh every many parte ſaine ye everich hem would drawen defence opinion wordes socrates partie praie droune criyng debating ayenſt coruen renten clothes wouen mine owne handes tho clothes araced clothes wenten away wening gone hem euery dele epicuriens stoiciens moch ſemed ſome trace ſteppes habite folie wenyng tho epicuriens stoiciens familiers peruerted ſome ye errour wicked multitude hem ſain ſemed philoſophers purſued death ſlaine thou haſte knowen exiling anaxagoras ne enpoyſoning socrates ne tourments zeno ſtraungers yet mighteſt thou haue knowen seneca canios soranos folke renome neither ouer olde ne vnſolempne whiche men nothing el ne brought death onely enformed maners ſemeden moſt vnlike ſtudies wicked folk thy thou oughteſt wondren though bitter sea driuen tempeſts blowing whiche moſte purpoſe ſaine diſpleaſen wicked men whiche ſhrewes hoſte neuer ſo great diſpiſe governed leader reaſon rauiſhed onely fletyng errour folily aud lightly ſometyme make hooſte ayenſt v aſſaile v ſtrenger leader draweth together richeſſes toure ententife ſarpleris ſachelles vnprofitable taken high abouen ſiker tumulte woode noyſe wareneſtored encloſed ſoche paleis whither clatering anoiyng folie may attaine ſcorne ſoch raveners henters fouleſt thing quiſquis compoſito ſerenus evo fatum ſub pedibus egit ſuperbum fortunam que tuens utram que rectus invictum potuit tenere vultum c ſo clear vertue ſad well ordinate living hath put vnder foote proude wierdes looketh vpright vpon eyther fortune hee may holden chere vndiſcomfited rage ne manaces ſea commoving chaſing vnware heate bottome ne ſhall move man ne vnſtable mountaigne hight veſenus writheth broken chimeneis ſmoking fire ne way thonder leites wonte ſmiten high coures ne ſhall move man whereto wretch drede ye tyrant wood felonnous ſtrength hope nothing ne drede thou ſo ſhalt thou diſarmen ye ire thilke vnmighty tiraunt quaking dredeth deſireth thing ſtable right man ſo doeth hath caſt away ſhilde remoued fro place enlaſeth chaine may drawen sentis ne inquit haec atque animo illabuntur tuo expers ne e lyrae quid fles quid lachrimis manas si operam medicantis expectas oportet ut vulnus detegas tuum c feleſt thou qd ſhee theſe thing entren aught thy courage art thou like aſſe harp wepeſt thou ſpilleſt thou teares thou abideſt helpe leche thee behoveth diſcover thy wound tho gathered ſtrength courage aunſwered ſayd needeth qd rehearſing amonicion ſheweth inough himſelfe ſharpenes wexeth woode againſt mee ne moueth thee ſee face maner place librarie thou haddeſt choſen right certaine liege thee mine hous thou diſputeſt oft science thing touching diuinite touching mankinde mine habite ſoche face chere ſoche ſought ſecretes nature thou enformedeſt maners reaſon al lyfe thenſample thorder heauen guerdon referre thee obeyſaunt certes thou enformedeſt ye mouth plato ſentence ſaine comen thing communalties bliſful ſtudied fully wiſedome gouerneden thilke thinges el ſo befell yt gouernours communalties ſtudien get wiſedome thou ſaideſt eke ye mouth ſayd plato neceſſarie cauſe wiſemen taken deſiren gouernaunce comen thinges ye governaunce citees ileft handes felonous tourmentors citizeins ne ſhoulden bringen peſtilence diſtruction good folke therefore followyng thilke authours deſired put foorth execucion act commen adminiſtracion thilke thing yt learned thee emong ſecrete veſting while thou god y• put thought wiſe folke knowen nothing ne brought maſtrie dignitie common ſtudie goodneſs therefore commeth wicked folke haue greuous diſcordes ne mighten bee releaſed prayer libertie hath freedome conſcience ye wrathe mighty folke hath alway diſpiſed ſauacion right oft reſiſted withſtand ye man y• hight canigaſt y• made alway thaſſaut ayenſt ye proſper fortune poore feoble folke oft eke put caſt triguill prouoſt ye king hous bothe wrong begon doen eke fully performed often haue couered defended aucthoritie put ayenſt peril yt ſaine put myne aucthoritie perill wretched poore folke y• couetiſe ſtraungers vnpuniſhed turmenteden alway miſeaſes greuaunces number neuer man yet drowe fro right wrong ſawe fortune richeſſes people prouinces harmed amenuſed eyther priuy rauenes commen tribute cariages ſory ſuffreden harme gloſe theoderike king gothes dedde year garner full corn commaunded y• man ſhould buye corne till corne ſold greuous dear price beoce withſtood ye ordinaunce ouercame knowing al ye king theodorike himſelfe coempcion ſay commen achate buiyng together yt eſtabliſhed vpon people ſoch maner impoſicion ſo bought buſhel corne muſt yeuen king ye fiueth parte cextus ye ſore hongry time eſtabliſhed greuous vnprofitable coempcion men ſeen well ſhould greatly tourmenten endomagen prouince campaine tooke ſtriſe ayenſt ye prouoſt pretorie ye common profite ye knowyng ouercame ſo coempcion asked ne tooke effect pauline counſailour roome richeſſes whiche pauline hondes paleis ſay officer woulden haue deuoured hope couetiſe yet drowe jowes hem gapeden much payne ye accuſacion adiudged beforne ne ſhould ſodainly henten ne puniſhen wrongfully albine counſailour roome putte ayenſt hate indignacions accuſour cyprian inough ſens haue purchaſed great diſcords ayenſt ſelf ought aſſured ayenſt folke ye loue right wiſeneſſe neuer reſerued nothing ſelf hemward king hall ſiker tho ſame accuſours accuſing condempned nomber accuſours one baſilius whilome chaſed king ſeruice compelled accuſing name need foraine money alſo opilion gaudencius haue accuſed mee ſo iuſtice regall whilome deemed theim bothe gon exile tretcheries fraudes without number judgement nolden obey defended hem ſikerneſſe holy houſes ſain fledden seintewarie apperceyued ye king commaunded auoyded citee rauenne certayne day aſſigned men ſhould marken hem forehedde hote yron chaſen hem toun thing ſeemeth might likened cruelty certes ſame day receyued accuſing name thilke ſame accuſoures may ſaied hereto hath ſtudie coning deſerued thus el foreſaied dampnacion made rightful accuſours fortune aſhamed certes fortune ben aſhamed innocence accuſed yet ought ſhe haue ſhame filth mine accuſours aske thou ſome gilte accuſed men ſaine would ſauen company ye senatours deſireſt thou heren maner accuſed y• ſhould diſtourbed ye accuſour bearen letter hee ſhould haue made senatours giltie ayenſt king royall majeſtie maiſtreſſe demeſt thou shal forſake blame ne ſhame thee certes haue would y• ſay ſauacion ye senate ne ſhall neuer let wilne confeſſe know entente accuſour diſtourbed ſhall ceaſe shall clepe felony ſinne haue deſired ſanacion order senate certes thilk ſame senate doen decretes judgment though ſinne felony wilne ſauacion folie lieth alway himſelf may chaunge merite thing ne trow judgement socrates lefull hide ſooth ne aſſent leaſings certes howſoeuer putte geſſen priſen judgement thee wiſe folke thing ye ordinaunce ſooth much folk ben comen day ſhall knowenit haue putte scripture remembraunce touchyng letter falſely made letter accuſed haue hoped freedome rome wt appertaineth ſpeaken thereof letter y• fraud ſhewed apertly libertie haue vſed confeſſion mine accuſours thing need hath great ſtrength freedom may men hopen certes would ſome freedom might hoped would haue anſwered word man hight camus accuſed canius ceſar germanes ſonne knowing conſenting coniuration made ayenſt canius aunſwered thus wiſt thou haddeſt wiſt thing ſorrow hath ſo dulled witte plaine onely ſhreud folke apparailen fellonies againſt vertue wonder greatly may perform thyngs haue hoped doen ne ne ſhreudneſſe commeth perauenture defaut like monſter maruail ye preſent ſight god may atcheued performed ſuch thyngs euery fellonous manne hath conceyued thought againſt innocent thing one thy familiers vnskilfully asked thus god whence commen wicked thing al leful fellonous folk deſiren blood death good men eke senate haue wilned gone deſtroyen haue ſeen alway batailen defenden good men eke senate deſerued father ſain senatours ſhoulden deſtruction thou remembreſt wel geſſe would doen ſain thing thou thy ſelfe alway preſent ruledeſt citie verone king gredie common ſlaughter caſt tranſporten vpon order senate guilt royal maieſtie gilt albin accuſed great ſikerneſſe peril defended senate thou woteſt well ſay ſooth ne ne auaunted neuer prayſing ſelf alway wight receiueth precious renome auaunting himſelf werkes amenuſeth ſecree conſcience thou mayeſt well ſeene end comen mine innocencie receiue paine falſe fellonie guerdoun vertue open confeſſion fellome euer iudges ſo accordaunt crueltie ſain mine accuſing hath eyther errour man wit el condition fortune vncertain unto mortal folke ne ſubmitted ſome hem ſay ne enclined ſome iudge haue pitie compaſſion although accuſed would brenne holy houſes ſtrangle prieſts wicked ſwearde greithed death good men algates ſentence ſhould puniſhed preſent confeſſed conuict remoued ye citie rome almoſt fiue hundred thouſand paas without defence dampned proſcription death ſtudies bounty haue doen senate well worthy merite ſayeth nay might yet neuer none hem conuict ſuch blame mine treſpace mine accuſours ſeen full well ye dignitie would darken medling ſome fellonie baren hond ſayd pollute defouled conſcience sacriledge couetiſe dignitie certes thou thy ſelf art planted chaſedeſt ſiege courage couetiſe mortal thing ne sacriledge ne leaue haue place thine eyen thou droppedeſt euery day mine ear thought thilke commandment pythagoras y• ſay menne ſhall ſeruen god goddes ne conuenient ne none need taken help fouleſt ſpirits thou haſt ordained ſet ſuch excellence thou madeſt like god ouer right clean ſecret chamber mine houſe ſay wife companie mine honeſt friend wiues father well holy worthy reuerenced deed defenden al ſuſpection ſuch blame oh malice accuſen taken y• philoſophy faith ſo great blame trowen haue affinitie malefice enchauntment becauſe repleniſhed fulfilled thy teaching enformed thy maners thus ſufficeth thy reuerence ne auail naught thou thy free rather blemiſhed mine oftencion certes y• harm y• haue betideth yet encreaſe harm gueſſing iudgement much folke ne looken nothing ye deſerts thing y• auenture fortune iudgen ſuch thing ben purueyed god y• temporal wilfulneſſe commaundeth gloſa thus wight haue proſperity good man worthy haue proſperitie ſo hath aduerſitie wicked man god hath forſake worthy haue aduerſitie opinion ſome folke thereof commeth good geſſing firſt thing forſaked wretch certes greeueth think right diuers ſentences people ſayth thus much ſay laſt charge contrarious fortune blame laied upon caitife men wenen hath deſerued ſuffereth put away good men diſpoyled dignity defouled name geſſing haue ſuffred turments good deed certes ſeemeth ſee felonous couines wicked men habounden ioy gladneſſe ſee euery lorell ſhapeth find new fraudes accuſe good folk ſee good folk ouerthrown drede peril euery luxurious tourmentour dare doen fellonie unpuniſhed excited yefts innocent diſpoiled ſikerneſſe defence therto liſt crien god manner ſtelliferi conditor orbis qui perpetuo nixus ſolio rapido coelum turbine verſas legemque pati ſidera cogis ut nunc pleno lucida cornu totis fratris obvia flammis condat ſtellas luna minores nunc obſcuro pallida cornu phoebo proprior lumen perdat c thou maker wheele beareth ſterres art faſtened thy perdurable chaire turneſt heauen rauiſhing ſweigh conſtraineſt ſterres ſuffer thy law ſo moon ſometime ſhining ful horn meeting beames sun brother hideth ſterres leſſe ſometime moon pale dark horn approcheth sun leſeth light euin ſterre heſperus firſt time night bringeth firſt cold ariſing cometh eft ayen uſed courſe pale ye morrow riſing sun icleped lucifer thou reſtraineſt day ſhorter dwelling time cold winter maketh leaues fall thou diuideſt ſwift tide night hote summer commen thy might attempreth variaunt ſeaſons yeare ſo zepherus debonaire wind bringeth ayen firſt summer ſeaſon leaues wind hight boreas hath reſt away autumne ſay laſt end summer ſeeds ſterre hight arcturus ſew woxen high corn ſterre sirius enchaſeth hem nothing unbounden old law ne forletteth werk proper eſtate thou gouernour gouerning thing certain end refuleſt thou gouern werks men due manner ſuffreſt thou y• ſliding fortune turneth ſo great enterchaunges thing ſo annoyous paine ſhould duly puniſh felon puniſheth innocent folk wicked manner ſitten high chaires annoying folke treden unrightfully neck holy men vertue clere ſhining naturally hid derk derkneſſes rightfull man beareth paine blame fellons ne forſwearing ne fraud couerd kempt falſe colour ne annoieth ſhrewdneſſe ſhrewdneſſe hem liſt uſen ſtrength reioycen hem put hem ſoueraigne king people without number dreden thou whatſoeuer thou knitteſt bond thing look theſe wretched earth men foule partie faire part ſo great werke tourmented ſee fortune thou gouernor withdraw reſtraine rauiſhing flood faſten ferme theſe earth ſtable thilke bond thou gouerneſt heauen ſo large haec ubi continuato dolore delatravi illa vultu placido nihilque mei queſtubus mota phi cum te inquit moeſtum lachrymantemque vidiſſem illico miſerum exulemque cognovi sed quam id longinquum eſſer exilium continual ſorrowe ſobbed broken theſe thinges ſhe chere peſible nothing amoved complaint ſaid thus ſaw thee qd ſhe ſorrowful weeping wiſt anon thou wretch exiled wiſt neuer ferre thine exile thy tale ne yſhewed certes thou ferre fro thy countrey thou nart putte thou haſt fayled thy way gone amiſſe thou haſt leuer wene thou put thy country haſt thou put thy ſelfe rather wight hath wight thou thy ſelfe ne might neuer haue done thee thou remember thee countrey thou art borne ni gouerned emperours ne gouernment multitude ye country hem athens one lord one king god lord thy country y• reioyſeth dwelling citizen put hem exile ye lord feeedome gouerned y• bridle obey iuſtice haſt thou forgotten thilke old law thy citie citie ordained eſtabliſhed wight hath leuer found therin • eat houſe el may nat exiled right place ſo contained within paleis thilk city drede may deſerue exiled letteth tenhabit forletteth alſo deſerue citezein thilke citie yt ſay face place ne moueth ſo mikell thine owne face ne ne aske rather ye wals thy librarie apparailed wrought yuorie glaſſe ſeat thy thoght put nat whilom book put maketh bookes worthy price precious yt ſay ſentence bookes certainly thy deſerts beſtowed common good thou haſt ſaid ſooth ye multitude thy good deed thou haſt ſaid ye honeſtie ye falſeneſſe thing ben oppoſed againſt thee thou haſt remembred thing knowne folke felony fraud thine accuſours ſeemeth thee haue touched forſooth rightfully ſhortly mighten tho ſame thing better plenteouſly couth mouth people knoweth thou haſte eke blamed greatly complained wrongfull deed senate thou haſt ſorrowed blame thou haſt wopen dommage thy renoun apaired thy laſt ſorrow enchaſed ayen fortune complayneſt guerdon ne euenly yolden deſerts folke thy latter end thy wood muſe thou prayedſt thilke peace yt governeth heauen ſhould governe earth many tribulation affection aſſailed thee ſorrow ire weping draw thee diverſly thou art feeble thought mightier remedy ne ſhullen yet touchen thee wch willen ſomdele uſen lighter medecines ſo ſo thilke paſſions waxen hard ſwelling perturbation flowing thy thoght mowen waxe eaſie ſoft receiue ye ſtrength mightie eagre medicine eaſier touching cum phoebi radiis grave cancri ſidus inaeſtuat tum qui largo negantibus sulcis ſemina credidit eluſus cereris fide quarnas pergat ad arbores nunquam purpureum nemus lecturus viola petas c heauie ſterre cancre enchaſeth beam phebus ſayne phebus ye ſunne ſigne cancre ſo yeueth largely ſeeds field refuſen receiue hem let gone beguiled truſt corne achornes okes thou wilt gather violet ne goe thou nat ye purple wood field chirkinge agriſeth colde feleneſſe winde hight aquilone thou deſire wilt vſen grape ne ſeek thou nat glutton honde ſtrayne preſſe ſtalkes vine firſt summer ſeaſon bacchus god wine hath rather yeuen yeftes autumne latter ende ſummer god tokeneth aſſygneth time abling hem proper office ne ſuffereth ſtounds himſelfe hath deuided conſtrayned beene imedled togider thy forletteth certaine ordinaunce ouerthrowing way ne hath glad iſſue ende werkes primum igitur pateris ne pauculis rogationibus ſtatum tuae mentis attingere atque tentare ut quis modus ſit tuae curationis intelligam c firſt wouldeſt thou ſuffer mee touch aſſay eſtate thought demaunds ſo yt may underſtond maner thy curacion aske qd thy thou wolt ſhall anſwer tho ſayd ſhe thus whether weneſt thou qd ſhe world gouerned fooliſhly hap fortune el weneſt thou gouernement reaſon b certes qd ne trowe nat manner yt ſo certain thing ſhould bee mooued fortunous fortune wote well god maker maiſter gouernour werk ne neuer yet day might put ſoothneſſe ſentence p qd ſhee ye ſame thing ſang thou little beforne bewailedeſt wepteſt onely men put cure god thing thou ne doubteſt nat nere gouerued reaſon ough wonder certes greatly yt thou art ſicke ſens thou art put ſo holſome ſentence let v ſeeken deeper conjecte lacketh ſay sen thou ne doubteſt yt world gouerned god gouernaile takeſt thou heed gouerned vnneth qd know ye ſentence thy queſtion ſo ne may yet anſweren thy demand deceiued qd ſhe yt ne failed ſomewhat ye maladie perturbation crept thy thought ſo ſtrength thy paleis ſhining open ſay remembreſt thou wt ye end thing whider entention kind tendeth haue heard told ſome time qd drerineſſe hath dulled memorie certes qd ſhe thou woteſt well whence thing comen proceden wote well qd aunſwerde god beginning may qd ſhe ye ſens thou knoweſt beginning thinges yt thou knoweſt nat ye end thinges ſuche beene ye cuſtomes perturbation power han yt may moue man place ſay y• ſtableneſſe perfection knowing certes may nat al arace ne alien would yt thou woldeſt anſwere remembreſt thou yt thou art man b ſhould remember yt qd phi mayſt thou tell qd ſhe thing man asketh thou qd whether yt reaſonable mortall beaſt wote well confeſſe wilt thou neuer yet thou thing qd ſhe qd well know qd ſhe cauſe thy malady right great thou haſt left knowen thy ſelfe thou art haue plainly founden cauſe thy malady el entre recouering thy heale thou art confounded foryeting thy ſelfe thou ſorowdeſt thou art exiled thy proper good thou ne wiſt end thing thy demeſt thou fellonous wicked men mightie welefull thou haſt foryetten gouernments world gouerned thy weneſt thou theſe mutation fortune fleten without gouernour theſe ben cauſes malady certes gret cauſes death thanke actour maker heale nature hath forleten thee haue great noriſhing thine heale ſooth ſentence gouernaunce world thou beleeueſt gouerning ſubiect ne underput folly theſe hap auenturous reaſon god therfore doubt thee nothing little ſparke thine heat life ſhall ſhine much time yet faſter remedy nature thought thus deceiued oft caſt away ſooth opinion clothen hem falſe opinion falſe opinion derkeneſſe perturbation wexeth confoundeth inſight darkneſſe ſhall ſomewhat aſſay maken thinne weak light meaneliche remedy ſo darkeneſſe deceyuing thing done away thou may know ſhining light nubibus atris condita nullum fundere poſſunt ſidera lumen si mare voluens turbidus auſter miſceat eſtum vitrea dudum parque ſerenis c ſterres couered black cloud ne mow yeten adowne light troubled wind hight auſter turning wallowing ſea medeleth heat ſaine boyling botome waues whylome clear glaſſe like faire bright dayes withſtand anon ſights men filth ordure reſolued fleeting ſtream reileth doun diuerſly high mountaignes arreſted reſiſted oft time encounteriog ſtone departed fallen ſome roch thy thou wilt looken deeme ſooth cleare light holden way right path weiue thou ioy driue fro drede fleme thou hope ne let ſorow approch ſaine let none theſe foure paſſions ouercome blend thee cloudie derke thilke thought bound bridle theſe thing reignen explicit liber primus poſt haec pauliſper obticuit atque ubi attentionem meam modeſta taciturnitate collegit ſic exhorſa eſt si poeuitus egritudinis tuae cauſas habitumque c ſhe ſlint little ſhe gadered temper ſtylneſſe mine attencion ſo might ſaine thus theſe thynges ſhee ſlint little ſhe apperceiued temper ſtilneſſe ententiue hearen ſhe began ſpeake wiſe qd ſhe haue underſtonden knowen utterly cauſes habite thy maladye thou languiſheſt art defected deſire talent thy rather fortune ilke fortune onely chaunged thou faineſt thee ward hath peruerted clereneſſe eſtate thy courage underſtonding felle manyfold colour deceit thilke maruailous monſter fortune ſhe uſeth full flattering familiaritie hem ſhe enforceth beguile ſo long till ſhe confound unſufferable ſorrow hem ſhe hath left deſpaire unpurueyed thou remembreſt well kind manner deſert thilke fortune thou ſhalt well knowe thou neuer ne haddeſt ne haſte yloſte anie fayre thing trowe ſhall greatly trauailen done thee remembren theſe thinges thou wont hurtelen deſpiſen manly wordes ſhe blandiſhing preſent purſudeſt ſentences drawen mine entre ſay mine enformacion ſuddaine mutacion ne betideth without manner chaunging courage ſo befall thou art little departed fro y• peace thy thought time yt thou drinke ataſt ſome ſoft delitable thing ſo entered within thee mowen make way ſtrenger drinkes medecines come forth therefore ſuaſion ſweetneſſe rethorien goeth onely right way ſhe forſaketh mine eſtatutes rhetorike come forth muſicke damoſel houſe ſingeth lighter mood prolacions heauier eyleth thee man hath caſt thee mourning weeping trow thou haſt ſeen ſome new thing uncouth thou weneſt fortune chaunged ayen thou weneſt wrong thou wene alway tho manner hath rather kept thee ward proper ſtableneſſe changing ſelfe right ſuch ſhe ſhe flattered thee deceiued thee unleful liking aud falſe wilfulneſſe thou haſt knowen atteint doubtous double viſage thilke blind goddeſſe fortune yet couereth wimpleth folke hath ſhewed ſelfe euery dele thee thou approueſt thinkeſt ſhe good uſe manner plain thee nat thou agriſeſt falſe trecherie deſpiſe caſt away y• plaieth ſo harmfully ſhe cauſe ſo much ſorrow thee ſhuld thee cauſe peace ioy hath forſaken thee forſooth y• neuer man may ſiker y• ſhe ne ſhall forſaken gloſe natheleſſe ſome book haue text thus ſooth ſhe hath forſaken thee ne ni man ſiker y• ſhe ne hath forſaken holdeſt thou thilk welefulneſſe precious thee ſhall paſſen preſent fortune dere worth thee yt ni faithfull dwell ſhe goeth away ſhe bringeth wight ſorow ſens ſhe may bee withholden man ſhe maketh wretch ſhe departeth fro thing fleeting fortune manner ſhewing wretchedneſſe come ne ſuffiſeth looken thing preſent eyen man wiſdom looketh meaſureth end thing ſame changing one another ſain aduerſitie proſperitie maketh menace fortune ne dreden ne flattering deſired thus laſt hooueth • ſuffren euell pacience done within floore fortune lay world ſith thou half one put thy neck vnder y• yoke thou wolt writen law wending dwelling fortune thou haſt choſen freely ben thy lady art thou nat wrongful makeſt fortune wroth aſper thine impacience yet thou mayeſt nat chaungen thou committeſt betakeſt thy fails wind thou ſhalt ſhouen nat thider thou wouldeſt whider wind ſhoueth thee thou caſteſt thy ſeeds field thou ſhouldeſt haue mind yeares amongs plentuous whiie barrein thou haſt betaken thy ſelf gouernaunce fortune thy behooueth thee obeyſant maners thy lady enforceſt thou thee arreſten withholden ſwiftneſſe ſweigh tourning wheel thou fool mortal fool fortune began dwell ſtable ſhe ceaſed ben fortune haec cum ſuperba verterit vice dextra ex aeſtuantis fertur euripi dudum tremen do ſeva proterit reges humilemque victi ſublevat fallax vultum non illa dura miſeros audit haud curat flerus c fortune proud right hand withtourned chaunging ſtounds ſhe fareth like manner boiling euripe gloſa euripe arme ſea ebbeth floweth ſomtime ſtreme ſide ſomtime text cruell fortune caſſeth adown king whylome ydrade ſhe deceiuable enhaunſeth vp humble diſcomfited ne ſhe neither heareth ne recketh wretched weeping ſhe ſo hard ſhe laugheth ſcorneth weeping hem ſhe hath maked weep free thus ſhe playeth thus ſhe proueth ſtrengths ſheweth great wonder ſeruants wight ſeen welefull ouerthrowne houre vellem autem pauca tecum fortunae ipſius verbis agitare tu igitur jus poſtulet animadverte p quid tu ô homo ream agis quotidianis querelis c certes would pleaden thee thing vſing word fortune take heed nowe thy ſelf ſhe ask right thou man wherefore makeſt thou giltie thine euery dayes plainings wrong haue done thee wt good haue beraft thee thine striue plete judge thou wilt poſſeſſion richeſſes dignity thou maieſt ſhewen euer mortall manne hath receyued tho thing ben proper grant freely yt thilk thing thine thou askeſt nature brought thee forth thy mother womb receiued thee naked needie thing nouriſhed thee richeſſes ready ententife fauour ſuſtain thee maketh thee impacient ayenſt enuironned thee haboundance ſhining good right liketh withdraw mine hond thou haſt grace hath vſed forraign good thou haſt right plain thee though thou haddeſt vtterly forlorn thy thing plaineſt thou haue done thee wrong richeſſes honour ſuch thing ben right ſeruants known lady come departen wend dare well affirm hardly tho thing thou plaineſt thou haſt forlorn thine thou ne hadſt forlorn hem shall defended vſe right certes lefull heauen make clear day ouercome tho ſame day derk night year hath eke leaue apparaile viſage earth floures fruit confound hem ſometime rain cold ſee hath eke right ben ſomtime caulm blandiſhing ſmooth water ſometime horrible waues tempeſts couetiſe men yt may ſtanched ſhal bind ſtedfaſt ſithen yt ſtedfaſtneſſe vncouth manner ſtrength ſuch play play commonly turn whirling wheele turning circle glad changen loweſt higheſt higheſt loweſt worth thou wolt ſo law yt thou ne hold nat thee wrong though thou diſcend adown ye reaſon play asketh woſt thou creſus king lidians king cyrus ful ſore agaſt little beforne creſus caught cyrus ledde fire brend rain diſcended heauen reſcowed mind paulus conſul rome taken king perciens weped pitouſly captivitie ye ſelf king thing bewaylen cry tragedy deed fortune yt aukward ſtroke ouertourneth realmes great nobley gloſe tragedie ſaine ditee proſperitie time endeth wretchedneſſe lernedeſt thou grece thou young entre ſeller iupiter ther ben couched two tonne one full good full harme right haſt thou plaine thou haſt taken plentuouſly good ſide ſain richeſſe proſperite eke departed fro thee eke mutabilitie yeueth thee rightful cauſe hope haue yet better thing natheleſſe diſmay thee thy thought thou yt art put commune realm ne deſire liuen thine proper right si quantas rapidis flatibus incitus pontus verſat arena aut quot ſtellifei edita noctibus coelo sidera fulgent tantas fundat opes nec retrahat manum pleno copia cornu humanum miſeras haud ideo genus ceſſet flere querelas c though plentie goddeſſe rich hylde downe full horne withdrawe hand many richeſſe ſee tourneth upward ſands moued rauiſhing blaſts el many richeſſes ſhinen bright ſters heauen ſterrie night yet mankinde nolde ceaſe weepe wretched plaint ſo god receyued prayer yeueth hem full large much gold apparaileth couetous folke noble clere honor yet ſeemeth haue gotten nothing alway cruel rauine deuouring haue gotten ſheweth gapings ſay gapen deſiren yet mo richeſſes bridle might withholden certaine end diſordinant couetie men euer rather fleteth large yefts brenneth hem luſt hauing certes quaking dredefull weneth himſelfe needy ne liueth neuermore rich igitur ſi pro ſe tecum verbis fortuna loqueretur quid profecto contrahiſceres non haberes ſi quid eſt quo querelam tuam jure tuearis proferas oportet therefore fortune ſpeak thee ſelf manner forſooth thou ne hadſt nat thou mighteſt anſwere thou haſt thing wherewith thou mayeſt rightfully defenden thy complaint behooueth thee ſhewen woll yeuen thee ſpace tellen boecius certainely qd theſe faire thinges annoynted honey ſweetneſſe rhethorike muſick heard ſowne eares delicious wretch deeper felyng harme ſayne wretch feelen harmes ſuffer greeuouſly remedy delight theſe word may gladden conforten hem theſe thinges ſtinten ſown eares ſorrow inſet greueth ye thought p right ſo doth qd ſhe theſe ne yet remedy maladie manner nouriſhing thy ſorrowes rebell ayenſt thy curacion time ſhall moue ajuſt ſuch thing peircen hem full deep natheleſſe thou ſhalt wilne leten thy ſelf wretch haſt thou foryeten number manner thy welefulneſſe ſpeak ſoueraign men citie tooke thee cure keeping thou orphelyn father mother choſen affinitie prince citie thou beganne rather lefe deare neyghbour thyng moſt precious kind propinquitie alliaunce may ne ſayed tho thou ne right welefull ſo great nobley thy father law chaſtitie thy wife opportunity nobleſſe thy maſculine child ſayne thy ſonnes ouer liſt paſſen common thing thou haddeſt thy youth dignity warned old men deliteth commen ſingular upheaping thy welefulneſſe fruite mortal thynges may haue wight price welefulneſſe mighteſt thou euer foryeten charge harme whiche might befall remembraunce thilke day thou ſaw thy two ſons made counſailours ladde together thy houſe ſo great aſſemble senatours blithneſſe people thou ſaw hem ſet court high chaires dignity thou rhetorien pronouncer king praiſings deſeruedeſt glory wit eloquence thou ſitting thy two ſons counſaylours place hight circo fulfille deſt bidding multitude people ſpradde thee ſo large prayſing laud men ſing victory tho yaue thou fortune trowe ſay tho feoffedeſt thou fortune glorious word deceiue deſt ſhe acoyed nouriſhed thee delices thou bare away fortune yeſt y• ſay ſuch guerdon ſhe neuer yaue private man wilt thou therefore lay reckning fortune hath firſt twidckled vpon thee wicked eye thou conſider number manner thy bliſſes thy ſorows thou mayeſt nat forſaken nart yet bliſful therfore thou weneſt thy ſelf welefull tho thing ſeemeden joyfull ben paſſed ni thou ſhouldeſt ſeem thy ſelf wretch thing ſemed ſorry paſſen alſo art thou commen ſuddain gheſt ſhaddow tabernacle life troweſt thou ſtedfaſtneſſe man thing oft ſwift hour diſſolueth ſame man ſay ſoul departed body although ſelde faith fortunous thing would dwellen yet natheleſſe laſt day man life manner death fortune alſo thike hath dwelt therefore weneſt thou doth recke thou forlet dying el ſhe fortune forlete thee flyen away cum polo phebus roſeis quadrigis lucem ſpergere caeperit pallet albentes hebetara vultus flammis ſtella permentibus c phebus sunne beginneth ſpreade cleareneſſe roſen charriots ſterre dimmed paleth white cheres flame ſunne ouer commeth ſterre light ſayne ſunne riſen dayſterre wexeth pale leſeth light great lightneſſe ſunne wood wexeth rodie roſen flour ye firſt summer ſeaſon breath winde zepherus wexeth warme cloudie winde auſter blowe fell liche goeth away faireneſſe thornes oft ſee clere caulme mouing floodes oft horrible wind aquilon moueth boyling tempeſt ouer whelueth ſea forme worlde ſo ſelde ſtable turneth ſo many enterchaunges wilt thou truſten tumblynge fortune men wilt thou trowen fleeting good certaine eſtabliſhed law perdurable nothing engendred ſtedfaſt ne ſtable tum ego vera inquam commemoras ô virtutum omnium nutrix nec inficiati poſſum proſperitatis meae velociſſimum curſum sed hoc eſt quid c ſaied thus nourice vertues thou ſayeſt full ſooth ne may forſake right ſwifte courſe proſperitye ſaine proſperitye ne commen woonder ſwiftly ſoone thing greatly ſmarteth remembreth aduerſities fortune moſt vnſelie kind contrarious fortune haue welefull phi thou abieſt thus qd ſhe yt tourment thy falſe opinion maiſt thou rightfully blamen ne aretten thing ſayeth thou haſt yet many haboundances thing textus ſo idle name aduenturous welefulneſſe moueth thee lefull thou recken many thynges thou haſt yet plentie therfore yt thilk thing thou haddeſt precious thy richeſſe fortune kept thee yet grace god vnwemmed vndefouled mayeſt thou plaine rightfully vpon miſcheefe fortune ſithen thou haſt yet thy beſt thinges certes yet liueth good point thilke precious honor mankind symachus thy wife father yt man made sapience vertue man thou wouldſt buy price thine owne life bewayleth wrong men doen thee himſelf liueth ſikerneſſe sentence put ayenſt yet liueth thy wife attempre wit paſſing woman cleaneneſſe chaſtitie would cloſe • ſhortly hounties ſhe like father tell thee yt ſhe liueth loth life keepeth thee ghoſt mate ouercome weeping ſorrow deſire thee thing mote graunten thee yt thy welefulneſſe amenuſed ſhall ſaine eke thy two ſons counſaylours child age ſhineth likeneſſe wit father elde father ſithen ſouerain cure mortall folk ſauen liues thou know thy ſelf thy good make thee welefull yet ben thing dwelled thee ward man doubteth ne deereworth thee thine life thy drie tear yet euery fortune hatefull thee ward ne ouergreat tempeſt ne hath yet fallen vpon thee thine ankers cleven faſt neither woll ſufferen ye comfort time preſent ne hope time coming paſſen ne failen bo pray qd faſt mote holden ye while holden howſoeuer thing ſhall well fleten forth eſcapen thou maiſt well ſeen great apparailes array lacked paſſed away fro phi
