haue ſomewhat aduanced furthered thee qd ſhe yt thou annoy forthink thy fortune ſaith haue ſomewhat comforted thee ſo yt thou tempeſt thee thus thy fortune ſithen thou haſt yet thy beſt thyngs may fuffren thy delices y• plaineſt ſo weeping anguiſhous lacketh ſomewhat thy welefulneſſe man ſo ſad great perfite welefulneſſe ne ſtriueth playneth ſome half ayen qualitie eſtate full anguiſhous thing ye condicion man good eyther commeth together wight el ne laſteth perpetuell ſome man hath great richeſſe aſhamed vngentill linage ſome man renomed nobleſſe kinrede incloſed ſo great anguiſh need thing yt leuer vnknow ſome man haboundeth richeſſe nobleſſe yet bewayleth chaſt life ne hath wife ſome man ſelily maried hath child nouriſheth richeſſes ſtraunge folk ſome man gladded child weepeth full ſore treſpace ſon • doughter ne accordeth wight lightly yt condicion fortune alway euery man ſomwhat vnaſſayed ne wote nought el dreadeth hath aſſayed add alſo euery welefull man hath full delicate feeling ſo thing befallen impacient vſed haue none aduerſitie anon throwen adown euery little thing full little thing tho withdrawn ſumme perfection bliſfulneſſe fro hem moſt fortunate many men troweſt thou would deemen hemſelfe ben almoſt heauen mighten attain leaſt partie remenaunt thy fortune ſame place thou cleapeſt exile countrey enhabiten thy nothing wretched thou weneſt ſaith thou thy ſelf ne wight el ni wretch weneth himſelf wretch reputation courage ayenward fortune bliſful man agreeabilitie egalitie ſuffereth man ſo weleful nold changen eſtate hath loſt pacience ſweetneſſe man welefulneſſe ſprant many bitterneſſes welefulneſſe although ſeem ſweet joyful vſeth yet may withholden ne goeth away woll well ſeen wretched bliſfulneſſe mortal thing neither dureth perpetuel hem euery fortune receiuen agreeably egally ne deliteth hem ben anguiſhous ye mortal folk ſeek ye bliſfulneſſe ſelf put ſelf errour folly confoundeth ſhall ſhew thee ſhortly point ſoueraign bliſfulneſſe thing thee precious thy life thou wilt aunſwere nay ſo thou art mightie ouer thy ſelf ſain tranquilitie thy ſoul haſt thou thing thy power thou noldeſt neuer leſen ne fortune may bynemme thee thou maiſt know bliſfulneſſe ne may ſtand thyngs fortunous temporell nowe vnderſtande gather together thus bliſfulneſſe ſoueraign good nature liueth reaſon ne thilke thing ſoueraign good may taken away wiſe worthie thing dign thilke thing may taken away ſheweth well vnſtableneſſe fortune may nat attayne receyue bliſfulneſſe yet moreouer manne tumbling welefulneſſe leadeth eyther wote changeable el wote wote bliſful fortune may blindneſſe ignoraunce wote chaungeable mote alway ben adrad ne leſe thing ne doubteth may leſen fayth mote alway agaſt leaſt leſe woteth right well may leſe continuall dread hath ne ſuffereth welefull el leſe weneth diſpiſed foreleten certes eke full little good born euen hart loſt ſain men force loſſe hauing much thou thy ſelf art hath ſhewed preued full many demonſtrations wote well ſouls men ne mowen dien wiſe eke ſens cleare certain yt fortunous welefulneſſe endeth death body may doubted death may take away bliſfulneſſe y• kind mortal thing ne deſcendeth wretchedneſſe end death ſithen know well many man hath ſought fruit bliſfulneſſe ſuffering death eke ſuffering pain tourments might preſent life make men bliſfull ſens thilk ſelf life ended ne maketh folk wretch quiſquis volet perennem cautus ponere ſedem stabiliſque nec ſonori sterni flatibus euri et fluctibus minantem curat ſpernere pontum montis cacumen alti bibulas vitet arena c manner folk ware ſtable woll founden hem perdurable ſeat ne caſt lowde blaſts wind eurus deſpiſe sea menaſing floudes let eſchew builden coppe mountain moiſt sand fell wind auſter tormenteth coppe mountain ſtrengths loſe ſands refuſen bear heauy weight thy thou wolt flien perillous aduenture ſay world haue mind certainly ſet thine houſe merrie ſeat low ſtone although wind troubling ſea thunder ouerthrowing thou art put quiet welefull ſtrength thy palleis ſhalt lead clear age ſcorning woodneſſe ire aire sed quoniam rationum jam te mearum fomenta diſcendunt paulo validioribus utendum puto age enim si jam caduca ac momentaria fortunae c bvt much nouriſhings reaſon diſcenden thee trow time vſen little ſtronger medicine vnderſtand ſo yefts fortune ne brittle ne tranſitorie hem may thyne time el ne foul looked conſidered perfitly richeſſes precious nature hemſelf el nature thee moſt worth richeſſe gold might money aſſembled tertes gold money ſhineth yeueth better renome diſpenden thilk folk muckeren auarice maketh alway muckerers ben hated largeſſe maketh folk clere renome ſith ſuch thing ben tranſferred one man another ne may dwell man certes money precious tranſlated folk ſtinten vſage large yeuing hath yeuen alſo money ouer world gadered toward one man ſhould make men needie certes voice hole yt ſain without amenuſing fulfilleth together hearing much folk ben apaſſed need maken hem poor forgone tho richeſſes ſtrait needy clepe theſe richeſſes ſens yt many folk ne may haue ne ne may commen one man without pouertie folk ſhining gem call precious ſtones draweth eyen folk hemward ſain beautie certes beautie bountie ſhining ſtones thilk clearneſſe ſtones hemſelf men wonder greatly men maruailen ſuch thing thing wanteth moouing joyncture ſoule bodye right might ſeemen fair creature hath ſoul reaſon ſo yt gem drawn hemſelf little laſt beautie world thentent creator y• diſtinction hemſelf yet mikel ben put vnder excellence ne haue deſerued way ye ſhould maruailen hem beautie field delighteth mikell vnto b ſhould delighten v ſith right fayre porcion right fayre werke ſayne world right ſo gladded ſometime y• face ſea clear alſo maruailen heauen starres sunne moone phi appertaineth qd ſhe thilk thing thee dareſt thou glorifie thee ſhining anye ſuch thyngs art thou diſtingued embeliſed ſpringing floures firſt summer ſeaſon ſwelleth thy plentie fruit summer art thou rauiſhed idle joy embraceſt thou ſtrange good thine fortune ne ſhall neuer make ſuch thing thine nature thing hath maked forrain fro thee sooth withouten doubt fruit yearth owen nouriſhing beaſts thou wolt fulfill thy need ſuffiſeth nature need yt thou ſeek ſuperfluitie fortune full thing full little thing nature hath apaid thou wolt achoken yt fulfilling nature ſuperfluities certes thilke thing yt thou wolt threſten pouren nature ſhullen ben unjoyful thee el annoyous weneſt thou eke yt fair thing ſhine diuers clothing clothing yt beauty agreeable looken vpon woll maruailen ye nature matter thilk clothes el workman wrought hem doth alſo long rout meine make thee bliſfull man ſeruants ben vicious condicions great charge deſtruction hous great enemie ye ſord himſelf ben good men ſhall ſtrange forrain goodneſſe put number thy richeſſes theſe foreſaid thing clearly ſhewed neuer one thilk thing yt thou accomptedeſt thy good na thy good thing beautie deſired ſhouldeſt thou ſorrie leſe ſhouldeſt thou rejoyce thee hold hem fair kind wt appertaineth yt thee alſo wel ſhoulden haue ben fair himſelf though departed thy richeſſes fair ne precious commen among thy richeſſes ſeemed fair precious therfore thou hadſt leuer recken hem among thy richeſſes deſireſt thou fortune ſo great afare trow thou ſekeſt driue away need abundance thing certes turneth contrarie certes needeth full many helping keepen ye diuerſitie precious hoſtile ments ſooth many thing haue need yt many thing haue ayenward little thing needeth meaſureth fill need kind outrage couetiſe ſo ye menne haue proper good ſet ſuch ye moten ſeek outward forraine ſubject thing condicion thing tourned vp ſo doun man yt diuine creature merit reaſon thinketh himſelfe ni neither faire ne noble poſſeſſion hoſtiliments ne han life certes al thing ben apaied beauty ye men ſemblable god reaſonable thought deſiren apparailen excellent kinde loweſt thing ne ye vnderſtanden howe great wrong done creatour would mankinde moſt worthy noble yearthly thing ye threſten dignity beneathen loweſt thing good every thing precious thilke thing whoſe good ſith ye deemen fouleſt thyngs good ſubmitten ye put ſelven vnder fouleſt thing eſtimation certes betideth without deſert certes ſuch condition mankinde onely hath knowing ſelfe paſſeth nobleſſe thing forletteth knowing ſelf brought beneathen beaſts liuing creature han kind knowen himſelf men letten knowing hemſelfe commeth hem vice brode ſheweth errour folly men yt wenen thing may ben apparailed ſtraunge apparailements forſooth may done wight ſhineth thyngs put thus thilke thing ſhinen manne apparailed certes thilke thinges commended praiſed apparailed natheles thing covered wrapped vnder dwelleth filthe deny thilk thing good yt anoyeth yt hath gabbe thou wolt ſay nay certes richeſſes haue annoyed full oft hem han tho richeſſe sith y• every wicked ſhrew wickedneſſe ye greedy folkes richeſſes wherſoever place gold precious ſtones weneth moſt worthy hath hem thou yt ſo buſie dredeſt ſwerd ſpear thou haddeſt entred path life annoyen wayfaring men wouldeſt thou ſing theef ſaith poore man beareth richeſſe ye way may boldly ſing beforne theeves hath whereof robbed precious right clear blisfulneſs mortal richeſſe thou haſt gotten haſt thou lorne thy ſikerneſſe foelix nimium prior aetas contenta fidelibus arvis nec inerti perdita luxu facilique ſera ſolebat jejunia ſolvere glande nec bacchia munera norat liquido confundere melle nec lucida vellera ſerum c blisful firſt age men held hem apayed meat true field broughten forth ne deſtroyed deceived hemſelfe outrage woont lightly ſlaken hunger even achornes okes ne coude medell yefte bacchus cleare honey ſain could make ne piemente clarre ne could medell bright fleece countrey syrian venime tirie ſaine coude dyen white fleece syrian countrey blood manner shellfiſh men finden tyrie blood men dyen purple ſlepten holſome ſleeps vpon ye graſſe dronken renning water lien vnder ye ſhadows ye high pine tree ne gheſte ſtraunger ne carfe yet ye high ſea oares ſhippes ne ne hadden ſeine yet new ſtronds leaden marchandiſe diver countreys tho cruell clarion full huſt full ſtill ne blood •• ad eagre hate ne dyed yet armures whereto would woodneſſe enemy firſt mouen armes ſawen cruel wound ne none meedes blood yſhad would time ſhould tourne ayen old manner anguiſhous loue folke burneth cruelly mountain ethna aye brenneth ala firſt dalfe gobbet weight gold couered earth precious ſtones woulden haue hid dalfe precious peril ſain hem firſt dalfe dalfe precious peril preciouſneſſe ſuch thing hath many man ben peril quid autem de dignitatibus potentiaque diſſeram quas vos vere dignitatis ac poteſtatis inſcii coelo exaequatis quae ſi improbiſſimum quemque ceciderint c bvt ſhall ſay dignity power yee men neyther knowen dignitie ne power areiſen high heauen whiche dignity power commen wicked man doen great dammages deſtructions doth flame ye mountaine ethna ye flame walloweth ne deluvy ne doth ſo cruel harm certes ye remember well trow yt thilke dignitie ye men cleape imperie counſaylours whylome beginning freedome elder coueited haue doen away pride counſailours right ſame elder time done away citie rome king name ſain nolde haue lenger king ſo yt dignity power ben yeuen good men thing ful ſeld agreable thing tho dignity power onely goodneſſe folke vſen hem therefore thus yt honour commeth vertue becauſe dignitie ayenward honour commeth dignitie cauſe vertue whiche thilke deereworth power ſo cleare ſo requirable yee yearthly creature conſider yee ouer thing ſeemeth ye haue power thou ſaw mouſe emong mouse challenged himſelfeward right power ouer mouse great ſcorne wouldeſt thou haue gloſa fareth men body hath power ouer ye body thou look well vpon body wight thyng ſhalt thou find frayle mankinde menne full oft bee ſlain biting fly el entring creeping wormes priuities man bodie ſhall men finden man y• may exerciſen haunten right vpon another man body el vpon thyngs beene lower bodye whiche cleape fortune poſſeſſions mayeſt thou haue euer commaundement ouer free courage maieſt thou remeue fro ſtate proper reſt thought yt cleauing together himſelfe ſtedfaſt reaſon whylome tyraunt wened confound free man courage wend conſtrayne tourments maken diſcoueren accuſen folke wiſlen coniuracion clepe confederacie yt caſt ayen tyraunt freeman hote owne tongue caſt viſage thilke wood tyraunt torment wood tyraunt wend haue made matter crueltie wiſe man made matter vertue wt thing man may doe another man yt ne may receiuen ſame thing folke himſelfe thus may man doen folke yt folke ne may doen ſame haue heard tolde buſiride woont ſlean gheſtes harbouren houſe ſlaine himſelfe hercules gheſt regulus taken battaile many men affrick caſt hem fetter ſoone muſt yeuen handes bee bound cheines hem whylome ouercommen weneſt thou mightie hath power doen y• ne may doen doe yet moreouer ſo yt theſe dignity power hadden proper naturall goodneſſe hem neuer nold commen ſhrewes contrarious thinges ne woont ifellowſhipped togethers nature refuſeth yt contrarious thing ben joyned ſo certaine wicked folke haue dignity oft time ſheweth well dignity power ne good owne kind ſens ſufferen hemſelf cleauen joynen hemſelf ſhrewes certaine ſame thing may moſt dignely judgen ſaine ye yefts fortune yt moſt plenteouſly commen ſhrewes yefts trowe ought bee conſidred man doubteth hee ſtrong ſeeth ſtrength ſwiftneſſe ſooth ſwift alſo muſick maketh muſiciens phiſicke maketh phyſiciens rhetoricke eke rhetoriciens nature euerie thing maketh property ne entermedled yt effect contrarious thyngs certes richeſſes may reſtraine auarice vnſtaunched ne power ne maketh man mightie ouer himſelf yt vicious luſts holden diſtrained chain ne mowen vnbounden dignity yeuen ſhreud folke onely ne maketh hem digne ſheweth rather openly vnworthy indigne thus certes yee haue joy clepe thing falſe name bearen hem contrary name ben full oft reprooued effect ſame thinges theſe ilke richeſſes ne oughten right bee cleped richeſſes ne ſuch power ne ought cleped power ne ſuch dignitie ne ought cleaped dignitie laſt may conclude y• ſame thing yefts fortune ni nothing bee deſired ne yt hath himſelfe naturall bountie well iſeene neither ioynen hem alway good men ne maken hem alway good joyned novimus quantas dederit ruinas urbe flammata patribuſque caeſis fratre qui quondam ferus interempto matris effuſo maduit cruore corpus viſu gelidum pererrans os non tinxit lachrimis ſed eſſe cenſor extincti potuit decoris c well known many great harmes diſtructions doen emperour nero let brennen citee rome made ſlea senatours cruell whilome ſlough brother made moiſte blood mother ſay let ſleen ſlitten ye wombe mother ſeen conceyued loked euery halue dedde cold bodie ne teare wette face ſo hard harted yt might dome man iudge dedde beautie natheleſſe yet gouerned nero ſcepter people phebus may ſeen comming vttereſt ariſing till hid beam vnder wawes yt ſaine gouerned ye people septre imperiall sunne goeth fro eaſt weſt eke nero gouerned septre people vnder ye cold ſterres highten septentrions ſain gouerned people yt vnder ye party north eke nero gouerned people ye violent winde nothus ſkorclith baketh brenning ſandes drie heate ſay ye people south yet ne might power tourne woodneſſe wicked nero ala greuous fortune oft wicked ſweard joyned cruell venime ſay venemous crueltie lordſhip tunc ego scis inquam ipſa minimam nobis ambitionem mortalium rerum fuiſſe dominatam sed materiam gerendis rebus optavimus quo ne virtu cacita conſeneſceret p et illa atqui hoc unum eſt c ſaid thus thou woteſt well thy ſelfe couetiſe mortall thinges ne hadden neuer lordſhip haue well deſired matter thinges doen ſaith deſire haue matter gouernaunces ouer comminalties vertue ſtill ſhould elden ſaine leſt er wext old vertue lay ſtill ne ſhould periſhe vnexerciſed gouernance commune men might ſpeaken writen good gouernement phi forſooth qd ſhe thing may drawen gouernaunce ſoche harte worthy noble nature natheleſſe may drawen tellen ſuch harte ybrought full perfection vertue ſain couetiſe glorie renome haue well adminiſtred ye common thing doen good deſertes profite ye common ſee conſider little void price thilke glory certaine thing thou haſt learned ye demonſtracion aſtronomy al ye enuironning ye yearth ne halt reaſon pricke ye regard greatneſſe ye heauen ſain y• maked compariſon yearth ye greatneſſe heauen men would judgen ne held ſpace ye little region world fourth part yearth inhabited liuing beaſts knowen thou haſt thy ſelfe ilearned ptholome proueth thou haddeſt withdrawen abated thy thought thilke fourth part moch ſpace ſee mary conteynen ouergone moch ſpace ye region drought ouer ſtretcheth ſaine ſands deſertes wel vnneth ſhuld dwellen right ſtrait place habitacion men ye enuironed cloſed leſt pricke thilke pricke thinken ye manifeſten publiſhen renome done name ben borne forth glory yt ſo narow ſo ſtraight throngen ſo litel bound mikell conteyneth large great alſo ſet thereto yt many nacion diuers tongue maners eke reaſon liuing inhabite cloſe thilke habitacle ye nacions difficultie wayes diuerſitie language defaulte vnuſage entrecomming marchandiſe onely ye name ſinguler men ne may ſtretchen eke ye fame city may ſtretchen laſte certes time marcus tullius ſelfe writeth boke renome ye commonwelth rome ne yet paſſed ne clomben ouer mountaine yt hight caucaſus yet rome well waxen redoubted ye parthes eke folk enhabiting seeſt thou ſtraite compreſſed thilke glory yee trauailen ſhewen multiply may glory ſinguler romane ſtretchen thider fame name rome may climben ne paſſen eke ſeeſt thou yt maners diuers folke lawes diſcordant amonges hemlelf ſo yt thilke thing yt ſom men judge worthy praiſing folke judgen worthy tourment hereof commeth yt though man deliteth prayſing renome may wiſe bringen forth ne ſpreden name many maner people therefore euery man ought apaid glory ye publiſhed among owne neighbour thilke noble renome ſhall reſtrayned within bound tho maner folke many man yt full noble tyme hath wretch nedy foryeting writer put mind away al ſo yt certes thilke thing profiten litell thing writing long derke elde away hem eke auctours ye men ſemen getten perdurabilitie ye thinken time comming fame ſhall laſten natheleſſe thou wilt make compariſon endleſſe ſpaces eternite wt thing haſt thou thou maiſt rejoycen thee long laſting thy name made compariſon ye abiding moment ten thouſand winter moch tho ſpaces ben ended yet hath moment ſome porcion although litell natheleſſe thilke ſelfe nombre yeres eke many yeres thereto may multiplied ne may certes compariſoned ye perdurabilite yt endleſſe thing yt ende may made compariſon thinges withouten ende thing haue end may maked compariſon thy although renome long time euer thee liſt thinken compared regard ye eternitie vnſtaunchable infinite ne ſhould onely ſeem littell plainly right nought yee ſemen certes ye nothing right ye audience people ydle rumour ye forſaken great worthineſſe conſcience vertue ye ſeken guerdon ſmall word ſtrange folke haue vnderſtand lightneſſe ſoche pride veine glory man skorned feſtinally merily ſoche vanite whilom man yt aſſaied ſtriuing word another manne uſage vertue proude vaine glory taken upon falſly y• name philoſophre rather man ſpeak thought wold aſſay wheder thilke philoſophre ſay yt would haue ſuffred lightly pacience wrong y• done fained philoſophre toke pacience litel receiued word outrage ſtriuing ayen reioyſing ſelf ſaid laſt thus vnderſtandeſt thou philoſophre man anſwerde bitingly ſaid well underſtand thou haddeſt holden thy tonge ſtill wt theſe noble worthy men certes ſuch folk ſpeak ſeken glory vertue qd ſhe atteyneth fame ſoche folke body reſolued deth laſt ſo men dien ſay body ſoul thing reaſon defendeth u beleue glory wiſe wt ſhould thilke glory thilke glory ſaid ni right naught wiſe ye ſoul hath ſelf ſcience good werkes unbounden priſon ye yerth wendeth freely heauen diſpiſeth erthly occupacion heauen reioyſeth exempt erthly thing faith recketh ſoul neuer glory renome world quicunque ſolam mente praecipiti petit ſummumque credit gloriam lace patentes aetheris cernat plagas artumque terrarum ſitum brevem replere non valentis ambitum c ſo ouerthrowing thought onely ſeeketh glory fame weneth ſoueraine good let loken upon brode ſhewing countreys heauen upon ſtraite ſeate earth ſhall aſhamed thencreaſe name may fulfill littel compas earth coueyten proude folk liften neckes idle deadly yoke world although renome yſprad paſſing toforn people goth diuers tonges although great houſes kindred ſhinen clere title honour yet natheleſſe death diſpiſeth high glory fame death wrappeth togithers high head lowe maketh equal euen hieſt loweſt wonen bone trew fabricius brutus ſterne caton thynne fame yet laſtyng ydle name marked letter although haue knowen fair word fame hem yeuen know hem deed conſumpt liggeth ſtill utterly unknowable ne fame ne maketh know ye wene liue ye lenger wind mortal name one cruel day ſhall take away alſo ſhall ye die ſecond death firſt death clepeth departing body ſecond death ſtinting renome fame sed ne inexorabile contra fortunam gerere bellum putes eſt aliquando cum de hominibus fallax illa non nihil bene mereatur tum ſcilicet cum ſe aperit c bvt moch thou ſhalt wenen qd ſhe beare untreatable batayle ayenſt fortune yet ſometimes falleth ſhe nothing diſceiuable deſerueth haue right good thanke men ſhe ſelfe openeth ſhe diſcouereth front ſheweth manner perauenture yet underſtandeſt thou ſhall ſay wondre deſire tell therefore vnneth may unpliten ſentence word deme yt contrarious fortune profiteth men fortune debonayre alway fortune ſemeth debonayre ſhe lieth falſly biheting hope welefulneſſe contrarious fortune alway ſothfaſte ſhe ſheweth ſelfe unſtable chaungyng amiable fortune diſceiueth folk yt contrary fortune teacheth amiable fortune blindeth beautie falſe goodes hart folk uſen hem contrary fortune unbindeth hem knowing frele welefulneſſe thamyable fortune maieſt thou ſene alway windy flowing euer misknowing ſelf contrary fortune attempre reſtrained wiſe thorow exerciſe aduerſite laſt amiable fortune flaterings draweth miſwandring men fro ſoueraine good contrarious fortune leadeth oft folk ayen ſothfaſt good halteth hem ayen hoke weneſt thou thou oughteſt leten litell thing aſpre horrible fortune hath diſcouered thee thought thy trew frendes ilke fortune hath departed uncouered thee certain viſages eke doutous viſages thy felawes departed away fro thee ſhe took away frends laft thee thy frendes thou rich welefull thee ſemed mykell woldeſt thou haue bought full knowing ſain knowing thy frends plain thee richeſſe lorne ſith thou haſte found moſt precious kind richeſſe ſaine thy frendes quod mundus ſtabili fide concordes variat vice quod pugnantia ſemina faedus perpetuum tenet c world ſtable faith varieth accordable chaungings contrarious qualitees element holden among hem ſelf alyaunce perdurable phebus ſonne golden chariot bringeth forth roſie day moon hathe commaundement ouer nightes nightes eſperus euen ſterre hath brought ſea gredy flowen conſtraineth certain end flood ſo lefull ſtretch brode term bound upon yearth ordinaunce thing bounden loue gouerneth earth ſea alſo hath commaundement heauen loue ſlaked bridle thinges louen togithers wolden make bataile continuelly ſtriuen fordone facion world leden accordable faith faire mouings loue holdeth togider people ioyned holy bond knitteth ſacrament mariage chaſte loues loue endeth lawes true felawes welefull mankinde thilke loue gouerneth heauen gouerned courage ¶here endeth ſecond boke jam cantum illa finierat cum audiendi avidum ſtupentemque arrectis adhuc auribus carminis dulcedo defixerat itaque paulo poſt inquam ſummum laſſorum ſolamen animorum quantum c ſhe ended ſong ſweetneſſe dytie perced mee deſirous herkening aſtonied yet ſtreight mine eares yt ſaine herken bet ſhe ſhould ſay ſo yt litel ſaid thus thou art ſouerain comfort corages anguiſhous ſo thou haſt remounted nouriſhed ye weight thy ſentences delite ſinging ſo trowe unperegall y• ſtrokes fortune ſaith dare well ſuffren thaſſauts fortune well defend tho remedy thou ſaideſt beforne yt right ſharpe y• agriſen hem deſirous hearing ask greatly hearen ye remedy ſaied ſhe thus feled well qd ſhe thou ententife ſtill rauiſhedeſt word abode till thou haddeſt ſoche habyte thy thought thou haſt el till ſelf maked ſame habit trew thing certes ye remnant thing ben yet ſay ben ſoch yt firſt men taſte hem bene biting bene receiued within wight ben ſwete thou ſayſt thou art ſo deſirous hearken hem great brenning wouldeſt thou glowen thou wiltes whider wold leden thee b whider qd p thilke blisfulneſſe qd ſhe thine hart dremeth moch thy ſight occupied diſtourbed earthly thing thou maieſt yet ſene thilk ſelf welefulneſſe b doe qd ſhew thilke welefulnes pray thee without taryeng p woll gladly done qd ſhe cauſe thee wol firſt marken word woll enforcen enforme thee thilk falſe cauſe blisfulneſſe thou knoweſt ſo thou haſte beholden thilke falſe goodes turned thine iyen ſo ſide thou may knowen eleereneſſe blisfulneſſe qui ſerere ingenuum volet agrum liberat arva prius fruticibus falce rubos filicemque reſecat c ſo woll ſowe field plenteous let firſt deliueren thornes kerue aſonder hoke buſhes ferne ſo corne may commen heauie eres greines hony ſwete mouth haue firſt taſted ſauors wycke sterres ſhinen agreably wind nothus letteth plungy blaſtes lucifer day ſterre hath chaſed away dark night y• day fairer ledeth roſen horſe ſonne right ſo thou beholding firſt y• falſe good begin withdraw thy neck fro yt yearthly affection afterwards good ſhullen entren thy corage tum defixo paululum viſu velut anguſtam ſuae mentis ſedem recepta ſic cepit p omnis mortalium cura quam multiplicium ſtudiorum labor exercet c tho faſtened ſhe litel ſight eien ſhe withdrew right ſtrait ſeate thought began ſpeake right thus cure qd ſhe mortall folke trauailen hem many maner ſtudies gon certes diuers wayes natheleſſe enforcen hem commen onely thende blisfulnes blisfulnes ſoch good ſo hath gotten ne may thing deſire thing forſooth ſo ſoueraine good conteyneth himſelf manner goodes good fayled thing might ſoueraine good ſome good ſoueraine good might deſired clere certaine bliſfulneſſe parfite ſtate ye congregacion goodes ye blisfulneſſe haue ſayd mortal folke enforcen hem get diuers way couetiſe euery good naturelly planted ye hart men miſwandring errour miſledeth hem falſe good men ſome hem wenen ſoueraine good liuen without need thing men demen ſoueraine good right digne reuerence enforcen hem reuerenced among neighbour honour haue gotten ſome folk ben holden right hie power ſoueraine good enforcen hem reignen el ioynen hem hem reigne ſeemeth folk nobleſſe renome ſoueraine good haſten hem getten hem glorious name artes werre peace many folke meaſuren geſſen ſouerayne good ioy gladneſſe wenen bee right blisful thing plongen voluptuous delites ben ſome folke enterchaungen cauſes end theſe foreſaid good deſiren richeſſes haue power delight el deſire power haue money cauſe renome theſe thing ſoch turned entencion deſirings werkes menne thus nobleſſe fauour people yeueth men ſeemeth hem maner cleereneſſe renome wife child men deſiren cauſe delite merineſſe forſoth frendes ne ſhullen rekened among goodes fortune vertue full holy maner thing theſe thing forſoth taken cauſe power el cauſe delite certes ready referren good body theſe foreſaid thing abouen ſemeth ſtrength greatneſſe body yeuen power worthineſſe beaute ſwiftneſſe yeuen glory renome health body ſeemeth yeuen delite theſe thing ſeemeth onely blisfulneſſe deſired thilke thing euery man deſireth moſte ouer thing deemeth ſoueraine good haue defined blisfulneſſe ſouerain good euery wight deemeth thilke eſtate deſireth ouer thing blisfulneſſe haſt thou thine eyen almoſt purpoſed forme welefulneſſe mankind ſain richeſſe honour power glory delites delite onely conſidred epicurus aud iudged eſtabliſhed delite ſoueraine good moche thing thought byreſt away ioy myrthe hart returne againe ſtudies men men corage alway reherſeth ſeeketh ſoueraine good ſo dyrked memory pathe right dronken man note nought path may returne home houſe semeth folke forleyen erren enforcen hem haue need nothing certes none thing may ſo moch performen blisfulneſſe eſtate plenteous good ne hath neede none thing ſuffiſaunt himſelfe unto himſelf folien ſoche folke wenen thilke thing right good eke right worthy honor reuerence certes nay thing ny neither foule ne worthy diſpiſed well nigh entencion mortal folke travailen get power eke ought rekened amongs goodes el ni wene thilke thing moſt worthy thing feble without ſtrength clereneſſe renome ought yt ben deſpiſed certes may man forſake thing yt right excellent noble ne ſemeth right clere renomed certes needeth ſay bliſfulneſſe anguiſhous ne drerie ne ſubject greuaunces ne ſorowes ſens right littell thing folke ſeken haue uſen may delighten hem certes theſe ben thing men willen deſiren getten cauſe deſiren richeſſes dignity reignes glorie delites therby wened haue ſuffiſaunce honour power renome gladnes good men ſeken thus ſo many diuers ſtudies deſire may lightly ſhewed great ſtrength nature ſo men haue diuers ſentences diſcordings algates men accorden louing end good quantas rerum flectit habenas natura potens quibus immenſum legibus orbem provida ſervet ſtringatque ligan irreſoluto singula nexu placet arguto fidelibus lentis promere cantu c lyketh ſhew ſubtil ſong ſlack delitable ſowne ſtrings nature mightely enclineth aud flitteth gouernment thing ſoche lawe ſhee purueiable keepeth great world ſhe binding reſtraineth thing bonde may unbounden ſo lion countrey pene beren faire chaines taken meates hand folke yeuen hem dreden ſturdie maiſters wont ſuffre beating horrible mouthes bledde ſain beeſtes devoured corage time paſſed hath idle reſted repaireth ayen roren greuouſly remembren nature ſtaken neck chaines unbound maiſter firſt torne bloody teeth aſſaieth woode wrathes hem ſain fretten maiſter iangling bird ſingeth hie braunches ſaine woode encloſed ſtraite cage although plyeng beſineſſe men yeue hem honied drinkes large meates ſwete ſtudy yet natheles thilke bird skipping ſtraite cage ſeeth agreeable ſhadowes woodes ſhe defouleth foot meat iſhad ſeeketh morning onely wood twireth deſiring woode ſwete voiſe yerde tree haled adown mighty ſtrength boweth redily croppe downe hand bent let gone anon croppe looketh vpright heauen ſonne phebus falleth euen weſtren wawes returneth ayen eftſones carte priuy pathe wont ariſe thing ſeken ayen proper courſe al thing rejoyſen returning againe nature ne none ordinance betaken thing hath joyned end beginning hath made courſe ſelf ſtable chaunge fro proper kind vos quoque ô terrena animalia tenui licet imagine veſtrum tamen principium ſomniatis verum que illum beatitudinis finem licet minime perſpicaci c certes alſo ye men ben erthly creature dreamen alway beginning although thin imaginacion maner thought nat clerely ne perfectly ye loken ferre thilke fine bliſfulneſſe therefore naturel entencion leadeth thilke good many maner errours miſtourneth therefro conſider thilke thing man weneth get bliſfulneſſe may commen thilke end weneth come nature money honor theſe foreſaid thing bringen men ſoch thing good ne fail ne ſemeth fail certes wold graunt maked bliſfull thing haue gotten ſo thilke thing ne mowen performe byheten defaut many goodes ſheweth clerely falſe beautie bliſfulneſſe knowen atteint thilk thing firſt forward thou thy ſelf haddeſt aboundance richeſſe nat long agon ask thee thaboundance al thilk rich thou neuer anguiſhous ſorrie thy courage wrong greuaunce betide thee ſide b certes qd ne remembreth euer ſo free thought ne alway anguiſh ſomewhat p qd ſhe thee lacked ſomewhat thou noldeſt haue lacked el thou haddeſt thou noldeſt haue b right ſo qd p deſireſt thou preſence one thabſence b graunt well qd p forſoth qd ſhe nedeth ſomewhat euery man deſireth b ye nedeth qd p certes qd ſhe hath lacke neede aught ni euery way ſuffiſant himſelf b qd p thou qd ſhe al plentie thy richeſſe haddeſt thilke lacke ſuffiſance b el qd p may rich maken man ni nedy ne ſufficient himſelf yet beheten ſemed eke certes trowe greatly conſider money hath owne kind ne may bynomen hem haue maugre hem bo know well qd p ſhouldſt thou beknowen qd ſhe euery day ſtrenger folke benomen feobler maugre hem whens come el theſe forain complaint quarels pleading men asken money hath binomed hem ſtrength gyle alway maugre hem boec right ſo qd phi hath man need qd ſhe ſeeken forain help may defend money boecius may ſay nay qd phil certes qd ſhe needed helpe ne money might leſe boecius doubtles qd philoſophie thing tourned contrary qd ſhe richeſſe men wenen ſhould maken ſuffiſaunce maken man rather haue need forain help maner guiſe qd ſhe richeſſe may driuen away need riche folke may neuer haue honger ne thurſt theſe rich men may fele cold lims winter thou wilt aunſwere rich men haue inough wherewith may ſtaunchen honger ſlaken thurſt doen away colde wiſe may need comforted richeſſe certes need ne may vtterly doen away need alway gaping greedy fulfilled richeſſe thing yet dwelleth need mote fulfilled hold ſtill tell little thing ſufiſeth nature certes auarice ſuffiſeth inough nothing ſince rich ne may doen away need maken need wt may ye wenen richeſſes mowen yeuen ſuffiſaunce quamvis fluente dive auri gurgite non expleturas cogat avarus opes c al ſo noble couetous man riuer gutter fleeting gold yet ſhould neuer ſtaunch couetiſe although neck charged precious ſtones red sea though ere field plenteous hundred ox neuer ne ſhal biting buſineſſe forleten liueth ne light richeſſes ne ſhall bearen compaigny dead sed dignitatis honorabilem reverendum que cui provenerint reddunt num vi ea eſt magiſtratibus ut utentium mentibus vi • tutes inſerant vicia depellant c bvt dignity commen maken honourable reverent ſo great ſtrength may putten vertue hertes folkes uſen lordſhip hem el may done away vice certes wont away wickednes wont rather ſhew wickedneſſe thereof commeth haue right great disdain dignity yeuen wicked men thing catullus cleped conſull rome hight nonius poſtome boche ſaith cleped congregacion vice breſt poſtome full corrupcion nonius ſet chaire dignite seeſt thou great vilonies dignity done wicked men certes unworthines wicked men ſhuld laſſe ſeen nere renomed none honour certes thou thy ſelfe ne mighteſt bee brought many peril thou mighteſt ſuffre thou woldeſt beare magiſtrate decorate ſaine peril might befall thee offence king theodorike thou noldeſt felawe gouernaunce decorate thou ſawe wicked corage licorous ſhrew accuſour ne may ſoche honour iudgen hem worthy reuerence deeme holde unworthy haue thilke ſame honour thou ſaw man fulfild wiſdome certes thou ne mighteſt deme unworthy honour el wiſedome whiche fulfilled boecius qd philoſophie certes qd ſhe dignity appertainen properly vertue vertue tranſporteth dignitie anon thilke man ſhe ſelfe conioyned moch honour people ne may make folke digne honour well ſeen clerely ne haue proper beautie dignitie yet men oughten take heed wight ſo moch outcaſt deſpiſed moſt folke ſo dignitie ne may maken ſhrewes worthy reuerence maketh dignite ſhrewes rather diſpiſed praiſed ſhrewes dignite ſheweth moche folke forſooth unpuniſhed ſaine ſhrewes reuengen hem ayenward upon dignity yelden ayen dignity great guerdon diſpotten defoulen dignity vilonie moch thou knoweſt thilke reuerence ne may nat commen theſe ſhadowy tranſitorie dignity underſtonde thus man uſed many maner dignity conſuls parauenture commen among ſtraunge nacions ſhuld thilke honour maken worſhipfull redoubted ſtraunge folke certes honour people naturel yefte dignity ne might neuer ceſſen among maner folke done office right fyre euery countrey ne ſtinteth enchaufen maken hote moch honorable reuerent ne commeth folk proper ſtrength nature onely falſe opinion folk ſaine wenen dignity maken folke digne honour anone therefore commen folke ne knowen thilke dignity honour vaniſhen away anon among ſtraunge folke mayſt thou ſaine ne amongs hem borne ne dureth thilke dignity alway certes dignitie prouoſtry rome whilom great power nothing ydle name rent senatorie great charge wight whilom office taken hede vitailes people corne thinges holden amongs hem great thing caſte thilke prouoſtrie haue ſaid little beforne thilke thing hath proper beaute ſelf receiueth ſometime price ſhining ſometime leſeth thopinion uſaunces dignity ne mowe make folke digne reuerence dignity wexen foule wyll ſilthe ſhrewes dignity leſen ſhining chaunging tymes wexen foule eſtimacion people han hem ſelfe beaute ought deſired ſaith none ne mowen yeuen beaute dignite none quamvis ſe tyrio ſuperbus oſtro comeret niveis lapillis c al ſo proude nero wode luxure kembe apparelled faire purpure tirie white peerles algates yet thereof hee hatefull folke ſay behated folkes yet wicked nero great lordſhippe yafe whilome reuerent senatours unworſhipful ſeates dignity vnworſhipfull ſeates clepeth nero ſo wicked yafe dignity would reaſonably wenen blisfulneſſe ſoch honour yeuen vicious ſhrewes vero regna regnumque familiaritas efficere potentem valent quidni c bvt reignes familiarity kynges may maken man ben mighty el blisfulneſſe dureth perpetually certes olde age time paſſed eke preſent time full enſamples king haue chaunged wretchedneſſe welefulnes noble thing clere thing power ni founden mighty keepe ſelfe power realmes authour maker bliſfulneſſe thilk power lacketh ſide amenuſeth nat thilke bliſfulneſſe bringeth wretchedneſſe yet al ſo yt realmes mankinde ſtretchen brode yet mote need ben moch folke ouer euery king ne hath lordſhip ne commaundement certes vpon thilk ſide power falleth yt maketh folke bliſfull right ye ſame ſide powere entreth vnderneth maketh hem wretch maner moten king haue porcion wretchedneſſe welefulneſſe tyraunt king cecile yt aſſayed ye perill eſſate ſhewed ſimilitude ye dredes realmes gaſteneſſe ſwerde hong ouer head familier thing power yt may done away bitings buſineſſe ne eſchew prickes drede certes yet woulden liuen ſikerneſſe may nat yet glorifyen hem power holdeſt thou yt thilke man mighty yt thou ſeeſt would done yt may done holdeſt thou mighty man yt hath enuironned ſides men arm ſergeants dredeth hem maketh agaſt dreden put ye hand ſeruaunts hee ſhould ſeeme mightie familiers ſeruaunts king ſhould tell thee thing ſith ſelfe haue ſhewed thee realmes hemſelfe ben ful great feebleſſe familiers certes ye royall power kinges hole eſtate eſtate abated full oft throweth adowne nero conſtrayned senecke familier mayſter cheſen death would die antonius commanded yt knight ſlowen ſwerds papinian familier papinian beene long time full mightie amonges hem court yet certes woulden haue renounced power two seneck enforced himſelfe yeuen nero richeſſe alſo haue gone ſolitarie exile ye great weight ſaine lord power fortune draweth hem ſhullen fall neyther hem ne might doe yt hee would thing thilk power though men yet ben agaſt thou wouldeſt haue thou nart ſiker thou wouldeſt forleten thou maieſt nat eſchewen wheder ben ſuch men friend need counſayled fortune vertue certes ſuch folk weleful fortune maketh frendes contrarious fortune maketh hem enemy peſtilence mighty annoy wight familiar enemy qui ſe volet eſſe potentem animos domet ille feroces nec victa libidine colla c ſo woll mightie mote daunten cruell courage ne put nat neck ouercommen vnder ye foule raynes lechery ſo lordſhip ſtretch ſo ferre yt country inde quaketh thy commandment thy law laſt iſle yt ſee hight tyle thrall thee yet thou maieſt nat putten away thy foule derke deſires driuen fro thee wretched complaint certes ni power thou haſt gloria vero quam fallax ſaepe quam turpis eſt unde non injuria tragicus exclamat gloria gloria millibus mortalium nihil aliud facta niſi aurium inflatio magna c glory deceiuable foule oft thynge vnskilfully tragedian yt ſaine maker dities yt highten tragedy cried ſaid glory glory qd thou nart nothing el thouſands folkes ſweller eares many haue full great renome falſe opinion people thing may thought fouler ſuche prayſing thilke folke prayſed falſely moten needes haue ſhame prayſing folke haue getten hem thank praiſing deſerts thing hath thilk priſe eched encreaſed conſcience wiſe folke meaſured good nat rumour ye people ye ſoothfaſtneſſe conſcience ſeme fair thing man haue encreaſed ſprad name followeth yt deemed ben foule thing ne yſprad encreaſed ſaid little yt ſith mote needes many folkes folke renome man ne may nat commen befalleth thou weneſt glorious renomed ſemeth next part erthes ben without glory without renome certes amongs theſe thing ne trow nat priſe grace people ni neither worthy ben remembred ne commeth wiſe judgement ne ferme perdurably name gentileſſe man ne may well ſeene vaine flitting name gentileſſe referred renome clereneſs linage gentil name forain thing ſay hem glorifien hem linage ſemeth gentilnes manner praiſing commeth deſerts aunceſters praiſing maketh gentilneſſe moten needes gentill ben praiſed thing followeth thou ne gentilnes thy ſelf ſain priſe cometh thy deſert forraine gentilneſſe ne maketh thee nat gentill certes good gentilneſſe trowe onely ſemeth manner neceſſite impoſed gentilmen ne ſhould nat outragen forleauen fro vertues noble kinred omne hominum genus terris simili ſurgit ab hortu unus enim rerum pater eſt unus cuncta miniſtrat c al linage men earth ſemblable birth one alone father thing one alone miniſtreth thing yafe sun beames yafe moone horne yafe men earth yafe ſterres heaven cloſed membres ſoules camen hie ſeat commen mortal folke noble ſeed noiſen boſten ye elder ye loke beginning god father authour maker ny foreliued wight ungentill nouriſhe courage vnto vice forlete proper birth quid autem de corporis voluptatibus loquar quarum appetentia quidem plenum eſt anxietatis c ſhall ſain delices body whiche delices deſirings ben full anguiſhes fulfillings hem ben full penaunce great ſickneſſes great ſorrows unſufferable right maner fruit wickednes ben thilke delices wont bringen body folke yt uſen hem delices joye may mouing wote well ſo euer woll remembren luxures ſhall well underſtand iſſues delices ben ſorowfull ſory thilke delices mow make folke blisful ſame cauſe moten theſe beeſts ben cleped blisful beeſts entencion haſteth fulfill bodely jolitee gladneſſe wife child honeſt thing hath ſaid ouer mokell ayenſt kind child founden tourmentours father many child biting euery condition needeth tellen thee haſt er time aſſayed art yet anguiſhous time approve ſentence diſciple euripidis ſaid hath child welefull infortune habet hoc voluptas omnis ſtimulis agit fruentes apiumque par volantium ubi gratia mella ſudit fugit nimis tenaci ferit icta corda morſu c every delyte hath anguiſheth hem prickes uſen reſſembleth theſe flyeng flyes clepen bee hath ſhedde agreable honnyes flyeth away ſtingeth hertes hem ſmitten biting ouerlong holden nihil igitur dubium eſt quin hae ad beatitudinem viae devia quaedam ſint nec perducere eo quenquam valeant c doubt theſe way ne maner miſtidings blisfulneſſe ne ne mowen ſeden folk thider beheten leden hem great harm theſe forſaid way ben enlaced ſhall ſhew ſhortly thou enforceſt thee aſſemble money thou muſt byreuen money hath thou ſhinen dignity thou muſt beſechen ſupplien hem yeuen tho dignity thou coueiteſt honour gone beforne folkes thou ſhalt defoule thy ſelf thorow humbleſſe aſking thou deſireſt power thou ſhalt awaits thy ſubiects anoyouſlie caſt many parils askeſt thou glory thou ſhalt ſo diſtract aſpre thinges thou ſhalt forgone ſikerneſſe thou woldeſt leden thy life delites euery wight ſhal diſpiſen thee forleten thee thou art thrall thing yt right foule britel yt ſaine ſeruaunt thy bodie wel yſeen litel brytel poſſeſſion coueiten putten goodes body aboue owne reaſon mayſt thou ſurmounten theſe olifaunts greatneſſe weight bodie mayſt thou ben ſtrenger ye bull mayſt thou ſwifter tygre behold ſpaces ſtableneſſe ſwift courſe heauen ſtint ſomtime wondren foul thing heauen certes ny nat rather theſe thinges wondren upon reaſon gouerned ſhyning thy forme ſayne beaute thy body ſwiftly paſſing tranſitorie certes flitting mutabilitie floures ſommer ſeaſon ſo ariſtotel telleth men eyen beeſte hight lynx ſo loking folk might percen tho thinges withſtond ſo looked thentrailes body alcibiades full fayre ſuperficie without ſhould ſeme right foule thy thou ſeemeſt fayre thy nature ne maketh nat diſceiuaunce febleneſſe eyen loken prayſe good body moch euer thee liſt ſo thou know algates ſo ſaine goodes body thou wondreſt upon may diſtroyed el diſſolued heet feuer three day foreſaid thing may reducen ſhortly ſumme theſe worldly good ne mowen yeuen behighten ne parfite congregacion good yt ne ben way ne pathes bringen men blisfulneſſe ne maken men blisfull heu heu quae miſeros tramite devios abducit ignorantia non aurum viridi quaeritis arbore c ala foly ignorance miſleadeth wandring wretch fro path good certes ye ſeken golde grene tree ne ye gadren precious ſtones vine ne hyden ginnes hie mountain catch fiſh ye may maken rich feeſts like hunte roe ye ne goe nat ford yt water hight thyrene ouer men know well crekes cauernes ſee yhyd floodes knowen eke water moſt plenteous white perles knowen whiche water haboundeth moſt reed purpure yt ſaine maner ſhelfiſh men dien purpure knowen ſtrondes habounden moſt tendre fiſhes ſharpe fiſhes hight echines folkes ſuffren hemſelfe ben ſo blind yt hem ne retchen know thilke goodes ben yhid coueiten plungen hem yerth ſeken thilke good ſurmounteth heuen beareth ye ſterres prayer may maken digne nice thoughtes men pray coueiten richeſſe honour ſo haue gotten tho falſe good great trauaile therby mowen knowen goodes hactenus mendacis formam faelicitatis oſtendiſſe ſufficerit quod ſi perſpicaciter intuearis ordo eſt deinceps c ſuffiſeth haue ſaid hyderto form falſe welefulneſſe ſo yt thou looke clerely ye order mine entencion requires henſforth ſhe wen ye welefulnes b forſoth qd ſee well ſuffiſance may commen richeſſe ne power realmes ne reuerence dignity ne gentilleſſe glory ne joy delices p haſt thou wel knowen ye cauſes qd ſhe b certes ſemeth qd ye ſee hem right though litel clifte leauer knowen hem openly thee phi certes qd ſhe ye reaſon al redy thilke thinge ſimply one thing without deuiſion yt errour folly mankinde devideth departeth miſledeth tranſporteth parfit good goodes falſe vnparfit ſay weneſt thou hath need power ne lacketh nothing boetius nay qd philoſ certes qd ſhe thou ſayeſt aright ſo yt thing yt partie febler power certes yt mote need needy foraine help boetius right ſo qd philoſ suffiſaunce power ben one kind boet ſemeth qd philoſophie demeſt thou qd ſhe thing yt maner yt ſay ſuffiſaunt mighty ought ben diſpiſed el right digne reuerence aboue thing boet certes qd doubte right worthy reuerenced phil let v adden qd ſhe reuerence ſuffiſaunce power ſo demen theſe thre thing one thing boetius certes qd let v adden graunt yt ſoth p demeſt thou qd ſhe yt derk thing noble yt ſuffiſant reuerent mighty el right noble right clere celebrate renome conſider qd ſhe haue graunted byforne y• ne hath need nothing moſt mighty moſt digne honour needeth clereneſſe renome clereneſſe hee might graunten himſelfe ſo lacke thilke clereneſſe might ſemen febler ſide outcaſt gloſe ſay nay ſo yt ſuffiſaunt mighty reuerent clereneſſe renome foloweth foreſaid thinges hath ready ſuffiſaunce boetius may qd deny mote graunten thing right celebrable clereneſſe renome nobleſſe p followeth qd ſhe adden clereneſſe renome ye foreſaid thing ſo amongs hem difference b conſequence qd p thing qd ſhe ne hath nede foraine thing may thing ſtrengthes noble honourable mery thing joyful boetius whence qd ſorowe might come thing ſoche certes may thinke philoſophie mote wee graunten qd ſhee thing ful gladneſſe foreſaid thing ſothe certes alſo mote graunten ſuffiſance power nobleſſe reuerence gladneſſe onely diuers name ſubſtaunce hath diuerſite boetius mote needly ſo qd philoſoph thilke thing qd ſhe one ſimple nature ye wickedneſſe men departeth deuideth enforcen hem getten partie thinge ne hath part ne getten hem neyther thilke partie ny none ne thing whole y• deſire boetius manere qd philoſophie thilke man qd ſhe ſecheth richeſſe flyen pouerty ne trauaileth get power hath leauer derke vyle eke withdraweth himſelfe many naturell delytes hee nolde leſe money hath aſſembled certes maner ne getteth ſuffiſaunce power foreleteth moleſtie pricketh filthe maketh outcaſte derkeneſſe hideth certes deſireth power waſteth ſcattereth richeſſe deſpiſeth delyces eke honour without power ne ne prayſeth glory nothing certes ſeeſt thou well many thing faylen hath ſometime defaute many neceſſitees many anguiſhes byten hym may done tho defaltes away forletteth mighty thyng moſt deſyreth right thus may make ſemblable reaſons honour glory delices ſo euery theſe foreſaid thing ſame y• theſe thing ſaine al one thing whoſoeuer ſeketh getten one theſe yt ne getteth deſireth boetius ſayeſt thou man coueite getten theſe thing togider philoſo certes qd ſhe wold ſay yt would get ſouerain blisfulnes yt ſhall finde tho thing haue ſhewed yt mowe yeue beheten boetius certes qd phi qd ſhe ne ſhullen men way ſeken bliſfulnes ſoch thing men wenen ne mowe gyuen one thyng ſinglerly menne ſeken boetius graunt well qd ne non ſother thing may ſaid philoſoph haſt thou qd ſhe forme cauſe falſe welefulneſſe turne flitte againe thy thought ſhall thou ſeene anon thilke bliſfulneſſe haue behight thee b certes qd clere open thogh blind man yt ſhewdeſt thou litel forne thou enforcedeſt thee ſhew cauſes ye falſe welefulneſſe begiled yt thilke bliſfulneſſe parfite parfitly maketh man ſuffiſaunt mighty honourable noble ful gladneſſe thou ſhalt well knowe haue well vnderſtanden theſe thing within hart know well thilke bliſfulneſſe yt men verely yeuen one ye foreſaid thing ſens one know doubtleſſe thilke thing full bliſfulneſſe philoſophie norice qd ſhe opinion ſay thou art bliſfull thou put thereto ſhall ſain boetius qd ph troweſt thou yt thing erthly mortall tombling thing yt may bringen eſtate bo certes qd trow thou haſt ſhewed wel yt ouer thilk good ni nothing ben deſired p theſe thing qd ſhe yt ſaine earthly ſuffiſaunce power ſoch thing erthly ſemen likeneſſe good el ſeemeth yeuen mortall folke maner goodneſſe ne parfite thilke good parfite may yeuen boe accord well qd phil qd ſhe moch thou haſte knowen thilke bliſfulnes eke thilke thing ben yt lien falſely bliſfulneſſe ſay yt deceite ſemen goodes behoueth thee knowe whence thou mow ſeke thilke bliſfulneſſe b certes qd yt deſire greatly haue abyden longe tyme herken p moch qd ſhe liketh diſciple plato book tymeo right littell thing men ſhoulden beſeche ye help god judgeſt thou yt done ſo wee may deſerue find ye ſeat thilke ſouerein god b certes qd denie yt ſhullen cleape father goodes withouten ny nothing founded aright p thou ſaieſt aright qd ſhe began anon ſingen right thus qui perpetua mundum ratione gubernas terrarum caelique ſator qui tempus ab aevo ire jubes ſtabiliſ que manens dans cuncta moveri quem non externae pepulerunt fingere cauſae c thou father ſoueraigne creatour heauen erthes gouerneſt world pardurable reaſon commandeſt time gone ſith age beginning thou dwelleſt thy ſelfe aye ſtedfaſt ſtable yeueſt al thing meued ne foryeue cauſes ne ceſſeden thee neuer compoun werke flattering mater onely forme ſouerain good yſet within thee without enuy meued thee frely thou art alder fayreſt hearing fayre world thy thought formedeſt world thy likeneſſe ſemblable fayre world thy thought thou draweſt thing thy ſoueraine enſampler commaundeſt world perfetlich ymaked haue freely abſolute perfite party thou bindeſt y• element nombres proporcionables cold thinges mowen accorden hotte thinges drie thing moiſt fire pureſt ne flie nat ouer hie ne heauineſſe ne draw nat adoun ouerlow yerthes yt plonged water thou knitteſt togider ye meane ſoul treble kind mouing thing deuideſt membres according thus deuided hath aſſembled amouing roundes goeth turne againe himſelf enuironneth full deepe thought turneth heuen ſemblable image thou euen lyke cauſes enhanceſt ſoules leſſe liues abling hem height light waines carte thou ſoweſt hem heauen yerth conuerted thee thy benigne law thou makeſt hem returne ayen thee ayen ledyng fyre father yeue thou yt thought ſtyen vp thy ſtraite ſeate graunt hem enuironne wel good ye light yfound graunt ſixen ye clere ſights courage thee ſcatter thou breake ye weyghts cloud earthly heauineſſe ſhine thou thy brightneſſe thou art clereneſſe thou art peſyble reſt debonayre folk thou thy ſelfe art beginning bearer leder path terme look thee end quoniam igitur quae ſit imperfecti quae etiam perfecti boni forma vidiſti nunc demonſtrandum reor c foraſmoche thou haſt ſeen forme good ny parfite forme good parfite trow yt good ſhew perfection bliſfulnes ſet thing trow ſhall firſt enquire weten ſoch maner good thilke good thou haſt diffiniſhed litell beforne ſaine ſoueraine good may found nature thing vaine imagination thought ne deſceue v put v ſothefaſtneſſe thylke thyng yt ſubmitted v may denied thilke ne right well goodes thing cleped imparfite proued imparfite ye amenuſing perfection thinge parfite hereof commeth euery thing generall men ſene thing imparfite certes thilke thinge generall mote ſome thing parfite ſo yt perfection away men may thinke ne ſay whence thilke thing cleped imparfite nature ne toke beginning thinges amenuſed imparfite procedeth thinges hole abſolute diſcendeth ſo ye vttreſt thing thing empty without fruite haue ſhewed little beforne bliſfulneſs freele vain imperfite may man doubt ni ſome bliſfulneſſe ſad ſtedfaſt parfite boecius concluded qd firmely ſoothfaſtly phi conſider alſo qd ſhe bliſfulneſſe inhabiteth commune accord conceit courage men proueth graunteth god prince thing good ſo nothing may thought better good may doubted yt nothing ny better ny good certes reaſon ſheweth god ſo good proveth force perfite good god ni ſuch ne may ben prince al thing certes ſome thing poſſeſſing ſelf perfite good ſhould worthy god ſhould ſeemen thilke thing firſt older god haue ſhewed apertly thing ben parfite firſt thing ben imparfite thy foraſmuch reaſon proceſſe ne go way without end owen granten ſoueraigne good right full ſoueraign perfit good eſtabliſhed ſoueraign good bliſfulnes mote need bliſfulnes ſet ſoveraigne good boecius take well qd ne ne may withſaid manner philoſ pray thee qd ſhe ſee thou mayeſt proven holily withouten corrupcion ſayd ſoueraign god full right ſoueraigne good bo manner qd phil weneſt thou aught qd ſhe father thing hath taken thilke ſoveraigne good himſelf ſoueraigne good men proueth full right thou mighteſt thinken god hath bliſfulnes himſelf thilk bliſfulneſe diver ſubſtance thou wene god hath received thilke good himſelfe thou mayeſt wene yaue thilke good god worthy god beknow confeſſe right dignely god right worthy thing ſo good nature diverſe wening reaſon ſens ſpeaken god prince thing faine whoſo faine may conioined theſe thing together eke laſt ſee well thing yt diver fro thing thilke thing ni ſame thing vnderſtanden ben diuers followeth well thilke thing yt nature diver ſoueraigne good thing ſoueraigne good certes felonous curſedneſſe thinken nothing ni worth alway thing name hem ne may ben better beginner may concluden right reaſon thilke beginning thing thilke ſame thing ſoueraigne god ſubſtance bo thou haſt ſaid rightfully qd pholoſ graunted qd ſhe ſoueraigne good bliſfulneſſe bo ſooth qd philoſ qd ſhe mote need graunten confeſſen ilke ſame ſoueraigne good god boe certes qd ne may deny ne withſtande reaſons purpoſed ſee well followeth ſtrength premiſſes philoſ look qd ſhe proved yet firmely thus ne mowen two ſoueraigne good ben diverſe among hemſelfe certes good diverſe among hemſelfe one ne mowen neither hem perfite ſo either hem lacketh ni perfite men may ſeene apertly ni ſoveraigne thing yt ſoveraignly good ne mowen way diver well concluded bliſfulneſſe god ſoueraigne good mote need ſoveraigne bliſfulneſſe ſovereign dignity boe nothing qd ſoothfaſt ne firme reaſon ne worthy thing god may concluded philoſo vpon theſe thing qd ſhe right theſe geometrician ſhewed propoſitions wont bringen thing yt clepen porriſmes declaration foreſaid thing right ſo woll yeue thee corollary mede crowne much getting blisfulneſſe men maked bliſful bliſfulneſſe dignity manifeſt open getting dignity men ben maked bliſful right getting iuſtice yt getting sapience maked wiſe right ſo need ſemblable reaſon haue gotten diuinitie made god every man bliſful god certes nature ni one god participation diuinity ne letteth ne diſtourbeth nothing ne many god bo qd fair thing precious clepe thou wilt corollary porriſme mede croune declaring p certes qd ſhe nothing ni fairer thing reaſon ſhuld added theſe foreſaid thing bo thing qd ph qd ſhe ſeemeth bliſfulneſſe containeth many thing weten whether theſe thing maken conioynen manner body bliſfulneſſe diverſity party member elſe theſe thing ſuch accompliſh himſelfe ſubſtaunce bliſfulneſſe theſe thing referred brought bliſfulneſſe ſay cheef hem bo would qd thou madeſt clearly underſtand thou ſayeſt thou recordeſt foreſaid thing phi judged qd ſhe blisfulneſſe good boe yes forſooth qd ſoueraigne good phi adde qd ſhe thilke good made bliſfulneſſe foreſaid thing thilke ſame bliſfulneſſe deemed ſoueraign ſuffiſaunce thilke ſelfe ſoueraigne power ſoueraigne reuerence ſoveraigne cleareneſſe nobleſſe ſoueraigne delite ſayſt thou theſe thing ſay ſuffiſaunce power theſe thing member bliſfulneſſe referred brought ſoueraigne good right thing brought cheef hem bo underſtond well qd thou purpoſeſt ſeek deſire hearken thou ſhew ph take thus diſcretion queſtion qd ſhe theſe thing qd ſhe member felicitie diver one ſuch nature party member diver member compounen body bo certes qd hath well ben ſhewed beforne theſe thing ben one thing phi member qd ſhe el ſhould ſeem bliſfulneſſe comoyned member alone thing may done bo thing qd ni doubtous abide hearken remenaunt thy queſtion open cleare qd ſhe thing ben referred brought good therefore ſuffiſaunce required deemed good thy power required men trowen alſo good ſame thing mowen thinken conjecten reuerence nobleſſe delite ſoueraigne good ſumme cauſe ought deſired thilke thing withholdeth good ſelf ne ſemblaunce good ne may well manner deſired ne required contrary though thing nature ne ben good algates men wenen good yet ben deſired though verely good therefore ſaid men ought wene right bounty ſoueraigne fine cauſe thing ben requiren certes thilke cauſe men requiren thing ſeemeth thilke ſame thing moſt deſired thus wight would riden cauſe heale ne deſireth ſo much mooving riden effect heale ſens thing ben required grace good ne ben deſired folke ſame good graunted bliſfulneſſe ſame thing theſe thing ben deſired thus certes onely bliſfulneſſe required deſired thing ſheweth clerely good bliſfulneſſe one ſame ſubſtance bo ſee qd wherefore men might diſcorden philoſ ſhewed god bliſfulneſſe one thing bo ſooth qd phi mow conclude ſikerly ſubſtaunce god ſet thilke ſame good none place huc omnes pariter venite capti quos fallax ligat improbis catenis terrenas habitans libido mentes hic erit vobis requies laborum c commeth together ye ycaught bound wicked chain delite earthly thing inhabiting thought ſhall reſt labour ſtable quiete peſible alone open refute wretch ſain ye combred deceiued worldly affection commeth ſoveraine good god refute hem willen commen thing y• river tagus yeueth golden gravel el thing river hermus yeueth red brink indus yeueth next hote partie world medleth green ſtones white ne ſhould cleren looking thouȝt hiden rather blind corage within derknes liketh exciteth moueth thought earth hath nouriſhed within low caues ſhining heaven governed whence ſtrength eſcheweth dark ouerthrowing ſoul whoſoever may knowen thilke light blisfulneſſe ſaine white beam sunne ne cleare aſſentior inquam cuncta enim firmiſſimis nexa rationibus conſtant tum illa quanti inquit tu aeſtimabis ſi bonum ipſum quid ſit agnoveris c boecius aſſent qd thing ben ſtrongly bounden right ferme reaſons philoſophie much wilt thou praiſen qd ſhe thou knoweſt like good boecius woll praiſe qd price without end ſhall betide know alſo togither god good philoſophie certes qd ſhe ſhall doe thee reaſon tho thing concluded little beforne dwellen onely graunting boecius dwellen graunted thee qd ſaine ſaith graunt thy foreſaied concluſions philoſophie haue ſhewed thee qd ſhe thing required many folke ne good ne perfite ben diuers one ſo hem lacking ne haue power bring good full abſolute erſt good gathered togider one forme one werking ſo thilke thing ſuffiſaunt thilke ſame power reuerence nobleſſe mirth forſooth theſe thing al one ſame thing ne haue whereby mowe put ye number thing ought required deſired bo ſhewen qd ne hereof may man doubten philoſophie thynges qd ſhe ne goodes ben diuers beginnen one thing ben good ne commeth getting unitie maked good boeci ſeemeth qd philoſo thyng good qd ſhe graunteſt thou good participation good boecius grant qd philoſo muſt thou graunten qd ſhe ſemblable reaſon one good one ſame thing thing effect ni naturally diuers nedes ſubſtaunce muſt one ſame thing boecius ne may denie qd philoſophie haſt thou knowen wel qd ſhe thing hath ſo long dwelling ſuſtaunce long one forletteth one muſt need dien corrumpen together boecius manner qd philoſo right beaſts qd ſhe ſoule bodie conioyned one dwelling together cleped beaſt unitie deſtroyed thy diſceueraunce one ſheweth well dead thing lenger beaſt bodie wight dwelleth one forme coniunction member well ſeene figure mankind party bodie diuided diſceuered one deſtroy unitie bodie forletteth beforne ſo would ren ſame manner thing ſhould ſeen without doubt euery thing ſubſtance long one forletteth one dieth periſheth bo conſider qd many thing ſee none philoſophie thing qd ſhe much liueth naturally foreletteth talent appetite deſireth come death corrupcion boe conſider qd beaſtes haue manner nature willing nilling ne find beaſt conſtrained fro withoutforth foreletteth deſpiſeth entencion liuen duren thankes haſten dien euery beaſt trauaileth deſende keep ſaluacion life eſcheweth death deſtruction certes doubt herbes tree ne haue feling soules ne natural working ſeruing appetite beaſts haue whether haue appetite dwellen duren philoſophie certes qd ſhe thereof dare thee doubt looke upon ye hearbes tree wexen firſt ſuch place conuenable hem whiche place mowe dien ne drien long nature may defend hem ſome hem wexen field ſome wexen mountaines wexe mareis cleauen rock ſome wexen plenteous ſondes wight enforce bear hem place wexen drye nature yeueth euery thing conuenient hem trauayleth ne die long haue power dwellen liuen wilt thou ſain yt drawen nouryſhings root right hadden mouth yplunged within earthes ſhedden mareis wood barke wilt thou ſaine ilke thing right ſoft marie alway hid ſeat within defended without ſtedfaſtneſſe wood uttereſt bark put ayenſt yt diſtemperaunce heauen defendour mightie ſufferen harme thus certes mayeſt thou well ſeene great diligence nature thing renouelen publiſhen hem ſeed ymultiplied ne ni man ne wote well ne right foundement edifice duren onely time right dure perdurably generacion ye thing eke yt men wenen ne haue ſouls ne deſire ſemblable reaſon keep yt ſaine yt according nature conſeruacion enduring wherefore el beareth lightneſſe flame vp weight preſſeth yearth adoun much thilke place thilke mouings couenable eueriche hem forſooth euery thing keepeth thilke according proper right thing ben contrarious enemy corrumpen hem yet hard thing ſtones cleauen holden party togither right faſt hard defenden hem withſtanding ne departen lightly yeuen place hem breaken deuiden hem natheleſſe retourne ayen ſoone ſame thing whence araced fire fleeth refuſeth deuiſion ne ne treat wilful moouings ſoule knowing naturell entencion thing thus right ſwallowen meat receiuen ne think draw breath ſleeping ſleepen certes beaſts loue liuings ne being ne commeth w •• nings ſoule beginning nature certes conſtrayning cauſes deſireth embraceth full oft time death nature dredeth ſaine thus man may conſtrayned ſo ſome cauſe deſireth taketh death nature hateth dreadeth full ſore ſometime ſeen contrary thus wight diſturbeth conſtraineth nature alway deſireth requireth ſay werkes generacion generacion dwelleth ſuſtayned long durabilitie mortal thing thus charitie loue euery thing hath himſelf ne commeth mouing ſoul entencion nature purueyaunce god hath yeuen thing ben create full great cauſe liuen duren deſiren naturelly life long euer mowen thou maiſt dreaden manner thing ne requiren naturally firm ſtableneſſe perdurable dwelling eke eſchewing deſtruction boeci confeſſe qd ſee well certainely withouten doubt thing ago ſeemeden vncertain philoſ qd ſhe thilk thing deſireth dwell perdurably deſireth one one deſtroyed certes ſhould none dwellen wight boecius ſooth qd philoſophie qd ſhe deſiren thing one boecius aſſent qd philoſophie haue ſhewed qd ſhe ilke ſame one thilke good boecius ye forſooth qd philoſophie thing qd ſhe requiren good thilke maiſt thou diſcriuen thus good thilke thing euery wight deſireth boecius ne may thought thing qd either thing referred brought nought flotten without gouernour diſpoiled one proper head el thing thing tenden hyen thing muſt ſoueraign good good philoſophie ſaid ſhe thus nourice qd ſhe haue great gladneſſe thee thou haſt fixed thy hart middle ſoothfaſtneſſe ſaine pricke thing hath diſcouered thee thou ſaideſt thou wiſteſt little beforne boecius qd philoſ thou ne wiſteſt qd ſhe end thing certes thing euery wight deſireth much haue gathered comprehended good thilk thing deſired mote need confeſſe good fine thing quiſquis profunda mente veſtigat verum cupitque nullis ille deviis falli ſe revolvat intimi lucem viſus c ſo ſeeketh ſooth deep thought coueiteth beene diſceyued miſwayes let rollen treaten within himſelfe light inward ſight let gatheren ayen enclyning compace long moouinges thought let teachen courage hee hath encloſed hidde treaſours hath compaſſed ſought without thilke thing blacke cloudes errour whylome couered ſhall light clearely phebus himſelfe ne ſhineth gloſa ſo woll ſeeke deepe ground ſooth thought woll deceyued falſe propoſicions gone amiſſe troth let well examine rolle within himſelfe nature property thing let eftſoons examine rollen thought good deliberacion deme let teachen ſoul hath naturell principle kindliche thidde within ſelf trouth ye imagineth thing without darkneſſe miſknowing ſhall ſeme euidently y• ſight vnderſtanding sun ne ſemeth ſight withoutforth certes bodie bringing y• weight foryeting ne hath chaſed thought y• clereneſſe knowing certainly ſeed ſooth holdeth cleaueth within corage awaked excited wind blaſts doctrine wherefore el deemen ye ye right ye aſked ſo nouriſhing reaſon ne liued yplunged deep heart ſain ſhould men demen y• ſooth thing asked nere root ſoothfaſtneſſe yplunged hid naturel principle ſoothfaſtneſſe liued within deepneſſe thought ſo muſe doctrine plato ſingeth footh euery wight learneth ne doeth nothing el recordeth men recorden thyngs ben foryetten tum ego platoni inquam vehementer aſſentior nam horum jam ſecundo commemoras primum quod memoriam corporea contagione c ſaid thus accord greatly plato thou recordeſt remembreſt theſe thyngs yet ſecond time ſay firſt left memory contrarious conjunction body ſoule eftſoones afterward loſt confounded thy charge burden ſorrow ſayed ſhe thus thou look qd ſhe firſt thyngs thou haſt graunted ne ſhall right ferre thou ne ſhalt remembren ilke thing thou ſaideſt thou niſteſt bo thing qd philoſ ye gouernment qd ſhe world governed bo remember well qd confeſſe well ne wiſt naught ſo ſee afarre thou purpoſeſt algates deſire yet hearken thee plainly phil thou ne wendeſt qd ſhe little beforne ye men ſhould dout world governed god bo certes qd ne yet ne dout ne nill neuer wene dout ſaith wot well god gouerneth world ſhall anſweren thee reaſons brought world qd ſo many diver contrarious party ne might never ben aſſembled forme one conioyned ſo many diver thing ſame diverſitie nature ſo diſcorden one fro muſt departen vnioynen thing y• conioyned ne one contained hath conioyned ybound ne certaine order nature ne ſhould bring forth ſo ordeyne mouings place time dooings ſpaces quality ne one aye ſtedfaſt dwelling ordained diſpoſed theſe diverſities moouings thilke thing whatſoeuer thing ymaked ladde clepe god word uſed folk phil ſaid ſhe sith thou feleſt thus theſe thing trow little doen thou mighty welefulneſſe hole ſound ne ſee eftſoones thy country let u looken theſe thing purpoſed beforne numbred ſaid qd ſhe ſuffiſaunce bliſfulneſſe accorded god ilke ſame bliſfulneſſe bo yes forſooth qd philoſ gouern world qd ſhe ne ſhall neuer haue need none help fro without el need help ne ſhould full ſuffiſaunce boet yes thus mote need qd philoſ ordeyned himſelfe alone thing qd ſhe boet may denied qd philoſ haue ſhewed god ſame good bo remembreth well qd philoſoph ordeyneth thing thilke good qd ſhe ſith han accorded good gouerneth thing himſelfe key ſteire edifice world kept ſtable without corrumping bo accord greatly qd haue apperceived little beforne thou wouldeſt ſay thus ſo thinne ſuſpection phi trow well qd ſhe trow thou leadeſt ententifely thine eye looken good natheles thing ſhall tell thee yet ne ſheweth laſſe token bo qd phil men trow qd ſhe rightfully god gouerneth thing key goodneſſe theſe ſame thing haue taught thee haſten hem natural contencion come good may man doubten ne gouerned voluntarily ne conuerten hem good ordeynour ben according enclining gouernour king bo mote need ſo qd realme ne ſhould ſeme bliſful yoke miſdrawings diver party ne ſauing obedient thing ne ſhould phi nothing qd ſhe keepeth nature enforceth gone ayenſt god boet qd philoſ thing enforced withſtande god might avaylen laſt ayen haue graunted almighty right bliſfulneſſe certes qd utterly ne might auayle philoſ nothing qd ſhe either may withſtand soveraigne god bo trow qd philoſ qd ſhe thilke soueraigne god thing gouerneth ſtrongly ordayneth hem ſoftely boetius ſaid thus delite qd onely end ſumme reaſons thou haſt concluded proued thilke word thou uſeſt deliten much ſo laſt fooles ſometime renden great thyngs oughten aſhamed hemſelfe ſain fooles reprehenden wickedly thinges touchen god gouernaunce oughten aſhamed ſelfe ſayed god refuſeth onely werkes men ne entermeteth phi thou haſt well heard qd ſhe fable poet gyaunts aſſaileden heauen god forſooth debonaire force god diſpoſed hem worthy ſain deſtroyed gyaunts worthy wilt thou rejoynen together thilk ſame reaſons perauenture ſuch conjunction may ſterten vp ſome fair ſpark ſooth boecius qd thee liſt philoſophy weneſt thou qd ſhe god ne almighty boecius man doubt certes qd philoſophy wight ne doubteth mind qd ſhe almighty ni nothing ne may boecius ſooth qd philoſophy may god euil qd ſhe boe nay forſoth qd phi euil nothing qd ſhe ſith may doen none euil may doen thing boecius scorneſt thou qd el playeſt thou deceiueſt thou haſt ſo wonnen thy reaſons houſe dedalus ſo enterlacing vnable vnlaced thou otherwhile entereſt thou iſſueſt otherwhile iſſueſt thou entereſt ne foldeſt thou togither replicacion word manner wonderful circle enuironning ſimplicity diuine certes little beforne thou began bliſfulneſſe thou ſaideſt ſouerain good y• god bliſfulneſſe thou yaue couenable yeft ſain wight ni bliſful god alſo therewith ſaideſt eke form good ſubſtance god bliſfulneſſe ſaideſt y• thilke one thilk ſame good required deſired kind thing thou prouedſt diſputing god gouerneth thing world gouernance bounty ſaideſt thing would obeyen ſaideſt y• nature euil nothing theſe thing ſhewedſt thou reaſons taken fro without prooues cercles homeliche knowing prooues drawen hemſelf faith accord eueriche hem philoſophy ſaid ſhe thus ne ſcorn ne play ne deceiue thee haue ſhewed thing greateſt ouer thing y• yeft god whylom praiden form diuine ſubſtaunce ſuch ne ſlideth vttereſt forrain thing ne receyueth ſtraunge thing right permenides ſaid greek thilk diuine ſubſtaunce ſaid thus thilk diuine ſubſtaunce tourneth world moouable cercle thing ilke diuine ſubſtaunce kepeth ſelf without moouings ſaine mooueth neuer mo yet moueth thing natheleſſe haue ſtyred reaſons taken fro without compaſſe thing treaten reaſons ben beſtowed within compaſſe ni thou ſhouldeſt meruaylen ſith thou haſt learned ſentence plato needes wordes mote coſins thing ſpeaken felix qui potuit boni fontem viſere lucidum felix qui potuit gravis c bleſſed man may ſeene clere well good bliſfull may vnbinden bound heauy earth poet thrace orpheus whylom right great ſorrow death wife maked conſtrayned weepely ſongs wood mouable renne maked riuers ſtonden ſtill maked hart hindes joynen dredeleſſe ſides cruell lion hearken ſong maked hare agaſt hound pleaſed ſong moſt ardaunt loue wife brend entrails breaſt ne ſongs ouercommen thing ne mighten aſſuagen lord orpheus plained heauen god cruel went houſes hell tempered blandiſhing ſongs reſouning ſtrings ſpekeſt ſong weeping yt euer receiued laued ye noble well mother caliope y• goddes ſang much might weeping much loue doubled ſorow might yeuen teach commoued hell required beſought ſweet praier y• lord ſouls hell releaſing ſay yeelden wife cerberus porter hell three head caught abaſhed new ſong three goddeſſes fury vengereſſes fellonies tormenten agaſten ſouls annoy woxen ſorrowfull ſorry teares wepten pity tho y• head ixion tourmented ouerthrowing wheele tantalus yt deſtroyed woodneſſe long thurſt diſpiſed y• flood drink foul hight vultor eateth ſtomack giſern tytius ſo fulfilled ſong nill eaten ne tyren laſt lord judg ſouls moued miſericordies cried ouercommen qd yeue orpheus wife beare companie hath well ybought ſongs dities putten law couenant yeft ſain till hell look behind wife ſhall come vnto v may yeue law louers loue greater law ſtronger himſelf law men may yeuen ala orpheus wife almoſt term night ſain y• laſt bound hell orpheus looked backward euridice wife loſt dead fable appertaineth whoſoeuer deſireth ſeeketh lead thought ſouerain day ſay clearneſſe ſoueraign good whoſoeuer ſo ouercommen fixe eyen pit hell ſaine ſo euer ſet thought earthly thinges euer hath drawen noble good celeſtiall leſeth looketh hell ſain low thing earth ¶thus endeth third book boece followeth fourth haec cum philoſophia dignitate vultus oris gravitate ſervata leviter ſuaviterque ceciniſſet tum ego nondum penitus inſiti maeroris oblitus c philoſophy ſongen ſoftly delectably foreſaid thynges keeping dignitie chere weight wordes ne utterly foryeten weeping mourning ſet mine hert forbrake entencion entended yet ſayne ſome thing qd thou art guidereſſe light thing thou haſt ſaid hitherto ben ſo clere ſhewing divine looking hem thy reaſons ne mowen ben ouercommen thilke thyngs thou toldeſt ſo y• whylom foryeten hem ſorow y• wrong hath done yet neuertheleſſe ne vtterly vnknowen mee ſame namely right great cauſe ſorrow ſo yt gouernour thyngs good euils mowen way el yt euils paſſen without puniſhing thing worthie ben wondred vpon thou conſidreſt wel thy ſelf certainely yet thing yet another thing ioyned wondred vpon fellonie empereſſe floureth full richeſſe vertue ni onely without medes caſt downe eke fortroden vnder y• foot fellonous folke abieth y• turments ſteed wicked fellons thing wight may maruailen ynough ne complainen yt ſuch thynges done reigne god thynges wote thing may ne good thing ſaid ſhe thus certes qd ſhe great maruaile abaſhing without end well horrible monſters thou weneſt ſaine yt right ordained houſe ſo much father ordaynour meine veſſels ben foule vile ſhould ben honoured heried precious veſſels ſhould ben defouled vile ſo thinges yt haue concluded little beforn ben kept whole vnaraced thou ſhalt wel know authoritie god y• whoſe reign ſpeake certes good folke alway mightie ſhrewes ben alway outcaſt feeble ne vice neuermore without pain ne vertues ne bee without mede bliſfulneſſe commeth alway good folke infortune cometh alway wicked folk thou ſhalt well knowen many thing kind ſhould ceaſen thy plaint ſtrengthen thee ſtedfaſt ſadneſſe thou haſt ſeen forme bliſfulneſſe haue whylome ſhewed thee thou haſt knowen bliſfulneſſe ſet thing treated yt trow neceſſary put forth ſhall ſhewen thee way ſhal bringen thee ayen vnto thy houſe ſhall fixe feather thy thought may ariſen height ſo tribulacion ydone away thou guiding path ſledes ſhalt mowen return hole ſound thy countrie sunt enim pennae volucres mihi quae celſa conſcendunt poli quas ſibi cum velox men induit c thy ſwift feather yt ſurmounten height heuen ſwift thought hath clothed tho feather deſpiſeth ye hateful earth ſurmounteth roundeneſſe yt great aire ſeeth y• cloudes behind back paſſeth height region fire enchaufeth y• ſwift moouing firmament till ariſeth houſes bearen ſterres joyneth way ſunne phebus fellawſhippeth way olde colde saturnus ymaked knight y• cleare ſterre y• ſaine yt thought made god knight ye ſeeking clere trouth commen knowledge god thilke ſoule renneth circle ſterres y• place yt ſhining night ipainted ſain night yt cloudleſſe night yt cloudleſſe ſeemeth y• heauen painted diuers image ſterres hath done inough ſhall forleten ye laſt heauen ſhall preſent wenden back ſwift firmament ſhall maked perfit y• worſhipfull light god holdeth lord thing ſceptre might attempreth gouernments world ſhining judge thing ſtable himſelfe gouerneth ſwift cart waine ſaine circular mouing ſunne thy way leadeth thee ayen ſo yt thou broght thider wilt thou ſay y• countrey thou requireſt thou ne haddeſt mind nowe remembreth well born wol faſten degree woll dwell thee liketh looken derkeneſſes yearth thou haſt forleten ſhalt thou ſeene theſe fellonous tyraunts wretched people dreadeth nowe ſhullen exiled thilke faire countrey turn ego pape inquam ut magna promittis nec dubito quin poſſis efficere tu modo quem excitaveris ne moreris c ſaid thus wonder yt thou beheteſt ſo great thyngs ne ne doubt thou ne mayſt well perfourm thou beheteſt pray thee thou ne tarry tell thilk thing thou haſt moued phil firſt qd ſhe thou muſt need know good folke alway ſtrong mightie ſhrewes beene feeble deſerte naked ſtrengths theſe thing certes euerich hem declared ſhewed good euill two contrary ſo good ſtedfaſt ſheweth feebleſſe openly thou know clerely y• freeleneſſe euill ſtedfaſtneſſe good knowen much fayth ſentence ſhall ferme haboundaunt woll gone one way woll confirme ye thing beene purpoſed nowe ſide yt ſide two thing beene effect deedes mankind ſtandeth ſayne power one theſe two faileth ni nothing may bee done lacketh ni wight vndertaketh woll done power faileth wil ni idle ſtant naught thereof commeth yt thou ſee wight would getten yt may getten thou mayeſt doubt yt power ne faileth hauen would boe open clere qd ne ne may denyed manner p thou ſee wight qd ſhe hath done would done thou nilt doubt ne hath power done bo qd phi euery wight may men holden hem mightie thing inſomuch man mighty thing inſomuch men hold mighty ne may men demen feeble bo confeſſe well qd p remember thee qd ſhe yt haue gathered ſhewed yt foreſaid reaſons yt y• entencion wil mankind y• lad diuers ſtudies haſteth commen bliſfulneſſe boet remembreth well qd hath ben ſhewed philoſo recordeth yt naught qd ſhe bliſfulneſſe thilk ſame good men requiren ſo yt bliſfulneſſe required boetius recordeth nat qd haue alway memorie fixed philoſo folke qd ſhe good eke bad enforcen hem without difference entencion comen good boetius conſequence qd philoſ certain qd ſhe yt getting good men maked good boeti certaine qd philoſ getten good men yt deſiren boe ſeemeth qd philoſophie wicked folke qd ſhe getten good deſiren ne mowen wicked bo qd philoſ ſo one qd ſhe deſiren good good folke getten good wicked folk doubt good folke ne mightie wicked folke feeble boeti ſo yt euer douteth ne may conſider nature thinges ne y• conſequence reaſons philoſ ouer qd ſhe two thing yt haue one ſame purpoſe kind one hem purſueth performeth ſame thing naturall office ne may thilk office
