naturell followeth manner couenable nature yt accompliſheth purpoſe kindely yet ne accompliſheth owne purpoſe whether theſe two demeſt thou mighty b yt conject qd yt thou woldeſt ſay algates deſire yet herken plainly thee philoſoph thou nilt denie qd ſhe moouement going ni men kind boeti forſooth qd philoſophy ne thou doubteſt qd ſhe yt thilk naturell office going ne bee ye office foot boe ne doubt qd philoſ qd ſhe wight bee mightie mooue goeth vpon foot another thilke naturell office foot lacketh enforceth go creeping hand wch theſe two ought bee holden mightie right boeti knit forth qd y• remnaunt philoſophy wight ne douteth y• may gone naturell office foot ne mightie hee yt ne may yt ſoueraigne good qd ſhe euen like purpoſed good bad y• good folke ſeeken naturell office vertues ſhrewes enforcen hem getten diuerſe couetiſes earthly thing y• ni naturell office getten thilk ſoueraine good troweſt thou otherwiſe bo nay qd y• conſequence open ſhewing thing haue graunted y• need good folke moten ben mighty ſhrews moten ben feeble vnmightie phil thou renneſt aright beforne qd ſhe judgment yt ſain judge right theſe leech beene woont hopen ſicke folke apperceiuen yt nature redreſſed withſtandeth yt malady ſee thee ready y• withſtanding ſhall ſhew thee thilke continuell reaſons looke greatly ſheweth feebleneſſe infirmitie wicked folke y• ne mowen commen yt naturel entencion leadeth hem yet almoſt thilk naturell entencion conſtraineth hem demen ſhrewes thilk naturell helpe forleten hem y• naturell helpe entencion goth alway beforn hem ſo great yt vnneth may ouercommen conſider great defaut power howe great feebleſſe wicked fellonous folke ſaieth y• greater thyng yt coueited deſire accompliſhed yt leſſe might coueiteth may accompliſh thy philoſophie ſaith thus ſoueraine good ne ſhrews ne requiren light medes ne vain game ne may followen ne holden faylen thilk ſumme height thing ſain ſoueraine good ne theſe wretch ne commen effect ſouerain good enforcen hem getten night day getting good ſtrength good folk full well yſeen right thou mighteſt demen mightie going goeth foot till might commen thilk place fro place ne lay way gone right ſo muſt thou need demen right mighty getteth attayneth end thing deſiren beyond end ni nothing deſire power good folk men may conclude wicked men ſeemen barrain naked ſtrength forleten vertues followen vice ni ne knowen good thing feble caitife y• blindnes ignorance el knowen well thing oughten followen lecherie couetiſe ouerthroweth hem miſtourned certes ſo doth diſtemperance feeble men mow wraſtlen ayen theſe vice ne know well forleten good wilfully tournen hem wilfully vice wiſe ne forleten mightie forleten vtterly wiſe yt forleten commune fine thing yt ben forleten alſo therewithal perauenture ſhould ſeemen ſome folk y• meruaile ſain ſhrews containen part men ne ne haue natheleſſe ſo thus ſtant thing ſhrews denie y• ſhrews denie ſimply plainly y• ne ne haue right thou mighteſt ſain y• cerrain man y• dead man ſo grant wel forſooth vicious folk ben wicked ne may abſolutely ſimply grant ben thilk thing withholdeth order keepeth nature thilk thing hath wt thing fayleth ſay forleteth natural order forleteth thilk ſet nature thou wolt ſain ſhrews mowen certes ne denie certes power ne deſcendeth ſtrength feebleſſe mowen done wickedneſſe ne might mighten dwellen form y• good people thilk power ſheweth euidently y• mowen right naught ſo haue gadered prooued litel beforn euill ſo ſhrews may ſhrewdnes concluſion clere ſhrews ne mowen right naught ne haue power much thou vnderſtondeſt y• ſtrength power haue definiſhed litel beforn thing ni ſo mighty ſouerain good b ſooth qd phil thilk ſame ſouerain good may done none euil boe certes qd phil wight qd ſhe weneth y• men mowen done thing boe man qd wit phil certes ſhrews mowen done euils qd ſhe bo ye would god qd ne mighten done none p qd ſhe ſo mighty done good thing may done thing ben mighty done euill thing ne mowen thing open thing manifeſt y• mowen done euil ben leſſe power yet proue concluſion helpeth haue ſhewed beforn y• power numbred among thing y• men oughten require haue ſhewed y• thing oughten deſired referred god right maner height nature mowen done euil fellonie ne may ben referred god euil number thing y• oughten ben deſired required open clear power ne mouing ſhrews ni power theſe thing ſheweth well good folke ben certainly mighty ſhrews doubtleſſe vnmighty clere open thilk ſentence plato ſoth y• ſaith wiſe men may done deſiren ſhrews mowen haunten hem liketh deſiren ſain come ſouerain good ne haue power accompliſh ſhrews done hem liſt tho thing delighten wenen attain thilk good deſiren ne getten ne attayne thereto vice ne commen bliſfulneſſe quos vides ſedere celſos solii culmine reges purpura claro nitente c ſo couerture vain apparailes might ſtripen theſe prowd king thou ſeeſt ſitten high chair glittering ſhining purpure enuironned ſorrowfull armures menaſing cruel mouth blowing woodnes heart ſhould ſeen y• thilk lord heaten within courage full ſtrait chain lecherit tormenteth hem y• one ſide greedie venimes troublable ire araiſeth hem flood troublings tormenteth ſide thought ſorrow halt hem werie • aught ſliding deceiuing hope tormenteth hem therfore ſith thou ſeeſt one head ſayn one tyraunt bearen ſo many tyranny ne doth thilk tyraunt deſireth ſith caſt ſo many wicked lord ſain ſo many vice haue ſo wickedly lordſhips ouer vides ne igitur quanto coeno probra volvantur qua probitas luce reſplendeat quo perſpicuum eſt nunquam bonis praemia c seeſt thou great filth theſe ſhrews ywrapped clereneſſe theſe good folk ſhinen ſheweth well good folk ne lacketh neuer mo medes ne ſhrews lacken neuer tourments thing done thilk thing thing done ſeemeth right thilk thing mede thus man renneth ſtady forlong crown lieth mede crown renneth haue ſhewed bliſfulneſſe thilk ſame good thing ben done thilk ſame good purpoſed werks mankind right commune mede mede ne may diſceuered good folk wight right thenceforth lacketh goodneſſe ne ſhall cleaped good thing folk good maners medes ne forſaken hem neuer mo ſo ſhrewes waxen wood hem liſt againſt good folk yet neuertheleſſe crown wiſe men ne ſhall fallen ne faden fro forrain ſhreudneſſe ne benimmen fro courage good people proper honour wight rejoyced goodneſſe taken fro without ſaith man goodneſſe man himſelf certes yaue thilke goodneſſe el ſome wight might bynome much euery wight proper bounty yeueth mede erſt ſhall faylen mede forleteth good laſt ſo medes required men wenen good nolde deme right mighty good part leſſe mede mede ſhall reguerdoned certes right fair mede right great abouen medes remember thee thilk noble corallary yaue thee little beforne gather together manner god himſelf bliſfulneſſe clere certain good people maked bliſful good thilk people ben bliſful accordeth conuenable god mede people ſuch day ne ſhall empairen ne wickedneſſe ſhall drinken ne power wight ne ſhall amenuſe ſain ben maked good ſith thus good men ne faylen neuer mede certes man ne may doubt vndepartable pain ſhrews ſain pain ſhrewes departeth hemſelf neuer mo ſo good euil pain medes contrary mote need right ſee betiden guerdon good alſo mote pain euil aunſwer contrary part ſhrews ſo bounty proweſſe ben mede good folk alſo ſhrewdneſſe ſelf tourment ſhrews whoſoeuer entetched defouled payne ne doubteth entetched defouled euil ſhrews wollen prayſen hemſelf may ſeemen hem withouten party tourment ſith ſuch vttreſt wickedneſſe ſay wicked thewes vttreſt worſt kind ſhreudneſſe ne defouleth ne entetcheth hem enfecteth enuenimeth greatly alſo look ſhrews ben contrary party good men great pain fellowſhippeth fouleth hem thou haſt learned little beforn thing hath one thilk ſame one good conſequence ſeemeth well thing hath good ſain ſaith vnity goodneſſe one manner followeth thing faileth good ſtinteth haue manner wherefore ſhrewes ſtinten thilk form mankind ſain form body without ſheweth theſe ſhrews whilom men wherefore peruerted tourned malice certes haue forlorn nature mankind ſo bounty proweſſe may enhauncen euery man ouer men mote need ſhrews ſhrewdneſſe hath caſt condicion mankind put vnder merit deſert men betideth thou ſeeſt wight tranſformed vice thou maiſt wene man ardant auarice rauenour violence forrain richeſſe thou ſhalt ſain like wolf fellonous withouten reſt exerciſe tongue chiding thou ſhalt liken hound priuy awaytour hidde rejoyceth rauiſh wile thou ſhalt ſain like fox whelp diſtempred quaketh ire men ſhall wenen deareth corage lion dredefull flying dredeth thing ne oughten dread men ſhall hold like hart ſlow aſtonied lache men ſhall hold like aſſe light vnſtedfaſt courage changeth aye ſtudies men ſhall hold like bird piunged foul vnclene luxury withholden foul delices foul ſow followeth forleteth bounty proweſſe forleteth man ſith ne may paſſen condicion god turned beaſt vela naricii ducis vagas pelago rate eurus appulit inſulae pulchra qua reſidens dea solis edita ſemine c eurus wind arriued ſailes vlixes duke countrey narice wandering ſhips ſee iſle circe faire goddeſſe doughter ſun dwelleth meddleth new gheſts drink touched maked enchauntments hand mighty ouer herb chaunged gheſts diuers manner one hem couered face form bore chaunged lyon countrey marmorike nayls teeth wexen hem newlych changed wolf howlyth would weep goeth debonairly houſe tygre inde ſo godhead mercury cleped bird archadia hath mercy duke vlyxes beſieged diuerſe euils hath vnbounden fro peſtilence hoſteſſe algates rower marriners hadden ydrawen mouthes dronken wicked drink woxen ſwine hadden ychaunged meat bread eaten acorn okes none limmes ne dwelleth hem whole haue loſt voyce bodye thought dwelleth hem ſtable weepeth bewayleth monſtrous changing ſufferen ouer light hand ſayth feeble light hand circe enchauntereſſe chaungeth body folk beaſts regard compariſon mutacion maked vice ne herb circe ne mighty ſo may chaungen limmes body algate yet may change heart within yhid ſtrength vigor men ſecretor heart ſain ſtrength reaſon thilk venimes vice drawen man hem mightily venime circe vice ben ſo cruel piercen thorow paſſen courage within though ne annoy body yet vice wooden deſtroyen men wound thought tu ego fateor inquam nec injuria dici video vitioſos tam ſi humani corporis ſpeciem ſervent c ſaid thus confeſſe aknow qd ne ne ſee men may ſay right ſhrews chaunged beaſts quality ſouls ſo keepen yet form bodye mankinde would ſhrews thought cruel wood woodeth alway deſtruction good men leful hem done certes qd ſhe ne leful hem ſhall well ſhew incouenable place natheleſſe ſo thilk men wene leful ſhrews bynommed hem ſo ne might annoien done harm good men certes great party pain ſhrews ſhould ben alledged releued ſo ne ſeem credible thing peraduenture ſome folk mote need ſhrews wretch ſilly may full done perform coueyten might accompliſh coueyten ſo wretchedneſſe wilnen done euil wretchedneſſe mowen done euil without mowing wretched ſhould languiſh without effect ſith euery theſe thing hath wretchedneſſe ſain done euil mowing done euil mote need ſhrews conſtrained vnſelineſſes wollen mowen performen fellonies ſhreudneſſes boet accord qd deſire greatly ſhrews loſten ſoon thilk vnſelineſſe ſain ſhrews diſpoyled mowing done euil philoſophy ſhullen qd ſhe ſoner paraduenture thou woldeſt ſoner hemſelf wene ni nothing ſo late ſo ſhort bond life long abide namely courage immortel ſhrews great hope hie compaſſings ſhreudneſſe oft deſtroyed ſodein end ware thing eſtabliſheth ſhrews end ſhrewdneſſe ſhrewdneſſe maketh wretch muſt need moſt wretch longeſt ſhrew wicked ſhrews wold demin aldermoſt caytifes vnſely ſhrewdneſſe ne finiſhed leaſt way vttereſt death haue concluded ſooth vnſelineſſe ſhrewdneſſe ſheweth plainly thilk wretchedneſſe withouten end certain pardurable bo certes qd concluſion hard wonderful grant know well accordeth moch thing haue granted beforne phil thou haſt qd ſhe right eſtimacion ſo euer wene hard thing accord concluſion right ſhew ſome premiſſes ben falſe el mote ſhew collacion propoficions ni ſpedeful neceſſary concluſion ne ſo premiſſes igraunted ni ſhould blame argument thing ſhall tell thee ne ſhall ſeme laſſe wonderful thing bene taken alſo neceſſary faith followeth purpoſed beforne boec qd phil certes qd ſhe theſe wicked ſhrews bliſful el laſſe wretch abien tourments haue deſerued payne juſtice ne chaſtiſed hem ne ne ſay y• man might think maners ſhrewes coriged chaſtiſed vengeance brought right way drede tourment ne yeuen folkes enſample flyen fro vice vnderſtand yet another maner y• ſhrewes vnſely ne puniſhed al ſo ne reaſon law correction ne none enſample looking boet maner ſhall y• qd hath tolde beforn ph haue graunted qd ſhe good folke ben bliſfull ſhrewes ben wretch boet yes qd philoſoph qd ſhe good added y• wretchedneſſe wight ny weleful y• ne hath medling good ſolitary wretchednes bo ſeemeth qd phil ſayſt thou qd ſhe thilke wretch lacketh good ſo good ny medled wretchedneſſe yet ouer wickedneſſe wretch yet another yuel annexed knit ſhall men demen unſely thilke wretche vnſelines releued participation ſome good boet ſhould qd ph certes qd ſhe han ſhrewes puniſhed ſomewhat good annexed hir ſhrewdneſſe ſaine ſame paine ſuffren good reaſon iuſtice thilke ſame ſhrewes eſcapen without tourment haue ſomwhat yuel yet ouer wickednes han done ſaine default pain default payne thou haſt graunted yuel deſert felony boet ne may deny qd philoſ moch qd ſhe ſhrewes vnſely wrongfully deliuered fro payne puniſhed rightfull vengeaunce open thing clere y• right ſhrewes puniſhed wickedneſſe wrong eſcapen vnpuniſhed boetius might deny qd philoſop qd ſhe may man deny y• al right ne good alſo contrary y• y• wrong ne wicked boet certes qd theſe thing cleere ynough wee haue concluded litell beforn pray thee y• thou tel thou accordeſt letten tourment y• ſoules y• body ended y• death ſaine vnderſtandeſt thou aught ſoules haue tourment y• deth y• body philoſ certes qd ſhe yea right great ſoules qd ſhe trowe y• ſome tourmented aſpreneſſe payne ſome ſoules trow exerciſed purging mekeneſſe counſaile ny nat determine paynes haue trauayled tolde yet hyderto thou ſhouldeſt know y• mowing ſhrews mowing thee ſemeth vnworthy ny mowyng eke ſhrewes thou playnedeſt yt ne puniſhed yt thou woldeſt ſee ne neuer mo withouten tourments wickedneſſe lycence mowing doen euill thou praydeſt might ſone ended thou wouldeſt fayne lernen ne ſhoulde longe endure ſhrewes vnſely lenger duringe moſte vnſely perdurable haue ſhewed thee vnſely ben ſhrewes eſcapen without rightfull payne ben puniſhed rightfull vengeaunce ſentence foloweth y• ſhrewes conſtrayued laſt moſt greeuous tourment men wene ne puniſhed boetius conſider thy reaſons qd ne trow nat y• men ſaine thing verely tourne ayen ſtudies men whome ſhoulde ſeeme yt ne ſhould nat onely leuen theſe thing eke gladly herken hem philoſo certes qd ſhe ſo men may nat haue eyen ſo wont derkeneſſe earthly thinges ne may nat lift hem vp light cleare ſoothfaſtneſſe like birdes night lightneth looking day blindeth hem men looken ordre thinges luſtes talent wene eyther leue mowyng doen wickednes el ſcaping without payne welefull conſider judgement perdurable law thou confirme thy courage beſt thing thou ne haſt need judge yeuen thee price mede thou haſt joyned thy ſelfe y• moſt excellent thinges thou haue enclined thy ſtudies y• wicked thing ne ſeke foraine wrekerie thy ſelfe thou thy ſelfe haſt thriſte thy ſelfe wicked thing right thou mighteſt looken diuers time foule yearth heauen yt thing ſtinten fro without ſo y• thou neither ne ſee nothing ſhuld ſeemen thee reaſon loking y• thou sterres earth y• people loketh theſe thing ſhal approch v hem haue ſhewed like beaſts wouldeſt thou ſain y• man forlorne ſight foryeten y• euer ſaw wened nothing fayled perfection mankind mighten ſeene ſame thing would ſaine y• blind ne alſo ne accordeth ye people yt ſhall ſaine thing ſuſteyned ſtrong foundements reaſon yt ſaine vnſelie yt done wrong folke yt wrong ſuffren boet would hearen thilke ſame reaſons qd philoſ denieſt thou qd ſhe ſhrewes ne worthie haue tourment boetius nay qd phil qd ſhe certain many reaſons ſhrewes vnſely boetius accordeth qd phil ne doubteſt thou qd ſhe thilke folke worthy tourment yt ne wretch boetius accordeth well qd phil thou ſet iudg knower thing whither troweſt thou men ſhould tourmenten hem yt hath done wrong el hem ſuffered wrong boetius doubte qd nolde doe ſufficient ſatiſfaction hem haue ſuffered wrong ſorrow hem hath done wrong phil ſemeth qd ſhe dooer wrong wretch ſuffred wrong boetius followeth well qd phil qd ſhe theſe cauſes cauſes enforced ſame roote filth ſinne proper nature maketh men wretch ſheweth well wrong men done ni wretchedneſſe receiueth wrong wretchedneſſe doeth wrong certes qd ſhe theſe orator aduocates done contrary enforcen hem commoue iudges haue pitie hem done greevaunces wrong ſhrews couenable thing ye accuſours aduocates wroth piteous debonaire ledden tho ſhrews haue done wrong judgment right men leden ſicke folke leche ſhoulden ſeeken malady ſin tourment couenant either entent advocate ſhould ceſſen el thoffice aduocates would better profiten men ſhould tourned habite accuſacion ſaine ſhoulden accuſe ſhrews hemſelf leful hem ſeen clift vertue haue forletten ſawen ſhould putten adoune filthes vice tourments paine ne oughten right recompenſacion getten hem bountie proweſſe loſte demen holde ilke paynes tourments hem eke woulden refuſe attendaunce aduocates taken hemſelfe iudges accuſours betideth y• wiſe folk ni place iletten hate ſaine hate ne hath place among wiſe men wight nill haten good men ouermoch foole haten ſhrews ni reaſon right languiſhing maladie body right ſo vice ſin malady courage ſo ne deme ſick bodie worthy hated rather worthy pitie well worthy hated pitie thought conſtrained felonous wickedneſſe cruell languiſhing body quid tantos juvat excitare motus et propria fatum ſollicitate manu si mortem petitis propinquat ipſa ſponte ſua volucres nec remoratur equos c deliteth exciten ſo great mouing hatredes haſten buſien fatal diſpoſicion death proper hand ſaine battailes conteke yee asken death haſteth owne ne death ne tarieth ſwift horſe men serpent lion tigre bere bore ſeken ſlean teeth yet thilke ſame men ſeken ſlean euerich hem ſweard lo maners diuers diſcordaunt mouen vnrightful hoſtes cruel battayles wilnen periſh enterchaungyng dartes reaſon crueltie ny inough rightful wilt thou yelden couenable guerdon deſerts men loue rightfully good folkes haue pitie ſhrewes hinc ego video inquam quae ſit vel felicitas vel miſeria ipſis proborum que improborum meritis conſtituta sed hac ipſa fortuna populari c ſee qd eyther bliſfulneſſe el vnſelineſſe eſtabliſhed deſerts good men ſhrewes ilke fortune people ſee ſomewhat good ſome euil wiſe man leauer exiled poore needie nameleſſe dwellen citee flouren richeſſe redoubtable honour ſtrong power wiſe clearly witneſfully office wiſe men treated bliſfulneſſe power gouernors ſhad amongs people neighbour ſubjects ſith namely priſon law theſe torment lawful pain rather owed felonous citizen ſelonous citizen pain eſtabliſhed good people boet maruaile greatly qd thyngs ſo miſſe enterchaunged torment felony preſſen confounden good people ſhrewes rauiſhen medes vertue honor great eſtates deſire eke weten thee ſemeth thee reaſon ſo wrongfull concluſion would wonder well laſſe trowed thing medled fortunous hap crepeth encreaſeth mine aſtoniyngs god gouernour thing ſo god yeveth oft time good men good mirth ſhrews euill aſpre thing yeueth ayen good folke hardneſſe ſhrews graunteth hem deſiren difference may betweene god doeth hap fortune men know cauſe philoſophie ne marueile qd ſhe though men wenen ſomewhat fooliſh confuſe reaſon order unknowen although thou ne know cauſe ſo great diſpoſicion natheleſſe much god good gouernour attempreth gouerneth world ne doubt thee thing doen right si quis arcturi ſidera neſcit mergatque ſeras aequore flammas propinqua ſummo cardine labi cum nimis ſceleris explicet ortus cur legat tardus plauſtra bootes c ſo know sterres arcture tourned ſoueraine centure poinct ſaine tourned nigh soueraine pole y• firmament wote y• ſterre bootes paſſeth gathereth waines drencheth late flambes ſea bootes sterre vnfoldeth ouerſwift ariſings ſhall wondren lawe y• high aire eke ne knowe y• horne full moone waxen pale infect boundes darke night moone darke confuſe diſcouereth sterres ſhe couered clere viſage common errour moueth folkes maketh wearie baſins braſſe thilke ſtrokes ſay maner people hight coribantes wenen moone eclipſe enchaunted therfore reſcue y• moone beaten baſins ilke ſtrokes ne man ne wondreth blaſtes wind chorus beaten y• ſtronds sea quaking floodes ne man ne wondreth weight snow harded cold reſolued brenning heat phebus sunne ſeen men readily cauſes cauſes ihid ſaine heauen troublen ye breſtes men mouable people aſtonied thing commen ſelde ſodainly age troubly errour ignoraunce departeth fro v ſo yt wiſten cauſe ſoche thinges betiden certes ſhoulden ceaſe ſeme wonder ita eſt inquam sed cum tui muneris ſit latentium rerum cauſas evolvere velataſ que caligine explicare rationes quaeſo uti hinc decernas c thus qd ſo thou haſte yeuen beheight vnwrappe ye hidde cauſes thing diſcouer reaſons couered darkneſſe pray thee thou deuiſe judge matter thou vnderſtand miracle wonder troubleth right greatly ſhe little ſmiling ſaid thou clepeſt qd ſhe tell yt greateſt al thinges y• mowen asked queſtion vnneth aught inough leauen ſaieth vnneth thing aunſwere perfitly thy queſtion ye matter ſoch doubte determined cut away waxen doubt without number right heddes idre serpent waxen serpent hercules ſlough ne ne manere ne none end wight conſtrained doubt right liuely quicke fire thought ſaine vigour ſtrength wit matter men wonte maken queſtions ye ſimplicitie purueighaunce god y• order deſtinie ſodayne happe knowing predeſtinacion diuine libertie freewill thinges thou thy ſelfe apperceiuedeſt well weight moch knowing theſe thing manner porcion medicine thee ſo haue little tyme doen yet neuertheleſſe would enforcen ſhewen ſomewhat although nouriſhings ditee muſike deliteth thee thou muſt ſuffren forbearen little ilke delite wene reaſons knit order boetius liketh thee qd ſo doe philoſophie tho ſpake ſhee right beginning ſayed right thus engendering thinges qd ſhe progreſſions moueable nature moueth maner taketh cauſes order formes y• ſtableneſſe diuine thought ilke diuine thought ſet put towre yt ſaine height ſimplicitie god eſtabliſheth many maner giſes y• thing doen maner men looken pure cleaneſſe diuine intelligence cleaped purueighaunce ilke maner referred men thinges moueth diſponeth old men cleaped deſtenie y• thing wight looketh well thought ſtrength one ſhall lightly mowe ſeene theſe two thing diuers purueighaunce ilke diuine reaſon eſtabliſhed soueraine prince thinges y• pueueighaunce diſponeth al thing certes deſtinie diſpoſicion ordinaunce cleauing moueable thinges diſpoſicion ye purueighaunce knitteth thing order purueighaunce embraſeth al thing heap although diuers although infinite deſtinie certaine departeth ordaineth thing ſingulerly deuideth mouing place formes tymes thus let vnfolding temporall ordinaunce aſſembled oned ye loking diuine thought cleaped purueighaunce thilke ſame aſſembling oning deuided vnfolden let called deſtine beit ſo theſe thinges diuers yet neuertheleſſe hanged yt one order deſtinably proceedeth ſimplicitie purueighaunce right werkman perceiueth thought forme thing yt wol make moueth effect werke leadeth y• looked beforne thought ſimply preſently corporall ordinance certes right ſo god purueighaunce diſponeth ſingulerly ſtably thing yt doen adminiſtreth maners diuers time deſtinie ilke ſame thinges hath diſponed whether deſtinie exerciſed eyther ſome diuine ſpirits ſeruaunts diuine purueighaunce el ſome ſoul el nature ſeruing god el celeſtiall mouings sterres el vertue angel el diuers ſubtelty diuels el hem el hem deſtinable ordinaunce wouen accompliſhed certes open thing yt purueighaunce vnmouable ſimple form thing doen moueable bond temporel ordinaunce thinges diuine ſimplicity purueyaunce hath ordayned doen deſtinie yt thing put vnder deſtiny certes ſubjects vnto purueiaunce purueyaunce deſtiny ſelfe ſubject vnder ſome thing put vnder purueiaunce y• ſurmounten ordinaunce deſtiny tho thilke ſtably fixed nigh firſt godhed ſurmounten ye order deſtinable mouabilitee right circle turnen ſame centre poinct thilke cercle innereſt moſt within joyneth ſimpleſſe middle centre poinct cercles turnen thilk y• vttereſt compaſſed larger enuironning vnfolde larger ſpaces ſo moch ferthereſt fro middeleſt ſimplicitie poinct thyng knitteth felowſhippeth himſelf thilke middle poinct conſtrayned ſimplicity yt ſay vnmouability ceaſeth ben ſhad flit diuerſly right ſo ſemblable reaſon thilke thing y• departeth furthereſt fro y• firſt thought god vnfolden alſo ſubmitted greater bondes deſtinie ſo moch ye thing free loce fro deſtinie asketh holdeth nere thilke centre thing ſaine god thing cleaueth ſtedfaſtneſſe y• thought god without mouyng certes ſurmounteth neceſſitie deſtinie ſoche compariſon skilling vnderſtanding thing yt engendred thing time eternity cercle centre right ſo y• order mouable diſtinie yt ſtable ſimplicity purueighaunce thilke ordinaunce moueth y• heauen ſterres attempreth y• elementes togither among hem ſelfe tranſformeth hem enterchaungeable mutacion thilke ſame order neweth ayen thing growing falling adoune ſemblable progreſſions ſeedes ſexes ſaine male female ilke order conſtraineth y• fortune dedes men bonde cauſes able vnbounden deſtinable cauſes paſſen fro beginnynges vnmovable purueyaunce mote need yt ne mutable thus y• thing well gouerned ſimplicitie dwelling y• diuine thought ſheweth forthe order cauſes vnable bowed order conſtrayneth proper ſtabilitie y• mouable thinges el ſhoulden flete folilie thing ſemen confuſe troubly v men ne mowen conſider thilke ordinaunce neuertheleſſe y• proper maner euery thyng dreſſyng hym good diſponeth hem ni nothing dooen euill thilke thing doen wicked folke ni done euill ſhrewes haue ſhewed plenteouſly ſeke good wicked errour miſturneth hem ne y• order coming fro y• poinct soueraine good ne enclineth fro beginning thou maieſt ſay wt vnreſt may worſe confuſion good men haue ſometime aduerſitie ſometime proſperitie ſhrewes haue alſo thing deſiren thing yt haten whether men liue ſoch holineſſe thoght ſaith men ſo wiſe ſoch folke demen good folke ſhrewes mote needes folke ſoch wenen maner dome men diſcorden thilk men yt ſome folke deme hem worthy mede folke deme hem worthy turment let v graunt ſuppoſe yt ſome man may well deeme know y• good people bad may know ſee thilke innereſt attemperaunce courage hath wont ſayd body ſaith may man ſpeaken complexion attemperaunce body ne ne ſaith like meruaile miracle hem yt ne know yt ſwete thing couenable ſom body y• hole ſom people bitter thing couenable alſo ſome people holpen light medicine ſome people ben holpen bitter medicine natheleſſe tho yt knowen maner y• temperaunce heale malady ne marueyleth nothing thing ſeemeth health courage bountie wt thing ſeemeth malady courage vice el keper good driuer away euill god y• gouernour leader thought y• god hath beholden yt high toure purveiaunce hee knoweth conuenable wight leaneth hem wot well yt conuenable hem lo hereof commeth herof done myracle thorder deſtinable god knoweth doth ſoch thing thing vnknowyng folke aſtonied conſtrayne ſaieth comprehend tell fewe thinges deuine deepeneſſe man reaſon may vnderſtand thilke manne thou weneſt right juſt right keeping equitie contrarie yt ſeemeth diuine purueighaunce wote lucan familier telleth yt victorious cauſe lyked goddes cauſes ouercome liketh caton ſo euer thou mayeſt ſeene yt done world unhoped el vnknowen certes y• right order thing thy wicked opinion confuſion ſuppoſe yt ſome man ſo wel thewed diuine judgement judgement mankind accorden hem togider ſo vnſtedfaſt courage yt aduerſitie come woll forleten parauenture continue innocencie ne may withholden fortune y• wiſe diſpenſacion god ſpareth man aduerſitie might enpairen y• god wil trauaile y• trauail ni • conuenable another man parfite vertues holy man nigh god ſo purueighaunce god would deme felony hee touched aduerſities ſo yt would ſuffre ſoch man bodily malady moued ſo ſaid philoſopher excellent ſayd great vertues haue edified body holy man oft time betideth yt ſumme thinges done taken gouerne good folke yt malice habundant ſhrewes ſhould ben abated god yeueth departeth folke proſperities aduerſities medled heap quality courage remordeth ſome folke adverſities ne ſhuld waxen proude long welefulneſſe folke ſuffereth travayled harde thyngs ſhould confermen vertues courage exercitation vſage patience folke dreden oughten mighten well bearen ſome diſpiſe mowe bear thilk folk god leadeth experience hemſelfe aſpre ſorrowful thing many folke haue bought honourable renome world price glorious death ſome men ne mowe ouercomen tourment haue yeuen enſample folke yt vertue may ouercommen adverſities theſe thing ny doubt ne done rightfully ordeinly parfite good hem ſeen theſe thing betiden certes adverſities cometh ſomtime ſhrewes ſometime deſiren cometh theſe foreſaid cauſes ſorrowful thing betiden ſhrews certes man ne wondreth men wene haue deſerued ben wicked merite ſhrewes tourmente agaſteth ſometyme doen felony ſometyme amendeth hem ſuffereth tourments proſperitie yt yeuen ſhrewes ſheweth great argument good people thing ſhould demen thilke welefulneſſe whiche proſperitie men ſeen ofte ſerue ſhrewes thing trowe god diſpenſeth parauenture y• nature ſome man ſo ouerthrowyng euill ſo vncouenable ye needy pouertie houſhold might rather agreue done felony maladie god putteth remedie yeuen richeſſe ſome man beholdeth conſcience defouled ſinnes maketh compariſon fortune himſelfe dredeth paraduenture bliſfulneſſe vſage joyfull leſing thilke bliſfulneſſe ne bee ſorowfull therefore would chaunge maners hee dredeth leſe fortune forleteth wickedneſſe folkes welefulneſſe yeuen vnworthily ouerthroweth hem deſtruction han deſerued ſome folke yeuen power puniſhen ſhall cauſe continuacion exerciſing good folk cauſe tourment ſhrewes ſo ni none aliaunce betweene good folkes ſhrewes ne ſhrewes ne mowen accorden among hemſelfe ſhrewes diſcorden hemſelfe vice vice renden conſciences doen oft tyme thinges thing haue done hem deme tho thinges ne ſhould haue doen thing y• ſoverain purueiance hath maked oft tyme myracle ſhrewes haue maked ſhrewes good men ſome ſhrewes ſeene ſuffre wrongfully felony ſhrewes waxen eſchaufed hate hem anoied hem retournen fruict vertue ſtudien vnlike hem haue hated certes diuine might y• might yuels good vſeth ye yuels couenably draweth effect good ſaieth yt yuel good onely y• might god y• might god ordeyneth thilke euill good one order embraceth thing ſo wight departeth ye reaſon thilke order yt aſſigned algates yet ſlideth another order ſo yt nothing lefull foly realme diuine purueiaunce ſayeth nothing without ordinance realme diuine purueiaunce ſith right ſtrong god gouerneth thing world lefull men comprehende wit ne vnfolden worde ſubtell ordinaunce diſpoſicion diuine entent onely ought ſuffice haue looked god himſelfe maker nature ordaineth thing good haſteth withhold thinges hath maked ſemblance ſay withholden thing good himſelfe good chaſeth iuels fro bond comminalties thorder neceſſitie deſtinable followeth thou loke purueiaunce ordeyning thinges men wenen outragious haboundant yerthes thou ſhalt ſeen place nothyng iuell ſee thou art charged weight queſtion weary length reaſon thou abideſt ſome ſweetneſſe ſong take draught thou art well refreſhed refect thou ſhalt ſtedfaſt fly higher queſtions thing si vi oelſi jura tonantis plura ſolers cernere mente aſpice ſummi culmina coeli thou wiſe wolt demen thy pure thought right lawes hie thonder ſain god looke thou beholde heightes ſoueraine heauen kepen sterres rightfull aliaunce thyngs old peace sunne imoued roddie fire ne diſtourbeth colde cercle mone ne ſterre icleped bere enclineth rauiſhing courſes abouten ſoueraine height worlde ne ſame ſterre vrſa ni neuer mo waſhen deepe weſtren ſea ne coueteth dien • ames ſea occian although ſee sterres iplonged sea heſperus sterre boodeth telleth alway late night lucifer sterre bringeth ayen cleare day thus maketh loue enterchaungeable perdurable courſes thus diſcordable battayle yput countrey ſterres accordaunce attempreth euenlike maners element moyſt thing ſtriuing drie thing yeuen place ſtoundes colde thinges joynen hem fayth hote thinges light fire ariſeth height heauy yearths auayleth weight ſame cauſes flourie yeere yeldeth ſwete ſmels firſt sommer ſeaſon warming hote sommer dryeth cornes autumpne commeth ayen heauy appels fleeting rayne deweth winter attempraunce nouriſheth bryngeth forth thing beareth life worlde thilke ſame attempraunce rauiſhing hideth benimeth drencheth vnder laſt death thing iborne among theſe thing ſitteth high maker king lorde weale beginnyng lawe wiſe iudge doen equitee gouerneth enclineth bridels thing tho thing ſterreth gone mouing withdraweth areſteth affirmeth moueable wandring thing ne called ayen right going thing ne conſtrayned hem efte ſones roundneſſe enclined thing continued ſtable ordinaunce ſhould departen weale ſaine beginning fallen ſaine tournen nought common loue thing thing asken holden fine good elles ne mighten faſten ne come e • tſones ayen loue retourned cauſe hath yeuen hem beyng ſaine god jam ne igitur vides quid haec omnia quae diximus conſequantur quid nam inquit omnem inquit c seeſt thou thing followeth thing haue ſaied boetius thing qd philoſophie certes qd ſhe vtterly fortune good boetius may qd philoſophie vnderſtand qd ſhe fortune wheder ſo joyfull fortune aſpre fortune yeuen eyther bycauſe guerdoning elles exerciſing good folkes elles bycauſe puniſhen elles chaſtiſen ſhrews fortune good fortune certaine eyther rightfull elles profitable boetius forſothe full reaſon qd conſider purueighaunce deſtinie thou oughteſt little beforne ſentence ſuſteyned ſtedfaſt reaſons lyke vnto thee let v nombren hem emonges ilke thinges thou ſaideſt little beforne ne able ben wened people philoſophie ſo qd ſhe boet common word men qd miſuſeth maner ſpeech fortune ſaine oft tymes fortune ſome wight wicked philoſophie wilt thou qd ſhe approche little word people ſo ſeme hem ouermoch departed fro vſage mankinde boetius thou wolt qd philoſophie weneſt thou qd ſhe thing profiteth good boetius yes qd philoſophie certes thing exerceth corrigeth profiteth boetius confeſſe well qd philoſophie good qd ſhe boetius qd philoſophie fortune qd ſhe hem eyther put vertue battaylen agaynſt aſpre thing el hem enclinen declinen fro vice taken way vertue boetius ne may deny qd philoſophie ſayeſt thou merie fortune yeuen good people guerdon demeth ofte people wicked boetius nay forſoth qd demen ſoth right good philoſophie ſaieſt thou fortune qd ſhe although aſpre reſtraineth ſhrews rightfull tourment weneth aught people good boet nay qd people demeth moſt wretched thing may thought philoſophie ware looke well qd ſhe leaſt wee followyng opinion people haue confeſſed concluded thing vnable wened people boetius qd philoſophie certes qd ſhe followeth commeth thing graunted fortune ſo euer bee hem eyther poſſeſſion vertue thencreaſe vertue el purchaſing vertue thilke fortune good fortune right wicked hem dwellen ſhreudneſſe ſaith thus weneth people boetius ſoth qd albeit ſo man dare confeſſe ne know philoſophie ſo qd ſhe right ſtrong man ne ſemeth abaſhen diſdaynen oft tyme heareth noyſe battail ne alſo ſeemeth wiſeman bearen grieuouſly oft ledde ſtrife fortune bothe one man eke ilke difficultie matter one man encreaſe hys glorious renome man conſerue ſapience ſay aſpreneſſe eſtate therefore called vertue ſuſteyneth enforceth ſtrengthes ſo ouercommen aduerſities ne certes thou arte putte encreaſe height vertue ne haſt commen fleten delices walken bodily luſt thou ſoweſt planteſt full eigre battayle thy courage ayenſt euery fortune ſorrowfull fortune confounde thee ne merie fortune ne corrumpe thee occupie meane ſtedfaſt ſtrengthes euer vnder meane ouerpaſſeth meane diſpiſeth welefulneſſe ſayeth vicious ne hath mede trauayle ſet hand ſayeth lieth power fortune leueſt ſay good iuel fortune ſemeth ſharpe aſpre ne exerciſe good folke ne chaſtiſe wicked folke puniſheth bella bi quinis operatus annis ultor atrides phrygiae ruinis c werker atrides ſain agamemnon wrought continued battayles ten yeere recouered purged wreking diſtruction troie loſte chamber mariage brother ſay agamemnon wan ayen heleine menelaus wife brother meane thilke agamemnon deſired yeuen ſayles grekes nauie brought ayen windes blood vnclothed pitee father ſorie prieſt yeueth ſacrifiyng wretched cuttyng throte doughter ſay agamemnon let cut throte doughter prieſt maken aliaunce goddes haue wind might wenden troy itacus ſay vlixes bewept fellowes ylorne fellowes fiers poliphemus liggyng great caue fretten dreint emptie wombe natheles poliphemus wood blind viſage yeld vlixes joy ſorrowfull teares ſay vlixes ſmote iye poliphemus ſtoode forehead vlixes joy ſaw poliphemus wepyng blind hercules celebrable hard trauaile daunted proude centaurus halfe horſe halfe man byraft diſpoiling fro cruel lion ſay ſlough lion birafte skin ſmote birdes hight arpies certain arrowes rauiſhed apple fro waking dragon hand heauy golden mettall drough cerberus hound hell triple chaynes ouercomer ſaied hath put vnmeke lord fodder cruell horſe ſay hercules ſlough diomedes made horſe fretten hercules ſlough idra serpent brent venim achileus flood defouled forehedde dreint ſhamefaſt viſage ſtroundes ſay achileus could tranſfigure himſelfe diuers likenes fought hercules laſt tourned bull hercules brake one horne ſhame hid hym riuer ouer hercules caſte adoune antheus giaunt ſtrondes libie cacus appeiſed wrathes euander ſay hercules ſlough monſter cacus apeiſed death wrath euander briſtled bore marked vomes ſhoulders hercules whiche ſholders hie cercle heauen ſhould thriſt laſt labour ſuſteined heauen vpon neck vnbowed deſerved eftſones heauen y• laſt ende trauayle goeth yee ſtrong men great enſample leadeth nice men make ye back ſayeth ye ſlowe delicate men ſee ye aduerſities ne fight againſt hem vertue winnen mede heauen mede ouercommen yeueth sterres ſaine yearthly luſt ouercommen man maked worthy heauen ¶thus endeth fourth book boetius dixerat orationiſque curſum ad alia quaedam tractanda atque expedienda vertebat b tum ego rectum quidem inquam c ſaid turned courſe reaſon ſome thing treated ſped boetius ſaid certes rightfull thine amoneſting full digne aucthoritie thou ſaideſt whilom queſtion diuine purveiaunce enlaced many queſtions vnderſtand well proue ſame thing aske thou weneſt happe bee thing wayes thou weneſt happe thing philoſophie qd ſhe haſte yelden aſſoilen debte beheſt ſhewen open way way thou maieſt come ayen thy countrie albeit ſo thinges thou askeſt right profitable know yet diuers ſomewhat fro path purpoſe doubt thou ne maked wearie miſſe wayes ſo thou ne maieſt ſuffice meaſure right way boetius ne doubt thee thereof nothing qd knowen thilke thing togider thing delite greatly ſhall ſteede reſt ſith ni doubten thynges following euery thyng thy diſputacion ſhall hauen ben ſtedfaſt vndoubtous faith philoſophie ſaid ſhe manner woll doen thee beganne ſpeaken right thus certes qd ſhe wight definiſhe hap maner ſaine hap betiding ibrought foorthe fooliſhe mouing knitting cauſes confirme hap ny right naught wiſe deeme vtterly hap ny ne dwelleth voyce ſayeth idell woorde without ſignificacion thynge committed voyce place might lefte dwellyng follie diſordenaunce ſithe god leadeth conſtrayneth thynges order ſentence ſooth nothing hath hys beyng naughte whiche ſentence none theſe olde folke ne withſayed neuer ſo ne vnderſtanden god prince beginner workyng eaſten manner foundement ſubject materiall ſaine nature reaſon thing waxen commen cauſes ſhall ſeeme thilke thyng commen woxen naught ne may done poſſible hap ſoche thing haue definiſhed little beforne boetius ſhall bee qd ni nothing right may cleaped eyther happe el adventure fortune ought ſo hidde fro people thing theſe word couenable philoſophie mine ariſtotle qd ſhe booke phiſike difiniſheth thing ſhort reaſon nigh ſothe boetius maner qd philoſophie ofte qd ſhe men done thyng grace thyng another thyng thilke thyng menne entenden doen betideth ſome cauſes icleaped happe right man dalfe yearth bycauſe tillyng field found gobet golde bedoluen wenen folke befall fortunous betidyng forſooth ni naught hath proper cauſes cauſes cours vnforeſeen vnware ſeemeth haue maked hap tiller field ne dolue yearth hider golde ne hid golde place golde ne found theſe cauſes abredgyng fortuit hap abredgyng fortuit hap commeth cauſes encountryng flowyng togither hemſelfe thentencion doer neyther hider golde ne deluer field ne vnderſtanden golde ſhould haue found ſaied betide ran togither dalfe hid golde may thus definiſhe hap hap vnware betidyng cauſes aſſembled thing doen ſome thyng thilke order procedyng vneſchuable betiding togither diſcendeth well purueighaunce ordeyneth thyngs place time maketh cauſes rennen aſſemblen togither rupis achimeniae ſcopulis ubi verſa ſequentum pectoribus figit ſpicula c tigris eufrates reſoluen ſpringen welle cragges roche countrey achemenee fliyng battayles fixen dart retourning breaſts hem folowen hem ſone ſame riuers tigris eufrates vnjoynen departen water commen together aſſembled cleaped together courſe moten thilke thing fleten togider water thenterchaunging flood bringeth ſhippes ſtockes araced flood moten aſſemblen water imedled wrappeth emplieth many fortunell happes maners wandring happes natheleſſe thilke declinyng lowneſſe yerth flowyng order ſlidyng water gouerneth right ſo fortune ſeemeth ſuffreth slaked vngouerned bridle ſuffreth bridle ſaine gouerned paſſeth thilke lawe ſaine diuine ordinaunce animadverto inquam idque uti tu dicis ita eſſe conſentio sed hac haerentium c vnderſtand well qd accord right thou ſayeſt aske liberty freewill order cauſes cleauen thus togither hemſelf el would weten deſtinall cheyne conſtrayneth mouyng courage men philoſophie yes qd ſhe liberty freewill ne ne neuer nature reaſon ne liberty freewill euery thyng may naturally vſen reaſon hath dome decerneth deemeth euery thyng knoweth ſelfe thyngs flien thyngs deſiren ilke thyng wight demeth deſired asketh deſireth flieth thilke thing troweth flien wherefore thyngs reaſon alſo liberty willyng nillyng ne ordayne ſayeth ne graunt liberty euen like thyngs soueraines devines ſubſtaunces ſain ſpirites judgement clere corrumpen mighty ready ſpeden thing deſired ſoules men moten needes free looken hem ſpeculacion looking deuine thought laſſe free ſliden body yet laſſe free ben gathered togither comprehended yearthly member laſt ſervage yeuen vice haue ifall poſſeſſion proper reaſon haue caſte away iyen fro light soueraine ſothfaſtneſſe low thing darcke anone darcken cloude ignoraunce troubled felonious talentes talentes approchen aſſenten heapen encreaſen ſervage haue joyned hemſelfe maner caytiues fro proper libertie thyng natheleſſe lookyng deuine purueiaunce ſeeth thyngs beholdeth ſeeth fro eterne ordeyneth hem euerich merites predeſtinate ſaid greke thyngs ſeeth thyngs heareth puro clarum lumine phoebum melliflui canit oris homerus c homer hony mouth ſaine homer ſweet ditees ſingeth sunne cleare pure light natheleſſe yet ne may infirme light beames breaken percen inwarde entrailes yearth el sea ne ſeeth god maker greate worlde looketh thyngs high ne vnderſtandeth thyngs heauineſſe yearth ne night ne withſtandeth blacke cloudes thilke god ſeeth ſtroke thought thyngs ſhull come thilke god looketh ſeeth thyngs alone thou mayſt ſaine ſonne tum ego en inquam difficiliori rurſus ambiguitate confundor c ſaid thus confounded hard doubt philoſ doubt qd ſhe certes conject nowe ſoche thyngs thou art troubled b ſeemeth qd repugnen contrary greatly god knoweth beforne thyngs freedome libertie ſo god looketh thyngs beforne ne god ne may deceyued maner mote need bee thyngs purueiaunce god hath ſeene beforne come god knoweth toforne onely werkes men alſo counſailes willes ne ſhall libertie arbitree ne certes ne may none deede ne ilke deuine purueiaunce ne may deceyved hath feeled beforne mighten wrythen away maner purueied ne ſhould ſtedfaſt preſcience thing commen rather vncertaine opinion thing trowen god deme felony vnlefull ne ne proue ilke ſame reaſon ſayeth ne alowe ne prayſe thilke ſame reaſon ſome men wenen mowen aſſoilen vnknitten knot queſtion certes ſaine thing ni commen purueiaunce god hath ſeen beforne commen rather contrary thyngs commen therefore ne may hid fro purueiaunce god maner neceſſitie ſlideth ayen contrarie partie ne ne behoueth needes thing betiden ypurueighed behoueth need thing yt commen ypurueighed ytrauailed ſaith thilke anſwere proceedeth right though men trauaileden buſie enquiren thing cauſe thing whether preſcience cauſe neceſſitie thing commen el yt neceſſitie thinges commen cauſe purueighaunce ne enforce ſhewen betiding thinges iwiſte beforne neceſſary ſo maner yt order cauſes hath ſelfe although yt ne ſeeme preſcience bryng neceſſitie betiding thing commen c •• te wight ſitteth behoueth neceſſitie opinion ſooth hym coniecteth ſitteth ayenwarde alſo contrary y• opinion ſoothe wight ſitteth behoueth neceſſitie ſitte neceſſitie one one neceſſity ſittyng certes neceſſity ſoth therefore ne ſitteth wight opinion ſitting ſoth opinion rather ſoth wight ſitteth beforne thus although cauſe ſoth commeth ſide ſayeth although cauſe ſothe commeth ſitting true opinion algates yet common neceſſity one thus ſemeth y• may make ſemblable skilles purueighaunce god thing commen although yt thing commen therefore purueighed certes purueighed therfore ne betide natheleſſe behoueth neceſſity either thing commen beene ypurueyed god el yt y• thing purueighed god betiden thing onely ſuffiſeth inough deſtroyen freedome arbitty yt ſaine freewill certes ſheweth well farre fro ſothe vp ſo doune thing y• ſeen betidyng temporall thing cauſe eterne preſcience wenen y• god purueyeth y• thing commen ben commen thing wene thilke thing betide whilom cauſes thilk ſouerain purueighaunce god hereto adde thinges right wote thing behoueth neceſſity thilke ſelfe thyng eke haue knowen thing ſhall betyden ſo behoueth neceſſity thilke ſame thinges betyde followeth betidyng thing iwiſt beforne ne may eſchewed y• laſt wight wene thing otherwiſe ni onely vnſcience deceiueable opinion full diuers farre fro ſothe ſcience wherfore thyng ſo commen betidyng ne certaine ne neceſſary may weten beforne y• thilke thing commen right ſcience ne may medled falſeneſſe ſaieth wote thing ne may falſe ne wote right thilke thing conceiued ſcience ne may none otherwiſe conceiued y• cauſe science wanteth leſing ſaieth weting ne receyueth leſing wote behoueth neceſſity y• euery thing right science comprehendeth ſhall ſaine maner knoweth god beforne thinges commen ne certain deme commen vneſchuably ſo may poſſible ne ſhullen comen god deceiued trowen god deceyued ſpeake mouth felonous ſin god wote right ſo thing commen ſo ſhullen commen ſo wote egally ſaith indifferently thing may done el ydone thilk preſcience ne comprehendeth certayne thyng ne ſtable el difference y• preſcience thilke jape worthy deuining tireſie deuinour y• ſayd ſay qd eyther ſhall el ne ſhall el moche worth deuine preſcience opinion mankind ſo demeth y• thing vncertain men done y• dome men betiding ny certain ſo none vncertaine thing ne may right certayne well thing betidyng certaine thilke thing hath wiſte beforne fermely commen whiche followeth freedome counſailes werkes mankind ni none ſith y• thought god ſeeth thyngs without errour falſeneſſe bindeth conſtrayneth hem betidyng neceſſity thing one igraunted receiued ſaine ni freewill ſheweth well great deſtruction great domages folowen thing mankind idell purpoſed behight medes good folke pain bad folke ſith mouyng free courage voluntarie ne hath deſerued hem y• ſaine neyther mede ne payne ſhould ſeeme thilke thing alderworſt demed aldermoſt juſt moſt rightful ſain ſhrewes ben puniſhed el good folk iguerdonned folkes ſen proper ne ſent hem one ne y• ſayne neyther good ne harm conſtraineth hem certain neceſſity thing comen ne ſhullen ther neuer ben ne neuer vice ne vertue ſhullen rather confuſion deſerts medled without diſcrecion yet followeth another inconuenience y• ne may thought felonous ne wicked y• thus ſo y• order thing commeth purueiaunce god ne nothing ni leful counſailes mankind ſaieth men haue power doen nothing ne nothing followeth vice referred maker al good ſaith followeth god ought blame vice ſith conſtraineth v neceſſitie done vice ni reaſon hopen god ne prayen god wt ſhould wight hopen god ſhould praien god ſith yt ordinaunce deſtinie y• ne may enclined knitteth ſtreyneth thing men may deſiren ſhould done away thilke aliaunce betwene god man ſaine hopen prayen y• price rightwiſeneſſe mekeneſſe deſerven y• guerdon diuine grace yt ineſtimable ſay ſo great y• ne may full praiſed maner ſay hope praiers ſeemeth y• men woll ſpeak god reaſon ſupplicacion ben conjoined thilk clearnes ni approched rather men ſeken impetren men ne wene hope ne prayer ne ſtrengthes y• neceſſitie thing comen received thing mowen conjoyned cleuen thilke ſoueraine prince thing behoveth neceſſitie linage mankind thou ſong little beforne departed unjoyned wele failen beginning ſaine god quae nam diſcors federa rerum cauſa reſolvit quis tanta deus c diſcordable cauſe hath rent vnjoyned binding aliaunce thing ſaine conjunction god man god hath eſtabliſhed ſo great battaile betweene theſe two ſoothfaſte thing ſaine betweene purueyaunce god free ſingular deuided ne ne wollen beene meddled ne coupſed togeder ni diſcord thing cleauen alway certaine hemſelfe thought man confounded overthrowne y• darke member y• body ne may fire darked looking ſaine y• vigour inſight ſoule body knowen thinne ſubtill knitting thing wherefore eſchaufeth ſo ſo great loue finden thilke note ſooth ycovered y• ſaine wherefore eſchaufeth y• thought man ſo great deſire know thilk notification y• ben ihid vnder y• couertures ſooth wote ought thilke thing anguiſhous deſireth knowe ſayth nay man ne trauayleth weten thing wote therefore y• text ſayth thus trauayleth weten thinges yknowe ne knoweth hem wt ſeeketh thilke blind thought hee hath deſired thynges hee wote right naught ſaith ſo deſireth thing need ſomewhat knoweth el ne coud deſiren may follow thing ne iwiſt though ſeeke thyngs ſhall find hem wight vncunning ignoraunt may knowe forme ifound ſoule beholdeth ſeeth high thought y• ſayne god knoweth togither y• ſumme ſingularities ſayne principle eueriche hem himſelfe ſoule hid cloud y• darkeneſſe member ye bodie ne hath foryeten ſelfe withholdeth y• ſumme thynges leſeth ſingularities ſo ſeeketh ſoothneſſe ni neyther nother habite wote ne hee ne hath foryeten yet remembreth ſumme thynges y• hee withholdeth asketh counſayle retreateth deepliche thinges iſeene beforne ſayne great ſumme mind ſo mowe adden partes y• hee hath foryeten thilke party hath withholden tum illa vetus inquit haec eſt de providentia querela marco tullio c ſaied ſhe qd ſhe old queſtion purueyaunce god marcus tullius deuided deuinacions ſaine bookes hee wrote deuinacions moued greatly queſtion thou thy ſelfe haſte iſought much vtterly long yet ne hath determined ne iſped fermely diligently cauſe darkneſſe difficulty yt mouing ye reaſon mankinde ne may mouen yt ſayne applien joynen ſimplicitie diuine preſcience ſimplicitie ye diuine preſcience y• men mighten thinken manner yt ſayne yt men mighten thinke comprehenden thing yt god ſeeth himſelf dwelled vtterly doubt reaſon cauſe difficulty ſhall aſſay laſt ſhew ſpeeden haue firſt iſpended anſwered thy reaſons thou art moued ask thou weneſt y• thilke reaſons hem aſſoilen queſtion ne ſpedfull inough ne ſufficient y• ſolucion y• reaſon y• deemeth yt preſcience neceſſity thing come ſaith way thus yt thilke thing y• preſcience wote beforn ne may vnbetiden yt ſayne moten betide preſcience ne putteth none neceſſitie thinges commen thou thy ſelfe haſt confeſſed beknow litle beforne cauſe ſaieth may cauſe end voluntarie thing mighten conſtrayned certaine betiding grace poſicion ſo yt thou may better vnderſtand y• followeth ſuppoſe yt ne bee preſcience aſke qd ſhe much appertayneth ſhoulden thinges yt commen free conſtrained betiding neceſſitie boecius nay qd philoſo ayenward qd ſhe ſuppoſe yt preſcience ne putteth neceſſitie thing trowe thilke ſame freedome ſhall dwellen hole abſolute unbounden thou wilt ſayne ſo preſcience ni cauſe y• neceſſity betiding thing commen algates yet ſigne thyngs betiden neceſſitie manner although y• preſcience neuer yet algates leaſt way certain thing end betidings thing commen ſhoulden neceſſary euery thing ſheweth ſignifieth onely y• thing ne maketh thing ſignifieth behoueth firſt ſhew nothing ne betideth ne betideth neceſſitie ſo may appear preſcience ſigne neceſſitie el nere neceſſitie certes thilke preſcience ne might bee ſigne thyng ni certes nowe certaine ye prooue yſuſteined ſtedfaſt reaſon ne ſhall ben lad ne prooued ſignes ne argument taken fro without cauſes covenable neceſſarie thou mayſt ſaine may thyngs ne betiden purueyed commen certes right trowen thyngs purueyaunce wote beforne commen ne betiden ne ſhould deemen rather although ſhall betiden yet ne haue neceſſitie kind betiden mayeſt thou lightly apperceyuen yt ſhall ſaine ſeene many thynges beforne eyen right men ſeene y• carter worching tourning attempring addreſſing cart chariot manner ſayth maieſt thou vnderſtand werkemen neceſſitie ſaieth looking conſtrayneth compelleth thilke thing done ſo boeci nay qd idle vain effect craft yt thyngs moued conſtrayning eyen ſight philoſo thing qd ſhe men done hem ne haue neceſſitie y• men done hem eke tho ſame thing firſt done commen without neceſſitie ben ſome thing betiden end betidings hem abſolute quit neceſſitie certes ne trowe yt man would ſayne thyngs men done ne betiden firſt ere done thilk ſame thing although men hadden wiſt hem beforne yet haue free betidings right ſcience thing preſent ne bringeth neceſſitie thing y• men done right ſo preſcience thing commen ne bringeth none neceſſitie thinges betiden thou mayeſt ſayne thilke ſame doubted whether y• thilke thing ne haue none iſſues betidings neceſſaries thereof may ben preſcience certes ſeemen diſcorden thou weneſt thing ſeene y• neceſſitie followeth hem neceſſitie fayleth hem ne might beene wiſt y• nothing may comprehended ſcience certaine tho thing ne haue certain betidings purveighed certayne ſhould darkneſſe opinion ſoothfaſtneſſe ſcience thou weneſt diuers fro holineſſe ſcience man ſhould deeme thyng bee otherwiſe ſelfe cauſe errour y• thyngs y• euery wight hath knowe wene y• tho thyngs knowe onely y• ſtrength nature thynges y• wiſt knowe y• contrarie euer knowe rather comprehended know ſtrength nature yc facultie yt ſayne power nature hem y• knowen y• thyng ſhould ſhewe ſhort enſample roundneſſe bodie otherwiſe ſight y• eye knoweth otherwiſe touching looking caſting beam waiteth ſeeth afarre y• bodie together without mouing ſelfe touching cleaueth round body moueth y• enuironning comprehendeth party roundneſſe man himſelfe otherwiſe beholdeth otherwaies imaginacion otherwiſe reaſon otherwiſe intelligence wit comprehended without forth figure bodie man vnſtabliſhed matter ſubject imaginacion comprehendeth onely figure without matter reaſon ſurmounteth imaginacion comprehendeth vniuerſall looking common ſpeech y• eye intelligence higher ſurmounteth y• enuironning vniuerſitie looketh pure ſubtiltie thought ilke ſame ſimple forme man perdurable deuine thought whyche ought greatly bee conſidered y• higheſt ſtrengthe comprehenden thynges embraceth contayneth lower ſtrength lower ſtrength ne ariſeth manner y• higher ſtrength wit ne may 〈1 page duplicate〉 〈1 page duplicate〉 comprehend nothyng matter ne imaginacion ne looketh vniuerſall ſpeces ne reaſon ne taketh ſimple forme ſo intelligence taketh intelligence looketh abouen hath comprehended forme knoweth deemeth thynges beene vnder forme ſhe knoweth hem thilke manner comprehendeth thilke ſame ſimple forme ne may neuer bee knowen none ſay none tho three foreſayed ſtrengthes ſoule knoweth vniuerſitie reaſon figure imaginacion ſenſible materiall conceyued wit ne ne vſeth ne reaſon ne imaginacion ne wit withoutforth beholdeth thyngs ſo ſhall ſay ſtroke thought fermely without diſcourſe collacion certes reaſon looketh thing vniuerſell ne vſeth imaginacion ne wit algates yet comprehendeth y• thynges imaginable ſenſible reaſon ſhee definiſheth y• vniuerſall conceit right thus man reaſonable twofooted beaſt ſo knowing vniuerſall yet ni wight ne wote well y• man thyng imaginable ſenſible ſame conſidereth well reaſon ni imaginacion wit looketh reaſonable concepcion alſo imaginacion albeit ſo taketh wit beginning ſeen formen figure algates although y• wit ne preſent yet enuironneth comprehendeth thing ſenſible reaſon ſenſible deeming reaſon imaginatife seeſt thou y• thing knowing vſen facultie power fro thyngs fro without ſoules ben emprinted ſoules right ben wont ſometime ſwift pointel fixen letter emprinted y• ſmoothneſſe plaineneſſe table waxe y• parchemine hath figure ne note gloſe argueth boece agaynſt y• opinion ſayth thus thriuing ſoule ne vnpliteth nothing ſaine ne doth thing proper mouing ſuffreth lieth ſubject figure y• note body without forth yeeldeth image idle euill vaine manner mirrour whence thriueth whence commeth thilke knowing ſoule diſcerneth beholdeth thing whence thilke ſtrength beholdeth ſingular thing el whence ſtrength deuideth thing yknowe thilke ſtrength gathereth together thynges deuided ſtrength choſeth y• enterchaunged way ſometime heaueth head yt ſay yt heaueth vp entencion right high thing ſometime diſcendeth right low thyngs returneth himſelfe ſufferaunce wit y• quicke bodie goeth exciting mouing y• ſtrengths thought right ſo y• cleareneſſe ſmiteth eyen moueth hem ſeeene right ſo voyce ſoun hurleth eares commoueth hem hearken ſtrength thought moued excited cleapeth forth ſemblable mouings ſpeces halt within ſelfe addeth ſpeces note thynges withoutfoorth medleth image thing withoutforth thinges hid within himſelfe quod ſi corporibus ſentiendis quamvis efficiant inſtrumenta ſenſuum c bvt body feeled ſay taking knowing bodily thinges albeit ſo yt quality body yt object fro withoutfoorth mouen entalenten inſtruments wit ſo yt paſſion bodie ſaine wit ſufferaunce goeth beforne ſtrength worching courage y• paſſion ſufferaunce clepeth foorth y• deede thought ſelfe moueth exciteth meane formes y• reſten withinforth ſenſible body haue ſaid courage ni taught oremprinted paſſion know theſe thing demeth knoweth owne ſtrength paſſion ſufferance ſubject body much tho thing abſolute quicke fro talent affection body god angel ne right intelligence onely diuine nature followeth thilke knowing worth either ſens knoweth proper nature ſubject ſaith ne knoweth appertaineth properly knowing knoweth ſubjects knowing ſhall wit imaginacion ſtriuen ayen reaſoning ſayne thilke vniuerſall thing reaſon weneth ſeene ni right naught wit imaginacion ſayne ſenſible imaginable ne may vniuerſall either judgement reaſon ſooth ne ni nothing ſenſible el reaſon wote well many thyngs ben ſubject wit imaginacion concepcion reaſon vain falſe looketh comprehendeth ſenſible ſingular vniuerſall reaſon would aunſwere ayenſt theſe two ſay wit imaginacion ſay ſoothly ſhe ſelf ſayne reaſon looketh comprehendeth reaſon vniuerſalitie ſenſible imaginable thilke two ſaine wit imaginacion ne mowen ſtretchen hemſelfe knowing vniuerſalitie knowing hem ne may exceeden ne ſurmounten bodily figure certes knowing thyngs men oughten rather yeuen credence ſtedfaſt perfite judgement manner ſtriuing haue ſtrength reaſoning imaginacion wit ſay reaſon imaginacion ſhould rather praiſe cauſe reaſon ſayeth cauſe wit imaginacion semblable thing reaſon mankind ne weneth diuine intelligence beholdeth knoweth thyngs come right reaſon mankind knoweth hem thou argueſt thus ne ſeeme men ſome thing haue certaine betidings ne may wiſt certainely betiden preſcience thilke thyngs trow preſcience theſe thyngs nothing betideth neceſſitie might haue judgement diuine thought partner reaſon right ſo haue demed behoueth imaginacion wit beneath reaſon right ſo would deemen rightfull thyng man reaſon ought ſubmit ſelfe beneath diuine thought may ſayth may counſail enhaunce v height thilke ſoueraine intelligence ſhall reaſon well ſeene ne may behold ſelfe certes thus manner preſcience god ſeeth thing definiſheth although haue certain betidings ne none opinion rather ſimplicitie ſouerain ſcience ſhet within manner bound quam variis terras animalia permeant figuris namque alia extento ſunt corpore c beaſts paſſen earth full diver figure ſome hem haue body ſtraught crepen duſt drawn hem trace forough continued ſay neders snail beaſtes wandering lightneſſe wing beaten windes ouerſwimmen ſpaces long aire moſt flying beaſts gladden hemſelf diggen trace ſteppes earth going foot gone either greene fieldes el walken vnder wood ſo thou ſeeſt diſcorden diuers formes algates face enclined heauieth dull wit linage man heaueth higheſt high head ſtandeth light vpright body beholdeth earth vnder thou earthly man waxeſt euill thy wit figure amoneſteth thee askeſt heuen thy right viſage haſt areiſed thy forehead bearen vp high thy courage ſo thy thought ne heauied ne put lowe vnder foot ſith thy body ſo high areiſed quoniam igitur uti paulo ante monſtratum eſt omne quod ſcitur c therefore haue ſhewed little beforne thyng wiſt ni known nature proper nature hem comprehenden let v looken much lefull v ſaieth let v looken may eſtate diuine ſubſtaunce ſo may well know eke wt ſcience common judgement creature reaſonables god eterne let v conſider eternity certes ſhall ſhewen v togider diuine nature diuine ſcience eternitie perfit poſſeſſion together life interminable ſheweth clearely compariſon collacion temporall thyngs thing liueth time preſent proceedeth fro preterities future ſain time paſſed time comming ne ni nothing eſtabliſhed time may embracen togither ſpace life certes yet ne hath taken time morrow hath loſt yeſterday certes life day ye ne liuen right moouable tranſitorie moment thilke thing ſuffereth temporall condicion although neuer began ne though neuer ceaſe ariſtotle demed world although life ſtretched infinite time yet algates ni ſuch thing men might trowen right eterne although comprehend embrace ſpace life infinite yet algates ne embraceth ſpace life altogither ne hath future yet ne ne hath lenger preterities ben done paſſed thilke thing hath comprehendeth togider plenty life interminable ne fayleth nought future ni nought preteritie eſcaped paſſed thilke ſame ywitneſſed prooved right ben etern behoueth neceſſitie thilk thing alway preſent himſelfe competent ſayth alway preſent himſelfe ſo mightie right pleaſaunce haue preſent infinite moouable time wherefore ſome men trowen wrongfully heren ſeemed plato world neuer beginning time neuer ſhall haue fayling wene thilke manner world maked eterne maker ſaith wene world god maked together eterne wrongfull wening thing lad life interminable plato graunted world thing embrace togither preſence life interminable thing clere manifeſt diuine thought ne ne ſhould ſeeme v god elder thing maked quantitie time rather proſperitie ſimple nature ilk infinite mouings temporall thing followeth preſentarie eſtate life immouable ſo ne may countrefeten ne faine ne euenlike immobilitie ſay eternitie god faileth faileth moouing fro ſimplicitie preſence god diſincreaſeth infinite quantity future preterity ſo may haue togider plentie life algates yet much ceaſeth neuer ben ſome manner yet ſeemeth ſomedele v followeth reſembleth thilke thing ne may attaine ne fulfillen bindeth ſelfe ſome manner preſence little moment preſence little ſwift moment beareth manner image likeneſſe aye dwelling god graunteth ſuch manner thyngs betideth ſemeth hem theſe thyngs haue ben ben preſence ſuch little moment ne may dwell therefore raviſhed tooke infinite way time ſay ſucceſſion manere done ſhould continue life going life ne might enbrace plentie dwelling thy wollen put worthie name thyngs followen plato let v ſay ſoothly god eterne world perpetuell ſith euery judgement knoweth comprehendeth nature thyngs ſubject vnto god alwayes eterne preſentarie eſtate ſcience ouerpaſſeth temporall moment dwelleth ſimplicitie preſence embraceth conſidereth infinite ſpaces time preterities time future looketh ſimple knowing thyngs preteritie right ydone preſently right thou wolt thinken aduiſe preſcience whych knoweth thyngs thou ne ſhalt deemen preſcience thyngs commen thou ſhalt deemen rightfully ſcience preſence inſtance neuer ne fayleth whych ni ycleped prouidence ſhould rather cleped purueyaunce eſtabliſhed full ferre fro right low thyngs beholdeth aferre thyngs right fro hie height thyngs askeſt thou diſputeſt thou thilke thyngs done neceſſitie whych yſeene yknown diuine ſight ſith forſooth men ne maken nat thilke thyngs neceſſarie whych ſeene ydone ſight addeth thy beholding neceſſitie thilke thyngs whych thou beholdeſt preſent bo nay qd phi certes qd ſhe men mighten maken digne compariſon collacion preſence diuine preſence mankinde right ſo ye ſeene ſome thyngs temporall preſence right ſo ſeeth god thyngs eterne preſence wherefore diuine preſcience ne chaungeth nature propertie thyngs beholdeth ſuch thyngs preſent ward ſhoulden betiden ward time commen ne ne confoundeth judgement thyngs one ſight thought knoweth thyngs commen well neceſſary neceſſary right ſo ye ſeene together man walke earth ſunne ariſen heuen ſo ye ſeene together one yet neuertheleſſe wee deemen diſcernen one voluntary neceſſary right ſo deuine looking beholding thing vnder ne troubleth nat qualitie thyngs certainly preſent ward condicion time forſooth ben future followeth ni none opinion rather ſtedfaſt knowing yſtrengthned ſoothneſſe god knoweth thyng ne vnwote nat thilk thyng wanteth neceſſitie ſayne god knoweth thing betide hee wote well ne hath neceſſity betide thou ſeeſt thilke thyng god ſeeth betide ne may nat vnbetide ſayeth betide thilke thyng ne may nat vnbetide betiden neceſſity thou ſtrein name neceſſity certes well confeſſen beknowen thing full ſad trouth vnneth ſhall wight ſeene come thereto beholder divine thought anſwere thee thus thilke thyng future referred diuine knowing neceſſary certes vnderſtanden owne kind men ſeene vtterly free abſolute fro neceſſities certes ben two manner neceſſities one neceſſity ſimple behoueth neceſſity men mortall deadly another neceſſity condicionell thus thou woſt man walketh behoueth neceſſity walke thilke thing wight hath iknow ne may nat none otherwiſe knoweth condicion ne draweth thilke neceſſity ſimple certes neceſſity condicionell proper nature ne maketh nat adjection condicion maketh neceſſity ne conſtrayneth man gone goth proper ſo goth neceſſary goeth right ſame manner purueyaunce god ſeeth thyng preſent mote thilk thing neceſſity although ne haue neceſſity owne nature certes future betiden freedome arbitry god ſeeth hem togider preſent theſe thyngs referred diuine ſight maked neceſſary condicion diuine knowing certes thilke thyngs conſidered hemſelfe abſolute neceſſity ne • eten ne ceaſen liberty owne nature certes without doubt thyngs ſhulien done god wo • e beforne ben commen betiden free arbitry free ſo betiden yet algates ne leſe proper nature firſt done hadden power haue betidde boetius ſayne qd thyngs ne neceſſary proper nature ſo commen manner likeneſſe neceſſity condicion diuine ſcience philoſophy difference qd ſhe tho thyngs purpoſed thee little beforn ſame sunne ariſing man walking while thilke thyngs done ne might vndone natheleſſe one hem done behoueth neceſſity done right ſo thyngs god hath preſent withouten doubt ſhullen ſome hem diſcendeth nature thyngs sunne ariſing ſome diſcendeth power doer man walking boetius ſaid wrong theſe thynges bee referred diuine knowing neceſſary conſidered hemſelf abſolute fro bonde neceſſity right ſo thyngs appereth ſheweth wit thou referre hem reaſon vniuerſall thou looke referre ſelfe ſingular thou ſaiſt thus power chaungen purpoſe ſhall voiden purueyaunce god peraduenture ſhall haue chaunged thyngs knoweth beforne philoſophy ſhall anſweren thee thus certes thou maiſt well chaunge thy purpoſe much preſent ſoothneſſe diuine purueyaunce beholdeth thou maiſt chaunge thy purpoſe whether thou chaunge whiderward thou tourne thou ne maiſt eſchew diuine preſcience right ſo thou ne maiſt flid ſight preſent eye although thou tourne thy ſelfe thy free diuers action thou maiſt ſayne ayen thus ſhall ſhall diuine ſcience ben chaunged diſpoſicion one thyng another thyng thilke preſcience ne ſee meth enterchaunge ſtounds knowing ſaith ne ſhall ſeemen v diuine preſcience enterchaungeth diuers ſtounds knowing ſo know ſometime one thyng ſometime knoweth contrary thing philoſophy forſooth qd ſhe diuine ſight renneth beforne ſeeth future clepeth hem ayen retourneth hem proper preſcience proper knowing ne enterchaungeth ſo thou weneſt ſtounds foreknowing dwelling aye commeth beforn embraceth ſtroke mutacions preſcience comprehenden ſeen thyngs god ne hath taken betidings thyngs commen proper ſimplicity hereby aſſoiled thilke thyngs thou putteſt little beforne ſayne vnworthy thyng ſayne future yeven cauſe preſcience god certes ſtrength diuine ſcience embraceth thyngs preſentary knowing eſtabliſheth manner thyngs ne oweth latter thyngs ſith theſe thyngs ben thus ſain neceſſity thyngs diuine preſcience freedome arbitry dwelleth hole vnwemmed mortal men ne law ne purpoſen wicked medes pain willing men ben vnbounden quite neceſſity god beholder foreweter thyngs dwelleth aboue preſent eternity ſight renneth alway diuers quality deed diſpenſing ordeining medes good men tourments wicked men ne idle ne vain ne put god hope prayer ne mowen vnſpeedfull ne without effect ben rightfull withſtand eſchew thou vice worſhip love thou vertues areiſe thy courage rightfull hope yeeld thou humble prayer high great neceſſity proweſſe vertue encharged commaunded ye nill diſſimulen ſith ye worchen done ſaine deed werks beforne eyen judge ſeeth alſo demeth thyngs deo gratias ¶thus endeth book boetius conſolation philoſophy book commonly entituled chaucer dream perſon mourning knight ſitting oak meant john gaunt duke lancaſter greatly lamenting death one entirely loved ſuppoſed blanch dutcheſs haue great woonder light liue day ne night may ſleepe welnigh nought haue ſo many idle thought purely default ſleepe trouth take keepe nothing commeth gothe ni nothing lefe lothe yliche good ioy ſorrow ſo haue feeling nothing maſed thing day point fall adoun ſorrowfull imaginacioun alway wholly mind well ye wote againſt kind liuen wiſe nature would ſuffiſe none earthly creature long time endure without ſleepe ſorrow ne may ne night ne morrow sleepe melancolie drede haue die defaut ſleepe heauineſſe hath ſlaine ſpirit quickeneſſe haue loſt luſtyhead fantaſies ben mine head beſt men might aſke ſo may ſleepe natheleſſe aſke leſeth aſking truly ſeluen cannot tell ſooth truly geſſe hold ſickeneſſe haue ſuffred eight yere yet boot neuer nere phiſicien one may heale done paſſe ouer vntill eft mote need left firſt matter good keepe ſaw might ſleepe late night vpon bed ſate vpright bade one reach booke romaunce tooke rede drive night away thought better play either cheſſe table booke written fable clerkes old time poet put rime rede mind men • ued law kind booke ne ſpake ſuch thing queenes liues king many thing ſmale among found tale thought wonder thing tale king hight seys wife beſt might beare life queene hight alcione befell thereafter ſoone king woll wenden ouer ſee tellen ſhortly ſee thus wiſe tempeſt gan riſe brake maſt made fall cleft ſhip dreint hem neuer found tels bord ne man ne nothing el right thus king seys loſt life ſpeake alcione wife lady left home hath wonder king ne come home long terme anon hart began yerne thought euermo wele thought ſo longed ſo king certes pitous thing tell heartely ſorrowfull life ſhe noble wife ala ſhe loued alderbeſt anon ſhe ſent eaſt weſt ſeeke found nought ala qd ſhe wrought whether lord love dead certes nill neuer eat bread make vow god mowe lord ſorrow lady tooke truly made booke ſuch pitie ſuch routh rede ſorrow trouth farde worſe morrow thinken ſorrow lady coud word man might find lord full oft ſhe ſwowned ſaid ala ſorrow full nigh wood ſhe ne ſhe coud rede one downe knee ſhe ſate anone wept pitie mercy ſweet lady dere qd ſhe iuno goddeſſe helpe diſtreſſe yeve grace lord ſee soone wete ſo bee fareth wiſe ſhall make ſacrifice holly become ſhall good body hart thou wolt lady ſwete send grace ſlepe mete ſleepe ſome certaine ſweuen may know euen whether lord quicke dead word ſhe hing downe head fell ſwowne cold ſtone woman caught anone brought bed naked ſhe forweped forwaked weary thus dead ſleepe fell ſhe tooke keepe iuno heard boone made ſleepe ſoone ſhe praide right ſo done indeed iuno right anone called thus meſſengere erraund come nere come ſhe thus go bet qd iuno morpheus thou knoweſt well god ſleepe vnderſtand well take keepe say thus halfe hee go faſt great ſee bid thing take seis body king lieth full pale nothing rody bid creepe body gone alcione queene ſhe lieth alone ſhew ſhortly nay dreint day body ſpeake right ſo right wonted while aliue go faſt hye thee bliue meſſenger tooke leue went vpon way neuer ſtent till came darke valley ſtant betweene rockes twey neuer yet grew corne ne gras ne tree ne naught aught beaſt ne man ne naught el saue wels came renning fro cliffes adowne made deadly ſleeping ſowne rennen downe right caue rocke ygraue amid valley wonder deepe theſe goddes lay aſleepe morpheus aud eclympaſteire god ſleepes heire ſlept none werke caue alſo derke hell pitte ouer good leyſer rout vye might ſleepe beſt hing chin vpon breſt ſlept vpright head yhed ſome lay naked bed ſlept while day laſt meſſenger come renning faſt cried ho ho awake anone naught heard none awake qd lieth blew horne right ear cried awaketh wonder hye god ſleepe one eye caſt vp asked clepeth qd meſſengere iuno bade thou ſhouldeſt gone told ſhould done told need rehearſe went way ſaide anone god ſlepe abraide ſleepe gan go bidde tooke vp dead body ſoone bare forth alcione wife queene ſhe lay right even quarter day ſtood right bed fete called right ſhe hete name ſaid ſweet wife awake let ſorrowfull life ſorrow lyeth rede certes ſweet love dede ye ſhall never live yſee good ſweet hart looke yee bury body ſuch tide ye mowe find ſee beſide farewell ſweet world bliſſe pray god ſorrow liſſe little bliſſe laſteth eyen vp ſhe caſteth ſaw naught ala qd ſhe ſorrow vſed within third morrow ſhe ſaid ſwowe may nat tell long dwell firſt matere tell wherefore haue told thing alcione seis king thus much dare ſay wele bolden every dele dead right defaut ſleepe ne red take kepe tale next tell wherfore ne might bote ne bale sleepe redde tale dreint seis king god ſleeping red tale wele overlooked everydele thought wonder ſo never heard ſpeake tho god coud make men ſleepe ne wake ne knew never god one game ſaid anone yet lift right euill pley rather ſhould dey defaut ſleeping thus would giue thilke morpheus goddeſſe dame iuno ſome wight el ne rought make ſlepe haue ſome reſt giue alther beſt yeſt ever abode liue onward right blive woll make ſleepe alite downe pure doues white woll yeve featherbed raied gold right well cled fine blacke sattin doutremere many pillow euery bere cloth raines ſlepe ſoft need turne oft woll yeve fals chamber hals woll paint pure gold tapite hem full manyfold one ſute ſhall haue wi • caue make ſleepe ſoone goddeſſe queene alcione thus like god morpheus may wil mo fee thus ever wan iuno goddeſſe ſhall ſo trowe ſhe ſhall hold paid vnneth word yſaid right thus haue told ſuddainly niſt luſt anone tooke ſleepe right vpon booke fell ſleepe therewith even mette ſo inly ſuch ſweven wonderfull never yet trowe man wit conne well ſweden rede ioſeph without drede egypt rad ſo kinges meting pharao coud leaſt v ne nat ſcarcely macrobeus wrote aviſion met king scipion noble man affrican meruailes fortuned trowe arede dreames euen lo thus ſweven thought thus may dawning lay met thus bed naked looked forth waked ſmale foules great hepe afraied ſlepe noiſe ſweetneſſe ſong met ſate among vpon chamber roofe without vpon tyles eueriche ſong wiſe moſt ſolemne ſeruiſe note ever man trow heard ſome hem ſong low high one accord tell ſhortly word never heard ſo ſweet ſteven thing heven merry ſowne ſo ſweet entunes certes towne tewnes noide heard hem ſing chamber gan ring ſinging ermony inſtrument melody heard yet halfe ſo ſwete accord halfe ſo mete none hem fained ſing ech hem pained find many crafty note ne ſpared nat throtes ſooth ſaine chamber full well depainted glas windowes well yglaſed full clere nat hole ycraſed behold great joy holly ſtory troy glaiſing ywrought thus hector king priamus achilles king laomedon eke medea iaſon paris heleine lavine wals colour fine paint text gloſe romaunt roſe windowes ſhit echone glaſſe ſunne ſhone vpon bed bright bemes many glad glidy ſtremes eke welkin ſo faire blew bright clere aire full attempre ſooth neyther cold ne hote na ne welkin cloud lay thus wonder loud thought heard hunt blow taſſay great horne know whether clere horſe ſowne heard going vp downe men horſe hound thing men ſpeake hunting would ſlee hart ſtrength hart vpon length much enboſed anon right heard would hunting gone right glad vp anone tooke horſe forth went chamber neuer ſtent till come field without ouertooke great rout hunter eke forreſters many relay limers highed hem forreſt faſt hem ſo laſt asked one lad lymere say fellow ſhall hunt qd anſwered ayen sir emperour occtonyen qd faſt god halfe good time qd go faſt gan ride come foreſt ſide euery man right ſoone hunting fell done maiſter hunt anone fote hote horne blew three mote vncoupling houndis within hart found hallowed rechaſed faſt long time ſo laſt hart rouzed ſtale away fro hound preuie way hound ouerſhot vpon default yfall therewith hunt wonder faſt blew forloyn laſt go walked fro tree went came whelpe fawned ſtood yfollowed coud good came crept low right yknow held downe head joyned eares laid ſmooth downe heares would haue caught anone fled fro gone followed forth went downe floury greene went full thicke graſſe full ſoft ſweet floures fele faire vnder foot little vſed ſeemed thus flora zepherus two make floures grow made dwelling trow behold though earth enuy wold gayer heuen mo floures ſuch ſeuen welkin ſterres forget pouerte winter cold morrowes made ſuffer ſorrowes foryeten ſeene wood woxen greene sweetneſſe dewe made waxe need eke axe many greene greues thicke tree ſo full leues euery tree ſtood himſelue fro well tenne foot twelue great tree ſo huge ſtrength fortie fiftie fadome length cleane without bowe ſticke crop brode eke thicke inch aſunder ſhadde vnder many hart many hind behind fawnes ſowers buckes full wood many roe many ſquirrels ſete full high vpon tree ete manner made feaſts shortly ſo full beaſts though argus noble countour sate recken countour recken figure ten tho figure newe ken craftie recken number tell euery thing number yet ſhould faile recken even wonder met ſweven forth romed right wonder faſt downe wood ſo laſt ware man blacke ſate yturned backe oke huge tree lord thought may bee eyleth ſitten anon right went nere found ſitte even vpright wonder welfaring knight manner thought ſo good mokell right yong thereto age foure twentie yere vpon beard little heere clothed blacke ſtalked even vnto backe ſtood ſtill ought ſooth ſay ſaw nought hing head adowne deadly ſorrowfull ſowne made time ten verſes twelue complaint himſelue moſt pitie moſt routh ever heard trouth great wonder nature might • uffer
